gold_sents: On May 27, 2015, a person jailed by the City of St. Ann, Missouri (the City), for failing to pay the fee required under the City's secured bail system, sued the City in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, arguing that the City had violated the Fourteenth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, and asking for declaratory relief, injunctive relief, damages, attorneys' fees, and costs.[SENTMARKER]On September 3, 2015, the Judge assigned to the case, Judge Rodney W. Sippel, granted a stay in the proceedings to allow the parties to test the effects of a provisional settlement agreement, under which plaintiff agreed to drop his non-equitable claims, and under which the City agreed to end its secured bail policy and pay the plaintiff a $10,000 fee for acting as a class representative.[SENTMARKER]On May 4, 2018, a Consent Agreement was signed by Judge Sippel, whereby most of the original relief sought was agreed to by the Defendant.[SENTMARKER]The Court retains jurisdiction for two years, which may be extended for one more year upon agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 21, 2015, a homeless man was arrested for violating the city's ordinance and was held in jail until he could pay a generically set bond amount to be released from jail.[SENTMARKER]He filed a class action lawsuit against the city in the United States District Court for the Eastern District Of Missouri, seeking declaratory, injunctive, and compensatory relief.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the City's policy and practice of refusing to release arrestees from jail unless they pay the amount of cash set by the City violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United Nations and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the City agreed to end its use of a fixed cash bail system for new arrestees and to notify all arrestees in writing upon release of the time, date, and place at which they are required to appear in court, if any.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement agreement, the City will not hold an arrestee in its custody for another municipality on charges prosecuted in a municipal court for more than 10 hours.[SENTMARKER]The City also agreed to pay the Plaintiff $10,000 as a class representative fee.[SENTMARKER]The case is now pending in the District Court.

gold_sents: On August 9, 2016, a group of individuals who were placed in jail because of an inability to pay fines, penalties, and other charges filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued thirteen St. Louis County municipalities under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and § 2201.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by ArchCity Defenders and private counsel, asked the court for declaratory, injunctive, and compensatory relief, claiming violations of the Fourth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]In their complaint, the plaintiffs claimed that the defendant municipalities engaged in a deliberate and coordinated conspiracy to fill their coffers by extorting money from thousands of poor, disproportionately African-American people in the St. Louis region.[SENTMARKER]On April 24, 2017, the case was dismissed as to all defendant municipalities except the City of St. Ann.[SENTMARKER]The case (including mediation efforts) is ongoing against the City.
pegasus_output_sents: The City of St. Ann and the City of Beverly Hills are being sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri for holding inmates in their jails for non-payment in each of the past five years.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants failed to provide inmates access to a shower, limited inmates’ use of phones, and failed to give inmates their medication for their chronic medical conditions.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the defendants held hundreds of people in jails on behalf of multiple municipalities.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs in full.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In June 2017, a man awaiting criminal trial and Lexington National Insurance Corporation filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that that the Criminal Justice Reform Act violated the bail provision of the Eighth Amendment, due process under the Fourteenth Amendment, and freedom from unreasonable search and seizure under the Fourth Amendment because the act favored non-monetary pre-trial release conditions over bail.[SENTMARKER]After and appeal to the Third Circuit regarding denial of preliminary injunction and a subsequent denial of certiorari in the Supreme Court, the plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]This case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 14, 2017, a New Jersey criminal defendant filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, damages, and other relief under the Criminal Justice Reform Act of 1983 (CJRA) against the Attorney General and the Camden County Prosecutor.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that New Jersey's criminal defendants were subject to liberty-restricting conditions of pre-trial release without having the opportunity to be released on monetary bail.[SENTMARKER]The defendants opposed the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, which was denied by the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The District Court held a hearing to determine probable cause for further detention, which the defendants opposed.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the parties agreed not to enforce the provisions of the CJRA until the case was settled.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

gold_sents: Persons in the custody of the New York State Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) brought this class action against DOCS and the New York State Division of Parole (DOP) for the extra-judicial imposition of sentences requiring post-release supervision.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss was denied by the District Court, and the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion for summary judgment was granted with respect to several defendants, but denied on the issue of qualified immunity; and plaintiffs' cross motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of liability for three officers was granted.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the qualified immunity decision, but the Second Circuit affirmed.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendants moved for summary judgment again, but that motion was denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is currently scheduled for trial in Summer 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2006, the Legal Aid Society represented hundreds of individuals arrested by the New York State Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) for violating the terms of post-release supervision (PRS) administratively imposed by the Division of Parole (DOP).[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on the grounds that because plaintiffs’ constitutional rights were not clearly established at the time that those rights were allegedly violated, state officials were entitled to qualified immunity for their actions.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, but the district court denied plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction because they had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Second Circuit, where the defendants moved for a writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit granted the motion and remanded the case for a determination of whether plaintiffs had timely filed their petition for a habeas corpus petition.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion for class certification, and the case was dismissed on the ground that the defendants were not entitled to qualify immunity.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States later ruled in favor of the defendants.

gold_sents: Civil Rights Corps sued Tulsa County and various judicial officers, alleging that the court system operated a wealth-based detention system by detaining arrestees without inquiring into their ability to pay bail.[SENTMARKER]While the plaintiffs motion for preliminary injunction was denied, the plaintiffs motion for class certification is still pending.
pegasus_output_sents: June 6, 2018 DATE | U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma ORG | Tulsa County, Oklahoma LAW | DATE ||| June 6, 2018, DATE | DATE DATE | In June 2018, four people were detained in the Tulsa County Jail because they could not afford to pay a money bond after arrest for felony and misdemeanor charges, did not have access to counsel by or before their first court appearance, and were therefore detained without counsel or proper process.[SENTMARKER]The named plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of all people who are or will be detained in Tulsa County because they are unable to meet secured financial conditions of release.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification on June 6, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court further granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case, finding that the plaintiffs had failed to show that the defendants had violated their equal protection and due process rights.[SENTMARKER]The district court remanded the case to the district court for further consideration of the parties' arguments.

gold_sents: On March 25, 2015, the plaintiffs filed a consumer class action on behalf of consumers nationwide who had been the subject of misleading and inaccurate background reports sold by the defendant, RealPage, Inc. to landlords.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), alleging that the defendant, RealPage, Inc., adopted and maintained a policy and practice of failing to timely update the criminal record information it maintained so as to eliminate records of cases that have been expunged, thus not accurately reflecting the final disposition of these cases.[SENTMARKER]Moreover, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendant systematically violated FCRA by failing to provide complete and accurate disclosures of all information the defendant maintains about consumers to these consumers upon request.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, and the defendant agreed to provide consumers additional information about federal agencies responsible for enforcing FCRA, refrain from including expunged criminal records in tenant screening reports, and disclose the names of vendors who retrieved criminal record information to consumers, plus damages.[SENTMARKER]The settlement term ended in 2020, and the case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 5, 2014, a consumer class action was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania on behalf of consumers nationwide who were the subject of misleading and inaccurate background reports sold by the Defendant RealPage, Inc. (RealPage) to landlords.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that RealPage violated the Fair Credit reporting Act by failing to timely update the criminal record information that it maintains to eliminate records of cases that have been expunged and (ii) failing to provide complete and accurate disclosures of all information it maintains about consumers to those consumers who made a request for their "file" copy.[SENTMARKER]On July 13, 2015, the parties executed a settlement agreement, which established a $936,200 settlement fund for payments to the consumer class members and for attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]On November 6, 2015, the court granted the parties' motion to dismiss the case on the basis that the settlement agreement did not conform with the law, but RealPage disagrees with the court's decision.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing to work out the details of the settlement, which is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 2020, the Nashville Community Bail Fund filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that a local rule which required it to agree to garnishment of judgment fees from bail bonds before it could post bail for indigent arrestees violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution and threatened its ability to operate as a non-profit.[SENTMARKER]The District Judge granted a preliminary injunction in March 2020 enjoining the County Criminal Court Clerk from garnishing fees from bonds posted by the Bail Fund.[SENTMARKER]In December 2020, the District Judge approved a consent decree where the Bail Fund and the County Government agreed to make the injunction permanent.[SENTMARKER]The matter is ongoing as the parties are litigating over who should pay attorneys fees and how much.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 5, 2020, the Nashville Community Bail Fund (NCBF) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee against the Office of the Clerk of the Criminal Court of the Twentieth Judicial District for violating the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the right against excessive bail and the right to due process under the Fourteenth and Eighth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the parties agreed to a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendants to comply with the terms of the consent decree, including that they would not enforce Rule 10(B) against any third-party attempting to post a cash bail bond in Davidson County.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the court would have the power to enter a final judgment against the defendants if the parties were unable to come to an agreement.

gold_sents: In May of 2016 two indigent people brought a suit against the City of El Paso in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas for jailing them for failure to pay fines, despite their inability to do so.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought this action under 42 U.S.C. 1983, and allege that the Defendants violated their Due Process and Equal Protection rights under the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs request declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]They want to enjoin the Defendants from enforcing their current debt collection program, which jails people who can't pay a certain portion of their fines for traffic and misdemeanor offenses.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that Defendants adopted their debt collection program to generate revenue for they city, and the individual plaintiffs were not informed that they could assert their indigence.[SENTMARKER]Rather, the Plaintiffs were simply told they had to pay or go to jail.[SENTMARKER]On January 12th, 2017 Judge David Guaderrama granted the Defendant's motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]Judge Guaderrama dismissed the Due Process claims, but did not reach the Equal Protection claims.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint in January 2017, and after the Court denied two motions to dismiss filed by defendants over the course of 2017, the parties stipulated to dismissal of the action pursuant to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement agreement, defendants agreed to maintain certain administrative practices for three years.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, these practices related to notice to defendants, policies and procedures for: payment plans; notice to defendants of court hearings and schedules; and indigency hearings and warrants issued for non-payment.
pegasus_output_sents: The Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the City of El Paso, Texas, the Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity (ECI), and other entities and officials, alleging violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the E-Government Act (ECA) in connection with the city's debt collection policies and practices for Class C misdemeanor traffic tickets.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants intentionally refused to inform low-income debtors of their rights, and to intentionally refuse to properly inquire into a debtors' financial inability to pay their fines and/or the debtors' reasons for failing to pay.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, but denied EPIC's request for a preliminary injunction to prohibit the defendants from collecting voter data unless and until they completed a privacy impact assessment as required by the ECI and the ECA.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay $100,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In January 2016, two indigent women that served imprisonment terms at the Randall County Jail filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the City of Amarillo's municipal code created a modern-day debtors' prison and violated their Fourteenth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]In August 2016, the Court granted the defendant's motion to dismiss and ordered the plaintiffs to pay $3,660.00 in litigation costs.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2016, a class action lawsuit was filed against the City of Amarillo, Texas, alleging that the City's fine collection system is unconstitutional as applied to indigent individuals.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by converting a fine only offense to jail time solely because an individual was unable to pay a fine.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that municipal officers violated the Equal Protection Clause by failing to make an affirmative determination of indigency status and consider adequate alternatives to incarceration.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that the plaintiffs had failed to state a plausible claim for municipal liability.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Foster children in Georgia's Fulton and DeKalb Counties brought suit against the state and counties Division of Family and Children Services.[SENTMARKER]The class of children alleged that they did not receive necessary treatment and services while spending months in emergency shelters, experienced abuse and neglect as a result of an insufficient number of caseworkers, and received inadequate health care and emotional services while in foster care.[SENTMARKER]In 2005 and 2006, the plaintiffs reached settlement agreements with the state, Fulton County, and DeKalb County.[SENTMARKER]As of November 2018, the State is still under the supervision of the independent monitor in order to meet the court-ordered benchmarks, having not yet completed sufficient improvements.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2002, nine foster children in the custody of the Georgia Department of Human Resources filed this action in the Superior Court of Fulton County on behalf of a class of Fulton and DeKalb County foster children and a subclass of African-American foster children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to correct alleged deficiencies in the foster care system.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motions to dismiss and for summary judgment, but the Tenth Circuit vacated and remanded with directions to consider separately each provision of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in October 2005, which required the defendants to pay approximately $10.5 million in attorney's fees and expenses.[SENTMARKER]The case was then transferred to the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, where the parties entered into a consent decree, which the district court approved on October 28, 2005 and was modified by agreed orders on December 15, 2008 and November 2, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties appealed to the United States Supreme Court, which remanded the case to the Eleventh Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the Supreme Court's decision in the NAACP case.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the defendants, and the case was dismissed on October 3, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs, who are children in the custody of the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services (DYFS), brought suit against the state alleging abuse, neglect, and lack of services.[SENTMARKER]After the New York Times published several articles about the deaths of children in the care of DYFS due to lack of care, in 2003 the state entered into a settlement agreement providing for a systematic overhaul of the state child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]The latest modification of the agreement was made in 2015 and remains in force.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 27, 2003, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey on behalf of two homeless children who were placed in the custody of the New Jersey division of youth and family services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the division violated the children's civil rights by failing to provide them with adequate in-for-dignified data in the form of a Title IV-B preventive services program designed to help children remain with their families or be returned to their families when appropriate.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that most federal statutes issue did not unambiguously confer rights under  1983.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a modified settlement agreement on July 27, 2006, which required the division to provide the children with home care, training, and health screening.[SENTMARKER]The agreement was approved and entered into by the District Court and the parties agreed that the children would not be placed in shelters.[SENTMARKER]The District Court entered an order requiring the Division to comply with the terms of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in part and denied in part by the district court.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs, children in the custody of the New York City Child Welfare Administration ("CWA"), and children who, while not in the custody of CWA, are or will be at risk of abuse or neglect and whose status is known or should be known to CWA, sought declaratory and injunctive relief against both the city and state for systematic deficiencies that jeopardized their well-being.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed on December 13, 1995, and the parties reached to two separate settlement agreements, one with the city and one with the state, on December 2, 1988.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs returned to court in January 2001, seeking an order directing the state to comply with specific terms of the state settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the state had acted with insufficient diligence in implementing the information management system, and therefore extended the terms of the agreement in this area and directed that the plaintiffs receive semi-annual reports.[SENTMARKER]The defendants provided a January 2017 report to show that they were continuing to develop, implement, and update their information systems for child welfare needs.[SENTMARKER]A year later, the court ended its supervision of the portions of the settlement that it had retained jurisdiction to enforce.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 1995, a group of children who were the legal responsibility of the New York City child welfare system filed a class action lawsuit against the City of NYC, the City's Department of Social Services, and the Governor of the State of N.Y.[SENTMARKER]alleging that systemic deficiencies in the Child Welfare Administration were endangering the well-being of thousands of children in the City.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement (the "City Settlement Agreement") on December 2, 1998, and the district court approved the settlement on March 31, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The parties moved jointly for class certification and approval of the City Settlement Agreement.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit affirmed the District Court's certification of the plaintiff class on September 26, 1997, finding that the settlement was fair, reasonable, adequate, and adequate.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States granted the parties' motion for summary judgment on October 2, 2006, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: This was a class action challenge to New York's unnecessary institutionalization of children in foster care in psychiatric facilities.[SENTMARKER]The initial settlement agreement, entered on February 28, 2011, provided for increased community-based placement opportunities for children in foster care with mental illness as well as individualized planning, staff training, and monitoring.[SENTMARKER]In addition to the initial settlement agreement, on July 7, 2011, the plaintiffs agreed to release defendants from all liability in exchange for payment from defendants.[SENTMARKER]On January 22, 2016, the parties agreed to extend the Court's jurisdiction until June 30, 2016, at which time its jurisdiction presumably expired.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2010, three children in the custody of the New York City Administration for Children's Services (ACS) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York alleging that ACS violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by improperly placing and detaining children in acute-care psychiatric hospitals longer than necessary and failing to move these children to the least restrictive placements appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated Title 11 of the ADA by failing to provide emergency and inpatient mental health services for children in foster care and child protective system.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in October 2010 that required the defendants to implement a new policy and procedure for the provision of emergency and in-patient psychiatric services for foster children.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay plaintiffs' counsel fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is final and binding on all parties, as weB as their successors and assigns.

gold_sents: On May 30, 2013, an eleven-year-old child in the custody of the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS), filed a lawsuit in the Court of Common Pleas, Abbeville County, South Carolina, against SCDSS and the Boys Home of the South (BHOTS), alleging that, as a result of Defendants' failures, Plaintiff was sexually assaulted on multiple occasions, causing him severe and permanent mental injury.[SENTMARKER]Following removal to Federal Court, in early 2014, Plaintiff settled with both SCDSS and BHOTS for an undisclosed sum of money.[SENTMARKER]BHOTS also permanently closed as a result of the lawsuit.
