Rushing in Anderson, South Carolina.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2014, the Plaintiff asked the Court to approve a settlement for John Doe, a minor child, who has settled all claims against the Defendants.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

gold_sents: On January 12, 2015, a class action lawsuit was filed against the South Carolina Department of Social Services (SCDSS) in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina, alleging numerous deficiencies in the operation of the state's child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]On September 28, 2015, the parties reached an interim settlement agreement, providing for an end to certain SCDSS practices, as well as for studies of additional SCDSS practices.[SENTMARKER]Monitoring revealed incremental improvements in conditions, and the settlement remains in effect.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 4, 2016, a lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina on behalf of children who were removed from their homes due to extreme family circumstances and placed in the legal custody of the South Carolina department of social services (DSS) at the direction and control of DSS.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Constitution and the laws of the United States by the defendants' failure to provide medical and dental assessments, periodic medical/physical and dental health screenings, and follow-up treatment to Plaintiff Children as required under the Medicaid Act.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a Final Settlement Agreement (FSA) in October 2016 requiring the defendants to develop a Health Care Improvement Plan (the "Plan") for all children in foster care in the physical or legal custody in South Carolina.[SENTMARKER]The FSA reflects the parties' agreement to address long-standing problems experienced by children and the operation of the state's child welfare system.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the FSA, the parties agreed that the court would have continuing jurisdiction to oversee compliance with the FSA.[SENTMARKER]The parties' joint report on the progress of the Plan was submitted to the court on January 5, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the final settlement agreement on October 5, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs in March 2019.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: A paraplegic individual who uses a wheelchair sued Chipotle for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and California state law in two of its California restaurants.[SENTMARKER]The defendant implemented a new "Customers with Disabilities" which the district court found to be in compliance with the ADA, but the Ninth Circuit found otherwise, that viewing the ingredients behind the counter was part of the "Chipotle Experience."[SENTMARKER]Ultimately, the defendant lowered the heights of the walls in front of the food-preparation areas in all of its California locations so that customers in wheelchairs could see the ingredients, and the plaintiff was awarded $898,549 in attorneys' fees and costs and $5,000 in statutory damages.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2005, a wheelchair-bound customer sued Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., alleging that the company violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the California Disabled Persons Act (CDPA) by denying him full and equal access to two of its restaurants in San Diego, California.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case with prejudice upon the defendants' motion to dismiss, but the Ninth Circuit remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the court found that the high walls at the two restaurants were in violation of the ADA and ordered Chipotle to pay damages.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: The California Department of Fair Employment and Housing filed this ongoing lawsuit on behalf of several LSAT test takers against the Law School Admissions Council (LSAC).[SENTMARKER]The State claims that LSAC routinely denies reasonable accommodations to test takers with disabilities in violation of the California Unruh Civil Rights Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]In 2014, the parties have agreed to a consent decree that the court approved.
pegasus_output_sents: The California Department of Fair Employment and Housing (DFEH) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on April 12, 2012 against the Law School Admission Council, Inc. (LSAC) alleging that LSAC violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the California Unruh Civil Rights Act (CULRA) by failing to grant individual plaintiffs' requests for disability-related accommodations to test-takers of the Law 19 Admission Test (LSAT) in violation of the ADA and CULRA.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in May 2014 and the parties entered a consent decree in which LSAC agreed to comply with the terms of the consent decree for a period of four years.[SENTMARKER]In May 2014, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case with prejudice, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]On May 29, 2014, the Court entered a final judgment in favor of the parties and entered a Consent Decree in which the parties agreed to implement a number of changes to the testing procedures used by LSAC and widely used in law school admissions.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires LSAC to provide each individual plaintiff with a written copy of their test-taker's score report, provide each plaintiff with an accessible scribe, and allow each plaintiff to use a computer for the writing 13 sample.[SENTMARKER]It also requires the defendant to provide the individual plaintiffs with a notation on their score report indicating that their exam scores were earned under non-standard time conditions.[SENTMARKER]In addition, LSAC has agreed to cease the practice of annotating score reports of candidates who receive the testing 17 disability related accommodations extended test time due to disability.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for dismissal of the case on May 29, 2014 with prejudice.

gold_sents: Disabled plaintiffs sued a public transit agency for violation of the Americans With Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation Act, alleging their bus system presented numerous barriers to access, subjecting the plaintiffs to delay, embarrassment, and ridicule by passengers and drivers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree, in which the defendant agreed to remedy the problems with its bus system and pay $250,000 in damages, fees, and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2000, two individuals with disabilities filed this class action suit in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado against the City of Steamboat Springs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the city had violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to make its public transportation system readily accessible to and usable by persons who use wheelchairs and by denying the benefits of its services, programs, and activities, as more fully set forth above.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree that was final and binding on all parties.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the city to make improvements to its transit system and to provide training for all bus and van operators, dispatchers, and mechanics.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the City to ramp or otherwise provide access to the restrooms at the Alpine Slide/stables area on the east side of the city's rodeo grounds.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 12, 2000 without prejudice.

gold_sents: Disabled patrons of a concert venue filed a class action against the owners and operators of the venue for failure to remove barriers to access.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, with Defendants agreeing not to obstruct wheelchair areas and to pay damages and attorneys' fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 26, 1992, a Colorado nonprofit organization representing persons with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado against the owners, operators, lessors, and/or lessees of Fiddler's Green, a concert hall in Denver, Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Colorado Consumer Protection Act by failing to provide adequate seating for persons with mobility limitations and their nondisabled companions in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the plaintiffs repeatedly asked the defendants to provide wheelchair seating at the concert hall.[SENTMARKER]The complaint further alleged that defendants negligently and falsely represented to the plaintiffs that reserved wheelchair seating was available at Fiddler’s Green concerts with the intent that the plaintiffs would purchase tickets for wheelchair seating.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, granted their motion for class certification, and entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On December 2, 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (“Amtrak”) for allegedly violating the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12131-12165, by failing to make its intercity rail stations accessible to individuals with disabilities by July 26, 2020, as required by the Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was never properly docketed or assigned to a judge, however, because the government announced its settlement with Amtrak on the same day.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required Amtrak to design at least 135 accessible stations, complete construction at 90 stations, and be in the process of constructing at least 45 stations within 10 years of the settlement date.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required Amtrak to train staff on ADA compliance, establish a monitor-approved process for managing ADA complaints, and create a settlement fund to compensate individuals who were harmed by Amtrak’s most inaccessible stations.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was monitored by the Federal Railroad Administration and the Department of Justice.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 2014, the United States filed this lawsuit against the National Railroad passenger corporation (Amtrak) to enforce Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) and its implementing regulation, 49 C.F.R. Part 37.[SENTMARKER]The complaint included an NDRN-generated report alleging that Amtrak stations across the country were inaccessible in violation of the ADA, including individuals who use wheelchairs, and of necessary remedies to bring its services, programs, and activities into compliance with the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which Amtrak agreed to make its stations accessible to and usable by individuals with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by the parties and is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement agreement, the parties agreed that the ADA would remain in effect for 10 years from the date of the effective date of this agreement, and that the parties would submit a Sunset Analysis to the Department of Justice (DOJ) and Federal Railroad Administration (FRA).[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that Amtrak would maintain records showing the dates and length of training, instructors, and attendees, including job titles.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Amtrak would place at least a 14-page advertisement in USA Today (Friday circulation; display the text of which is attached as Exhibit 4) within 60 days of the Effective Date of this Agreement.[SENTMARKER]In the event the parties fail to comply with the settlement, the court may order Amtrak to pay a civil penalty of up to $1 million.

gold_sents: On July 22, 2013, attorneys from United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against the State of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that nearly two hundred children with disabilities were unnecessarily segregated from their communities and the general population by the State, which had placed them in nursing homes.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ sought an injunction requiring the State to comply with Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), 42 U.S.C. § 12131-12134, which, as interpreted by the Supreme Court in Olmstead v. L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999), forbids the unnecessary institutionalization of disabled individuals, and mandates that their rehabilitative and medical needs be provided in a manner that enables disabled individuals to be independent and integrated members of the community.[SENTMARKER]L.C., 527 U.S. 581 (1999), forbids the unnecessary institutionalization of disabled individuals, and mandates that their rehabilitative and medical needs be provided in a manner that enables disabled individuals to be independent and integrated members of the community.[SENTMARKER]In June 2014, the case was consolidated with another pending case, which is in the Clearinghouse as PB-FL-0007.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 4, 2014, the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida entered a final judgment against the State of Florida in a lawsuit brought under title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (the "ADA").[SENTMARKER]The final judgment found that the State had violated the ADA by placing hundreds of children with disabilities unnecessarily in nursing facilities and failing to provide sufficient reimbursement rates for in-home nursing services.[SENTMARKER]The court also found that Florida had violated Title II by failing to ensure that these children have opportunities to move to more integrated settings appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]In the final judgment, the court ordered the State to implement a number of remedial measures, including requiring that the children be recertify every six months that the services they receive are medically necessary.[SENTMARKER]The State also agreed to pay the families of the children at risk of institutionalization to cover the costs of their care.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on April 4, 2014.[SENTMARKER]In a separate settlement, the State agreed not to place any children under the age of 21 into nursing facilities.

gold_sents: In 2005, two organizations that advocates for people with disabilities filed this lawsuit n the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the City of Detroit, claiming that the city had failed to meet federal and Michigan accessibility standards in altering intersections and sidewalks.[SENTMARKER]In 2006, the parties negotiated a plant to correct the affected intersections and sidewalks.[SENTMARKER]As of 2018, a special master continues to monitor implementation of the agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: The Center for Community Access, Inc. and the Michigan Paralyzed Veterans of America (MPVA) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan in June 2006 against the City of Detroit for violating the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (R&A) by failing to install curb cuts and other accessibility improvements in the city.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the ADA by not installing curb cuts to meet the required accessibility standards and codes.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement in August 2006 that required the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was finalized in September 2010 and the parties entered into a new agreement in April 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would not file a motion for contempt until the parties had reached a final settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In April 2012, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This was a case brought to make a 300 unit apartment complex in Canton Township, MI accessible to persons with mobility impairments.[SENTMARKER]It was filed in 2006 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan by two individuals and the Fair Housing Center of Southeastern Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The suit eventually resulted in about three quarters of a million dollars in retrofits, damages to the plaintiffs and attorney fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2006, a disabled resident of Canton, Michigan filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Michigan, alleging that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act by failing to design, construct, and/or operate a complex that was accessible to and useable by individuals with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants failed to design and construct the rental office and its appurtenant parking and sidewalks in such a manner that the facilities were readily accessible and useable.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the plaintiffs were repeatedly retaliated against by the defendants because they asserted their rights under the fair housing act.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a partial settlement in December 2006, and the parties entered into a final judgment in March 2007.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered in March 2007, and the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $325,000.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to provide the plaintiffs with a permanent injunction against violations of the ADA and PWDCRA.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was subject to court approval.

gold_sents: A class action lawsuit was filed on July 10, 2012, against the Mississippi Department of Education, under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act of 2004 (IDEA), alleging that the defendant had failed to execute its responsibilities under IDEA, by not ensuring that the Jackson Public School District provide disabled students with a free and appropriate public education in the least restrictive environment, even after conducting an investigation into the School District and identifying its systemic failure to meet its IDEA obligations.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on September 29, 2014 stipulating the implementation of a Program Sustainability Plan for the 2014-2015 school year.[SENTMARKER]On September 11, 2015 District Court Judge Daniel P. Jordan III granted a motion to dismiss with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act of 2004 ("IDEA"), 20 U.S.C.  1400 et seq., was passed in 2004 to ensure that children with disabilities receive the free appropriate public education they are entitled to receive under the IDEA.[SENTMARKER]In the Jackson Public School District, students with disabilities have been denied the educational and supportive services they need to achieve academically, and have been removed from their schools and forced into substandard segregated settings with little to no appropriate academic programming and related services.[SENTMARKER]During the 2010-2011 school year, there were over 3,000 students with disability receiving special education services in Jackson Public Schools.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought widespread systemic relief to reform the manner in which JPS administers its special education program.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction and ordered JPS to provide some of its most academically vulnerable students with instmction via video streaming from other classrooms.[SENTMARKER]JPS has also proposed creating a separate alternative school program to serve only those students who have been subjected to multiple disciplinary disciplinary actions.

gold_sents: On August 3, 2006, plaintiffs, a group of disabled persons receiving public benefits filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the South District of New York against the New York Human Resources Administration alleging that it discriminated against disabled persons by involuntarily segregating them by transferring their public benefits cases from local benefit centers to three hub centers that only serviced people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The Court approved a proposed settlement agreement in June of 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 19, 2006, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on behalf of persons with disabilities and persons eligible for public assistance.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged discrimination on the basis of handicap in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the New York State Human Rights Law (N.Y.[SENTMARKER]HR Law).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction prohibiting further case transfers from local Job Centers to the hub centers.[SENTMARKER]The parties attempted to negotiate a settlement of monetary claims, but the parties were unable to reach a settlement.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to this court in November 2011 and the parties entered a settlement agreement on November 7, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendants would provide plaintiffs with draft training materials for their review and comment, and that the plaintiffs would be entitled to reasonable counsel fees and costs as part of the settlement.

gold_sents: Students sued the New York City Department of Education, the City of New York, and the chancellor of the New York City Department of Education to seek injunctive relief under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Individuals with Disabilities in Education Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and New York state law.[SENTMARKER]The student plaintiffs are either student in Staten Island District 75 schools or vulnerable to being sent to those schools, which are separated from New York City community schools.[SENTMARKER]District 75 students receive their education in a restrictive setting where they are largely isolated from interactions with students who do not have disabilities.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief in the form of a permanent injunction against future violations and an order for a remedial plan to reimagine policies, practices, and norms that will permit each student to learn in the most integrated setting possible.[SENTMARKER]The case remains open.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 22, 2012, Disability Rights New York filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York on behalf of a class of Staten Island students with disabilities who are being educated in segregated and unequal public schools and classrooms in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504), the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), and the NYCHRL (NYHRL) laws.[SENTMARKER]The Named Plaintiffs and putative Plaintiff Class Members are represented by Disability Advocates, Inc. (DRNY), a New York-based non-profit that provides services, programs, and activities for Staten Island District 75 students.[SENTMARKER]DRNY is authorized to conduct business under the name Disability Rights in New York.[SENTMARKER]The District Court entered a final judgment in favor of the District Court, finding that the defendants had violated the ADA, Section 504, and the IDEA by failing to provide a free appropriate education to children with disabilities in the least restrictive environment in which they can learn alongside their non-disabled peers, to the maximum extent appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment also ordered the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

gold_sents: Four blind or visually impaired library patrons sued the Free Library of Philadelphia in in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, seeking relief under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and Title II of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the Library's new program to lend e-reading devices was discriminatory, because the Nook Simple Touch devices the library had procured were inaccessible to visually impaired users, and because accessible alternative devices were available.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The library agreed to transition to the exclusive use of accessible devices within four years, and to add ten accessible e-readers within 60 days of the settlement date.
pegasus_output_sents: The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 ("ADA"), 42 U.S.C.  12132, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (" Rehabilitation Act"), require public institutions that receive federal funds to provide equal access to e-book technology.[SENTMARKER]In 2010, four blind library patrons sued the Free Library of Philadelphia in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, alleging that the Library's e-reading device lending program violated the ADA and Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the library's lending program discriminated against the blind by denying them access to a NOOK e-reader device, which is completely inaccessible to the blind.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Final Settlement Agreement, which required the library to comply with Section 504 and Title II of the ADA by refraining from lending any inaccessible e-books to its blind patrons.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, granted their motion for a permanent injunction, and entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs filed a suit in federal court on January 20, 2011, against Millcreek Township, PA and the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the sidewalks and intersections in Millcreek were not in compliance with the disability accessibility mandates of the Americans with Disabilities Act and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and sought injunctive and declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]On November 23, 2016, the parties partially settled, with the Township and PennDOT committing to adhere to ADA requirements in the future and to retrofit sidewalks and intersections where necessary.[SENTMARKER]A series of consent decrees, over which the court retains jurisdiction, have been entered and the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2011, three individuals with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the United States district court for the western district of Pennsylvania against Millcreek Township, Pennsylvania and the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation (PennDOT) alleging violations of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Section 504).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Millcreek and PennDOT violated Title II by failing to make certain improvements to pedestrian walkways, intersections, and other facilities accessible to persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, but not damages, on behalf of themselves and the class.[SENTMARKER]On September 28, 2011, the parties entered into a Consent Decree and Partial Settlement with respect to some of the claims set forth in the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to allow at least fifteen days to agree upon any modifications to the consent decree and partial settlement, and the parties will retain jurisdiction to enforce all terms of this consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires Millcreek to install at least 110 curb ramps each year until the remaining curb ramps are installed, to establish a nondiscrimination and sexual harassment policy, and to inform its employees that sexual harassment will not be tolerated and employees who practice it will be disciplined.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed that PennDOT required Erie and Meadville to be added to the case, and that the parties have continued discussions and negotiations regarding several unresolved additional issues.

gold_sents: In 1996, parents of a student with autism filed this lawsuit on his behalf against the Arkansas Department of Education and the Williford School District under the IDEA, the ADA, Section 504, and 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The parents claimed that their son was unfairly discriminated against due to his disability and was deprived of an appropriate education.[SENTMARKER]In 2004, the Eastern District of Arkansas Court held that neither defendant had violated the federal statutes and found for state and the school district.
pegasus_output_sents: The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas is the only federal court in the country that has jurisdiction over the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), 20 U.S.C.  1400, and the Americans with Disabilities Act ( 504 of the Rehabilitation Act).[SENTMARKER]In two separate cases, the parents of an autistic boy sued the Arkansas Department of Education (ADE), the Williford School District, and several school district officials, alleging violations of the IDEA and  504.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed all of the plaintiffs' claims with prejudice, but the case was re-opened and the plaintiffs filed a second suit in 2000 naming the same defendants as the first.[SENTMARKER]In the second suit, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their son's rights by failing to provide him with a "free appropriate public education" ("FAPE"), violating 504 of the RA, and retaliation against plaintiffs for asserting their rights and creating a hostile environment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment and remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: This federal lawsuit was filed in 2000 in the Eastern District of California; in it, a former high school student and the Gay-Straight Alliance Network sued his school district for failure to take effective measures to remedy continuing harassment that he faced based on his sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled for a consent decree entered August 15, 2002, which required the defendants to implement a mandatory staff training program, revise its policies, select compliance coordinators, develop systems for reporting harassment and discrimination, allow students to form a gay-straight alliance, and create a community advisory group.[SENTMARKER]The decree implementation period was 6 months.
pegasus_output_sents: In June 2005, a group of gay and lesbian students filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California alleging that the school district violated their civil rights by failing to protect them from harassment and discrimination based on their actual or perceived sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the district's anti-harassment and anti-discrimination policies were not sufficient to prevent the harassment, discrimination, and school safety violations.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim on the basis of associational standing.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent order in which the district agreed to implement a "Mandatory Student Training Program" for all certificated employees, administrators, and non-certificated staff who are responsible for monitoring student behavior.[SENTMARKER]The program will be mandatory for all students in one grade level in all VUSD high schools and 20 continuation schools.[SENTMARKER]The district also agreed not to pay any of the plaintiffs for any services.[SENTMARKER]The consent order is effective immediately.

gold_sents: The plaintiff, Students for Fair Admissions (SFFA) sued the U.S. Department of Education to compel compliance with its FOIA request related to its investigation of Princeton University.[SENTMARKER]The defendant notified Princeton of the request and the lawsuit, and Princeton then filed a lawsuit against SFFA to enjoin the disclosure of the materials requested under FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The present case was consolidated into that suit, and the parties jointly stipulated to this case's dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: Students for Fair Admissions, Inc. (SFFA) filed this suit on January 11, 2016, under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]SFFA sought documents concerning the investigation of Princeton University in the complaint.[SENTMARKER]As of October 27, 2016, the Department had not received any documents from SFFA in response to its FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]On April 18, 2016, John Carroll, an officer of the Department's New York Office for Civil Rights, had a telephone conversation with Edward Vaughn, the President of SFFA, and Edward's counsel about the matter.[SENTMARKER]On July 17, 2016, the Court entered an order enjoining the Department from continuing to withhold any and all non-exempt records responsive to SFFA's FOIA request, and ordered the Department to produce, by a date certain, any documents responsive to the FOIA request and a index of any responsive records under claim of exemption.[SENTMARKER]On December 2, 2017, the Court dismissed the case, finding that the Department did not have a reasonable effort to search for and produce the documents requested by SFFA.

gold_sents: Princeton sued U.S. Department of Education and OCR in a "reverse FOIA" to stop them from releasing documents related to an OCR compliance review to Students for Fair Admissions, Inc., which had submitted a FOIA request and filed a lawsuit against the DOE to compel disclosure.[SENTMARKER]Parties voluntarily dismissed case.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Department of Education's Office for Civil Rights (OCR) received a complaint alleging that Princeton University had discriminated against applicants on the basis of race and national origin in the admissions process.[SENTMARKER]OCR conducted a compliance review of Princeton's undergraduate admissions program in the course of the review.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the University had violated the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) and the Trade Secrets Act (TS Act) by failing to disclose certain confidential and commercially sensitive documents and information relating to the University's admissions program to OCR.[SENTMARKER]On October 27, 2016, the complaint was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, 2017, the University filed a reverse FOIA action under the Administrative Procedure Act seeking to set aside the Department's and OCR's final decision to disclose the documents as arbitrary and capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law.[SENTMARKER]The case was docketed as Students for Fair Admissions, Inc v. United States Department of education, No. 1:16-cv-02154-TSC (D.D.C.)[SENTMARKER](the FOIA Action) and is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 26, 2010, a group of students with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the Louisiana Department of Education for failing to provide accessible free public education to students with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]After negotiations, the court approved a Consent Decree in March 2015.[SENTMARKER]An Independent Monitor continues to file periodical assessments as the State works toward full compliance under court supervision.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 31, 2015, ten students with disabilities filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the Orleans Parish School Board, alleging violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Individuals with Disability Education Improvement (IDEA) Act, and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (Section 504).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs represented a class of approximately 4,500 New Orleans students who were denied access to public school because of their disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the ADA and Section 504 by denying access to students who the school knew or should have known were disabled.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the defendants to: (1) provide annual technical assistance to each school under its jurisdiction regarding the prohibited practice of undocumented suspensions; .[SENTMARKER](2) develop a written complaint investigation protocol describing the school’s process for investigating allegations of discrimination on the basis of disability; .[SENTMARKER](3) disseminate information to parents of students at each school about prohibited practice; and (4) provide a child-specific paraprofessional for students with special needs.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay the plaintiffs in full.

gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 2003, a group of Westfield High School students filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts, alleging that the school had violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution by restricting their right to free speech.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs wanted to pass out candy canes with an attachment that contained the story of the candy cane and some Bible verses to fellow students.[SENTMARKER]The school denied the group access to show the film, because it was "church-related," and the school feared that allowing students to wear the armbands would result in a disturbance among the students.[SENTMARKER]In a settlement agreement, the school agreed not to punish the named plaintiffs in any way for distributing literature during non-instructional time, and to allow the Bible Club to meet at the flagpole on school grounds before the start of each school day to conduct a morning prayer.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the school to pay the plaintiffs' attorney's fees and costs of $28,500.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.
pegasus_output_sents: The National Federation of the Blind, The Council of Parent Attorneys and Advocates, Inc., and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland on May 31, 2018 against the Department of Education, Office for Civil Rights, and Department of Justice.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the March 5, 2018 issuance of a new Office of Civil Rights (OCR) manual, which allegedly eliminated certain substantive rights of complainants that the OCR was designed to protect, violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (CRCPA).[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on November 29, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay $50,000 in attorneys' fees and costs in full and final settlement of any and all claims for attorney's fees and cost in connection with this case.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice one year from the date of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed without prejudice and the parties have the option of re-opening it.

gold_sents: On May 14, 2020 the plaintiffs filed a lawsuit against the Department of Education (ED) in the United States District Court in the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that regulations issued by ED "sharply limit educational institutions' obligations to respond to reports of sexual harassment and assault" and therefore contravened Title IX of the Education Amendmentsof 1972.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing with responses to the complaint due on July 31, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 (''Title IX') prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex in educational institutions receiving federal funds, not experienced harassment or violence.[SENTMARKER]On July 12, 2019, a nonprofit organization representing students of color, LGBTQ students, and students with disabilities filed this suit against the U.S. Department of Education in the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The nonprofit organization alleged that the Department violated Title IX when it failed to conclude an investigation of a complaint that a student had been raped by a male student while walking home from school.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the District failed to provide the student with appropriate support services as necessary to ensure the community’s safety, and failed to take action to ensure that the student's right to an education free from sexual harassment and assault was protected.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that, in violation of Title IX, the Department failed to comply with its obligations under the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the nonprofit's motion for summary judgment, granted the plaintiffs' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief, and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 8, 2006, two black high school seniors filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the University of Michigan and the Michigan Attorney General challenging the implementation of a state constitutional amendment that was to go into effect on December 23, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties to the case either took no position or consented to the relief, and the Court granted the motion to intervene on December 14, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the State of Michigan's motion to dismiss and ruled that the state statute was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 18, 2008, the District Court issued a final order granting summary judgment in favor of the Attorney General, concluding that the portions of Proposal 2 that affect Michigan’s public institutions of higher education impermissibly alter the political process in violation of the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reversed the district court's grant of summary judgment, finding that the portion of the amendment that affects public institutions is unconstitutional on its face.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In late 2003, several students with disabilities filed a lawsuit against the New York City Department of Education and the New York City School Board for failing to follow the orders of impartial hearings requiring them to compensate or fund tuition and services for the special education needs of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2008 a settlement agreement was approved which included injunctive and compensatory relief.
pegasus_output_sents: 2003 DATE | New York City Department of Education ORG ||| August 12, 1986 DATE ||| New York State Education Department ORG||| August 11, 2007 DATE | The Garden City Group, Inc.<n>On August 12, 2003, a group of parents of children with disabilities filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the New York Department of education.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their rights under the 14th Amendment of the United States Constitution by failing to comply with decisions, determinations, orders and statements of agreement and orders of Impartial Hearing Officers (IHOs) entered pursuant to the individuals with disabilities education act (IDEA).[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification on August 11, 2007, and the parties agreed to a settlement on December 11, 2007 that provided for the payment of $1,590,625.25 in attorney's fees and $132,705.93 in expenses.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2008, the court approved the Stipulation and Settlement Agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the plaintiffs would be entitled to reasonable attorneys' fees and costs in the event that the parties did not comply with the IHOs.[SENTMARKER]The court also approved the release of the defendants from the litigation.

gold_sents: In 2012, a parent, individually and on behalf of their student-child with an educational disability in the Buffalo City School District, filed this class action complaint in the the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Buffalo City School District Board of Education and its superintendent denied free appropriate public education to children with educational disabilities, failed to promptly provide children with disabilities related services, and failed to provide parents with meaningful participation in their children's educational decision-making process.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the parties reached a settlement that required more timely speech and language therapy for members of the class and awarded attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in March 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act of 1973 ("IDEA"), 20 U.S.C.  1400 et seq., requires school districts to provide free, appropriate public education, including special education and related services, to educationally disabled children and their parents.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs in this case, who reside in the Buffalo City School District, allege that the district's practices, customs, policies, and procedures violate the rights of children and parents of such children under the IDEA and the New York State Education Law and regulations.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs allege that, in failing to provide services to such disabled students when services for non-disabled students were provided, the district discriminated against the student members of the class in violation of Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and that the District failed to provide the individual Plaintiff with individual and individual and learning services as required by a prior agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the district agreed to pay the plaintiffs in full and to implement a program to ensure that the individual plaintiff received the services she needed.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved by the district court on June 17, 2014 and is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On February 15, 1996, students filed a class action lawsuit against Owasso Independent School District ("OPS"), claiming that it had violated  Title IX of the Education Amendment of 1972, the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution and 42 U.S.C. § 1983 by intentionally denying  female students an equal opportunity to participate in interscholastic and other school-sponsored athletics.[SENTMARKER]On October 2, 1996, the Court entered a consent decree, which settled each of the claims stated in the Complaint and resolved all claims asserted against individuals who were named in their official and individual capacities, dismissing claims for damages.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 2, 2016, three female high school students filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma on behalf of female students who participated in interscholastic and other school-sponsored sports.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the school district had violated Title IX by failing to fund and sponsor girls' sports so that the interests and abilities of all female students at the school were accommodated in a non-discriminatory manner.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree provided for the construction of a softball field on the high school campus and required the district to provide equal access to weight training and conditioning facilities and equipment to female athletes and male athletes.[SENTMARKER]The district also agreed to expand participation opportunities for female students in middle school sports.

gold_sents: Parents, on behalf of female students of Chouteau Public Schools, brought suit against the school district alleging that the school had violated female students' rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and Title IX of the Education Amendment through disparate treatment with respect to interscholastic athletics and programs.[SENTMARKER]In a settlement agreement, the school district agreed to take steps to remedy the discriminatory actions by, among many things, providing coaching, facilities and equipment to both male and female athletic teams on a gender-neutral basis.
pegasus_output_sents: In June 2000, a group of female students at Chouteau public schools filed a class action lawsuit against the Chouteau School District under Title IX of the United States Constitution and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Chouteau has violated Title IX by denying female students meaningful participation opportunities in interscholastic and other school-sponsored athletics.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that the district has failed to effectively accommodate the interests of the female students.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the district agreed to fund and sponsor more female athletic teams, provide female students with better equipment and supplies, and promote sports participation opportunities.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by Judge Michael Burrage on June 30, 2000 and is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: A lawsuit was filed on behalf of all school-age students with disabilities in Pennsylvania seeking to increase the number of children with disabilities educated with their non-disabled peers, and to make sure schools provided real supports to make sure inclusion would work as required by the IDEA.[SENTMARKER]After eleven years, the parties reached a settlement; however, the final report demonstrates many of the terms of the agreement was not met.
pegasus_output_sents: In the late 1970s, disability advocacy groups filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania on behalf of students with disabilities whose parents sought their education in regular class with supplementary aids and services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania's Department of education violated the Individuals with Disabilities in Education Act (IDEA) by failing to identify disabled students, develop individual educational programs or plans, and provide a free appropriate public education in the least restrictive environment to the maximum extent reasonably possible.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in which the Commonwealth agreed to implement a set of provisions designed to increase the number of students included in regular education classrooms and the benefit they received from education.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the Commonwealth to create materials representing that all children, including those children with disabilities, are welcome in school and to disseminate information to parents about training opportunities and materials.

gold_sents: In 2015, a transgender boy filed a lawsuit against his school district because they would not allow him to use the boys' bathroom.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the school district's motion to dismiss, but the appeals court reversed and remanded, and the district court has since granted a preliminary injunction allowing plaintiff access to the boy's bathroom.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court agreed to hear the school district's appeal in 2016, but later remanded the case after the Department of Education and Department of Justice withdrew their prior guidance on the issue.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court to determine whether the plaintiff's graduation from high school rendered the case moot.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2018, the district court denied the defendant’s motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a second amended complaint on February 15, 2019, and a motion for summary judgment on March 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2019, the court granted the summary judgment; the defendant appealed the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 9, 2014, a student at Gloucester High School filed a Title IX lawsuit against the Gloucester County School Board (the "School Board"), alleging that the School Board's transgender restroom policy violated Title IX and the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the policy discriminated against the student on the basis of his sex in violation of Title IX.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed G.G.[SENTMARKER]'s Title IX claim and denied his request for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Fourth Circuit vacated the district court's preliminary injunction, and the Supreme Court granted a writ of certiorari.[SENTMARKER]The School Board then implemented the policy and created three single-stall unisex restrooms for use by all students, regardless of their biological sex or gender identity.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals granted a stay of the District Court's mandate.[SENTMARKER]The District Court then granted a rehearing en banc.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court issued a final judgment in favor of the school board.[SENTMARKER]The school board appealed the decision to the Virginia Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado by three former employees who were employed by a company known as E.PNG.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that El Paso converted its defined benefit pension plan from a traditional defined benefit plan to a cash balance plan, in particular one based on a final average pay formula to one.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the charge and the EEOC was unable to resolve the controversy.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of El Paso and the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' Motion to Certify Class in part and denied the class in part without prejudice.

gold_sents: On September 29, 2011, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC") brought this lawsuit against Beverage Distributors Company, LLC ("BDC") on behalf of a visually impaired company employee in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 ("ADA").[SENTMARKER]The EEOC claimed that BDC discriminated against the employee in violation of the ADA when it conditioned his employment on the results of a medical exam and subsequently refused to hire him as a night warehouse loader upon learning that he had a disability.[SENTMARKER]The jury initially awarded the employee $132,347 in back pay, but it found that his damages should be reduced by $102,803 because he could have mitigated those damages by finding a comparable position.[SENTMARKER]On December 9, 2013, the District Court vacated these findings and awarded injunctive relief, only to be reversed by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit because of erroneous jury instructions.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit denied the EEOC's petition for rehearing in May 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in December 2015, and the matter appears to be closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 9, 2012, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against Beverage Distributors Company, LLC (BDC), a wholesale liquor distribution company, alleging that BDC violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) when it withdrew its conditional offer of employment as a Night Warehouse Loader upon being informed that Mr. Mike Sungaila was legally blind and terminated his employment.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive relief prohibiting further discrimination by the employer and mandating corrective action, including hiring Sungalia into a night warehouse loader position.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the EEOC's motion for summary judgment, and the jury found in favor of the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on January 9, 2012 requiring BDC to hire an outside consultant to provide employee training and assistance in revisions to BDC's policies, job postings, notice posting, and reporting and compliance review.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendant to report its compliance with the decree to the Court within six months of the decree's entry.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, BDC has asked the court to postpone the decree until the Tenth Circuit rules on the issue of whether BDC is liable for discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The case is being handled by the EEOC’s Denver office.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2006, a group of female financial advisors filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court in Washington, D.C. alleging that Morgan Stanley had discriminated against them and a class of similarly situated persons on the basis of their sex in several aspects of their employment.[SENTMARKER]The named plaintiffs alleged that they were denied equal employment opportunities to their female financial advisers and female registered financial advisor trainees in violation of federal and applicable state civil rights laws.[SENTMARKER]The parties engaged the services of Hunter Hughes, Esq., a highly experienced professional mediator, skilled in mediation of complex class actions, including employment discrimination litigation.[SENTMARKER]On April 23, 2007, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement agreement, Morgan Stanley agreed to revise the "Power Rankings" used to allocate accounts and other business opportunities to ensure equitable and fair account distribution without regard to gender.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed to provide its Human Resources staff with appropriate training regarding compliance with state, federal, and local employment discrimination laws and its anti-discrimination and harassment policies.[SENTMARKER]The complaint reporting process and the Diversity Monitor's role in the review of individual complaints will expire on September 30, 2015 and the term for the settlement is five years.

Lauderdale facilities during the preceding six months.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay a total of $395,000 in compensation to the female employee.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (''EEOC'') filed suit against Bay State Milling Company in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida, alleging that Bay State violated the Age Discrimination in Employmem Act by failing to hire a qualified applicant for a vacant Miller position for which he was qualified because of his age.[SENTMARKER]On November 5, 2013, the parties filed a joint motion for approval of a consent decree, which included mandatory training for the hiring manager, interviewing officials and the company's human resources department, with an emphasis on age-related discriminatory practices and age sensitivity.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was approved on December 10, 2013 by Judge Donald L.
