gold_sents: On May 8, 2013, the EEOC filed suit in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida under 42 U.S.C. § 1981 and 42 U.S.C. § 2000 against Dynamic Medical Services, Inc., on behalf of several sales employees.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that they were coerced into adopting Scientology religious views and practices.[SENTMARKER]In December of 2013, the case was settled for $170,000 and a series of anti-discrimination measures on the part of Dynamic.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 23, 2013, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida against Dynamic Medical Services, Inc., a Florida corporation that provides medical and chiropractic services, for religious discrimination in employment pursuant to Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (C.R.A.).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Dynamic required its employees to attend Scientology religious practices courses, such as screaming at ashtrays or staring at someone for eight hours without moving, as a condition of employment.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the employees were subjected to adverse employment actions including constructive discharge or termination from their employment with Dynamic as a result of their reporting, and in retaliation for, their reporting of, and opposition to violations of the FCRA, Florida Statute Chapter 760.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the company failed to accommodate the religious beliefs of one of the employees, Rommy Sanchez, who was forced to participate in several Scientology practices at the Church of Scientology.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a consent decree in which Dynamic agreed to pay $170,000 to settle the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was approved by the court on December 23, 2013 and is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent decree are confidential.

gold_sents: In September 2002, the Chicago District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit against HQ Global Workplaces, Inc. in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois alleging discrimination on the basis of disability and retaliation in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the EEOC alleged that the defendant maintained policies on leave and part-time status availability precluding reasonable accommodation in violation of the ADA, terminated complainant based on her disability, and disciplined complainant's manager for providing complainant with a reasonable accommodation.[SENTMARKER]Following some discovery, the parties jointly dismissed the lawsuit in May 2003.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 1999, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against HQ Global Workplaces, Inc., a Chicago-based employer.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the employer violated Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide a reasonable accommodation to an employee who was disabled and her local manager for complying with the requirements of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a joint motion to dismiss with prejudice, which was granted by Judge James B. Zagel.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice and without costs by agreement on May 15, 2003.

gold_sents: The EEOC filed suit against Sears Roebuck and Company, alleging that Sears violated the Americans with Disabilities Act by enacting an inflexible workers compensation policy, and failing to provide reasonable accommodations to employees seeking to return to work after injury.[SENTMARKER]The court approved a consent decree, which required payment to individual claimants, revision of policies, recordkeeping, reporting, and training.[SENTMARKER]The matter appears to be closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 10, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against Sears Roebuck Company, alleging that Sears violated the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) by failing to accommodate a class of employees with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, Sears terminated the employment of one of its Chicago-area employees, John Bava, on account of his disability rather than accommodating him by extending his leave or returning him to work in an available position which he could have performed.[SENTMARKER]The complaint further alleges that Sears unlawfully maintained an inflexible one year leave policy, which provided for discharge of employment after a year instead of "reasonable accommodation" and which instead provided for termination of employment, all in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]On August 2, 2005, the court entered a consent decree requiring Sears to comply with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On February 8, 2006, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a lawsuit against the Board of Trustees for Southern Illinois University under Title VII in the Southern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The Department of Justice asked the court for injunctive relief, alleging that the defendant discriminated against non-specified minorities on the basis of race and white males on the basis of race and gender.[SENTMARKER]The day after, the parties entered into a consent decree with injunctive reliefs and the case was dismissed on December 2, 2008.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 16, 2006, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois entered a consent decree against the Board of Trustees of SouthernIllinois University ("SIU Board").[SENTMARKER]The consent decree, which was entered by Judge J. Phil Gilbert on February 9, 2006, prohibits the use of race, sex, national origin or religion as a basis for discrimination in the recruitment, selection, hiring or employment of persons for paid fellowship positions at SIU.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the terms and conditions of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed that there would be no further enforcement of Title VII unless the parties reached a settlement agreement within two years of the date of entry of this decree.

gold_sents: In 2001, four former employees of Mid-West Wire Specialties, Inc. filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant discriminated against them on the basis of their sex, female, in violation of Title VII, in that they were sexually harassed by other employees of the defendant and faced retaliation for resisting the sexual advances.[SENTMARKER]In 2002, the parties reached a settlement that awarded monetary damages and backpay for for class members.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in August 2002.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2001, two female employees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois on behalf of a group of approximately 47 female temporary workers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subject to a hostile work environment, quid pro quo sexual harassment, and retaliation for opposing sex discrimination and sexual harassment or rejecting sexual advances of their supervisors.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed to pay approximately $500 (five hundred dollars) to each of the female employees.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was preliminarily approved by the court in August 2001 and was entered into on December 3, 2001.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The motion was denied and the parties entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On July 12th, 2000 eight female employees filed suit in the United States District Court in the Northern District of Illinois against DaimlerChrysler Corp.  They alleged DaimlerChrysler engaged in age discrimination, gender discrimination, race discrimination, and violations of the American with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]As discovery progressed various plaintiffs were added and some were dismissed from the case.[SENTMARKER]Settlement negations concerning the remaining plaintiffs resulted in individual settlement agreements.[SENTMARKER]The exact terms of these settlements are not available.[SENTMARKER]The case was completely dismissed on October 29th, 2002.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 21, 1991, a female employee of DaimlerChrysler Corporation filed a charge of discrimination in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) against DaimlerChrysler and the International Union of the United Auto Workers Local Union.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated the ADA by failing to accommodate the plaintiff's disability.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also alleged that DaimlerChrysler discriminated against her by denying her the same rights as enjoyed by white employees as regards the making, performance, modification and termination of their employment relationship with DaimlerChrysler.[SENTMARKER]On November 30, 2000, the defendant filed a motion to dismiss the complaint pursuant to Fed.R.Civ.P.[SENTMARKER]United States District Court for the Northern district of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]On July 26, 2001, the court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment and the case was closed.

gold_sents: Financial advisors who sued their employer, Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., for race and gender discrimination in compensation did not state a plausible claim, so their complaint was dismissed pursuant to Title VII Section 703(h), which allows employers to compensate employees differently on the basis of seniority, merit, or quality or quantity of production.[SENTMARKER]The differences in compensation are only unlawful when they result from an intention to discriminate because of race, color, religion, sex or national origin.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 21, 2012, a group of African-American Financial Advisors (FAs) filed a class action suit in the Northern district of Illinois against Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith Incorporated, and Bank of America Corporation alleging racial discrimination in hiring, compensation, account distribution, and teaming.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Merrill Lynch's long history of systemic discrimination against African-Americans and women, and its retention bonuses to Merrill Lynch FAs, had a disparate impact on African American and female FAs.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiffs' initial motion for class certification in August 2010, and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]In December 2012, the plaintiffs filed a second class-action suit, this time against both Merrill Lynch and Bank, seeking class certification under Title VII and Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to amend the complaint to include race and gender discrimination claims.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Eastern district of the U.S. District Court for the Eastern Division, where the case is still ongoing.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States has not yet issued a decision on the case.

gold_sents: In December 2013, the EEOC brought this suit against Bright Petroleum for scrutinizing, disciplining and discharging against its female employee who filed a charge of sex discrimination with the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC and Bright Petroleum entered a three-year consent decree on December 12, 2014.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 23, 2013, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against The Bright Market, Inc. and its owners, June and Jay Tucker, alleging that the company violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.C.[SENTMARKER]2000e-5(f)(1) and (3) by firing a female employee after she filed a charge of discrimination with the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the employer retaliated against the female employee by subjecting her to scrutiny, discipline, and termination because she filed the charge with the Commission.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the company's actions were intentional and demonstrated a reckless indifference to the worker's protected rights.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the parties agreed to pay $15,000 in back wages plus interest and compensatory and punitive damages, as well as other relief, including a permanent injunction to prevent the company from engaging in any future retaliation.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Sarah Evans Barker on December 19, 2014 and is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2005 a group of former employees of the Boeing Company filed suit in the United States District Court of Kansas against the Boeing Company (Boeing), Spirit Aerosystems Inc. (Spirit), the Onex Corporation (Onex) and Midwestern Aircraft (Midwestern).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory, injunctive and monetary relief as well as class certification, alleging pattern or practice of age discrimination, disparate impact and disparate treatment by the defendants during the layoff and rehire process, in connection with Boeing's sale of its commercial airplane manufacturing facilities to Onex.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought eight claims, two of which were dismissed during the pleading stage, five were dismissed as the District Court granted summary judgment in the defendants' favor in two separate opinions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the 10th Circuit Court, but the 10th Circuit affirmed the lower court's decisions.[SENTMARKER]The remaining claim in the case after the Circuit Court decision was the plaintiffs' ADEA claim of disparate treatment.[SENTMARKER]A number of individual plaintiffs settled with defendants.[SENTMARKER]After the plaintiffs failed to appear at a hearing on a motion to dismiss, Judge Melgran granted the motion.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed on February 9, 2015, and the appeal was dismissed on June 16, 2015 for failure to prosecute.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 2006, a group of former Boeing employees filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Kansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) and the Employment Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) by terminating and failing to rehire employees over the age of forty when they sold their commercial airplane manufacturing facilities to Spirit AeroSystems, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The defendants required Boeing employees to sign a "Consent to Release 5 Personnel Information" form, which violated the ADEA and the Older Workers Benefit Protection Act (OWPCPA), and the OWPCPA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: In February 2001, the EEOC brought this Title VII sex discrimination action against the Jonesboro Manufacturing Company on behalf of an employee who claimed that a male coworker repeatedly made inappropriate sexual comments to her, and after she complained nothing was done.[SENTMARKER]The defense immediately filed a motion to dismiss for failure to timely serve the summons and complaint.[SENTMARKER]While this motion was pending, the EEOC voluntarily dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 1996, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Louisiana against Jonesboro Manufacturing Co., Inc., a Monroe, Louisiana-based manufacturer of machine tools, alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by engaging in unlawful employment practices on the basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that a female machine operator at the defendant's Jonesboro facility was harassed and/or constructively discharged because of her sex by a male employee, who made sexually offensive remarks to her and other female employees.[SENTMARKER]The defendant did not take any reasonable steps to prevent the harassment, nor did it take any corrective action to stop the harassment.[SENTMARKER]On October 2, 1997, the defendant filed a motion to dismiss the complaint, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay a total of $9,900 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendant to institute and carry out anti-harassment policies, practices, and programs which provide equal employment opportunities for female persons, and which eradicate the effects of its past and present employment practices, including but not limited to, unlawful discrimination and retaliation against any person for having engaged in activity protected by Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on February 27, 2001.

gold_sents: On August 22, 2005, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII retaliation claim against Tasa, Inc., (doing business as Orr Minden Country Chevrolet) on behalf of a black employee who had a pending race discrimination charge and no discipline or warnings at the time of his firing.[SENTMARKER]The complaint was filed with a joint motion for a consent decree, which the Court (Donald E. Walter) approved on November 11, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the decree provided for damages ($60,000 to the employee) and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties bore their own costs.[SENTMARKER]Under the decree, Tasa, Inc., had to provide annual Title VII training to all employees in Louisiana, to post an EEOC poster in a conspicuous location, to report to the EEOC annually the date, attendees, and subject matters of the Title VII trainings, and to institute and follow a promotion policy.[SENTMARKER]The promotion policy required that all vacant positions be posted before an employee is promoted to the positions, that all qualified candidates be interviewed, and that all applications, resumes, and interview notes be maintained.[SENTMARKER]The decree expired automatically after three years.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 17, 2003, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Louisiana against Tasa, Inc. d/b/a Orr Minden Country Chevrolet, a Louisiana corporation doing business as Orr Minden Chevrolet.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that David Thompson, an African American, was unlawfully discharged by the Defendant in retaliation for having filed a charge of employment discrimination based on his race with the Commission.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the Defendant's discharge of Mr. Thompson was motivated by the retaliatory animus of its owner Larry Coker.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to a consent decree, which required it to institute and follow promotion policies and procedures pursuant to which, for the duration of this decree, it shall: (i) post all vacant positions before promoting any employee to the position; .[SENTMARKER](ii) conduct an annual anti-retaliation training program for all of its officials, managers, supervisors, and employees; and (iii) pay the Commission's attorney's fees and costs incurred in cormection with the litigation of this lawsuit.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered on October 17, 2003 and is subject to final approval by the court at a later date.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for partial summary judgment on October 31, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The defendant then filed a motion to dismiss the case on the grounds that it had not complied with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2004, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendant.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay the commission's attorneys' fees, costs, and to implement an anti-discrimination training program.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered in October 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed that the case will be closed.

gold_sents: On April 13, 2015, a transgender man who was fired when he refused to sign an agreement to present and be treated as a woman at work as a condition of his employment filed a Title VII sex discrimination claim in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC later intervened in the case.[SENTMARKER]District Judge Carl Barbier directed the parties to arbitrate the case pursuant to an arbitration agreement between the plaintiff and his employer.[SENTMARKER]After the conclusion of the arbitration, which yielded monetary relief for the individual plaintiff, the EEOC continued to litigate the case to obtain injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]Judge Barbier entered an 18-month consent decree which required the defendant retrain its employees and post notice of what constitutes a violation of equal employment opportunity policies.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against First Tower Loan, LLC, doing business as Tower Loan of Lake Charles, alleging that Tower Loan violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Louisiana Employment Discrimination Law by terminating a transgender employee because of his sex.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the termination constituted unlawful discrimination on the basis of gender identity, sex stereotypes, and gender identity because the employee would not sign Tower Loan's written agreement.[SENTMARKER]On December 10, 2015, the court granted the EEOC's Motion to Compel Arbitration.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the parties agreed that the parties would not engage in any employment practice which discriminates on the grounds of gender or transgender status or sex stereotyping.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the parties to: (a) train each employee annually at a minimum with the first training to be held within six months after the entry of the consent decree; .[SENTMARKER](b) report any complaints about harassment or discrimination to Defendant’s Human Resources office; .[SENTMARKER](c) ensure that all persons in active concert or participation with it/them will not be discriminated against because of their gender identity or gender identity; .[SENTMARKER](d) require all parties to pay their own costs and attorney's fees incurred in this action; and (e) ensure compliance with the terms of the decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree was entered by Judge Carl Barbier on December 5, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion to dismiss, and the case was dismissed by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 8, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed a lawsuit in the District Court of Maryland, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, against Avado Brands, Inc, alleging that it violated the terms of a prior Negotiated Settlement Agreement with the plaintiffs due to a racially hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay $9,166.21.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 8, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against Avado Brands, Inc. d/b/a Don Pablo's Restaurant, alleging that Avado violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and other federal employment laws.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, from November 1999 to June 2002, Avado engaged in a pattern of racial discrimination and retaliation against a female employee who was a manager at the restaurant.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the female employee was subjected to intimidation, ridicule, and insult, on the basis of her race, and subjected to different terms, conditions, and privileges of her employment, as a result of the conduct of her manager.[SENTMARKER]The defendant entered into a settlement agreement with the EEOC in which it agreed to pay the plaintiff $50,000.00 in monetary relief and to provide her with two (2) hours of anti-harassment training to all management employees at its Maryland facilities.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was approved by the bankruptcy court on July 19, 2005 and became effective two years later.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into another settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed not to retaliate against any of its employees who complained about harassment or discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiff on July 22, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in the amount of $300,000.00, which was paid to the plaintiff by the defendant.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on July 31, 2006.

gold_sents: On September 30, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of an African American employee (plaintiff-intervenor), filed a lawsuit in the District Court of Maryland, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, against Coca-Cola Enterprises, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive relief, compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and other forms of affirmative relief claiming that the defendant did not promote the plaintiff-intervenor because of his race, African American.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to promote the plaintiff-intervenor to a higher-paying position as well as pay him $60,500.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland against Coca-Cola Enterprises, Inc. (CCE) alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by refusing to promote Mark Mason to the position of Field Service Manager because of his race, African-American.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the Defendant discriminated on the basis of race in the wages and other compensation and benefits that were paid to Mr. Mason in violation of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to pay a total of $325,000 in compensation and to provide training for all managers above the grade 15 level in the Baltimore/Washington Cooler Service Department.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Benson Everett Legum on October 1, 2004 and was entered into in effect three years later.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: The case was brought by African American employees of Friedman's, a jewelry store, and sought equitable and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged they had suffered from working in a racially hostile work environment and alleged that Friedman's had engaged in a pattern and practice of racial discrimination in hiring, promotion, compensation, and other terms and privileges of employment.[SENTMARKER]The case was finally settled on February 12, 2009, after Friedman's had entered into bankruptcy two times.[SENTMARKER]The named plaintiffs and class members received over a million dollars for costs with a portion to cover attorneys' fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 6, 2003, African American employees of Friedman's, Inc. filed a class action lawsuit against St. Paul Mercury Insurance Company in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois under the Civil Rights Act of 1866, alleging racial discrimination in employment practices of the insurance company.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the company had created and maintained a system-wide policy and/or pattern or practice of race-based disparate treatment that limited the employment opportunities of African Americans.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the complaint alleged a hostile work environment for African Americans and similarly situated African Americans as a class, on the basis of their race.[SENTMARKER]The parties engaged in mediation in November 2005, but the mediation failed to produce a settlement.[SENTMARKER]On January 14, 2005, the parties filed a bankruptcy petition in the Southern District of Georgia, where the case was administratively closed, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included the following provisions: Explicitly limiting the number of African American applicants hired; paying African Americans less than similarly-situated white employees; and maintaining a work environment that is hostile to African American workers.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for summary judgment on January 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion for partial summary judgment, which was granted by the court on January 14.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 28, 2017, six transgender individuals currently serving in the United States military filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland Maryland contesting the President's ban on transgender service in the U.S. military.[SENTMARKER]Judge Garbis initially granted a motion for a preliminary injunction in September, but this was later stayed in 2019 when the Supreme Court issued a stay of this nationwide injunction in two factually similar cases contesting the ban.[SENTMARKER]This case changed dramatically in 2018 when the government altered its policy on transgender service in the military, eliminating an outright ban and instead putting new guidance on transgender men and women entering the service.[SENTMARKER]Judge Russell, reassigned to the case in 2018, dissolved the preliminary injunction, saying that it was only meant to stay a complete ban on transgender service in the military.[SENTMARKER]This also dismissed all claims against the 2017 outright ban as moot, and removed all plaintiffs that were already in the service and not seeking to join.[SENTMARKER]Discovery is ongoing in the case.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2017, a group of transgender service members filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court in Washington, D.C. alleging that the military's policy on transgender personnel violated the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, enjoining enforcement of the Accession and Retention Directives and reverting the policy to the status quo that had existed before the Presidential Memorandum Id.[SENTMARKER]In light of the Supreme Court's Order, Defendants moved for the Court to stay the nationwide effect of the district court's preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 4, 2019, the Court vacated without prejudice the preliminary injunction and remanded for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On June 14, 2019, the Ninth Circuit issued its decision in Karnoski, concluding that the plaintiffs had established a likelihood of success on the merits of their equal protection claim.

gold_sents: In 2016, three Pocomoke City, Maryland police officers filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they suffered racial discrimination and retaliation by their employer in violation of their First and Fourteenth Amendment rights and the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, two of the officers reached a partial settlement with Pocomoke City requiring adoption of anti-discrimination policies and procedures by the police department and awarding monetary damages to the officers.[SENTMARKER]As of September 30, 2020, the case is still ongoing pending a final settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2016, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EOC) filed this complaint in the United States district court for the district of Maryland against the Pocomoke City Police Department, the Worcester County Sheriff's Office, and the State of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that African American officers serving on the PoCOMoke City police department suffered racially discriminatory acts and a racially hostile work environment, and that the defendants violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by unlawfully terminating one officer and retaliating against another officer who complained of racial harassment.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to a consent decree, which was entered into with the consent of the parties on March 16, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The decree requires the defendants to: (1) provide a neutral reference to any potential employer that contacts the defendant; .[SENTMARKER](2) pay reasonable attorney's fees and other costs against the defendants; and (3) provide the EEOC with a copy of all documents relevant to its compliance with the decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this Title VII racial-harassment and retaliation suit against A & R Truss Company for violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e et.[SENTMARKER]seq.).[SENTMARKER]Alleging that Defendant had repeatedly subjected a black employee at the New Buffalo facility to racially offensive epithets and had met the employee's complaints with threats and intimidation, the EEOC sought monetary and injunctive relief, including compensation for emotional harm and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a one-year consent decree that provided monetary and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The employee received $20,000.[SENTMARKER]A & R Truss was subject to an array of anti-harassment, anti-retaliation, training, policy, and notice provisions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: August 15, 2005 DATE | A R Truss Company ORG | Western District of Michigan DATE ||| Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C.  2000e et seq.<n>On August 15, 2005, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EOC") filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Western district of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant engaged in unlawful employment practices by subjecting an African American employee to racial harassment based on his race, African American.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay $25,000 in non-pecuniary damages and to implement a race discrimination and harassment policy.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also agreed to post a notice of its anti-harassment policy within ten days of its entry into the court and to provide training to its current managers and any new managers hired during the effective dates of this Decree.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is contingent upon the defendant signing an appropriate settlement agreement and release of all claims.

gold_sents: EEOC's Charlotte, NC office filed this lawsuit alleging discrimination based on national origin against the defendant, Sears, Roebuck & Co. in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina (Eastern Division) on 09/16/1998.[SENTMARKER]EEOC alleged on behalf of a job applicant who was a naturalized American of Mexican origin that the defendant refused to hire him because of his national origin and specifically Spanish accent.[SENTMARKER]The district court's granting of summary judgement to the defendant was reversed on appeal.[SENTMARKER]The defendant and the applicant settled and voluntarily dismissed his part of the case, while the EEOC and the defendant entered into a 1-year consent decree, which prohibited national origin discrimination and mandated training and posting of an Equal Employment notice.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 16, 1998, the EEOC filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina, alleging that Sears, Roebuck and Company failed or refused to hire Francisco G. Santana because of his national origin, Hispanic (Mexican-American) because of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and that such refusal violated Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted Sears's motion for summary judgment, but the case was reopened and the parties appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court remanded the case to the district court for further consideration.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree, which required Sears to: (a) post an Employee Notice in a place where it is visible to all employees at its Morehead City, North Carolina store; .[SENTMARKER](b) provide annual training to all managers concerning the federal employment discrimination laws, particularly as they apply to national origin; .[SENTMARKER](c) ensure that all managers abide by the requirements of its equal employment opportunity policy; and (d) provide a copy of its nondiscrimination policy at the time of hire or transfer.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered on May 1, 2001 and was effective for one year from the date of its entry.[SENTMARKER]In the appeal, the parties argued that Sears had violated the consent decree by failing to post the Employee Notice, failing to comply with the training, and failing to respond to the EEOC's complaints.[SENTMARKER]The case was re-opened on May 2, 2001 and closed on May 3, 2002.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for re-opening of the case on May 4, 2002.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and the plaintiff-intervenor, the complainant, filed this class action lawsuit against Pitt-Ohio  Express, Inc., a transport company, in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Pitt-Ohio discriminated against women by refusing to hire women as truck drivers or dockworkers, in violation of Title VII 42 U.S.C. § 2000e.[SENTMARKER]On October 1, 2008, the court approved a settlement agreement between the plaintiff-intervenor and Pitt-Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to pay $265,000 in monetary relief and  $305,000 in attorney fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]That same month, the court approved a consent decree between EEOC and Pitt-Ohio.[SENTMARKER]This decree required the defendant to pay $$2,430,000 to EEOC (to be distributed to women that were affected by the defendant’s discrimination), to adopt anti-discrimination policies, to offer driver and/or dockworker positions to the women that were discriminated against, and regularly report to the EEOC to ensure compliance.[SENTMARKER]This decree had a duration of five years.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 31, 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC") filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio against Pitt Ohio Express, LLC ("Pitt Ohio") alleging that Pitt Ohio violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Title VII") by failing to hire a qualified female applicant for a truck driver or dockworker position based on her sex.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that since September 1, 1997, Pitt Ohio failed to hire or offer positions to other female applicants because of their gender.[SENTMARKER]Pitt Ohio agreed to a consent decree in which it agreed to comply with the terms of Title VII, including hiring practices and procedures which comply with Title VII and the hiring process and types of questions to be asked of applicants.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required Pitt Ohio to implement an equal opportunity component in its personnel policies and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was approved by the court on October 8, 2008 and is effective for five years.

gold_sents: In August 2001, the Cleveland District Office filed this lawsuit against Sundance Rehabilitation Corporation in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio alleging violation of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, the Equal Pay Act of 1963, and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint specifically alleged that the defendant required terminated employees to sign a waiver of claims against the defendant, including EEO violations, in order to receive severance pay.[SENTMARKER]Following discovery and motions for summary judgment for both parties, the District Court granted summary judgment to the EEOC in July 2004.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed the decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in September 2004.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals reversed the District Court's judgment in October 2006.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court granted an extension of time to file a petition for a writ of certiorari in June 2007.[SENTMARKER]However, the docket does not indicate that this option was exercised.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio under the antiretaliation provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Equal Pay Act (EPA), and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against defendant SunDance Rehabilitation Corporation (SunDance).[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that SunDance violated Title VII by requiring employees fired in a reduction in force to waive their rights to file an EEOC charge and to participate in EEOC proceedings as a condition of receiving severance pay.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the EEOC's motion for summary judgment in favor of SunDance.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, SunDance appealed, claiming that the district court's decision to grant summary judgment to the EEOC violated its right to a fair and just trial.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States denied SunDance's appeal.

gold_sents: On May 25, 2007 the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a lawsuit against the Village of Woodmere, Ohio in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio to enforce Title VII, 42 U.S.C. §2000e, et seq.[SENTMARKER]The D.O.J.[SENTMARKER]asked the court for injunctive and compensatory relief, alleging the defendant had violated Title VII by discriminating against two employees in the defendant's police department on the basis of their race (white) in termination of their employment.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement and the Court entered a three year consent decree on May 23, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to implement new policies to deal with racial discrimination complaints and provide mandatory nondiscrimination training.[SENTMARKER]The individuals were to receive monetary awards, and one of them receive reinstatement.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio against the Village of Woodmere, Ohio, alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discharging two former police officers on the basis of their race.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed or refused to take appropriate action to remedy the effects of its discrimination against Amy Mengay, a former officer in the defendant's police department, by terminating her employment as a probationary police officer and failing or refusing to take action to rectify the effect of her discrimination against Timothy Ellis, another former officer.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in 2007 to resolve the matter.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendants to: (a) report to the EEOC any complaint of discrimination or retaliation made by any individual pursuant to their written policies and procedures referenced in paragraph 4 of the decree; .[SENTMARKER](b) provide the name and contact information of the officer in question within 30 days of the date of the complaint; .[SENTMARKER](c) pay the plaintiff's attorney's fees; .[SENTMARKER](d) require the defendant to provide the EEOC with a copy of the policy and procedures that prohibit employment discrimination; and (e) create a non-discrimination policy.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants in 2007 and the parties agreed to settle the matter without further order.

gold_sents: On December 9, 2011, an openly gay former employee of Ohio Bell Telephone Company filed suit in U.S District Court for the Northern District of Ohio alleging that he had been dismissed in violation of the ADA, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, and multiple sections of Ohio's Civil Rights Act. Plaintiff took his husband's last name after the couple was married in Massachusetts and had AIDS and alleged he was fired for those reasons.[SENTMARKER]The court denied Defendant's motion to dismiss and the case settled in September 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: In February 2012, a former Ohio Bell employee filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio alleging discrimination in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (OCRA) and Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Ohio Bell discriminated against the employee because the employee was HIV positive and had entered into a same sex marriage.[SENTMARKER]Ohio Bell terminated the employee after the employee missed work for his father's funeral.[SENTMARKER]The court granted Ohio Bell's motion for summary judgment, finding that there was no evidence that the employee's termination was based on his gender, and that his termination was unrelated to his disability.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]In a separate case, a former AT&T employee who was fired because of his same-sex marriage filed a similar complaint against Ohio Bell in the same district court.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: On January 18, 2001, the U.S. Department of Justice ("D.O.J.")[SENTMARKER]filed a lawsuit under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against the City of Sulphur in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Oklahoma alleging that the City discriminated against a Mexican-American employee on the basis of his national origin, when it failed or refused to promote him and took no action to remedy the effects of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The D.O.J.[SENTMARKER]sought injunctive and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]On February 23, 2001, the Court entered a consent decree, containing injunctions on discrimination and retaliation, with orders to the defendant to implement a nondiscriminatory policy and antidiscrimination training.[SENTMARKER]The individual received $45,000.[SENTMARKER]The decree expired after five years.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Oklahoma against the City of Sulphur, Oklahoma, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII by failing or refusing to hire or promote an employee on the basis of his national origin, Mexican-American, when the employee was denied a promotion to the position of Sanitation Department Superintendent.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also allegedly failed or refused to take appropriate action to remedy the effects of the discriminatory treatment of the employee.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was entered by Judge Frank H. Seay on February 26, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The decree required the defendant to comply with Title VII and to pay the employee in full and in part.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the city to implement non-discriminatory employment policies and practices that treat all employees in the same way, regardless of national origin.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered with the consent of the parties and is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents:
On November 3, 2003, African-American employees of Kraft Foods filed a lawsuit against their employer in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. 2000e, contending that Kraft had discriminated with regard to discipline and hiring.[SENTMARKER]

The court approved a preliminary settlement agreement on May 1, 2007 in which Kraft agreed to pay $1.325 million and grant other forms of non-monetary relief.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 1999, a former employee of Kraft Foods filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania on behalf of African-Americans employed at Kraft's Philadelphia Bakery.[SENTMARKER]She alleged that Kraft discriminated against African- Americans with respect to job discipline and classification.[SENTMARKER]She also alleged that she was subjected to racial discrimination in the assignment of entry-level positions.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, from November 1999 to December 2006, Kraft retaliated against African American employees who complained about their treatment by firing or disciplining them more frequently and more severely than Caucasian or White hourly employees.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, the parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on December 31, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the settlement in March 2006, and the parties agreed to implement a program to monitor compliance with the terms and conditions of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $75,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: Four plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and others similarly situated, filed a lawsuit against Latrobe Specialty Steel Company for violations of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA).[SENTMARKER]All four plaintiffs were over the age of fifty and were terminated following the discovery of inappropriate emails on their work email accounts.[SENTMARKER]Despite the plaintiffs' claims that the emails were a pretext for age discrimination, the court held that there was no evidence that but for their ages, the plaintiffs would not have been terminated.[SENTMARKER]Thus, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendant, which was affirmed by the appellate court.[SENTMARKER]Taxation was assessed against the plaintiffs in the amount of $21,863.88.
pegasus_output_sents: In October 2007, a group of former Latrobe employees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania, alleging that the company discriminated against older employees by terminating them based largely, if not exclusively, on their age.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their termination was based on the fact that they had repeatedly sent sexually oriented and pornographic emails through Latrobe's employee email system to other employees as well as outside third parties which violated the company's policies, practices and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of Latrobe, concluding that the plaintiffs had failed to demonstrate that "but for [sic] their ages," LSS would not have terminated their employment.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Third Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the district court's summary judgment, finding that plaintiffs failed to show that their age was a factor in their termination.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 30, 2010, the plaintiff, an African American job applicant with a felony criminal record, filed this class action lawsuit against the defendants, a company and its affiliates which specialized in training truck drivers and placing them with trucking companies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants refused to procure placement for applicants with a felony conviction, and because of this practice, disparately impacted African American and Latino applicants.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on August 17, 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 17, 2012, a former truck driver filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court in the Philadelphia District Court.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, who was African American and Latino, alleged that Driver Solutions' policy of rejecting applicants with criminal histories had a disparate impact on African Americans and Latinos in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in January 2012 involving monetary relief of $475,000 and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was entered into voluntarily between the parties and their attorneys without any findings of liability.[SENTMARKER]The parties have retained Kurtzman Carson Consultants LLC, an experienced class action claims administrator, to administer the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' request for a further stay of litigation so that they could revive settlement negotiations in advance of private mediation.

gold_sents: This sexual harassment case was brought by the Memphis office of the EEOC in 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case was resolved by Consent Decree in November 2007 which provided individual relief and also required anti-discrimination training, posting of policies and reports to the EEOC.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 5, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against A&I Products, Inc. (A&I) on behalf of two female employees who were subjected to sexual harassment by a co-worker and retaliated against them after they filed a charge of discrimination with the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the two women were subjecting each other to unwelcome sexual harassment because of their sex and that the harassment created a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]The court of appeals reversed the district court's grant of summary judgment on the EEOC's retaliation claim, and the parties entered into a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree provided for two years of employment discrimination training for all employees at the Memphis, Tennessee facility, as well as a payment of $15,000 to one of the female employees.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendant to pay the female employee for her legal fees and expenses.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case on December 7, 2007, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: The Memphis Office of the EEOC brought this suit against Paramount Staffing, Inc. in September 2006 in the United States District Court for the Western District of Tennessee (Memphis).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged discrimination and retaliation based on race (African American) and national origin (American).[SENTMARKER]The parties settled out of court on a two-year consent decree.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee on March 22, 2004 against Paramount Staffing, Inc., a Memphis-based temporary staffing agency.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the agency violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by failing to place African-American and Hispanic employees into temporary positions because of their race and national origin and by retaliating against one employee who complained about alleged discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on August 19, 2010 to resolve the case.[SENTMARKER]As part of the consent decree, the parties agreed that Paramount would post its hiring and placement policies in English and Spanish and that it would not tolerate or condone race and retaliation discrimination in any form.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required Paramount to give a neutral reference to any potential employer of Earnestine Toler who may request a job reference.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Paramount agreed not to retaliate against any employee who participated in the EEOC’s investigation or who otherwise may complain about any discrimination in the workplace.

gold_sents: In 2006, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) brought this suit against Sharp Manufacturing Company in the U.S. District for the Western District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Sharp violated the Americans with Disabilities Act by failing to provide the complainant with reasonable accommodation and discharged her because of her disability.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive and monetary relief as well as punitive damages against the defendant.[SENTMARKER]In 2009, the court approved the parties’ consent decree.[SENTMARKER]This decree had a duration of one year and instructed the defendant to: refrain from unlawful employment discrimination and retaliation; report to the EEOC on compliance with Title VII; revise its policies on reasonable accommodations; post notices of this agreement in their offices; pay $30,000.00 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: September 2004 DATE | Sharp Manufacturing Company of America ORG | U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee DATE | Western Division DATE | January 2009 DATE ||| Sharp Electronics Corporation DATE | ||| American Disabilities Act of 1990 DATE | Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 DATE | EEOC DATE | Dispute of this case brought by the EEOC on September 2004 against Sharp Manufacturing Co. of America.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Sharp Manufacturing failed to provide an employee with a reasonable accommodation and discharged her because of her disability, osteoarthritis.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on January 2009 to resolve the case.[SENTMARKER]The decree required Sharp Manufacturing to post a notice at its Memphis, Tennessee facility for six months, post a copy of the consent decree to all current employees, distribute a copy to all new employees upon the employee's hire, and provide reasonable accommodations to the employee.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge S. Thomas Anderson on January 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for summary judgment on October 31, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion, and the parties entered a final judgment on January 23, 2009.

gold_sents: On January 22, 2004 a group of Fairfield Resorts employees filed this class action lawsuit against Cendant Corporation, Fairfield Resorts, and 15 individuals working at Fairfield Resorts in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, Nashville Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were filing suit over alleged sexual harassment, gender discrimination, and retaliation they experienced on the job.[SENTMARKER]On October 28, 2005, Judge William J. Haynes approved a consent decree granting monetary relief to plaintiffs and other female employees.
pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] December 22, 2004 DATE | Middle District of Tennessee ORG | Cendant Corp.<n>On December 22, 2004, a group of former and current female employees of Fairfield Resorts, Inc. filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District Of Tennessee, Nashville Division, alleging sexual harassment, gender discrimination, and retaliation in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Tennessee Human Rights Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to sexual harassment and gender discrimination in the workplace, and that the defendants retaliated against them by demoting them to positions in which their monthly income was significantly reduced, by denying them promotions for which they were qualified, and by subjecting them to other adverse terms and conditions of employment.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $50,000.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was approved by the court on December 22, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendants to: (i) modify their complaint processing system so that any complaints of harassment, discrimination or retaliation can be made; .[SENTMARKER](ii) publicize in each of their work locations the specific identity of the individual(s) to whom any complaints are made; and (iii) make corrective action available to the complaining party once corrective action has been taken.[SENTMARKER]In the event that the parties do not mutually agree to mediate the dispute, then either party may apply to the Court for appropriate relief to enforce the provisions of this consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent decree were not to exceed $50,000.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed not to retaliate against each other.

gold_sents: On September 28, 2006, The Dallas District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued Beall Concrete Enterprises, Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of U.S. Concrete, Inc. under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and the Age Discrimination in Employment Act. On April 3, 2008, Judge Reed O'Connor approved a consent decree over the remaining claim that the defendant had violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to pay the complainant $50,000 in backpay, conduct ADEA training for its employees for two years, and post a notice about federal anti-discrimination employment laws.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas against Beall Concrete Enterprises, Inc., a Dallas-based concrete company, alleging that the defendant violated the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) and Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (ADEA) by failing to provide reasonable accommodation and then terminating their employment due to a record of a disability.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the parties agreed not to appeal the summary judgment ruling on the ADA claims until the expiration of the term of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was signed on April 17, 2007 and was entered into by the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit on April 18, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay $50,000 in backpay to the EEOC for the claim asserted by the EEOC on behalf of Charles Gentry.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case without prejudice.

gold_sents: On November 9, 1999, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of a female employee, filed a lawsuit in the Northern District Court of Texas, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, as amended, against Parfumes De Couer Limited, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought reinstatement of the applicant, injunctive relief, compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and other forms of affirmative relief claiming that the defendant fired the complainant based on her sex because she was pregnant.[SENTMARKER]On March 23, 2001, the District Court entered a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the complainant $5,000.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas on March 26, 2001 against Parfumes De Couer, Ltd., Inc., a Texas-based fragrance company, alleging that it violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discharging a female employee based on her sex, female, and because of her pregnancy.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which Parfumes de Couer agreed to implement policies, practices, and programs that provide equal employment opportunities for all of its female employees, and eradicate the effects of the Defendant's past and present unlawful practices.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Sidney A. Fitzwater in March 2001 and is subject to final approval by the court at a later date.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent decree are subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On September 19, 2002, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of a black employee, filed a lawsuit in the Western District Court of Texas against Union Pacific Railroad Company.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2004, the District Court (Judge David Briones) entered a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the plaintiff-intervenor $84,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 19, 2002, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against Union Pacific Railroad Company (Union Pacific) alleging that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discharging an African-American employee because of his race.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, in April 1998, Union Pacific began to perform criminal background checks on all employees whose background investigation revealed them to have a felony conviction in the seven year period preceding their application for employment and who did not disclose that information in their application.[SENTMARKER]In accordance with a two-year consent decree, the defendant is required to pay $84,000 to the charging party, who had been reinstated to his job (without back pay) through defendant's internal complaint process approximately 20 months after his discharge.[SENTMARKER]The defendant is also enjoined from retaliating in any manner whatsoever against any employee employed by the Railroad in the El Paso, Texas Transportation Department for opposing any employment practice made unlawful by Title VII.[SENTMARKER]In addition, on an annual basis, defendant must mail or e-mail copies of its policies to its management and supervisory employees and provide training to its managers and supervisors that explains the damaging effects of race discrimination and retaliation.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay a total of $84,000 in disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to final approval by the court.

gold_sents: This class action suit was filed on January 12, 2006, under 38 U.S.C. § 4301, et seq. ("USERRA") in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff class consisted of all past and present pilots of American Airlines who are or were members of the United States Armed Services and who took military leave from January 2001 to 2006.[SENTMARKER]They asked the court for injunctive and declaratory relief, alleging that American Airlines had violated USERRA by discriminating against pilots who took military leaves of absence.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that they were unfairly charged fewer "in service" days which prevented them from bidding on a number of benefits including flight schedules, paid vacation time, and earned sick leave.[SENTMARKER]Pilots who had taken comparable types of non-military leave were not similarly penalized.[SENTMARKER]After filing two amended complaints, and the court denying the defendants' second motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs motion to certify class, preliminarily approve settlement agreement, and approve forms of class notice.[SENTMARKER]This motion was granted by U.S. District Court Judge Barbara M.G.[SENTMARKER]Lynn in a final order on August 1, 2008.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 28, 2008, three former American Airlines pilots filed a class action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the Northern District Of Texas against American Airlines, Inc. and the Allied pilots Association.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that American had violated the employment rights of its pilots by denying them the ability to bid on flight schedules based on their seniority status and to earn other employment benefits, including paid vacation time and earned sick leave.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and granted their motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to further court approval.

gold_sents: On August 22, 2003, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ("EEOC"), on behalf of a female employee, filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District Court of Washington, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended by Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, against Huntwood Industries, Inc.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive relief, compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and other forms of affirmative relief claiming that the defendant subjected the plaintiff-intervenor to a sexually hostile work environment because of her sex, female, resulting in her constructive discharge.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2004, the District Court (Judge Frederick Van Sickle) entered a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the complainant $100,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 20, 2003, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Washington against T R A Industries, Inc., a Spokane-based manufacturer of custom cabinets.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by subjecting a female employee to a sexually hostile work environment because of her sex, resulting in her constructive discharge.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendant agreed to implement a series of corrective and preventive measures to further the objectives of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendant to develop and present to all employees a manual specifically addressing employment discrimination and sexual harassment, to provide equal employment opportunities for all 25 employees, and to implement anti-discrimination and anti-sexual harassment policies, procedures, and training for employees, supervisors, and management personnel to the extent not already established.[SENTMARKER]As part of the consent decree, the defendant also agreed to pay $100,000 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendant on July 21, 2006, and the parties agreed to settle the case on December 31, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment, and the case was closed.

gold_sents: In March 2002, the Seattle District Office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued Laidlaw Inc., a school bus company, in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington for alleged violations of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complainant intervened in May 2002, alleging that the defendant violated the Washington Law Against Discrimination and state tort law by discriminating against her on the basis of sex.[SENTMARKER]The defendant moved for summary judgment, which was granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The case went to trial in June 2003.[SENTMARKER]The court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs on their federal and state law claims and in favor of the defendant with regard to punitive and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court awarded $3,029.78 in economic damages and $30,000 in non-economic damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties appealed in September 2004, but the appeals were dismissed in October 2004.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington in May 2002 against Laidlaw Transit, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Laidlaw Education Services Corp., alleging that Laidlaw violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Washington Law of 1991 by subjecting female employees to disparate treatment on the basis of their sex.[SENTMARKER]The parties stipulated to the dismissal of these appeals with prejudice, and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On April 1, 2004, the jury awarded plaintiff $3,029.78 in economic damages and $30,000 in non-economic damages with costs and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In June 2006, the EEOC filed suit in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin against the restaurant chain International House of Pancakes (IHOP), its former president, and another company that together with IHOP operated restaurants throughout Illinois and Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sued under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e) and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 (42 U.S.C. § 1981a) on behalf of two female employees and similarly situated employees of the Defendants.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the EEOC alleged that the Defendants engaged in unlawful employment practices on the basis of sex and retaliation, and that they had subjected female employees to a sexually hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]In 2009, the jury held for the EEOC.[SENTMARKER]In 2012, the parties settled, and the Court approved a Consent Decree/Settlement Agreement (lasting 2 years) that awarded monetary damages to two female claimants and promised injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 27, 2007, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin on behalf of two female servers employed at an International House of Pancakes (IHOP) franchise in Racine, Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the servers were sexually harassed in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 when an assistant manager at the IHOP restaurant subjected them to a sexually hostile working environment based on their gender.[SENTMARKER]The defendants, Management Hospitality of Racine, Inc. d/b/a IHOP, and Salauddin Janmohammed, were found to have violated Title VII when they required all of their new employees to watch a video educating them on sexual harassment in the workplace, and to sign their sexual harassment policy.[SENTMARKER]The jury found in favor of the two servers on the hostile work environment claim, and the defendants agreed to pay $50,000 in damages to one of the servers.[SENTMARKER]In addition, Flipmeastack was ordered to create a new sexual harassment training program for all employees under its direct or indirect supervision that emphasizes the responsibility of supervisors to prevent and correct promptly and sexually harassing behavior and to post, at all restaurants, a toll-free number for harassment and discrimination complaints by employees and a written anti-harassment and anti-discrimination policy.

gold_sents: Five non-profit organizations focused on environmental justice filed this lawsuit against the Environmental Protection Agency for failing to issue preliminary findings in Title VI complaints.[SENTMARKER]Judge Armstrong granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss with regard to each individual claim addressing a specific complaint in which the EPA failed to issue preliminary findings.[SENTMARKER]Judge Armstrong granted the defendant's motion to dismiss with regard to the claim that the EPA's pattern and practice of failing to issue preliminary findings violated the APA.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered settlement talks which have, as of October 2019, been unsuccessful, and the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 7, 2016, the Sierra Club, a nonprofit community organization, and the San Francisco Bay Area Air Quality Management District filed a suit against the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) alleging that the EPA violated Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by permitting an oil-refinery expansion in a low-income and African American community in Beaumont, gold_sents: This case was filed by the American Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts on May 16, 2005 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff claimed that the department's provision of more than a million dollars of public funds to a ministry called "The Silver Ring Thing" (SRT) that uses federal abstinence education funding to bring "unchurched" students to Jesus Christ constituted an unlawful establishment of religion and a governmental endorsement and preference for religion in general and specific tenets of the ministry in particular.[SENTMARKER]The ministry developed a three hour presentation that was meant to occur directly following a mandatory abstinence education assembly in public schools and which, according to the plaintiff, was "permeated with religion."[SENTMARKER]In a two-year settlement agreement entered on February 22, 2006, the defendants acknowleged that they had terminated the SRT grant effective January 31, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The agreement provided that defendants would not fund SRT's abstinence eduction as it had been structured and implemented during the fiscal year 2005, that strict requirements would be made before considering funding any future proposals from SRT, and that extensive monitoring of SRT's activities would occur if SRT was given a grant.

gold_sents: In 2012, evangelical Christian business owners filed a RFRA challenge to rules adopted pursuant to the 2010 Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, arguing that the rules infringed on their religious freedom by requiring them to provide coverage for emergency contraception through their group health insurance plan.[SENTMARKER]In November 2012, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the contraception mandate did not substantially burden the plaintiffs' religious freedom.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit granted expedited en banc review, and oral arguments occurred on May 23.[SENTMARKER]On June 27, 2013, the 10th Circuit reversed the District Court's injunction denial and sent the case back to the District Court, with instructions to consider two prongs of the injunction inquiry and to rule on the plaintiffs' injunction motion.[SENTMARKER]The next day, the District Court granted the plaintiffs' emergency motion for a temporary injunction pending the full injunction hearing.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted cert., and on June 30, 2014, affirmed the 10th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Court said other ways were open to the government to reach its asserted interest of ensuring the availability of contraception coverage.
