pegasus_output_sents: On September 12, 2012, Hobby Lobby and Mardel, two Oklahoma businesses, filed this suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Attorney's Office in the Western district of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the regulations issued under the Patient Protection Act of 2010 violated their First Amendment rights and their rights under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 (RFRA) and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on the basis of RFRA and the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment, and the district court denied their motion for an injunction pending resolution of the appeal.[SENTMARKER]On October 1, 2013, the plaintiffs filed an appeal to the Tenth Circuit and the court granted them a temporary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The court stayed all district court proceedings until the appeals process was complete.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2013, a group of religious-based universities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Western District of Oklahoma under the First Amendment, Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause, Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the Administrative Procedure Act against federal government.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged the Affordable Care Act's requirement that employee and student health plans provide coverage of contraception violated their religious foundings.[SENTMARKER]On November 6, 2015, the Supreme Court granted certiorari on the question of whether the accommodation to the contraceptive services mandate as applied to religious nonprofits violates the RFRA.[SENTMARKER]This case was consolidated with six others.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court issued a per curiam order remanding all seven cases to their respective courts of appeals, and ordered that the parties be given time to come to agreement on ensuring contraceptive access without burdening religious freedom.[SENTMARKER]Following revised HHS policies, the District Court permanently enjoined the defendants from forcing religious organizations to provide contraceptive care.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed
pegasus_output_sents: Oklahoma Baptist University, Oklahoma Wesleyan University, and Southern Nazarene University filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) under the 2010 Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs object to the mandate that requires their health insurance plans to provide free coverage of certain contraceptive services, including so-called emergency contraceptives (ECs) that cause early abortions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argue that the mandate chills their religious exercise, burdens their religious rights, and violates the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA).[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the district court's decision, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2013, Bishop Zubik, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Pittsburg and the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Pittsburg filed a U.S. District Court lawsuit in the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Federal Government challenging the the contraception mandate of the Affordable Care Act. After the Trump Administration took office, the parties settled and dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2010, Congress enacted the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, Pub L No. 111-148, 124 Stat.[SENTMARKER]1029 (the "Act" or "Obamacare"), which requires employers with religious objections to cover certain contraceptive services in their employee health insurance plans.[SENTMARKER]On May 21, 2012, Catholic Charities and the Catholic Diocese of Pittsburgh filed this suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the western district of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Act violated their rights of religious conscience under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1993 ("RFRA") and the First Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, converted the preliminary injunction to a permanent injunction, and granted the government's motion to dismiss for lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the government agreed to pay the plaintiffs $3 million in costs and fees.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

gold_sents: On November 22, 2013, a group of nonprofit religious organizations filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, the Administrative Procedure Act and the First Amendment against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]On December 26, 2013, United States District Court (Judge Todd J. Campbell) denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The same day, the plaintiff filed an appeal with the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 6th Circuit (No. 13-6640).[SENTMARKER]On June 11, 2013, the 6th Circuit affirmed, holding that the ACA did not unlawfully burden the plaintiffs' religion.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded back to the 6th Circuit in light of a Supreme Court case Zubik v. Burwell.[SENTMARKER]Following the Zubik decision, the Departments of Health and Human Services, Labor, and Treasury adopted new rules on October 6, 2017 that allowed for religious and moral objections to providing contraceptives under the ACA.[SENTMARKER]As a result, on January 28, 2018 the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 12, 2012, Catholic Charities of Tennessee, Camp Marymount, Inc., St. Cecilia Congregation, and Aquinas College filed suit in the United States District Court for the Middle District, Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Affordable Care Act's contraceptive coverage requirement violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, the Free Speech, Free Exercise, and Establishment Clauses of the First Amendment, and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The district courts denied the plaintiffs' motions for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded back to the district courts for further consideration in light of the Supreme Court's Hobby Lobby decision in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted the defendants' petition for a writ of certiorari, vacated the district court's judgment, and remanded the case back to us.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2012, Criswell College, an evangelical Protestant college located in Dallas, filed a lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas against the Federal Government seeking to enjoin enforcement of provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) extending universal contraception coverage in employer-sponsored private health insurance coverage.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs contend that this mandatory contraception coverage violates their sincerely held religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2013, the case was dismissed for lack of jurisdiction because it was not ripe for review.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2010, The Criswell College, a Texas non-profit corporation, filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, alleging that the Affordable Care Act of 2010 (ACA) violated its First and Fifth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) by requiring the college to provide health insurance coverage for abortion, abortifacients, embryo-harming pharmaceuticals, and related education and counseling, or providing plans that cause access to the same through its insurance company.[SENTMARKER]On March 30, 2010, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on April 9, 2013 without prejudice.

gold_sents: The lawsuit was based on fair housing testing that DOJ had conducted between July 2008 and January 2009, in which rental agents made a series of racialized remarks, steering white testers away from certain locations, and implying that black applicants were more likely to fail criminal background checks.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2009, the United States Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama under the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. §3601, against operators of the Rolling Oaks Apartments, seeking injunctive and monetary relief for race discrimination.[SENTMARKER]After the court (Judge Mark Fuller) denied cross-motions for summary judgment, the matter settled.[SENTMARKER]In February 2011, the Court entered a four-year consent decree enjoining the Defendants from discriminating on the basis of race in the operation of the Rolling Oaks Apartments and ordering  $15,500 in civil penalties.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2009, the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Alabama entered a consent decree in the Fair Housing Act case brought by the Department of Justice against the owner and manager of a residential apartment complex in Clanton, Alabama.[SENTMARKER]According to the consent decree, the defendants had engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race or color in the rental of dwelling units at Rolling Oaks Apartments.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree requires the defendants to provide and process rental applications on a non-discriminatory basis and to maintain all rental applications, whether deemed complete or incomplete, and any correspondence about the availability of dwellings at the apartment complex.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also have to post an easily readable "For Rent" or "Vacancy" sign or notice at each apartment building in which the dwelling unit is available.[SENTMARKER]In addition, each defendant must hold an in-person training for all new Management Agents.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed that the defendants will not discriminate against qualified applicants or tenants because of race, color, or any other factor.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice at the end of the four-year period.

gold_sents: On September 30, 2009 the United States Department of Justice filed a lawsuit against First United Security Bank under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. claimed that the Bank had engaged in a pattern or practice of home-mortgage lending discrimination against black applicants.[SENTMARKER]On November 18, 2009 an agreement was entered that required the Bank to change several of its practices and to pay monetary damages to some African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the agreement were satisfied and the case dismissed in April 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Alabama filed a lawsuit in federal court in Birmingham, Alabama against First United Security Bank for violating the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the bank charged African-American borrowers higher rates than similarly-situated white borrowers on home mortgage-related loans.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the bank failed to serve the lending needs of majority African-Americans in west central Alabama on an equal basis with majority-white tracts.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into an amended settlement agreement in June 2014 that requires the bank to post and display in each branch or ofilce a notice of non-discrimination in the setting of interest rates for first-lien refinance loans originated in 2004 for owner-occupied one-to-four family houses.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the Bank is prohibited from discriminating on the basis of race or color in any aspect of a residential real estate-related or credit transaction.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the amended agreement are subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In November 2011, two undocumented Mexican immigrants and three fair housing groups filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Alabama against the State of Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that a state statute violated the Fair Housing Act and was preempted by federal immigration law because it required mobile home owners to pay for a government-issued registration while prohibiting undocumented residents from making payments to government officials.[SENTMARKER]Because the law made it illegal to possess a mobile home without registration and because it was illegal for undocumented residents to obtain the registration, the law effectively made such persons homeless.[SENTMARKER]The District Court (Judge Myron H. Thompson) enjoined the State from enforcing the law.[SENTMARKER]The State appealed, but the Eleventh Circuit rendered it moot because in May 2012 the Alabama legislature amended the statute to exclude mobile home registration.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the case in May 2014, upon stipulation of the parties.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 18, 2011, the plaintiffs filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama against the state of Alabama and the revenue commissioner for the state.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the federal Fair Housing Act and the Supremacy Clause and Due Process Clause of the United States Constitution by enforcing Section 30 of the Beason-Hammon Alabama Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act (HB 56), which prohibits the plaintiffs from paying an annual registration fee and to obtain and prominently display a current manufactured home identification decal.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, with the order set to expire on December 7, 2011 at 4:30 p.m. ET.[SENTMARKER]On December 12, 2011, the defendants filed a motion to dissolve the order, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, pending further discovery and final presentation of evidence.

gold_sents: This case resulted in the largest residential fair lending settlement in U.S. history, with $335 million being paid to compensate African-American and Hispanic borrowers who were allegedly charged more based on their race or national origin.
pegasus_output_sents: The Department of Justice today announced that Countrywide Home Loans, Inc., a U.S.-based mortgage lender, has agreed to pay more than $500,000 to African-American and Hispanic mortgage borrowers who were steered into subprime loans and placed into prime loans based on their race or national origin.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval and is the first time that the Justice Department has alleged and obtained relief for these borrowers under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act. According to the complaint, from 2004 to 2008, Countrywide discriminated by charging more than 200,000 African-qualified and Hispanic borrowers higher fees and interest rates than non-Hispanic white borrowers in both retail and wholesale lending.[SENTMARKER]The complaint further alleges that as a result of Countrywide's policies and practices, qualified African-Americans and Hispanics were placed in subprime loans rather than prime loans, even when similarly-qualified non- Hispanic white borrowers received prime loans.[SENTMARKER]Countrywide also allowed its employees to alter the standard fees it charged in connection with processing a loan application and the standard allocation of closing costs between Countrywide and the borrower.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, Countrywide will be required to collect, maintain, and report data with respect to certain loan terms and borrower information for residential loans, including the race and national origin of each retail home loan borrower, pursuant to the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA).[SENTMARKER]The settlement also requires Countrywide to implement policies and procedures to prevent discrimination if it returns to the lending business during the next four years.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the complaint alleges that the mortgage lender violated the federal housing law by encouraging non-applicant spouses of mortgage loan applicants to sign away their home ownership rights by encouraging them to leave their homes.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco and the Federal Housing Authority.

gold_sents: On September 26, 2013, the United States of America filed a lawsuit in the Southern District of California against Plaza Home Mortgage, Inc., under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African American and Hispanic borrowers because of race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]On December 1, 2013, the District Court entered a consent order that prohibited the defendant from discriminating on the basis of race or national origin and required the defendant to  place $3 million into a settlement fund.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2016 after the defendant had substantially complied with the consent order.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 26, 2013, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California entered a consent order against Plaza Home Mortgage, Inc., a San Diego-based mortgage lender, for violating the Fair Housing Act, the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, and the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act. According to the consent order, from 2006 through at least 2010, Plaza discriminated against African-American and Hispanic borrowers by allowing its wholesale mortgage brokers to charge higher broker fees for residential real estate-related loans than non-Hispanic white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The consent order requires Plaza to implement specific, race- and national origin-neutral standards for the assess ment of broker fees on residential real- 19 estate related loans that Plaza underwrote, and to post a notice of these standards in each location where applications for the loans are accepted.[SENTMARKER]In addition, since 2010, Plaza has hired a nationally recognized civil rights law firm to help implement and manage its compliance program, and retained the services of a national non-profit fair housing organization to review Plaza’s policies and implement initiatives designed to prevent discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of Plaza on December 29, 2016, and the case was dismissed without prejudice.

gold_sents: On May 30, 2014, the City of Los Angeles  filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against JP Morgan Chase Bank, under Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA) and Fair Housing Act/Fair Housing Amendments Act (FHAA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought damages, declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that the defendants lending practices were predatory and intentionally discriminated against minority borrowers, and had a disparate impact on minorities.[SENTMARKER]On August 6, 2015, the plaintiff field an ex parte application to stay the case pending appeal of related action.[SENTMARKER]On September 2, 2015, the case was dismissed as stipulated.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2012, the City of Los Angeles filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against JPMorgan Chase Co., JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., Chase Manhattan Bank USA, and Wells Fargo 4 Co. alleging that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act by denying credit to certain neighborhoods based on race, color, or national origin in their 27 residential real estate-related lending transactions.[SENTMARKER]The defendants collectively are referred to as "JPMorgan" in the suit.[SENTMARKER]The City's damages include lost tax revenues and the need to provide 21 increased municipal services.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed in 2012 to a global settlement with the Department of Justice, HUD, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and the 25 state attorneys general.[SENTMARKER]The terms and conditions of the settlement were not disclosed in this suit.

gold_sents: This sex discrimination fair housing case was brought by the United States in 2010 in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Iowa against the owners of an apartment complex and their manager, alleging sexual harassment by the manager of two female tenants.[SENTMARKER]The women claimed they were subjected to offers of maintenance services in return for sex, pervasive, unwanted touching, gestures and remarks.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff claimed these actions constituted a pattern and practice of sexual discrimination in violation of the Fair Housing Act.[SENTMARKER]Though the owners had gone out of business during the course of the litigation, they entered into a five-year Consent Decree that included detailed prohibitions against sex discrimination, should they ever again engage in the business.[SENTMARKER]The manager was forever banned from any job involved in any aspect of the operation of any dwelling.[SENTMARKER]Defendants agreed to pay $80,000 in compensatory damages to aggrieved persons identified by Plaintiff and $15,000 in civil penalties.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 2011, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Iowa entered a consent order in a case brought by the United States Department of Justice under the Fair Housing Act of 1968 (the "Fair Housing Act") against property management company Elders, Inc. and property manager J.8 Property Management, L.C.[SENTMARKER]The consent order required the defendants to adopt a nondiscrimination policy and to provide residents of Park Towers Apartments in Waterloo, Iowa with a written Nondiscrimination Policy and a copy of the HUD booklet, Fair Housing; Equ.al Opportunity for A ll.[SENTMARKER]According to the consent order, the defendants failed to comply with the terms of the consent by failing to provide the residents of the apartment complex with an adequate notice of their nondiscrimination policies and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also failed to provide sufficient notice to the residents that they would be making changes to their policies.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants on September 22, 2011 and the case was dismissed with prejudice five years later.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2008, minority homeowners on behalf of similarly situated minority homeowners filed a class-action complaint in U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against H&R Block Inc., H&R Block Bank and its wholly-owned subsidiary,under the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1691, et seq. ("ECOA") and the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. § 3601 et seq.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants maintained a pattern or practice that had a discriminatory impact on minority applicants in their home financing policies and practices.[SENTMARKER]On August 21, 2013, the plaintiffs filed a stipulation to dismiss the case with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 7, 2013, a group of African-American homeowners brought suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts on behalf of themselves and similarly situated homeowners who obtained a mortgage loan from one of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Equal credit Opportunity Act, the Fair housing Act, and the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act by giving mortgage brokers discretion to increase the credit rate above the rate otherwise available to the homeowner.[SENTMARKER]Although the policy was neutral, the policy had an adverse effect on African-Americans in that they paid higher discretionary charges on their home loans than did similarly situated white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, granted their motion for declaratory and injunctive relief, and entered a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have entered into a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: The defendant to this 2008 family-status discrimination lawsuit brought by the United States in the District of Nebraska, was a condominium association whose "Amended Master Deed and Declaration" stated that no unit should be "sold or leased to a person who has a child under the age of 16 who will occupy or reside in the unit 180 days or more a year."[SENTMARKER]The suit's complainants alleged that this clause posed an obstacle to their intended sale of their condo units.[SENTMARKER]After discovery, the parties entered mediation, and on March 3, 2010, District Judge Warren K. Urbom approved a three-year consent decree.[SENTMARKER]In addition to a general prohibition against discrimination in the sale or rental of the condominium units, the decree required the defendants to develop and post a non-discrimination policy and to amend the master deed to excise  the prohibition against families with children.[SENTMARKER]Defendants agreed to pay $77,500 to the complainants, an additional $35,000 to other aggrieved parties, and a $15,000 civil penalty to the United States.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 29, 2008, the United States brought this civil rights action in the District of Nebraska against The Latvian Tower Condominium Association, Inc. ("LTCA") and its president, Karl Tegtmeyer.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Fair Housing Act, Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1988, 42 U. S.C.  3601 et seq. ("the Act"), and Section 814(a) of the Fair housing Act. According to the complaint, the defendants and their officers, employees, agents, successors, and all other persons in active concert or participation with any of them discriminated against prospective buyers because of the familial status of the potential buyers.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the allegations in any manner.[SENTMARKER]On November 12, 2009, the court entered a consent order in which the defendants agreed not to discriminate in any aspect of the sale of dwellings because of familial status and to post a fair housing sign in all common areas of the condominium complex.[SENTMARKER]The consent order is effective immediately upon the entry of the consent order and will remain in effect for three years.[SENTMARKER]The United States is seeking injunctive relief, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains, and civil penalties.

gold_sents: An association of residents of a New Jersey neighborhood filled a lawsuit claiming that the defendants' redevelopment plan for the Gardens neighborhood represented a violation of the Fair Housing Act and the United States and New Jersey Constitutions.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that the defendants' redevelopment plan, which razed numerous homes in a minority neighborhood, was discriminatory.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed the District Court's pretrial decision in favor of the town to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, which reversed, and found that the plaintiffs were entitled to a trial.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted certiorari to review the question whether disparate impact claims were available under the Fair Housing Act.  About two weeks prior to the scheduled argument, the parties settled; the city will construct 44 new homes, 20 for current residents in exchange for allowing redevelopment.[SENTMARKER]Seven households that elected to relocate will be compensated.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2005, a group of residents of the Mount Holly Gardens neighborhood of Mount Holly, New Jersey, filed a lawsuit against the Township of Solebury alleging that the Township's redevelopment of the neighborhood violated the Fair Housing Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that, among other things, the Township denied them a building permit.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' prerogative writ claims without prejudice as unripe.[SENTMARKER]On May 5, 2005, the district court granted summary judgment in favor of the Township.[SENTMARKER]The case was then appealed to the Third Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Third Circuit reversed the District Court's grant of summary judgment, finding that the plaintiffs had established a prima facie case of disparate impact sufficient to withstand summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement and the case was closed.

gold_sents: Low-income minority individuals in need of affordable housing filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1871, 42 U.S.C. § 1983, and the Civil Rights Act of 1964 against the Town of Smithtown, complaining that  Smithtown operated its voucher program with a residency preference that discriminated on the basis of race, color, and national origin.[SENTMARKER]The court entered an order and final judgment approving the parties' settlement agreement under which the Town of Smithtown agreed to implement an anti-discrimination educational program, to affirmatively market the Section 8 Program to minority persons, to inform the public of its non-discriminatory policies, to maintain and preserve records for purposes of recordkeeping and reporting, and to pay $925,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]This settlement remains in effect until 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 13, 2007, a group of African-American and Hispanic residents of Smithtown, New York filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court in the Central District of the New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Smithtown's use of a residency preference for allocation of Section 8 vouchers in violation of the Fair Housing Act and other civil rights laws.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which Smithtown agreed to implement a series of measures to ensure that minority residents were not denied access to Section 8 housing assistance.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required Smithtown to: (1) provide training to all of its current employees and agents involved in the Section 8 Voucher Program; .[SENTMARKER](2) make changes to its policies, operation, methods, and procedures governing the Program; and (3) advertise the Program in a manner that is less likely to be read by potential minority applicants.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement were not disclosed.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice as to Smithtown without costs.

gold_sents: On December 06, 2010, the United States filed suit under 42 U.S.C. 3601 of the Fair Housing Act against the owner of the Burgundy Gardens Apartments, LLC in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York (Judge Kenneth Karas).[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff, represented by the Untied States Department of Justice asked the Court to 1) declare the Defendant's conduct a violation of the Fair Housing Act, 2) enjoin the Defendant from discriminating on the basis of race in the rental of dwellings, 3) award monetary damages and 4) assess a civil penalty.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the Plaintiff claims the Defendant's rental practices discriminated against African American prospective tenants.[SENTMARKER]On April 4,2012, the parties reached a settlement.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant was enjoined from further discriminatory rental practices on the basis of rate, and paid $150,000 in damages and $25,000 as a civil penalty.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 5, 2010, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York filed a lawsuit against Burgundy Gardens Apartments, LLC, d/b/a Burgundy Gardens, alleging that Burgundy Gardens discriminated against African Americans who were seeking rental housing because of race or color.[SENTMARKER]Burgundy Gardens agreed to pay $150,000 into a victim fund that will be available to compensate people who were harmed by the discriminatory rental practices of BURGUNDYS, and to pay a civil penalty of $25,000.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree on April 16, 2012 (the "Consent Decree"), which enjoined Burgundy Gardens from discriminating in any aspect of the rental of dwellings against qualified applicants or tenants because of color or race.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required Burgundy Gardens to educate its employees on federal and state housing discrimination laws, and submit periodic reports to the Government containing information about its rental activity.[SENTMARKER]Under the consent decree, Burgundy Gardens also agreed to distribute a nondiscrimination policy to all of its current tenants, employees, agents, and anyone acting under the direction of Burgundy Gardens.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction for the duration of the Consent Decree, after which time the case shall be dismissed with prejudice.

gold_sents: The United States filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing Act against architects and developers of an apartment building claiming that the defendants designed and constructed the building so that it was inaccessible to persons with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff entered into two separate three-year consent decrees; one requiring the architect to make all of its future designs compliant with the FHA and to pay a $20,000 civil penalty; the other with the developers requiring extensive retrofits to the building, $60,000 in damages and a $35,000 civil penalty.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 14, 2011, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York entered a consent decree in a case brought by the United States under the Fair Housing Act, Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968 (the "Fair Housing Act" or the "Act") against the developers and architect of The Larkspur, a residential apartment complex in Manhattan.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Deborah A. Batts on October 5, 2011 in the amount of $35,000.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered the consent decree to ensure that the apartment complex would be accessible to persons with disabilities and that the defendants would not discriminate in the design, construction, or sale of the apartment units.[SENTMARKER]As part of the consent Decree, the defendants agreed to pay a total of $35,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed not to discriminate in any way in the development or construction of any new apartment units that they may develop or construct.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed to provide the plaintiffs with a copy of a notice of their nondiscrimination policies and procedures, as well as a statement that the dwelling units include features required by the Act.

gold_sents: On April 12, 2012, the United States sued GFI Mortgage Bankers under the Fair Housing Act and Equal Credit Opportunity Act for charging African American and Hispanic borrowers higher fees and costs for home mortgage loans than it charged similarly situated white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a Consent Decree on August 27, 2012, which required GFI to pay $3.555 million and implement fair lending policies and a fair lending monitoring system.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 2, 2012, the Department of Justice and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York filed a lawsuit in federal court in Manhattan against GFI Mortgage Bankers, Inc., a New York-based mortgage banker, alleging that GFI engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination by charging African-American and Hispanic borrowers higher interest rates and fees on home mortgage loans because of their race or national origin, not based on their creditworthiness.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, from 2005 through at least 2009, GFI charged higher fees and interest rates to African-Americans than to similarly-situated non-Hispanic white borrowers because of GFI's home-loan pricing policy.[SENTMARKER]The complaint further alleges that the disparities were statistically significant between Hispanic and white borrowers in the cost of home loans.[SENTMARKER]GFI settled the case in 2012 and agreed to implement a fair lending program that requires its employees and agents to explain the benefits and consequences of each loan product to an applicant's selection of a loan product and to ensure compliance with the Fair Housing Act, the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, and the Fair Lending Act.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 2014, a non-profit organization that provides housing assistance to formerly incarcerated individuals filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for Eastern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant, who owned and managed a multi-building apartment complex, had a discriminatory policy that unlawfully prohibited anyone with a criminal record from renting an apartment.[SENTMARKER]After years of discovery and litigation, the parties settled for over $1 million.
pegasus_output_sents: The Fortune Society filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York in October 2014 against Sandcastle Towers Housing Development Fund Corporation (HDFC), Sarasota Gold LLC, E M Associates LLC, and Weissman Realty Group LLC (Weissman) pursuant to the Fair Housing Act of 1968 and New York City Human Rights Law  1367.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that HDFC, Sarasota Gold, and E M had engaged in a pattern or practice of discrimination on the basis of race and color at The Sand Castle, a multi-building apartment complex they own and manage in Queens, New York.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants' policy of categorically excluding applicants who have felony or non-traffic misdemeanor convictions from tenancy, which causes an unjustified disparate impact on African-American and Hispanic applicants in violation of FHA, was consistent with a policy of limiting the number of new minority tenants in the building.[SENTMARKER]After discovery, both parties moved for summary judgment on this disparate impact claim, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 12, 2005, individual New York residents and the New York ACORN local chapter filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Easter District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Nassau County and the Village of Garden City under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs asked the court to enjoin the defendants from proceeding with discriminatory zoning practices; to order Garden City to approve a proposed zoning that would allow for affordable housing; and to order the defendants to take all actions necessary to assure that the Social Service Site be redeveloped to maximize the availability of affordable and integrated housing.[SENTMARKER]On February 15, 2012, Judge Arthur D. Spatt granted defendant County's motion for summary judgment dismissing all claims against it.[SENTMARKER]On April 22, 2014, Judge Spatt issued a final order for the plaintiffs and ordered Defendant Garden City to take a number of steps to prevent discrimination and to increase access to affordable housing.[SENTMARKER]After Judge Spatt's order, both parties appealed the decision.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit affirmed in part and remanded in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is back in the lower courts on remand.[SENTMARKER]On remand, Judge Spatt found that the plaintiffs had met their burden at trial in demonstrating that the Garden City’s proffered reasons for its chosen zoning change could have been met by another practice, such as R-M zoning, that had a less discriminatory effect.[SENTMARKER]Magistrate Judge Arlene R. Lindsay thereafter awarded plaintiffs $5,255,108.94 in attorneys fees and costs from Garden City.[SENTMARKER]On March 15, 2019, Judge Spatt signed the parties’ stipulation of discontinuance with prejudice, except without prejudice as to the court’s jurisdiction for the purpose of interpretation or enforcement of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the County to pay $5,400,000 to the plaintiffs to be used for the purpose of furthering and promoting mixed-income affordable housing; $120,000 to NYCC to be used for activities related to fair and affordable housing; and $400,000 to plaintiffs’ counsel for attorneys’ fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2005, a non-profit housing developer filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York alleging that the Village of Garden City and its Board of Trustees violated the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, MHANY Management, Inc., and the New York Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now (NY ACORN), alleged that the defendants violated the fair housing law by changing the zoning of a certain area of the village in violation of the law.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for summary judgment, which was granted on February 12, 2012, and the case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motions to dismiss in their entirety.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2016, the Second Circuit affirmed, in part, the final judgment, and remanded the case to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed an appeal.[SENTMARKER]The appeal was denied on October 2, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to a settlement.

gold_sents: This 2011 federal fair lending lawsuit in the Western District of Texas was brought by the United States against a local bank the U.S. alleged had engaged in a pattern or practice of providing loans to Hispanics only at higher rates than to non-Hispanics, without justification.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement, submitted simultaneously with the complaint, the bank agreed to develop and establish uniform pricing policies and procedures designed to ensure nondiscriminatory pricing, and to numerous other implementation provisions, including fair credit training, systemic monitoring, complaint resolution processes, and $91,000 in damages to aggrieved persons.[SENTMARKER]The provisions of the order were scheduled to last 4 and 1/4 years.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2009, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Western District of Texas filed this suit against Nixon State Bank, a Texas-based bank, alleging that the bank discriminated against Hispanic borrowers by charging higher interest rates on unsecured consumer loans than non-Hispanic borrowers.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, from at least 2006 through December 2009, the bank charged higher rates of interest to Hispanic borrowers compared to non- Hispanic borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that prior to 2010, the bank did not properly instruct its loan officers regarding their obligation to treat prospective customers without regard to national origin, and the bank failed to supervise or monitor the loan officers effectively to ensure compliance with fair lending laws.[SENTMARKER]As a result of the alleged violations of ECOA, the court entered an order requiring the bank to pay $91,600 to compensate Hispanic borrowers for monetary damages that affected persons may have suffered from the alleged discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The order also requires the bank's employees who originate loans covered by the order to provide a notice of non-discrimination to its management officials, loan officers, and any other employees or agents who participate in the origination of the loans.[SENTMARKER]The bank has also agreed to implement a complaint resolution program to address consumer complaints alleging discrimination regarding loans originated by Nixon.

gold_sents: The United States Department of Justice filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing and Equal Credit Opportunity Acts against PrimeLending, claiming that the defendant displayed a pattern or practice of discrimination in lending on the basis of race against African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order in which Primelending agreed to refrain from practicing race based discrimination, submit to a monitoring and reporting program, provide borrowers with a general notice of nondiscrimination, provide equal credit opportunity training to its employees, provide a total of $2 million to be distributed among those aggrieved,  allocate any unclaimed portion of the $2 million to organizations that provide general financial education to African-American borrowers, and maintain a complaint resolution program to resolve discrimination claims.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Texas brought this suit against Prime Lending, Inc., a mortgage lender, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African-American borrowers in the terms and conditions of residential real estate-related transactions.[SENTMARKER]The defendant agreed to pay $22,000 to the plaintiff, the Urban League of Greater Dallas, and to implement a complaint resolution program to address consumer complaints alleging discrimination regarding loans secured by residential real property originated by the Defendant.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to final approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on October 1, 2011.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2013,  the U.S. Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against Fort Davis State Bank, alleging that it charged Hispanic borrowers higher interest rates on unsecured consumer loans compared to the rates it charged white borrowers, in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]In January 2014, the District Court (Judge Robert A. Junell) approved a consent order in which the bank agreed to implement a variety of practices to address these alleged violations and to pay damages to aggrieved borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The consent order remained in effect until early 2017.[SENTMARKER]Since there has been no substantive docket activity after 2014, the case is presumably closed.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA) prohibits financial institutions from discriminating on the basis of national origin in their lending practices.[SENTMARKER]Fort Davis State Bank (FDSB) charged Hispanic borrowers higher interest rates on unsecured consumer loans compared to the rates charged to similarly situated non-Hispanic white borrowers from January 1, 2008 to December 31, 2010.[SENTMARKER]FDSB did not properly instruct its loan officers regarding their obligation to treat prospective customers without regard to national origin, and the Bank has failed to supervise or monitor the performance of its Loan Officers to ensure compliance with fair lending laws.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2011, the FDIC filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against FDSB.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that FDSB discriminated against Hispanic borrowers by charging higher rates of interest on unsecured loans to Hispanic borrowers than to similar-sized white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]On December 31, 2010, the court entered a consent order that required FDSB to pay $159,000 in monetary damages and to implement a complaint resolution program to address consumer complaints alleging discrimination.[SENTMARKER]In addition, FDSB was required to provide a notice of non-discrimination to its employees who originate loans covered by this consent order.[SENTMARKER]The consent order is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On September 26, 2013, the United States of America filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District of Wisconsin against Southport Bank, under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice, sought a declaratory judgment, injunctive relief, compensatory damages to all of the victims of the defendant's discriminatory policies, and a civil penalty, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African American and Hispanic borrowers because of race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]On October 11, 2013, the District Court (Judge Joseph Peter Stadtmueller) entered a consent order between the parties.[SENTMARKER]The defendant did not admit to any pattern or practice of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The order enjoined the defendant from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race or national origin in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction in violation of the Fair Housing Act or any credit transaction in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.  Among other things, the defendant's employees will have to participate in a fair lending training program and will be subject to monitoring and reporting requirements.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also has to place $687,000 into a settlement fund to compensate for monetary damages that aggrieved persons may have suffered.[SENTMARKER]The order terminates after three years if the defendant has complied during that time period.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Wisconsin filed this complaint against Southport Bank of Kenosha, Wisconsin, alleging that the bank discriminated against African-American and Hispanic borrowers in its residential mortgage lending by charging them higher fees than non-Hispanic white borrowers because of their race and national origin.[SENTMARKER]The complaint, filed on October 11, 2013, alleged that from 2007 to 2008, Southport charged hundreds of African-Americans and Hispanic wholesale borrowers higher fees in violation of the Fair Housing Act, the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, and the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act. According to the complaint, Southport's business practice was to allow its mortgage brokers to vary their fees and thus alter the price set based on a borrower's objective credit-related factors.[SENTMARKER]In 2008, the complaint alleged that, in addition to charging higher fees, Southport did not conduct any type of broker monitoring to determine whether there were disparities between the total fees charged to minority and white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]On October 10, 2013, the court entered an order enjoining Southport from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race or national origin in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the bank to pay a civil penalty of $225,000.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Following an investigation by the United States Department of Justice, the U.S. filed this lawsuit against the State of Connecticut, its Department of Mental Retardation, and the Director of Southbury Training School (Southbury) on July 25, 1986, alleging that living conditions at Southbury placed residents in grave danger of bodily harm and death.[SENTMARKER]On the same day, the parties also entered into a consent decree that required Southbury to provide better programming, disciplinary procedures, medical care, recordkeeping, and increase staffing.[SENTMARKER]After some problems with compliance and placing the state in contempt, the Court assigned a special master to monitor Southbury.[SENTMARKER]After making significant progress, on March 25, 2006, the court ended judicial oversight, but retained jurisdiction over the consent decree and remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]On November 2, 2009, the Court granted a joint motion to dismiss the case because the parties agreed that the consent decree and remedial plan were fully implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: The United States Department of Justice ("DOJ") filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri on September 11, 1985 against the State of Connecticut, its governor, the Department of Mental Retardation ("DMR"), and the director of Southbury Training School ("STS"), a Connecticut institution for persons with developmental disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA"), 42 U.s.C.  1997 et seq., by failing to provide adequate medical care to all of its residents, failing to comply with the terms of the consent decree, and failing to integrate the institution with the St. Louis Public Schools.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree which required the defendants to submit an implementation plan addressing the procedures by which the consent consent decree would be effectuated.[SENTMARKER]The district court found the defendants in contempt of court for failing to meet its obligations.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the district court's decision to dismiss the case, and the case went to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that the District Court did not have jurisdiction to hear the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 19, 1996 and the defendants appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the appeal on December 9, 1996.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Disability Rights Washington filed this class action on behalf of individuals with intellectual disabilities in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington in April 2014.[SENTMARKER]They sued the State healthcare authority and department of social services, alleging that budget cuts resulted in inadequate services in violation of the Nursing Home Reform Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement one year later and the final settlement was approved in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is ongoing and under court supervision through September 30, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 16, 2018, a resident of a private nursing facility in Seattle, Washington, filed a class action lawsuit against the Washington State Department of Social and Health Services (DSHS) and the Department of Health Care Authority (HCA) alleging that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Nursing Home Reform Act (NHRA), and the Medicaid Act by failing to screen, assess, and/or receive specialized services for persons with intellectual disabilities and related conditions living in privately-operated Medicaid-certified nursing facilities.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that defendants failed to provide Medicaid benefits with reasonable promptness, violated the ADA, the NHRA, and the Social Security Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in December 2016, which required the defendants to implement a pre-admission screening and resident referral system, post a notice on their website, and provide annual PASRR training to all employees of hospitals and nursing facilities, including but not limited to PASRR Level I screeners.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required defendants to post the 20 class notice on its website.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted class certification in April 2018, and the parties filed a petition for early termination of the agreement in March 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to dismiss the case in March 2019 if the defendants achieved full compliance with each and every 18 compliance metric in advance of September 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed not to appeal the district court's approval of the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: Individuals with intellectual disabilities residing in the Wyoming State Training School filed this lawsuit in 1990 to challenge conditions at the School and a lack of community placement options.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed in 1991 to a settlement that was designed not only to improve conditions in the institution, but also to prevent unnecessary institutionalization and create options for community living for individuals with intellectual disabilities in Wyoming.[SENTMARKER]The court's jurisdiction was ended in 1994.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 3, 1990, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Wyoming against the Wyoming State Training School and other Wyoming state agencies and officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated the rights of individuals with mental retardation residing at the state training school by failing to provide alternative services for them in their communities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Stipulation Agreement on April 24, 1990.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would engage in good faith negotiations to resolve this dispute.[SENTMARKER]On April 30, 1990, the court certified the class as a class, and the parties agreed to a Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendants to provide adequate transportation and other services for individuals with developmental disabilities residing at WSTS.[SENTMARKER]The final decision was entered by the court on October 12, 1994.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement on October 26, 1994.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants on October 27, 1994.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $75,000.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to provide the plaintiffs with an individual education plan.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment on October 28, 1994.

gold_sents: These 2007 consolidated cases were brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona to challenge the "Legal Arizona Workers Act", which mandates investigation and prosecution of employers who knowingly or intentionally employ unauthorized aliens and requires the revocation of the licenses of employers found to have done so.[SENTMARKER]It also makes mandatory a previously voluntary verification process.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court affirmed the lower courts' rulings, holding that the Act fell within ICRA's savings clause and thus was not expressly preempted by federal law.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2007, a group of business, labor, and civil rights organizations filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the state of Arizona, the Arizona Attorney General, the Governor of Arizona and the Director of the Department of Revenue of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state's employer sanctions law, the Migrant and Seasonal Worker Protection Act (AWPA), was preempted by federal immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, and the district court held that the law was not preempted.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals granted the plaintiffs' motion for a writ of certiorari on March 9, 2009, and the case was dismissed on September 17, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the United States Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted the defendants' appeal on October 2, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed that the case should be dismissed.

gold_sents: On July 6, 2010, the United States filed a lawsuit under the Supremacy Clause and the Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution against the state of Arizona and the Governor of Arizona in her official capacity in the U.S. District Court of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff claimed that the recently enacted S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070, which contains several provisions designed to "discourage and deter the unlawful entry and presence of aliens" in Arizona, impermissibly infringes on the federal government's right to enact and enforce immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2010, the district court issued a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed the grant of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On April 11, 2011, the U.S. Court of Appeals, 9th Circuit, issued an opinion upholding the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. Supreme Court granted cert on December 12, 2011 and issued their opinion on June 25, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court affirmed in part and reversed in part, striking down most of the challenged provisions of S.B.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2010, the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona entered a preliminary injunction against Arizona's "alien smuggling prohibition" in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act ("INA") and the Administrative Procedures Act ("APA"), 28 U.C.[SENTMARKER]1391(b)(1) and (3) and the Constitution of the United States, Article VI, Clause 27 2 and Article I, Section 8 of the INA, and the statutes' preemption provisions.[SENTMARKER]The U.N.[SENTMARKER]Attorney General's Office and the Department of Homeland Security ("DHS") filed a motion for injunctive relief seeking to enjoin implementation of S.B.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the motion, and on April 11, 2011, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the district court's preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The court of appeals remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed not to appeal.

gold_sents: On May 17, 2010, a group of organizations and individuals filed a lawsuit against the Sheriff and Attorney of each of the 15 counties in Arizona, in their official capacities, in the U.S. District Court of Arizona, Phoenix Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by organizations such as the ACLU and the National Immigration Law Center along with private counsel, sought declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that the recently enacted S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 was a violation of the Supremacy Clause of the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiff contends that S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 conflicts with federal law and procedures and that local law enforcement agencies are ill equipped to deal with the complexities of immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction in February 2012, which the defendants appealed.[SENTMARKER]In a related case, Arizona v. United States, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down most of S.B.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a Motion for Preliminary Injunction against the remaining provisions of S.B.[SENTMARKER]1070 and while the parties were going through discovery disputes, the defendant filed a motion for summary judgment on March 17, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a response to the defendant's summary judgment and on September 4, 2015, the district court ruled in favor of the defendant with regard to plaintiff's claims under the Supremacy Clause, Equal Protection Clause, the Fourth Amendment, Article II, Section 8 of the Arizona Constitution, the Due Process Clause, and 42 U.S.C. §1981.[SENTMARKER]Notably, the court also entered a judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on count three claim which was appealed.[SENTMARKER]Finally, on September 15, 2016, both parties conferred and filed a joint case disposition in which the plaintiff settled for $1.4 million.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2010, a group of individuals and organizations brought this lawsuit against the State of Arizona challenging the constitutionality of the state's immigration law, Arizona Senate Bill 1070, as amended (S.B.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the law violated the First Amendment right to free speech.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction in June 2010, and the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the district court's injunction in September 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in March 2012, and the case is now resolved.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed that the city of Chandler will not enforce the law.

gold_sents: On June 8, 2015, civil detainees confined in the Tucson Sector of the U.S. Border Patrol filed a class action lawsuit, alleging violations of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment and the APA due to inhumane and punitive conditions while they were detained in holding cells.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a PI mandating that defendants must maintain conditions of confinement adequate for the detainees' physical needs and provide detainees with mats and blankets after 12 hours.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit affirmed the PI order.[SENTMARKER]In 2018 the plaintiffs filed a motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of defendants' obligation to provide raised beds for detainees held for any period requiring sleep; the district court denied this motion.[SENTMARKER]After a 7-day trial in January 2020, the district court held that these extended confinement conditions violated the Constitution and issued an order enjoining the defendants from holding detainees for longer than 48 unless they provided conditions of confinement that meet basic human needs.[SENTMARKER]This permanent injunction was ordered and has been in effect since April 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 8, 2015, three civil immigration detainees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona, alleging that the conditions of their confinement violated their constitutional right to sleep.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the detainees were exposed to any number of unsanitary and unhygienic practices.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction in part, but denied the motion for reconsideration.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed the district court's summary judgment in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In 2018, former Latino/a guests at Motel 6 locations in Arizona filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that Motel 6's policy of disclosing guests' information to DHS and ICE agents without requiring a warrant or reasonable suspicion of criminal activity violated the United States Constitution and federal and state law.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged Motel 6 conspired with DHS and ICE agents to violate guests’ Fourth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]In February 2020, the parties agreed to class action settlement terms and the district court approved the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The court retains jurisdiction over the matter for the duration of the consent decree.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 24, 2018, a group of Motel 6 guests filed a class-action lawsuit against Motel 6 and its parent company, Motel 6 LLC, alleging that Motel 6 violated federal and state law by disclosing guest registration information, including personal information, to federal immigration agents without a warrant or reasonable suspicion of criminal activity.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief, monetary relief, and other relief.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2018, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: (i) Motel 6 would not disclose guests’ personal information to DHS and ICE agents; .[SENTMARKER](ii) the plaintiffs would receive compensation for the harm they suffered; .[SENTMARKER](iii) the parties would provide training to Motel 6 employees; and (iv) the court would retain jurisdiction over the case for the 10 duration of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]On August 31, 2018, the court dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Following his arrest and confinement at the Coconino County Detention Facility (CCDF), plaintiff challenged the prolonged detention of inmates at CCDF triggered by detainer requests from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement Agency (ICE).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff claimed this policy violated Article II, section 8 of the Arizona Constitution and the Fourth   and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]He sought class-wide declaratory and injunctive relief for all CCDF detainees subject to this prolonged detention policy despite their eligibility for pretrial release.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. District Court for the district of Arizona denied the plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction, citing his inability to demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits of his claims.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff moved to dismiss the case thereafter, which was accepted by the court.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 30, 2018, a resident of Arizona filed this lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Arizona against the Coconinos County Sheriff’s Office and the CoConino County Board of Supervisors, alleging that the County’s policy of prolonging detention of inmates for whom it receives a detainer request from ICE violates the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution and Arizona’s 20th Amendment to the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff sought a preliminary injunction, seeking to enjoin the County from detaining an unauthorized immigrant at the request of federal immigration authorities.[SENTMARKER]The District Court denied the Plaintiff’s motion for a temporary restraining order and injunctive relief, and the case was dismissed on July 2, 2018.

gold_sents: In June 2017, the Center for Biological Diversity sued DHS and CBP, bringing challenges to the Trump Administration's proposed border wall (FOIA, environmental statutes, APA, IIRIRA).[SENTMARKER]After consolidation with several cases, on Feb.[SENTMARKER]2018, the Court granted the government's motion to dismiss (except for the FOIA claim) and denied plaintiffs' SJ cross-motions.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to dismiss the FOIA claim.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's order.[SENTMARKER]Lastly, the Supreme Court denied the plaintiff's petition for writ of certiorari regarding the constitutional issue of separation of powers in the IIRIRA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 2, 2017, the Center for Biological Diversity filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and Customs and Border Protections (CBP) seeking declaratory and/or injunctive relief under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) for violations of NEPA, the Coastal Zone Management Act (CZMA), and other laws related to the construction of a border wall prototype project along a 15-mile stretch of the international border between San Diego and Calexico, California.[SENTMARKER]In January 2017, President Donald J. Trump issued Executive Order No. 13767, entitled "Border Security and Immigration Enforcement 13 Improvement," which directed DHS to construct a "secure, 14 contiguous, and impassable physical barrier" along the entirety of the nearly 2,000-mile-long border.[SENTMARKER]The Center's FOIA request sought records related to DHS's compliance with NEPA and the APA, as well as CBP's authority under IIRIRA section 102(c) to waive the laws in the August 2, 2017 Determination Pursuant to Section 22 102 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996, 23 As Amended, 82 Fed Reg. 35,984.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the FOIA request for lack of jurisdiction, and the case was consolidated with two other FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted DHS summary judgment on the non-constitutional challenges to the waiver determination, finding that the waivers were precluded by the Secretary's waiver of N EPA and the CZMA, and that the plaintiffs' environmental claims were barred by the waivers.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the FOIA requests for non-jurisdictional reasons.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the district court's decision to the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit reversed the decision by the District Court, holding that it did not have jurisdiction to consider MCorp's challenge Id.[SENTMARKER]1995 and organized groups' challenge to the administrative waivers, and held that the coverage formula under  4 was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court granted summary judgment to DHS.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On May 23, 2018 the ACLU of Northern California filed this lawsuit against Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) under the Freedom of Information Act, alleging that ICE had not provided the ACLU with documents they had requested related to ICE's purchase of automated license plate reader data.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a schedule for the documents to be released on a rolling basis, which was completed in November 2018.[SENTMARKER]A settlement also required ICE to pay attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 23, 2018, the ACLU of Northern California filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against U. S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking records relating to contracts between ICE and private companies for access and use of automated license plate reader (ALPR) technology and related training material, privacy guidance, audit logs, and other documents relating to any use and sharing of ALPR data by ICE.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICE wrongfully withheld the requested records in violation of FOIA and sought declaratory and injunctive relief with respect to the search, release and disclosure of 17 of the requested agency records, as well as attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement, which is subject to court approval, was entered into on May 23, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties did not dispute that the public had a right to access the records requested by the ACLU, and that ICE had violated FOIA by failing to comply with the statutory time for the processing of FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment in favor of the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: Two San Francisco Bay Area fathers filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after being detained for over 6 months in ICE custody without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction and class certification ordering that individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. § 1231(a)(6) pending a determination as to whether they can remain in the United States with “live claims”  before an adjudicative body cannot be detained for more than 180 days without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed both orders to the Ninth Circuit, and on April 7, 2020, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's order.[SENTMARKER]Following plaintiffs' motion to enforce the preliminary injunction, the court granted it in part, finding that the defendants had not substantially complied with certain requirements, but denied it in part.[SENTMARKER]As of April 16, 2021, this case is pending a writ of certiorari in front of the Supreme Court.
pegasus_output_sents: This case was brought by two noncitizens who were detained in the United States without a bond hearing to determine whether they posed a flight risk or a danger to the community.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought class certification on their statutory and constitutional claims, and a preliminary injunction enjoining the government from detaining plaintiffs and the class for more than 180 days without providing them with a bond 24 hearing before an immigration judge at which the government has the burden of justifying 25 detention.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification, and the Supreme Court granted the government's petition for a writ of certiorari.[SENTMARKER]On April 7, 2020, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's grant of the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that the plaintiffs had standing to sue under the INA and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed not to appeal.

gold_sents: On June 7, 2018, Community Legal Services in East Palo Alto and the National Immigration Project of the National Lawyers Guild filed this lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement for failure to comply with a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request submitted on March 2, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled in August 2020, resulting in a $16,000 litigation expenses and the release of the requested documents.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 2, 2017, Community Legal Services in East Palo Alto and the National Immigration Project of the National Lawyers Guild filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) against the United States Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Department of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that DHS and ICE violated the FOIA by failing to respond to a FOIA 10 request sent to them on March 2.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the defendants failed to conduct a reasonable search for records responsive to the FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to pay $16,350.10 (Sixteen thousand three hundred-fifty dollars and ten cents) to the plaintiffs and to vacate their claims for attorney's fees, costs, and litigation expenses under the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay the plaintiffs' legal fees and expenses.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the court on May 2, 2018.

gold_sents: A group of Iranian refugees and their U.S. sponsors filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) denied their refugee resettlement applications en masse in February 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs applied for refugee resettlement through the Vienna, Austria-based Lautenberg-Specter program for Iranian religious minorities, but received mass denials with the sole explanation that they were denied "as a matter of discretion."[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Lautenberg Amendment, which mandates that the denial state "to the maximum extent feasible, the reason for the denial," as well as Fifth Amendment due process and DHS's own regulations.[SENTMARKER]On July 2018, the court declared the denial notices unlawful, and ordered DHS to re-issue new notices.[SENTMARKER]As of June 3, 2020, the case is still ongoing.
