pegasus_output_sents: On February 19, 2018, a group of Iranian refugees filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) violated the Lautenberg Amendment and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by denying their applications for refugee admission to the United States.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that DHS denied the applications of approximately 87 Iranian refugees, many of whom had been waiting nearly a year for their applications to be processed.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification and granted their motion for partial summary judgment, finding that DHS violated the law by denying the applications as a matter of discretion without further explanation.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and no further action is pending.

gold_sents: The city and county of San Francisco brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the Department of Justice (DOJ) had unlawfully conditioned states' acceptance of certain federal funds on their compliance with federal immigration enforcement efforts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that these conditions violated the Spending Clause and the separation of powers under the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted summary judgment for the plaintiff in March, 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: California and San Francisco sued the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the DOJ's immigration-related conditions on the Byrne JAG Program funding violated the Constitution's separation of powers and the spending clause of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the district court's 10 judgment in favor of San Francisco on the merits of the case.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ moved for partial dismissal or summary judgment on two of the five conditions.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed amended complaints in November 2018, seeking declaratory relief that the conditions were unconstitutional violations of the Separation of Powers and the Spending Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought to enjoin the DOJ from enforcing the three conditions, as well as a permanent nationwide 14 injunction on any current or future JAG awards.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the DOJ’s motion for partial summary judgment and the parties filed an amended complaint in November 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, but the parties are continuing to seek permanent injunctions.

gold_sents: On February 14, 2019, a group of asylum seekers from Central America and several legal organizations filed this lawsuit against the Trump Administration in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Administration's new policy of forcing asylum seekers to return to Mexico while awaiting their court hearings (the Migrant Protection Protocols), violated the INA and APA.[SENTMARKER]The district court issued a nationwide injunction which was later affirmed by the Ninth Circuit, but the U.S. Supreme Court subsequently halted the injunction, leaving the MPP in effect nationwide.On April 10, 2020, the government filed a petitino for certiorari with the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]On October 19, 2020, the Supreme Court granted certi.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 28, 2020, a group of non-Mexican asylum seekers brought suit in the Northern District Court of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) alleging that the government's new policy of forcing asylum seekers to return to Mexico while they await their removal proceedings violated their rights under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and the 8 Administrative Procedure Act (APA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were represented by the nonprofit organization Tahirih Justice Center, which offers legal representation and social services for individuals who seek protection, including asylum, in their immigration proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the policy violated their right to a meaningful right to apply for asylum under  1225(b)(1).[SENTMARKER]The government moved for an emergency stay of the injunction pending its appeal, which was granted on April 10, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, pending the outcome of the appeal.

gold_sents: On June 16, 2019, plaintiffs--three immigration attorneys and two noncitizens who filed FOIA (FOIA) requests for individual immigration case files (known as A-Files)--filed this class-action suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs, represented by the American Immigration Council and the Northwest Immigrant Rights Project, sought declaratory relief that defendants’ failure to make timely determinations on plaintiffs’ and proposed classes’ A-File FOIA requests violates FOIA, and a nationwide injunction requiring defendants to make timely determinations.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for declaratory and injunctive relief and ordered the defendants to provide quarterly reports on their compliance with the FOIA.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 16, 2019, three immigration attorneys and two noncitizens filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of individuals who filed Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests for individual immigration case files, also known as Alien 4 Registration Files or A-Files.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated FOIA by failing to meet the statutory deadline with respect to A-File FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in 1992, in which the parties agreed to implement expedited processing of FOIA requests where the requester demonstrates that an individual’s life or personal safety would be jeopardized or that substantial due process rights would be impaired by the failure to process a request immediately.[SENTMARKER]On August 28, 2020, the Ninth Circuit reversed the settlement agreement and remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, granted their motion for class certification, and granted preliminary injunctive relief to the plaintiffs.

gold_sents: This lawsuit was filed in response to a July 6, 2020 ICE directive that would effectively force out of the country many international students studying remotely during the 2020 coronavirus pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The University of California filed suit claiming that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act. Plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order and an order vacating and setting aside the policy.[SENTMARKER]They also sought declarative relief and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]In a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, the plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs in this case continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 6, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2020, the Regents of the University of California sued the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and the Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP), a division of ICE, in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The Regents alleged that the SEVP's July 6, 2020 memorandum and news release requiring schools to certify to SEVP for each F-1 visa student attending such school that, among other things, a student is not taking an entirely online course load for the fall 2020 semester and that the student is taking the minimum number of online classes required to make normal progress in their degree program was arbitrary, capricious, or otherwise not in accordance with law.[SENTMARKER]The Administrative Procedure Act (APA) provides that federal agencies are accountable to the public and their actions subject to review by the courts.[SENTMARKER]On July 10, 2020, The Regents served Defendants with the summons and complaint filed in this matter, as well as a Motion for Temporary Restraining Order and Order to Show Cause re: TRO Motion to enjoin Defendants from implementing the Directive.[SENTMARKER]On August 4, 2020, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on the merits of the case, finding that the July 6 Directive was unlawful for failure to follow the rulemaking procedure required by the APA.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendant's motion to dismiss the case on the basis that the defendants had not provided any justification for its about-face.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then issued an exemption to a preexisting regulation that required international students on F-1 visas to attend classes in person if they wished to remain in this country.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Seven unnamed individuals sued ICE and DHS over their new directive that would effectively force international students to take in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought injunctive relief prohibiting the enforcement of the directive and an order vacating the directive.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance, but the plaintiffs in this case filed an amended complaint that sought a formal declaration that the July 6 directive was improperly issued and an order that the government administer the student visa program in accordance with the March guidance for the duration of the emergency.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the students' claims were mooted by the rescission and granted the government's motion to dismiss on October 1, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2020, a group of graduate students on F-1 visas filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the central district of California, alleging that the California state emergency declared in response to the COVID-19 pandemic was unlawful and unlawful promulgated.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order (TRO) enjoining the implementation of a policy change that barred student visa holders from remaining in the United States during the upcoming fall semester if their universities cancelled in-person classes.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]In a second motion to dismiss, the court dismissed the case without prejudice, finding that the plaintiffs had failed to show that the policy change violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the federal immigration law.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2020, the State of California, the City of Los Angeles, the City of Long Beach, the City of Oakland, and the Los Angeles Unified School District filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that President Trump's Memorandum violated the constitutional mandates for the census (actual enumeration and apportionment) and separation of powers, as well as violating the Census Act and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of September 28, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2019, a lawsuit was brought by the City of L.A.[SENTMARKER]and the Los Angeles County on behalf of the residents of California alleging that the Census Bureau's 2020 Census count exclusion of undocumented immigrants from the count was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory, injunctive, mandamus, and other relief, including a declaration that the Constitution and the Census Act require the apportionment base used to apportion congressional representatives to include all persons 15 counted in each state, including undocumented immigrants.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court agreed and affirmed the vacatur of the Secretary of Commerce's decision to exclude 27 undocumented immigrants in his apportionment report to Congress.[SENTMARKER]The case was referred to the District Court for the Northern District of California for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]In a final judgment, the Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.

S.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The complaint seeks declaratory and injunctive relief to effect the release by the Defendants of agency records that Plaintiff has requested from the Defendants pursuant to FOIA.[SENTMARKER]In recent years, there has developed significant public interest and controversy over the conditions of confinement of immigrant detainees placed into custody by the defendants.[SENTMARKER]On April 3, 2018, the Plaintiff filed a FOIA request with ICE seeking certain categories of information related to detention of individuals during their immigration proceedings, limited to ten discrete categories of data related to detainees having disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff's representative called ICE's Office of Diversity and Civil Liberties and spoke to a female employee.[SENTMARKER]On September 7, 2017, the Plaintiff also called the Adelanto Detention Facility located in or near the city of Adelanto, California.[SENTMARKER]On February 8, 2018, the plaintiff filed a motion for a preliminary injunction against the Defendants' failure to respond to its FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff's motion was granted on February 7, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion, permanently enjoining the Defendants from charging the Plaintiff any retrieval fees, duplication charges, or review fees as a condition of providing the requested records, and ordered the Defendants to provide the requested documents to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 6, 2015, a class-action lawsuit was filed in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and two ICE officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Due Process Clause of the Constitution by detaining them without individualized determination of flight risk and danger to the community, but rather to deter other migrants from coming to the United States.[SENTMARKER]According to the plaintiffs, such detention violated the Fifth Amendment, the Immigration and Nationality Act, and applicable DHS regulations.[SENTMARKER]The parties subsequently conferred and submitted a joint proposal for a preliminary injunction to prevent DHS from applying this policy until a final determination has been reached on the merits of this action.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for injunctive and declaratory relief, and granted the defendants' motion to proceed anonymously.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 18, 2017, the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Council filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, seeking for the court to compel United States Customs and Border Patrol to comply with a Freedom of Information Act request.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought records of CBP action revoking, suspending, or terminating participation int he Global Entry System for certain Arab and Muslim U.S.[SENTMARKER]Citizens and Lawful Permanent Residents.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered joint status updates.[SENTMARKER]In March 2019, the parties informed the court that they had resolved the records production dispute.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, they informed the court that they had reached an agreement regarding attorneys’ fees and costs, and requesting that the case be dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case on July 26, 2019.

S.[SENTMARKER]Customs and Border Protection (CBP) seeking agency records relating to actions taken by CBP to revoke, suspend, or terminate participation in the Global Entry System (GES) for certain Arab and Muslim American citizens and Lawful Permanent Residents (LPRs) without any legal justification.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that CBP violated the FOIA by failing to respond to ADC's expedited processing request within ten (10) business days.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a joint status report on or before February 15, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties have resolved their differences as to CBP's search for and production of non-exempt, responsive records subject to the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The only remaining issue for the parties to discuss is possible attorneys' fees under the FOIA, which the parties propose filing by March 22, 2019 to update the Court on the parties' anticipated course of action.

gold_sents: On August 23, 2018, Muslim Advocates filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the United States Department of Justice [DOJ] and United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement [ICE].[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged violations of the Freedom of Information Act [FOIA], 5 U.S.C. § 552(a).[SENTMARKER]Muslim Advocates had requested information from both defendants regarding Operation Janus, where the DOJ reviewed the files of naturalized citizens and began intensive denaturalization efforts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case moved to settlement negotiations; an agreement on all FOIA issues was reached on January 13, 2020, but negotiations over attorneys fees are ongoing as of June 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 11, 2018, Muslim Advocates, a not-for-profit legal advocacy and educational organization, filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Justice's National Security Division (NSD) and the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking documents related to the federal government's denaturalization efforts, including but not limited to "Operation Janus", a joint initiative between DOJ and ICE.[SENTMARKER]The FOIA request sought nonidentifying information reflecting the countries of origin and/or ethnic background of individuals identified as candidates for de naturalization complaints.[SENTMARKER]On January 25, 2018, the NSD issued a final determination on the FOIA request, and on July 6, 2018, the parties filed a joint status report.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2018, the court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment, finding that the Civil Division's refusal to process the request violated the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted a partial fee waiver and ordered the parties to file a new Joint Status Report on or before June 15.[SENTMARKER]The parties are currently in discussions regarding the production of responsive documents.

Trump.[SENTMARKER]The court granted class certification and partial summary judgment to the plaintiffs on August 2, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the ruling.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 9, 2018, a group of noncitizens who entered the United States illegally and who wish to seek asylum filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California challenging the government's categorical bar on asylum eligibility for individuals and families crossing the southern border outside designated ports of entry.[SENTMARKER]The suit was brought on behalf of individuals and groups that provide legal and social services to immigrants, including individuals who crossed the border from Mexico and who filed applications for asylum with Defendant USCIS.[SENTMARKER]On November 19, 2018, the court issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the implementation of the rule, and ordered the Government to reunite separated families within 30 days.[SENTMARKER]On December 7, 2018, the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit issued its opinion denying the Government's request for an emergency administrative stay and stay pending appeal of the district court's restraining order pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: 37 families detained at three ICE-managed family residential centers sued the U.S. Department of Homeland Security alleging violations of their Fifth Amendment constitutional rights, violations of the Administrative Procedure Act, and violations of the Flores Settlement Agreement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the congregate environment and unsanitary conditions of the detention centers make them a tinderbox for a COVID-19 outbreak.[SENTMARKER]They sought immediate release until proper protocols could be implemented.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order which was granted in part and denied in part on March 30.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered ICE to provide appropriate infection protocols for the adults (a similar order from another case, Flores, applies to the children), to comply with CDC guidelines for congregate institutions, and to file a report regarding FRC capacity, implementation of the CDC guidelines, the number of detainees released, and videotape of the living conditions at the FRCs.[SENTMARKER]On May 26, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss and a motion in opposition to the temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the plaintiffs' later motion for a preliminary injunction demanding wholesale release of detainees on July 22.[SENTMARKER]On December 10, the court dismissed the claim under the APA and the writs of mandamus.[SENTMARKER]A hearing is scheduled for February 16, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In January 2005, a class-wide settlement agreement was reached in a class action lawsuit brought by noncitizen parents and minor children seeking asylum in the United States who were detained at family residential centers (FRCs) in the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The agreement required the government to provide certain rights to all minors detained at FRCs.[SENTMARKER]In March 2020, the plaintiffs filed this suit in the Central District Court of California, alleging that the government was failing to adequately protect them from contracting COVID-19 during the removal process.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were concerned about the conditions of their confinement, asking the Court to mandate improved safety protocols or, in the alternative, to release them.[SENTMARKER]On March 21, 2020, the court granted the government's motion for summary judgment, finding that it had complied with its obligations under the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 23, 2020, a group of transgender people in civil immigration detention filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs requested an injunction ordering supervised release of all transgender people in immigration detention in light of the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]On June 2, the court denied the plaintiff's motion for TRO and motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]After filing an amended complaint in August, 2020, the case was dismissed on January 6, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 5, 2020, a group of transgender people in immigration detention filed a class-action lawsuit in the District Court, alleging that the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) violated their Fifth Amendment due process rights and the Administrative Contract Act (APA) by failing to adequately protect them from the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICE failed to provide adequate medical care to transgender immigrants in its custody, violated the APA, and violated the Due Process Clause of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) and certified a class of all transgender immigrants held in ICE detention facilities nationwide.[SENTMARKER]The TRO ordered ICE to provide transgender detainees with access to medically necessary, gender-affirming care, including hormone replacement therapy and other gendering affirming care, and to refrain from detaining any additional transgender immigrants until the COvid-19 pandemic ends.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Three non-citizen soldiers in the U.S. military brought this class-action lawsuit against the Department of Defense in September 2017.[SENTMARKER]The Department was refusing to certify their honorable military service for purposes of expedited naturalization under the Immigration and Nationality Act.[SENTMARKER]The court issued a preliminary injunction in October 2017, requiring the Department to certify honorable service within 2 days of a soldier’s request, without imposing additional procedural or substantive requirements.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the plaintiffs and the Department of Defense are in mediation.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 24, 2017, ten individuals (the "Nio Plaintiffs") brought a class action suit against the United States Department of Defence ("DOD") and Secretary James Mattis, alleging that the military's refusal to issue them N-426 forms is unlawful under the Administrative Procedure Act ("APA") and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The Nio plaintiffs also challenged the Department of Homeland Security's ("DHS") and USCIS's decision to put their naturalization applications on hold pending DOD's completion of the enhanced security screening ("DHS/USCIS Security Screening Requirement") it now requires for MAVNI enlistees prior to initial entry training ("IET") or active-duty service.[SENTMARKER]On September 1, 2017, the Nio Plaintiffs filed a complaint in the District Court for the District of Columbia against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants were unlawfully imposing extra-statutory requirements in violation of  1440.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification, granted their motion for summary judgment, and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint status report for the case on August 5, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the parties agreed that the parties would resolve the issues in the case, including the issue of the DHS/USCIS security screening requirement.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Non-citizen soldiers in the U.S. military brought this lawsuit in May 2017, challenging policies of the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Defense that unlawfully delayed their naturalization applications.[SENTMARKER]The court certified a class and granted a preliminary injunction against the agencies on October 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2019, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, ruling that the agencies’ policy of delaying naturalization applications was arbitrary and capricious, in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The court issued a permanent injunction on August 20, 2020, and retained jurisdiction to enforce the injunction.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 5, 2017, the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) announced that it would end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.[SENTMARKER]On September 6, 2017, a group of states and the District of Columbia filed suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, alleging that DHS violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by rescinding the DACA program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHS's policy regarding the use of DACA applicants' information for immigration-enforcement purposes was arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and denied defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that the rescission was inadequately explained.[SENTMARKER]In a related case, the Fifth Circuit affirmed the district court's preliminary injunction in favor of the government.[SENTMARKER]On October 5, 2018, the court entered a preliminary injunction requiring DHS to continue processing renewal applications.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a joint motion for summary judgment, which was granted in part by the parties, and the parties agreed that the case should be dismissed for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.

gold_sents: In 2018, several states filed a complaint against the Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the immigration-related conditions being placed on funding disbursed by the Department of Justice violated the Separation of Powers, the APA and the Tenth Amendment Anti-Commandeering.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, a judge granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, the defendants appealed this judgment.[SENTMARKER]And later, the plaintiffs made a motion for summary judgment on the 2018 immigration-related conditions.[SENTMARKER]In February 2020, a Second Circuit panel reversed the district court's order granting partial summary judgment, vacated the mandate and injunction, and remanded the case to the district court, concluding that the Attorney General was statutorily authorized to impose the challenged conditions and that the imposition of these conditions was not arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment is currently pending before the district court.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 26, 2020, the states of California and the City of San Francisco filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District Of New York, alleging that the federal government's immigration-related conditions on the Byrne Program Criminal Justice Assistance grant funds were unlawful.[SENTMARKER]The conditions required the States and localities to (1) provide access to their correctional facilities for federal immigration enforcement agents (the "access condition"); and (2) enjoin the government from imposing these conditions on any Byrne JAG applicant in order to receive the funds.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied California's request for a preliminary injunction enjoining DOJ from enforcing the Section 1373 condition on the State and its subdivisions, finding that the record was insufficient at the motion to dismiss stage to 79.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the district court granted partial judgment in favor of plaintiffs, enjoining the enforcement of the challenged conditions as to them and mandating the release of 2017 Byrne grant funds to plaintiffs, and remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In July 2020, several immigration advocacy and nonprofit organizations filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that by excluding “undocumented immigrants from: (a) the tabulation of the total population of the states; .[SENTMARKER](b) the calculation and statement of the whole number of persons in each state; and (c) the calculation and statement of the apportionment of the House of Representatives among the states” the federal government were violating the Enumeration and Apportionment clauses of the United States Constitution, Equal Protection under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, the Separation of Powers, the Census Act, and.[SENTMARKER]In August 2020, this case was consolidated with State of New York v. Trump.[SENTMARKER]For additional information, on this case, please see State of New York v. Trump.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2020, a lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Commerce and President Donald J. Trump by the Immigration Coalition of the Mid-Atlantic and the American-Arab Civil Rights League.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Constitution by excluding undocumented immigrants from the population count for purposes of apportioning congressional seats to states.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory, injunctive, and/or mandamus relief.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2020, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that the plaintiffs had failed to show that they would be harmed by the exclusion of undocumented immigrants.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2008, national, state and local chambers of commerce and other nonprofit organizations advocating for their members' business interests filed a lawsuit against the State of Oklahoma, claiming that Sections 7 and 9 of the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act, which impose tax penalties on businesses that don't check the work eligibility of all of their employees in a federal database and allow discharged employees to bring discrimination suits against their employers for employing unauthorized workers, were preempted by the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs a preliminary injunction on June 4, 2008, and on appeal to the Tenth Circuit the injunction was upheld except for as to the verification requirement.[SENTMARKER]On remand to the District Court, the case was stayed pending the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Whiting, which Supreme Court later held that an Arizona law requiring employers to use E-Verify was not preempted by federal law.[SENTMARKER]Pursuant to this decision, the district court entered in a judgment on December 19th, 2012, holding that Oklahoma can require persons to contract with the State to use the employment authorization system.[SENTMARKER]However, the provision creating a cause of action for discrimination against employers who terminate an authorized employee while retaining an unauthorized employee and the provision requiring businesses to verify individual independent contractors’ authorization status and creating a withholding for work performed by individual independent contractors, were both struck down.
pegasus_output_sents: Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act of 2007 (H.B.[SENTMARKER]2385.32 of the Act)<n>Lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma on February 1, 2008, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief from defendants, Oklahoma Governor Brad Henry, Oklahoma Attorney General W.A.[SENTMARKER]Purcell, and the Tulsa Chamber.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that Section 7(b), 7(c), and 9 of the Oklahoma Act were expressly and impliedly preempted by federal law and thus unconstitutional under the Supremacy Clause.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that there was a conflict between the Social Security Administration laws (which forbids the use of social security numbers to verify immigration status) and those state statutes which require use of Social Security numbers for employment purposes if the employer wishes to do business with the State.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction against enforcement of the law, but the case was appealed to the Tenth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Tenth Circuit held that the district court did not abuse its discretion in granting the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: In 2008, two detainees filed a habeas petition and class action suit in the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Warden of Allegheny County Jail challenging their continued detention pursuant to immigration detainers and alleging violations of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought habeas relief and class certification.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2008, the district court (Judge David S. Cercone) denied the habeas petition as moot, dismissed the action, and denied the motion for class certification because ICE had assumed custody of both petitioners.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 23, 2008, Wilmer Urbina, Omar Romero-Villegas, and others filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western district of Pennsylvania on behalf of a class of individuals who were detained in the Allegheny County Jail without due process and based solely on an immigration detainer which does not authorize their detention.[SENTMARKER]The class is so numerous that it is believed that there were as many as 76 individuals being detained on immigration detainers in one recent month.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their detention violated the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution and that their due process was violated.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for writ of habeas corpus and granted their motion for a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On August 23, 2012, ICE Agents and the State of Mississippi filed claims alleging that deferred action Directive commands ICE officers to violate federal law, compels them to violate their oaths of office, violates the Administrative Procedure Act ("APA"), unconstitutionally usurps and encroaches upon the legislative powers of Congress, as defined in Article I of the United States Constitution, and violates the obligation of the executive branch to faithfully execute the law, as required by Article II, Section 3, of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On January 24, 2013, the Court found that ICE Agent Plaintiffs had standing to proceed, but the State of Mississippi did not.[SENTMARKER]On July 31, 2013, the Court dismissed Plaintiff's claims without prejudice for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, finding that the dispute must be governed by the Civil Service Reform Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed the judgment of the District Court.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 2012, a group of immigration agents and deportation officers sued the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the State of Mississippi, alleging that the DHS’s Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program violated the United States Constitution and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a permanent injunction preventing the implementation of the Directive and preventing DHS from taking any adverse action against plaintiffs for failure to follow the Directive.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs’ claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, but the case went to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs, and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]7, 2013, 16 Indian guestworkers filed a lawsuit in E.D.Tx.[SENTMARKER]for harm suffered as a result of an allegedly fraudulent and coercive employment recruitment scheme by Defendant Signal International.[SENTMARKER]As of July 5, 2018, 20 of the 21 plaintiffs had reached a settlement with the Burnett defendants; the remaining plaintiff's claim was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as to the Signal defendants and Dewan defendants.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 7, 2013, a group of African-American workers filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to a hostile and abusive work environment on account of their race and alienage, and that their housing conditions violated the applicable health and safety standards under the federal Occupational Health and Safety Act and the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that the defendants violated the federal statutes: 1) The Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2003; 2) The Civil Rights Act of 1866; 3) The Ku Klux Klan Act of 1871; and 4) The Occupational Safety and Health Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs a safety bonus in addition to their regular hourly wage.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the District Court in August 2013 and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into on July 20, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to share the settlement proceeds in the form of a litigation trust, which has been created for the distribution of the settlement funds.

gold_sents: On October 26, 2015, sixteen undocumented immigrants formerly detained in Dallas County, Texas, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Dallas County and the Dallas County Sheriff under 42 USC §1983 for violations of the Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought damages and an injunction preventing the defendants from detaining the plaintiffs solely based on a request from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), an immigration hold, or an immigration detainer.[SENTMARKER]Over time, the case was consolidated with two other lawsuits with identical claims.[SENTMARKER]The state of Texas also intervened as a defendant.[SENTMARKER]The district court initially granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, but allowed the plaintiffs to file an amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The court then dismissed the plaintiffs' due process claims, allowing them to move forward only with their Fourth Amendment claims.[SENTMARKER]By October 18, 2018, only one plaintiff was still represented by counsel and pursuing a claim (26 had dismissed their claims with prejudice, and 18 had fallen out of contact with counsel and were designated as pro se; their claims were later dismissed).[SENTMARKER]That plaintiff reached a private settlement with the defendants and the court ordered entry of the final judgment on December 4, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff was to be paid $9,500.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 7, 2019, a group of immigrants filed a lawsuit against Dallas County, Texas, alleging that the county violated their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by refusing to grant them immediate release on bond and by detaining them based on immigration holds after they were otherwise eligible for release.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were held in detention by Dallas County in connection with state criminal charges and were subject to federal immigration detainers issued by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Form I-247, a component of DHS.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that Dallas County's practice of refusing immediate release to individuals with immigration holds resulted in pretrial detention.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a motion for new trial in April 2015, and the case was transferred to the district court in January 2019.[SENTMARKER]In October 2019, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the parties settled the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendants would not have to pay any of the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees.

gold_sents: This suit challenges Texas's "Sanctuary City" legislation, Senate Bill 4 (SB4), which requires local Texas law enforcement to cooperate with federal immigration officials and punishes them if they do not.[SENTMARKER]Unlike the other suits in this special collection, this suit does not challenge President Trump's "Sanctuary City" Executive Order.[SENTMARKER]This case was quickly consolidated with the two other before Judge Orlando L. Garcia; please refer to El Cenizo v. Texas for further information and updates.[SENTMARKER]This case was administratively closed on Oct. 24, 2017 in light of the consolidation.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 7, 2017, a lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the State of Texas, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, and the Texas Department of Public Safety (DPS) alleging that the state's new immigration law, Senate Bill 4, or "Show Me Your Papers Bill," is impermissible, vague, and violates the Fourteenth Amendment's guarantee of the equal protection of laws and the Supremacy Clause of the First and Fourth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed on behalf of the County of El Paso and its Sheriff, Richard Wiles, as well as TOPEF, an education organization based in San Antonio, Houston, and Dallas.[SENTMARKER]El Paso is under a federal court settlement agreement where it created a policy prohibiting the enforcement of civil immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, El Paso has adopted a policy that prohibits its investigators from making inquiries into the citizenship or residency status for the purpose of determining whether an individual has violated civil immigration law or for the purposes of enforcing those laws.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the County and Sheriff Wiles also seek a declaratory judgment that El Paso’s current policies regarding federal immigration enforcement comply with state and federal law and do not violate SB 4.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund, a non-profit organization that seeks to protect the rights of Mexican Americans in Texas.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit was dismissed by Judge Orlando L. Garcia of the District Court.

gold_sents: An individual unlawfully detained in the Bexar County Adult Detention Center filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act for damages.[SENTMARKER]The case settled in November 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 24, 2017, the Plaintiff filed this suit against Bexar County in the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that he was unlawfully detained in the Bexar County Adult Detention Center (BCADC) from March 24, 2016 until June 8, 2016 without his consent, without notice of any charges, without a warrant, notice to appear in removal proceedings, or an order of removal, and in violation of law.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICE was liable under the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) for falsely imprisoning the Plaintiff pursuant to a detainer request issued by the ICE San Antonio Field Office.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted ICE's motion for partial summary judgment and granted the defendants' motion for declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This is one in a series of cases challenging comprehensive state immigration laws.[SENTMARKER]In this case, a coalition of immigrant rights groups and individual immigrants challenged Utah's law, HB 497, on preemption grounds and as a violation of equal protection, the right to travel, and the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]A preemption case brought by the Department of Justice was later consolidated with this case.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the District Court for the District of Utah has issued a temporary restraining order enjoining the statute.[SENTMARKER]Following the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Arizona, the Court ruled on the motions for preliminary injunctions in June 2014 and ruled against the key provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]In November 2014, the parties filed a joint report, in which the State of Utah agreed to permanently scrap the key problematic provisions of HB 497.[SENTMARKER]On December 4, 2014, the Court entered a judgment per the parties' proposed final agreement and dismissed the remaining claims without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on attorney fees and costs and the case closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 25, 2012, the U.S. District Court for the Central District of Utah granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order against Utah's immigration enforcement law, House 4 Bill 497.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the law violated the Supremacy Clause, the Fourth Amendment, and the Right to Travel.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, but the Supreme Court held in Arizona v. Arizona on June 25, 2012 that the district court had no jurisdiction to hear the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a parallel motion for preliminary injunction against the law, which the court granted.[SENTMARKER]On November 22, 2011, the parties filed a joint motion for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the joint motion and enjoined enforcement of Section 10 of the Immigration and Nationality Act and Section 10(b) of the Administrative Procedure Act. On May 3, 2011, the plaintiffs filed a separate motion to enjoin enforcement of the law.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the court on June 22, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case on November 22, 2012 and the case was transferred to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the motion and granted the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court issued its decision in Arizona in June 2012.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2018, Migrant Justice and four individual members of the organization filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implemented retaliatory policies in response to their activism on behalf of immigrant farm workers, including extensive surveillance and false imprisonment, in violation of their First Amendment Rights and that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) aided these practices by consistently and intentionally sharing personally identifying information about the plaintiffs with ICE in a manner that violated their Fourteenth Amendment Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the plaintiffs and the DMV settled, and the DMV agreed to implement new protocols to protect against disclosing immigration and citizenship information with ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then settled with the remaining defendants on October 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included $100,000 in damages, deferred action for the plaintiffs so they would not be deported, and ICE informing its employees that all immigrants are protected by the First Amendment.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 21, 2019, the ACLU of Vermont and the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Attorney's Office for the District of the Vermont against the United States Department of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and the Department of Homeland Security (OHS) for violating the rights of migrant farm workers in the state of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that ICE and DMV had violated the right to due process and the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by targeting and detaining migrant workers in violation of ICE's immigration policies.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' conduct has caused a number of Vermont-based farm owners to discourage their employees from participating in Migrant Justice activities for fear that their workers would be detained.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief to end Defendants' unlawful and 21 discriminatory practices, as well as monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: On July 31, 2018, two non-profit organizations and fifteen individuals filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Trump Administration's implementation of the waiver provision of the Travel Ban (Presidential Proclamation No. 9645), alleging that it violates the Administrative Procedure Act and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]After the Trump Administration concluded, President Biden revoked the Travel Ban and ordered that visa applications resume processing on January 20, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 31, 2018, a group of individuals and organizations filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western district of Washington challenging the government's implementation of the waiver provision of President Trump's travel ban.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs allege that the government has failed to follow its own policies and procedures, and have put in place a waiver process in which applicants are denied waivers without ever receiving notice or an opportunity to apply [and] are denied without having to have an interview.[SENTMARKER]The parties do not dispute that they are subject to personal jurisdiction in the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]On August 1, 2018, the court granted the parties' motion to dismiss on the ground that there were no agency decisions subject to review under the Administrative Procedure Act and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on the grounds that they had not shown that there was a substantial likelihood of success.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In March 2020, during the outbreak of COVID-19 in the Seattle area, persons critically vulnerable to the disease and held in an immigration detention facility near Seattle filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued ICE and its directors for violation of their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that continued detention in the face of a potential outbreak in the detention facility would expose the plaintiffs to substantial harm and amount to punishment in violation of the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]On March 19, the court denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order seeking immediate release.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied the plaintiffs' second motion for a temporary restraining order on April 8.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on April 30, which the court has not yet resolved.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: Petitioners-Plaintiffs are people who are particularly vulnerable to serious illness or death if infected by COVID-19 and who are held in civil detention by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) at the Tacoma Northwest Detention Center 9 (NWDC) in Tacoma, Washington as they await the adjudication of their immigration cases.[SENTMARKER]On March 16, 2020, the Petitioners filed a petition for habeas corpus, seeking a writ of habeas corpus or injunctive relief, against ICE and The GEO Group, Inc., a private detention center run by ICE.[SENTMARKER]The Petitioners alleged that the defendants' conditions of confinement subject plaintiffs to heightened risk of contracting COVID19, for which there is no vaccine, known treatment, or cure.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the Board of Immigration Appeals on December 2, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The case is now being reviewed by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Court will determine whether the case should be dismissed for lack of standing.

gold_sents: This class-action case was brought challenging the Santa Cruz County Jail's practice of strip searching individuals held in the jail.[SENTMARKER]The case settled and was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 28, 2009, a class action lawsuit was filed against the County of Santa Cruz and the Santa Cruz County Sheriff's Office on behalf of individuals who were subject to strip and/or visual body cavity searches prior to arraignment on certain charges.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the searches violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution by subjecting the individuals to the searches without reasonable suspicion that they would be productive of contraband or weapons.[SENTMARKER]According to the suit, each class member suffered actual damages as a result of being 5 subjected to a strip search before arraignment 28 without having, and recording in writing, a reasonable suspect that the search would have been productive.[SENTMARKER]The class also included those who were subjected to strip searches in the presence of persons who were not officially 24 participating in such searches and those who had been searched in places where they could be and 25 were visualized by members of the opposite sex.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay $3,875,000 to the class.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The court has not yet approved the settlement, but the parties have agreed that it is fair and reasonable.

gold_sents: A female arrestee filed this strip search case against the Humboldt County Jail and various officials challenging the jail's mandatory, blanket strip search policy.[SENTMARKER]The court found no pattern or practice.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff refiled, naming the deputy sheriff who conducted (and videotaped) the search, and the case was settled.[SENTMARKER]We have no further information about this case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 23, 2004, a woman was arrested for allegedly driving under the influence of alcohol and was taken to the Humboldt County Jail in Eureka, California, where she was forced to strip naked from the waist up in the presence of other inmates to search for contraband or weapons.[SENTMARKER]The woman brought this suit against Humboldt County and its deputy, Anne Goldsmith, under 42 UC  1983 and the Fourth and 11  14th Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Goldsmith violated the plaintiff's Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by subjecting her to an unreasonable search without reasonable suspicion that such searches would be productive of contraband or 11 weapon.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment on May 23, 2006, and the case was closed on June 9, 2006.[SENTMARKER]On June 26, 2006, the defendant appealed to the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice.

gold_sents: On April 16, 2007, Plaintiff, represented by private attorney Mark E. Merin, filed a 42 U.S.C. § 1983 class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California challenging the Solano County Sheriff's policies and practices concerning the use of strip and visual body cavity searches in Solano County Jail.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff alleged that such searches, conducted in the absence of any reasonable suspicion of contraband or weapons, violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]In September 2009, two years after the defendants revised their search policies to comply with federal law, the parties settled with the defendant paying $110,000 in damages and $100,000 in attorney fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 16, 2007, a man arrested in Solano County, California, filed a class action lawsuit against the Solano County Sheriff's Office, alleging that the sheriff's office violated the Constitution by subjecting pre-arraigned detainees to strip and/or visual body cavity searches without reasonable suspicion that the searches would be productive of contraband or weapons.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants' policy, practice, and custom of subjecting arrestees to strip searches before arraignment without having, and recording in writing, a reasonable suspicion of the search's productiveness, violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]On March 29, 2009, the parties reached a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay $12,500 to each of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved by Judge Frank C. Damrell, Jr. of the District Court for the Eastern district of California on September 29, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on March 29, 2009.

gold_sents: In 2011, several inmates of the Fresno County Adult Detention Facilities filed a lawsuit against the County of Fresno, California, alleging that it violated prisoners' Constitutional rights by maintaining dangerous facilities and failing to provide basic health care.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the parties settled the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to implement a remedial plan and to pay $900,000 in attorneys' fees and $40,000 per year for monitoring fees and expenses.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 13, 2011, two prisoners in the Fresno County Jail filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of California, alleging that the conditions of confinement in the jail violated the constitutional and statutory rights of all prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to provide timely access to health care and that the prisoners were at risk of injury and violence from other prisoners.[SENTMARKER]In May 2015, the parties entered into a consent decree, which was approved by the Court on December 13, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendants to implement a plan to ensure that all prisoners had access to timely health care.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay plaintiffs' counsel $40,000 per calendar year, or a pro-rated portion thereof, for all fees and expenses related to monitoring the implementation of the consent decree and the plan.[SENTMARKER]The Court also appointed the Prison Law Office as class counsel to represent the class of prisoners who were or will be incarcerated in the county jail.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case, and the parties filed a motion for final approval of the Consent Decree in December 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties then engaged in extensive settlement negotiations, which resulted in the parties reaching a final consent decree that was approved in December 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to implement the plan, which is subject to the court's approval, in the future, and provide all prisoners with access to medical care.

gold_sents: This is a class action suit brought in 1993 by prisoners at the Merced County Jail to challenge their conditions of confinement.[SENTMARKER]The District Court for the Eastern District of California issued some initial injunctive relief to prevent overcrowding, and a settlement was preliminarily approved but seemingly never finalized.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in 2000.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 4, 1993, a group of inmates of the Merced County Jail in California filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of California against the County of Merced, the Sheriff's Office, and the Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (DCR) alleging that the defendants violated the inmates' civil rights by failing to provide them with adequate medical and mental health care.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that inmates were forced to sleep on the floor of the jail because the jail was not adequately equipped to treat them.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for injunctive relief and ordered the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with a copy of a proposed settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was approved by the court on August 5, 1993 and was entered into effect on March 4, 1993.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for partial summary judgment on August 6, 1993 and the case was dismissed on March 10, 1994.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement conference on March 11, 1994.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on March 12, 1994.[SENTMARKER]The case is still ongoing.

gold_sents: This 2011 lawsuit alleged that Alameda County had violated the decedent's constitutional rights in its agents' use of excessive force.[SENTMARKER]The suit further alleged that Corizon Health, Inc. was negligent in its failure to provide decedent with treatment for alcohol withdrawal.[SENTMARKER]In February, 2015, the parties settled for $8,300,000 in damages and injunctive relief that included health training.[SENTMARKER]The injunctive relief is set to end February 1, 2019, and little activity had appeared on the docket since 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 13, 2012, the family of a pretrial detainee in the custody of the Alameda County Sheriff's Department filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California against the County and Corizon Health, Inc. (Corizon), a Delaware corporation that provides medical and nursing care to prisoners and detainees in the County's jails.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants violated Title 42 of the United State Code, Sections 1983 and 1988, and the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution by denying inmates access to appropriate, competent, and necessary care for serious medical and psychiatric needs.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for summary judgment on all of the claims, and the case was transferred to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in January 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: (i) that all inmates in Alameda County Jails would receive medical screenings and patient assessments; .[SENTMARKER](ii) that the County would pay $20,000 in damages to the plaintiff; .[SENTMARKER](iii) that a nurse practitioner or physician's assistant would conduct all patient assessments on all inmates; and (iv) that there would be no more than every two years in accordance with the terms of the provisions of Title 42.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by Judge Jon S. pegasus_output_sents: On November 14, 2016, the United States District Court for the Northern District of California entered a consent decree in a class action lawsuit filed on behalf of inmates with mobility disabilities incarcerated in Santa Clara County's Main Jail North, Main Jail South, and Elmwood Correctional Facility.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), 42 U.S.C.  12101 et seq.; Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Rehabilitation Act) and California Government Code Section 11135 (State and Federal Disability Laws) by failing to consistently provide accessible transportation, programs, services, and activities to inmates with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms in the consent decree: (1) a policy of providing a safe and secure shower chair which shall be readily accessible and provided immediately upon request; .[SENTMARKER](2) religious programming; .[SENTMARKER](3) facilities for male inmates at the Elmwood Correctional Complex in Milpitas, California; and (3) the Elmwood Complex Women's Facility in Milpitas.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed that in lieu of installing a bench in the X-ray changing room, the County shall provide a chair for an inmate with a Mobility Disability.

pegasus_output_sents: On November 1, 2018, three pretrial detainees filed a civil rights class action lawsuit against the County of Alameda on behalf of all pretrial detainees housed at the Santa Rita Jail in Dublin, California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the County violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution by depriving them of a minimal level of night time sleep.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that there was no separate facility for pregnant women and that there were no other facilities available to house pregnant women in the jail.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief on April 22, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the County agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $75,000.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed not to appeal.

pegasus_output_sents: On October 30, 2019, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of former and current inmates of the Santa Rita jail in San Francisco.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jail violated the First, Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution by failing to provide them with adequate outdoor recreation, inadequate medical care, unsanitary conditions of confinement, and requiring inmates to provide the medical care for newly booked, detoxing detainees.[SENTMARKER]The class was represented by experienced civil rights and class action counsel.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Magistrate Judge Jacqueline Scott Corley, who entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' attorney's fees and costs.

gold_sents: This putative class-action lawsuit, brought by inmates in Orange County Jail, argued that county and the sheriff violated the U.S. Constitution, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act in failing to provide adequate care amidst the 2020 coronavirus pandemic.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought habeas corpus, injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted class certification and partially granted a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction, which mandated more social distancing, providing for more PPE, and improved sanitation policies.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed this decision to the Ninth Circuit, and applied in both the district court and the Ninth Circuit to stay the case in the lower court until the appeals court had ruled.[SENTMARKER]Both denied these applications, however the Ninth Circuit remanded to the district court saying that the defendants could try to modify the injunction if there were any changed circumstances.[SENTMARKER]Defendants did so, but the district court denied any modifications once again.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed this decision to the Ninth Circuit, which likewise rejected the defendants' motion.[SENTMARKER]Finally, the defendants went to the Supreme Court and asked them to stay the injunction while the Ninth Circuit heard the case on the merits.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court obliged on August 5, staying the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of February 17, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 30, 2020, ten inmates at the Orange County Jail filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California, alleging that the conditions of confinement at the jail violated their constitutional and other statutor rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to take adequate measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 within the jail.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on May 26, 2020, and the defendants filed an appeal in the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals on June 2, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit denied the request for an emergency injunctive relief from Nevada's Calvary Chapel Dayton Valley for COVID mitigation measures.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed an emergency motion to stay the district court's May 26, 2020 preliminary injunction order in light of the evidence of changed circumstances they presented in support of the motion to dissolve the injunction.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a temporary restraining order and a motion to implement protections against COVID, which was granted on June 3, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On June 4, 2020, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the defendants' appeal, and the parties entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered on June 5, 2020 and the case was closed on June 6, 2020.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 3, 2013, a class action lawsuit was brought in the United States District Court for the District of Washington, DC by a group of former inmates who alleged that the District's Department of Correction had a practice of overdetaining and strip searching inmates past their release dates.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' and class members' due process rights were violated for the period September 1, 2005 to December 31, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The District says that the DOC began videotaping strip searches in April 2008, i n response to a complaint from a trans-gender inmate.[SENTMARKER]The District will pay up to $250,000 for each class member who qualifies as an Overdetention Class Member a sum of $370.00 for the first calendar day of over detention, plus $250 per day for each day for which they were supposed to be released, or subjected to a strip search after they had been to court appearance and were entitled to release because of their appearance.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in August of 2005, which provided monetary relief to individual class members who had been overdetained and ordered to be detained by the District.[SENTMARKER]The case is still pending.

pegasus_output_sents: In 2002, a class of women arrested in the District of Columbia were taken to the Superior Court for presentment on D.C. warrants or code offenses and were subjected to blanket strip, visual body cavity and/or squat searches while being held in the cell block awaiting presentment.[SENTMARKER]The women filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the district of Columbia, seeking injunctive and declaratory relief and monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied both motions and certified two classes: a Fourth Amendment Class and a Fifth Amendment Class.[SENTMARKER]After the parties filed briefs in this matter in 2003, the district court entered summary judgment in favor of the District, and the case was dismissed as a matter of law.[SENTMARKER]The parties have a dispute regarding the effect of the disclosure of the unredacted documents filed in this case.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the District's motion for summary judgment and dismissed the District as a party.[SENTMARKER]The case has been pending for over five years.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 11, 2015, a deaf inmate at the District of Columbia's Correctional Treatment Facility filed this suit in the U.S. District Court in Washington, DC, alleging discrimination and retaliation in violation of the Americans with Disability Act and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The inmate claimed that he was forced to communicate with staff and other inmates only through lip-reading and written notes due to a lack of interpreter to assist him.[SENTMARKER]He also alleged that the District failed to provide him with adequate access to a qualified American Sign Language (ASL) interpreter, telecommunication devices, visual alarms and visitation.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the inmate's motion for summary judgment in part, and denied his motion for attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2009, inmates of the Manatee County Jail challenged the constitutionality of a post-card only jail policy in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]In 2010, the court ruled that the policy was reasonably related to penological interests.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs moved for reconsideration, but as of October 15, 2016, the Court had not issued any orders regarding the motion.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 4, 2009, two inmates of the Manatee County Jail, Florida, filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District, Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jail's Postcard-Only Mail Policy violated their First Amendment rights by prohibiting family members, friends, or loved ones of inmates from sending inmate mail only on postcards.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case without prejudice, stating that the plaintiffs were purporting to bring the class action for themselves and all others similarly situated.[SENTMARKER]On September 24, 2009, the court held, for a second time, that the Maricopa County Jail's "Postcard Only" mail policy was constitutional.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed, pending a decision on whether the case is moot.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 8, 1999, a group of HIV-positive inmates at the Fulton County Jail in Atlanta, Georgia filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia against the county, the county board of commissioners, and Correctional Healthcare Solutions, Inc.
