pegasus_output_sents: On January 27, 2009, a former detainee at the Cook County Jail brought a class action in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Illinois alleging that the defendants showed deliberate indifference in its administration of dental care.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary and permanent injunction against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion for a preliminary injunction, and the district court subsequently decertified one class, modified the other class, and determined that the detainees’ motion for injunctive relief was moot.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to provide dental care to all detainees at the jail.[SENTMARKER]The court of appeals granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment in favor of the defendants in the second case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to implement the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: In June 2014, an inmate at the Cook County Jail filed a class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against Cook County.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorneys' fees, and costs, alleging overcrowding and lack of funding that led to violations of Indiana state law and the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case based on counsel's representation that the alleged counts were unsupported.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2014, a pre-trial detainee at Cook County Jail in Chicago, Illinois, filed a civil rights lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Chicago against Toni Preckwinkle, the President of the Board of Commissioners of Cook County, Thomas Dart, and Cara Smith, the Executive Director of the Cook County Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that he was subject to barbaric living conditions in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment because he was not given food for 2 1/2 days, was forced to sleep in the common area of a cell block which was under construction without any mattress, pillows, or blankets, was moved after two hours’ sleep to a day room where he again was required to sleep on the floor, and was frequently moved thereafter to various holding areas over several days, at least one of which did not have access to a bathroom, forcing Plaintiff to urinate on himself.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff also alleged that as a result of the policy and custom of instituting and allowing cruel and unusual conditions of confinement at the Jail, pretrial detainees were subjected to barbaric and unusual living conditions.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the Defendants' motion to dismiss on the grounds that: (1) they were improper defendants; .[SENTMARKER](2) they failed to sufficiently allege a Monell claim; and (3) Plaintiff did not allege that the Defendants’ operation of the Jail is unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The complaint did not include any claims against the individual officers involved in the alleged perpetration of the unconstitutional acts, he alleges that the defendants’ underfunding the Jail was unconstitutional, and the Court further denied the motion for leave to amend the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on October 15, 2015.

pegasus_output_sents: In December 2015, a class action was brought against the Marion County Sheriff's Department and the City of Indianapolis under 42 U.S.C.  1983.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the sheriff's practice of not releasing inmates at the conclusion of their sentences, but rather keeping them in jail until Community Corrections is ready to process them as a group, is unreasonable and results in substantial delays in the release of these individuals.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied certification of the class because it held that the class was not "identifiable," and the district court granted certification as to two of those subclasses but denied it as to the remaining three.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the Indiana Supreme Court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted the plaintiffs' motion to transfer the case to the lower court, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff's motion for class certification was granted in part and denied in part.

gold_sents: Built in 1991, the Campbell County Detention Center was designed to hold 135 prisoners.[SENTMARKER]It quickly became overcrowded.[SENTMARKER]In the weeks before this lawsuit was filed in the district court for the Eastern District of Kentucky, on April 29, 2005, the jail's population reached a high of 276 prisoners, many of whom were forced to sleep on the floor.[SENTMARKER]Many of the inmates were awaiting transfer to the Kentucky Department of Corrections (KDOC), which was also named as a defendant in the lawsuit.[SENTMARKER]The KDOC addressed overcrowding at the jail by simply reducing the required floor space for each prisoner from 50 to 40 square feet.[SENTMARKER]This lawsuit, filed pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 1983 by attorney Robert B. Newman of the Cincinnati, Ohio, law firm Newman & Meeks, alleged the overcrowding violated the prisoners' Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, the class of inmates at the detention center, sought injunctive relief and nominal damages.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2005, several inmates at the Campbell County Detention Center in Newport, Kentucky, filed a federal lawsuit against Campbell County, Campbell County Jailer Greg Buckler, and the Kentucky Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the detention center was overcrowded and that such overcrowding caused unconstitutional conditions of confinement to exist at the Detention Center.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit was certified as a class action, which means that it has been brought on behalf of all persons currently incarcerated at the jail and all persons who will in the future be incarcerated there.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree, which was approved by the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky on November 30, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a process for and implement a Retrial Conditional Release Program, and to work with the Pretrial Services Division of the Administrative Office of the Courts in order to develop a protocol for the medical treatment of convicted felons housed in their facilities.[SENTMARKER]As part of their participation in the agreement, the parties also agreed to submit a proposed consent decree on or before 11/30/2005.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was signed by Judge William Ovington of the district court.

gold_sents: In April 2020, pretrial and post-conviction detainees at Prince George's County Jail filed this class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that in light of COVID-19, they were being held in conditions that violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]A subclass of pretrial, medically vulnerable plaintiffs also alleged that they are being held in violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On May 21, the court granted in part the plaintiff's motion for temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]Defendant appealed and were denied a stay pending their appeal.[SENTMARKER]On July 7, the plaintiffs submitted an amended complaint, pointing to the lack of mental health services during an indefinite lockdown.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint motion to stay proceedings on August 27 pending settlement talks.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 21, 2020, a class action lawsuit was filed against the Prince George’s County Department of Corrections (PGCDOC) on behalf of a group of immigration detainees held at the county jail.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jail's inadequate response to the COVID-19 pandemic violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs sought injunctive relief to address the jail’s inadequate containment strategies and conditions of confinement during the pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order and entered a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the jail to limit the number of operational entrances and exits to the facility, provide adequate medical monitoring of sick prisoners in isolation, and to release COVID-positive prisoners who have paid bail until it deems them non-contagious.[SENTMARKER]The jail refused to comply with the consent decree, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the plaintiffs have no further legal recourse.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 8, 2003, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey on behalf of individuals charged with non-indictable or minor offenses who were strip searched by corrections officers at the Camden County Correctional Facility in the City of Camden, New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants violated the Constitution's unreasonable search provisions by strip-searching all individuals who were admitted to the facility and by unlawfully detaining many of those individuals after they were released on bail.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which each class member will be entitled to an equal share of a $7.5 million settlement fund, after payment of administrative costs, incentive awards to the representative plaintiffs, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The defendants maintain that their current written policy is constitutional, and has been reviewed by the New Jersey Department of Corrections for compliance with state law.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also addresses the alleged practice of Camden County in unlawfully detentioning many members of the settlement class after they posted bail in the city.

gold_sents: In March of 2002, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice, acting pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA"), 42 U.S.C. § 1997 et seq., commenced an investigation into the conditions of confinement at the Santa Fe County Adult Detention Center in Santa Fe, New Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ concluded that the conditions and practices at the Detention Center violated the constitutional rights of convicted inmates and pre-trial detainees.[SENTMARKER]On November 11, 2004, the DOJ and Sante Fe County entered into a Memorandum of Agreement, which detailed the agreed reforms and set forth timetables for completion.[SENTMARKER]By its terms, the Agreement was to last for a period of three years, and remedy unconstitutional practices relating to: (1) medical and mental health care; .[SENTMARKER](2) suicide prevention; .[SENTMARKER](3) protection of inmates from harm; .[SENTMARKER](4) fire safety; .[SENTMARKER](5) sanitation; and (6) inmate grievance procedures (including court access).[SENTMARKER]On November 1, 2009, after a two year extension to compel Santa Fe County to meet the benchmarks in the agreement, the DOJ allowed the terms of the agreement to expire.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ is no longer monitoring the county.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2002, the United States District Court for the District of N.M.[SENTMARKER]entered into a settlement agreement with Santa Fe county, the Santa Fe adult detention center, and the county board of commissioners to resolve a civil rights lawsuit brought by the Department of Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the detention center violated the constitutional rights of inmates by failing to provide a medically appropriate diet for inmates with conditions that require the inmates to receive special diets, inadequate prenatal care for pregnant inmates, and inadequate treatment, housing, and medical supervision for drug and alcohol withdrawal.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into by the parties on March 20, 2007, and the parties agreed to resolve the case by November 1, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into the settlement agreement to end the investigation conducted pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act ("CRIPA").[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to implement a plan for the identification, treatment, and control of Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus Aureus ("MRSA") at the Detention Center.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion to dismiss the case in the District Court, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The District Court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants on November 1, 2007 and the case is closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 15, 2010, a class action was brought in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico on behalf of people with mental disabilities arrested and detained in the Doo Ana County Detention Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act and the New Mexico Constitution by failing to provide adequate mental health services to individuals with disabilities in the detention center.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought removal of this action, pursuant to the Declaratory Judgment Act, NMSA 1978,  44-6-1 to 44-615 (1975), and New Mexico common law, due to the existence of federal questions.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case was closed on January 15, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to implement a series of reforms, including the creation of a mental health unit, training for detention center staff, and other improvements.

gold_sents: This case was brought by a woman who was arested, subjected to excessive force and a strip/cavity search all on the basis of a false complaint filed by a family member.[SENTMARKER]A jury awarded her $19,645 in compensatory damages and $5,000,000 in punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed the punitive damages award as not available against municipalities, and reduced the compensatory damages award because Plaintiff had been offered slightly more as settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 7, 1997, a woman was arrested by the New York City Police Department for violating her Fourth Amendment rights when she was strip-searched by two female officers at Central Booking, where she was being held for misdemeanor charges.[SENTMARKER]The woman filed a notice of claim with the Office of the Comptroller of the City, alleging that she had been falsely arrested, that the police had employed excessive force during the arrest, and that her strip search violated the Fourth Amendment right against unreasonable search and seizure.[SENTMARKER]After a jury trial, the jury awarded the woman $19,645 in compensatory damages, $5,000,000 in punitive damages, and other damages against the individual officers involved in her case.[SENTMARKER]The City appealed, claiming that the jury's verdict was based on an official City policy that was contrary to the settled law of the Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States, however, reversed the award of punitive damages and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2009, former inmates at the Delaware County Jail filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Sheriff's Office of Delaware County was guilty of rape, sodomy, sexual battery, and blackmail.[SENTMARKER]The alleged negligence and misconduct of jailers deprived inmates of their the Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments Rights.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in 2011 for monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in May 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2011, a group of female inmates in the Delaware County, Oklahoma jail filed this civil rights lawsuit against the county, alleging that the jailers would "bargain" with the female inmates to show their breasts in exchange for cigarettes, cupcakes, snacks, candy, personal items, and other things they could not obtain for themselves while in the jail.[SENTMARKER]The women also alleged that they were sleeping in the shower because it was so crowded in the cells.[SENTMARKER]In response to the retaliation, the women who came forward with the complaints wrote a letter, which they all signed, begging for help from the outside.[SENTMARKER]The letter resulted in an investigation by the Sheriff, and the women were transferred to other jails in the county.[SENTMARKER]The Sheriff's office investigated the women's complaints and found that they had been retaliated against for their complaints.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the women filed a motion for summary judgment, which was granted by Judge James H. Payne.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the United States District Court for the Northern district of Oklahoma, where it was assigned to Judge T. Lane Wilson.[SENTMARKER]Judge Wilson entered a final judgment in favor of the women in December 2011.[SENTMARKER]The women filed an amended complaint in March 2012, which was dismissed by Judge Wilson.[SENTMARKER]The original complaint alleged that the women had been discriminated against on the basis of their race, gender, and that the county had violated their civil rights by failing to provide them with adequate medical care, adequate food, adequate clothing, adequate shelter, and adequate transportation.[SENTMARKER]The court also found that the sheriff had violated the defendants' rights to due process and due process.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case against the sheriff in March 2012.

gold_sents:
On April 21, 2005, a woman filed a class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]She alleged that the City of Philadelphia of had an unconstitutional practice of strip searching all pre-trial detainees, regardless of criminal charge or reasonable suspicion.[SENTMARKER]On February 20, 2009, the parties entered into a $5.9 million settlement.[SENTMARKER]
The Court entered final approval of the settlement on November 3, 2009.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 17, 2006, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania on behalf of individuals who were strip-searched upon entry into the Philadelphia Prison System after being charged with misdemeanors or other minor crimes.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' policy of strip-searching all pretrial detainees upon admission was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The parties engaged in extensive discovery from July 2005 until November 2005 to determine whether the policy was reasonable under the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of the constitutionality of the blanket strip search policy on January 23, 2006, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement on February 20, 2008.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement provides that thirty percent of the settlement fund will be paid to Class Counsel as an award of attorneys' fees, together with an award for the reimbursement of expenses.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also requires that all correction officers have access to the policy.

gold_sents: On August 22, 2007, the plaintiff filed suit against the County of Lancaster and the Lancaster County Prison Board in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that his constitutional rights were violated when he was strip searched in front of other inmates upon arrival at the Lancaster County Prison after being arrested for a parole violation.[SENTMARKER]He sought class action certification, declaratory judgment, a preliminary and permanent injunction, and punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement with the court on July 29, 2009 that affirmed a new policy of not strip searching detainees arrested for minor offenses and created a fund to compensate those who had been strip searched.[SENTMARKER]The case ended on April 9, 2010 when the court certified the class and granted final approval to the settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2007, a man charged with a nonfelony offense filed a class action lawsuit against the County of Lancaster and the Lancaster County Prison Board, alleging that the defendants violated his Fourth Amendment rights under color of state law by strip-searching him without reasonable suspicion that he was concealing a weapon or contraband.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in March 2009, which provided for a $2,507,200 settlement fund, with an initial contribution of $1,946,860, and required the defendants to retrain their Corrections Officers to ensure compliance with the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On September 1, 2009, the parties filed an amended complaint, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief, seeking to change practices at the prison.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for preliminary approval of the settlement, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement on July 28, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for class certification on November 11, 2007, and the case was assigned to the Honorable Paul Diamond, who presided over the case until September 1, 2009.[SENTMARKER]On November 11, 2009, Judge Diamond certified the class, which included all individuals who entered the custody of the prison and were placed in prison clothing.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on September 1, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The parties then entered into an amended settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on September 2, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement provides for a new strip search checklist and requires the prison board to train its officers to ensure that they are not strip-search individuals who are not suspected of concealing contraband or weapons.

gold_sents: Plaintiff, a county jail inmate who suffered scarring and isolation from multiple MRSA infections was successful in obtaining a settlement against county defendants for their alleged failure to implement appropriate quarantine protocols and correct medical care, and for maintaining unsanitary conditions at the jail.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 19, 2009, an inmate at the Northampton County prison in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania filed this civil rights lawsuit against the county and its private contractor, Prime Care Medical, Inc., in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants violated his Eighth Amendment rights under the Civil Rights Act of 1866, as amended, 42 U.S.C.  1983 by failing to adequately treat and/or provide adequate medical care to inmates who required medical care.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the plaintiff's allegations, and the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendant's motion for partial summary judgment, finding that the defendant had failed to show that it had violated its contract with the county.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: This class action case was brought by prisoners of the Dauphin County Prison against the County of Dauphin, PA, seeking monetary, declaratory, and injunctive relief for conducting unconstitutional and unnecessary strip searches upon all persons placed in the Dauphin County Prison, as of September 16, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in 2009, resulting in monetary and injunctive relief granted.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 16, 2007, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania on behalf of individuals charged with misdemeanor offenses who were strip-searched at the Dauphin County Prison.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their Fourth Amendment rights by strip-searching them without reasonable suspicion that the individuals were concealing a weapon or contraband.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on January 26, 2009, which created a fund of $2,160,500.00 (the "Settlement Fund") to pay for the claims of the class members, the administrative costs of the settlement, an incentive award to the named plaintiffs, and the attorneys' fees and expenses.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The court is currently considering a motion to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: The ACLU of Pennsylvania filed this class action suit on behalf of pretrial detainees in a PA jail with subclasses of those who were at a heightened risk of contracting COVID-19.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the conditions in the jail failed to meet CDC recommendations and amounted to a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction on April 9, 2020 seeking immediate release from ACJ.[SENTMARKER]The parties then began working on a consent order to implement public health measures to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 in the jail, which was approved by the court on May 27.[SENTMARKER]The consent order was extended on August 24 and the plaintiffs habeas and ADA claims remain in dispute.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 24, 2020, three individuals held at the Allegheny County Jail in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, filed this class action lawsuit against the county and the United States Department of Justice (D.C.) alleging violations of their rights under the Fourteenth Amendment and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought writs of habeas corpus as release is the only means to protect them from constitutionally deficient conditions that place them at a substantial risk of severe injury or death from the virus while at ACJ.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief and granted their motion for release from ICE detention.[SENTMARKER]On April 7, 2020, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to comply with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to implement additional safeguards to protect inmates and employees from COvid-19.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to further court approval.

gold_sents: On October 6, 2010, the Prison Legal News filed a class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for South Carolina under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against Berkeley County.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by public interest counsel, asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as damages, claiming that the defendants' unlawfully censored and excluded the plaintiff's books and magazines protected by the 1st and 14th Amendments, which are sent to individual subscribers in custody at the Berkeley County Detention Center (BCDC).[SENTMARKER]On May 3, 2011, the United States filed a Complaint in intervention pursuant to the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act, 42 U.S.C. § 14141, and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized 42 Persons Act of 2000, U.S.C. § 2000cc.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2012, Judge Sol Blatt, Jr., issued the consent injunction requiring the defendants to implement new policies regarding incoming mail and access to religious materials.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 2018, the Human Rights Defence Center and Prison Legal News filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina on behalf of inmates at the Berkeley County Detention Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the detention center's policy of prohibiting all publications sent by mail to detainees violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Act of 1994 (RLUIPA).[SENTMARKER]The parties sought injunctive and declaratory relief, including the right to receive expressive material through the mail.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order in which the parties agreed to allow detainees access to books, magazines, and other non-Christian religious texts in accordance with the First Amendment and RLUIPA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for partial summary judgment and entered a final judgment in favor of the parties.

gold_sents: This 2017 class action lawsuit was brought by a former inmate of the Davidson County Jail in the U.S. District for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendant violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments in failing to prevent the spread of scabies in the prison.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff has not yet filed a motion to certify class.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2017, a former inmate at the Metro-Davidson County Detention Facility in Nashville, Tennessee, filed a class action lawsuit against CoreCivic, a private company that owns and operates the facility, alleging that the Defendant violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution and the prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment by failing to adequately screen those entering its facility, treat those infected with scabies, respond to inmate requests for medical attention, and quarantine the infected individuals in its care.[SENTMARKER]The class is defined as all male inmates exposed to and infested with the parasite Sarcoptes scabiei (hereafter "Scabies"), who have been, or who in the future may become, housed at the Defendant's facility in Davidson County.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff and the class members were forced to endure painful, itching rashes and sleeplessness while they were housed in the facility.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant retaliated against other inmates, including inmate J.N., for requesting medical treatment.[SENTMARKER]The defendant failed and refused to train its employees upon the proper methods and means to detect, prevent, and treat scabies within its facility.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the medical conditions of Plaintiff and members of the class worsened as a result of the defendant's continued, deliberate indifference to their medical needs and the inhumane conditions of confinement within the meaning of the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff and class members have complied with all requirements of the Prison Litigation Reform Act, 42 U.S.C.   1997e(a) ("PLRA"), and had exhausted their administrative remedies.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: A deaf prisoner of the El Paso County jails sued the County in the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas for their failure to accommodate his disability.[SENTMARKER]He was held for eleven days without access to an attorney or an interpreter, in violation of the Americans With disabilities Act ans Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. A private settlement was reached in July 2012 which, according to reports, required installation of videophones in the County jails.[SENTMARKER]We have no further information about this case.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 9, 2012, a deaf man filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the County of El Paso, Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, Jose Luis Rodriguez, was in custody awaiting trial on a criminal charge.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the defendant to provide him with reasonable accommodations, including videophone devices, interpreters, and access to closed captioning.[SENTMARKER]The defendant failed to comply with the court's order and the court granted the plaintiff's motion for injunctive and declaratory relief, attorneys' fees, litigation expenses, and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 15, 2012, a group of juvenile prisoners filed a lawsuit in the Middle District of Florida against the Polk County Jail, claiming violations of their physical and medical care.[SENTMARKER]Preliminary injunction was denied.[SENTMARKER]Class certification was granted.[SENTMARKER]A bench trial was held on from November 18, 2013 to December 18, 2013.[SENTMARKER]On April 16, 2015, Judge Merryday issued an opinion denying relief to the plaintiffs, holding that plaintiffs failed to show defendants' violations of their constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 30, 2013, a group of inmates at the Central County Jail in Bartow, Florida, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida against the Polk County Sheriff's Office and Corizon Health, Inc., a health care provider retained by the Sheriff.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their Eighth Amendment rights under the Fourteenth Amendment by failing to provide them with adequate mental health care and by denying them access to their dinner trays.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment for the Sheriff but denied the officers' claim of qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court reversed the Fifth Circuit and addressed the question whether an application of excessive force can result in an Eighth Amendment violation "if the inmate does not suffer serious injury."[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Three minors represented by the Southern Poverty Law Center, Florida Justice Institute, Inc., and Florida Legal Services, filed suit on September 4, 2019 in the Northern District of Florida against the Florida Department of Juvenile Justice (DJJ).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought class action certification to represent children subject to solitary confinement in DJJ-run detention centers.[SENTMARKER]The defendant's summary judgment motion on the merits was denied on December 6, 2019, and the case is in ongoing mediation talks.
pegasus_output_sents: July 24, 2017 DATE ||||| American Disabilities Act ORG ||| 14th and Eighth Amendments LAW ||| 1343, 2201, 2202,  42 U.S.C.  1983 LAW | Florida Youth Development Center LAW | Miami-Dade County LAW |  2018 DATE | Miami Dade County ORG [CONTRACTED] On July 24, 2017, a group of children with disabilities filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Florida on behalf of children who were being held in solitary confinement at the Florida Juvenile Development Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DJJ was subjecting children diagnosed with serious mental illness, trauma, learning disabilities, intellectual disabilities, and who had engaged in acts of self-injury or attempted suicide to a risk of harm by placing them in punitive isolation in dangerous conditions.[SENTMARKER]They sought declaratory and injunctive relief requiring DJJ to cease the challenged unlawful policies and practices.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was closed on July 24, 2017.

gold_sents: DOJ's investigation of the conditions at the Hawaii Youth Correctional Facility ("HYCF") in August 2004 concluded that the facility lacked policies to protect the detained youth from abuse or suicide risks.[SENTMARKER]DOJ recommended reforms at the HYCF through a Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) that was executed by the parties.[SENTMARKER]This case was brought to retain jurisdiction of the district court of Hawaii's jurisdiction over the case until a final order is entered to dismiss the case with prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 14, 2004, the United States Attorney's Office for the District of Hawai'i filed this lawsuit in the United District Court for the district of Hawaii against the State of Hawaii and the Hawaii Department of Education.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the State failed to provide access to medical and mental health care, adequate special education instruction, and adequate harm protection measures to the youth at the Hawaii Youth correctional facility in Kailua, Hawaii.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act of 2004 and the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act of 1974 (IDEA).[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a memorandum of agreement in which the parties agreed that the DOJ would have the right to conduct unannounced visits to the facility.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that they would have no remedy or action available for the State's alleged breach of this Agreement other than the reinstatement of the complaint that this Agreement settled.[SENTMARKER]On February 9, 2006, the parties filed a joint stipulation to dismiss the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion to dismiss with prejudice, and the case was closed.

gold_sents: The Attorney General filed suit against the state of Ohio, its governor, the director of youth services, and the superintendents of its juvenile correctional facilities pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 14141 for an alleged pattern or practice of violating the rights of juvenile detainees under the 14th Amendment, the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The United States alleged that Ohio failed to protect the youth at its facilities from harm and undue risk of harm, failed to meet their medical and mental health needs, and failed to provide adequate special education services.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed as a result of Department of Justice (DOJ) investigations into the conditions of confinement at the Scioto and Marion centers that began in 2005.[SENTMARKER]The Marion facility closed soon after the first injunction in this case.[SENTMARKER]Ohio achieved substantial compliance in 2015, and the consent decree was terminated on December 3, 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2005, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) notified the State of Ohio of its intent to investigate conditions of confinement at the Scioto Juvenile Correctional Facility (Scioto) in Delaware, Ohio, pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act, 42 U.S.C.  1997, and the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994,42 U.N.C  14141.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, the Cohen Report addressed issues regarding protection from harm, medical care, mental health care, and special education at Scioto.[SENTMARKER]On June 4, 2008, the parties entered into a stipulation for injunctive relief (the Stipulation) concerning conditions at both Scioto and the Marion juvenile correctional facility.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an agreement on the resolution of the plaintiffs’ claims, which the Court approved on March 29, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties have since amended their agreement twice, and the parties have agreed to withdraw without prejudice its motion for a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]On March 29, 2011, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The Court entered a final judgment in favor of the State on March 30, 2011.[SENTMARKER]On March 30, 2012, the parties agreed to enter into a consent decree for the purpose and structure of the PROGRESS Unit.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree, which is subject to court approval, requires the State to implement a medical quality improvement program, environmental conditions, and management of special dietary needs for youth.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the State's motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice.

gold_sents: The juvenile plaintiff brought suit against the Minnehaha County Juvenile Detention Center, challenging the center's policy of strip-searching all juveniles admitted to the Detention Center, without any reasonable suspicion that the juveniles were concealing weapons or contraband.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit overturned the District Court's ruling, holding that the search of the named plaintiff did not violate the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the parties reached a monetary settlement before having to relitigate the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 1, 2000, a former juvenile detainee filed this civil rights lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of S. Dakota.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that her civil rights were violated when she was strip searched and questioned about her religious beliefs and practices.[SENTMARKER]The district court certified two classes of plaintiffs, one for injunctive relief and one for punitive damages.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to reconsider the district court's summary judgment in light of the Second Circuit's decision in NG v. Connecticut, 382 F.3d 225 (2d Cir.[SENTMARKER]2004), which held that the JDC's written search policy in effect in August 1999 was unconstitutional and that the subsequent changes to the policy did not cure the constitutional defects.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2006, the Eighth Circuit remanded the case for further proceedings consistent with its August 9th, 2006 opinion.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the amount of $75,000.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice in accordance with the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: This suit was filed May 7, 2004.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs were individuals who had been involuntarily civilly confined pursuant to Sexually Violent Predator Act into the custody of the Florida Dept.[SENTMARKER]of Children and Families in the Florida Civil Commitment Center (FCCC).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs argued that the State failed to provide adequate rehabilitive treatment necessary for their eventual recovery and release.[SENTMARKER]In November 2009, after five years of discovery and motions practice, the case settled, with the State agreeing to implement policies that addressed all the plaintiffs' allegations.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2004, a group of sex offenders who were civilly detained under the Florida Sexually Violent Predator Act filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their constitutional rights by failing to provide adequate treatment, mental health services, and on-site medical services to the residents confined at the facility.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a class-action settlement in June 2009, and the case was dismissed with prejudice in June 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint motion for approval of the settlement and dismissal of the case with prejudice on June 2009.[SENTMARKER]On June 4, 2009, the court granted the motion, removed the case from the trial calendar, and gave the parties 60 days to file a motion seeking approval of a settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved by the court on June 5, 2009.

gold_sents: On February 27, 2002, four individuals involuntarily detained by the Illinois Department of Human Services ("DHS") pursuant to the Sexually Violent Persons Commitment Act (“SVP Act”) on behalf of themselves and all others similarly situated filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for Northern Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendants failed to provide adequate and meaningful health treatment to the plaintiffs and those similarly situated and the treatment and care that was given was punitive and Constitutionally inadequate.[SENTMARKER]In 2005, Judge Leinenweber granted the plaintiffs’ demand for declaratory relief concerning the previous Special or Secure Management Status (“SMS”) used at the Joliet Treatment and Detention Facility (the “TDF”) stating that it was unconstitutional; however all of the plaintiffs’ remaining claims were denied including the claim of inadequate treatment.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 3, 2003, three civilly committed sex offenders filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the District of Northern Illinois against the Illinois Department of Human Services and the Illinois SexualLY Violent Persons Treatment Facility.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their civil rights by failing to provide them with adequate treatment and confinement conditions.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice and without costs with leave to move to reinstate on or before October 13, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiffs with education and vocational services.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]14, 2014, a number of prisoners in Louisiana filed a class action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 claiming that the state violated the ADA, Rehabilitation Act, and their 14th Amendment due process rights by keeping them incarcerated despite their being found not guilty by reason of insanity and committed by the court to the state's mental health facility.[SENTMARKER]On July 18, 2016, the Court dismissed the case without prejudice to the right to reopen it within sixty days if the parties did not settle.[SENTMARKER]The parties subsequently settled, agreeing to send individuals found not guilty due to insanity to mental health institutions.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 19, 2014, the Advocacy Center for the mentally ill filed this class action lawsuit in the United States district court for the middle district of Louisiana against the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals (DHH) alleging that the defendants violated the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (RA) by failing to provide adequate mental health care to individuals who were found not guilty by reason of insanity (NGRI) and committed to a mental health facility pursuant to the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The class was represented by counsel experienced in the prosecution of class actions.[SENTMARKER]On November 16, 2016, the parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs' reasonable attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that they would submit a report to the court on the first working day of each month beginning November 16, 2016 and that the parties would have thirty (30) days from the date of the settlement to come into or establish compliance with the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion for judicial enforcement on November 16, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on December 19, 2016.

gold_sents: This was a class-action lawsuit in which the plaintiffs alleged that the Commonwealth of Massachusetts had failed to provide medically necessary services as required under the federal Medicaid Act, and that it had failed to inform parents and children that they were entitled to these covered services.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Commonwealth violated provisions of the federal Medicaid Act by failing to provide home-based services to thousands of children across the state.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the district court approved a remedial plan intended to restructure the children’s mental health system by incorporating intensive home-based services, including behavioral health screenings, assessments, case management, crisis intervention and in-home therapeutic supports.[SENTMARKER]It also appointed a monitor to oversee implementation and compliance.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to extend the monitor’s appointment several times, with the final extension expiring on December 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion to again extend the monitor’s appointment; the First Circuit overturned this ruling on May 4, 2020.[SENTMARKER]As of August 2020, the extension is before the district court on remand.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 31, 2001, a class of Medicaid-eligible children, acting through their parents or guardians, filed this class action lawsuit in the United States district court for the district of Massachusetts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Medicaid Act's provisions covering early and periodic screening, diagnostic, and treatment services (" EPSDT"), as well as the statute's "reasonable promptness" requirements for providing those services to low-income children suffering from serious emotional disturbances ("SED").[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on three grounds.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion, and the parties agreed to a joint remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendants would not require a primary care visit or EPSDT screening as a prerequisite for an eligible child to receive MassHealth behavioral health services.[SENTMARKER]The court issued a final judgment, largely adopting the Commonwealth's proposed remedial plan, in June 2013.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed and the case was remanded to the First Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The First Circuit affirmed the district court's final judgment in January 2006, holding that the Commonwealth had violated Medicaid Act provisions by failing to provide with reasonable promptness and EPSDT services to SED children.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The U.S. sued the State of Mississippi under the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. alleged that the State knowingly failed to provide adequate mental health programs for adults with mental illness and segregated adults with disabilities in their State-run hospitals.[SENTMARKER]After a four-week bench trial, the court found that the health system violated the ADA and required a special master to determine and oversee the remedial process.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2016, the United States filed this lawsuit against the State of Mississippi under Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) alleging that the State was violating the ADA by requiring thousands of Mississippi residents with mental illness or developmental disabilities to receive services in state-run psychiatric hospitals instead of community-based services.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the state's policies, practices, and actions have led to the unnecessary segregation of individuals with mental illnesses in state hospitals and placed many other individuals at serious risk of institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The parties have stipulated that Mississippi must comply with the ADA and its implementing regulations.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the court granted the State's motion for summary judgment, finding that it had not adequately articulated a necessary element of the claim.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants' motion for a declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 15, 1996, the United States filed a lawsuit under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997, against the State of Tennessee, the Tennessee Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation (DMH/MR) and the Memphis Mental Health Institute (MMHI), in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee, Memphis Division.[SENTMARKER]On March 15, 1996, the same day as the complaint was filed, the parties submitted a joint motion for entry of a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]Under the settlement agreement the defendants agreed to implement all policies, systems, procedures and rules currently in place, to provide quarterly status reports, provide the government access to the facilities, records, patients, and employees of MMHI, and to confer in good faith on the provisions of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On May 21, 1997, the Court entered judgment in accordance with the consent decree and terminated the case, retaining jurisdiction for necessary enforcement of the decree.[SENTMARKER]And, on September 18, 1998, the District Court (Judge Gibbons) granted the parties' joint motion for a stipulation and order, effectuating the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]On June 21, 2005, the District Court (Judge Bernice B. pegasus_output_sents: On March 15, 1996, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this civil rights class action in the United States District Court for the Western District of Tennessee on behalf of mentally ill patients at the Memphis Mental health Institute (MMHI) in Memphis, Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, pursuant to the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), the patients were deprived of their constitutional rights to adequate medical care and treatment as an appropriate professional would consider reasonable to ensure their safety and freedom from undue bodily and chemical restraints.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, in April 1991, the DOJ first informed state officials that conditions at MMHI, including a lack of professional and direct care staff, posed unreasonable risks to the health and safety of MMHI patients in violation of the civil rights act.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ then notified the Governor of Tennessee, the Attorney General, and the Commissioner of Mental Health and Mental Retardation of its intent to investigate allegations of unconstitutional conditions at the MMHI.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, 1998, the parties entered into a consent decree (Conviction Decree) in which the parties agreed that, among other things, the practice of restraining patients and placing patients in a locked-door room must cease immediately.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required that MMHI provide adequate, professional nursing care to its patients.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that there would be no further violations of the consent decree unless there was a violation of any of the terms of the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The Consent Decree was entered in effect on March 15, 1996.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs in March 1996 and the case is closed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On January 29, 2014, the defendant in this case filed this suit in the United States District Court in the Northern district of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The defendant alleged that the government's investigation of the defendant did not violate the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA), so the court ordered the government to disclose to defense counsel highly sensitive classified information based on Section 106 of FISA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion in part and denied in part without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the Supreme Court in June 2013 for lack of Article III standing.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit reversed the district court's order in June 2014 and held that the investigation did not violated the law.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a hearing on the issue of whether disclosure was necessary to determine the legality of the challenged FISA collection, as required by FISA, and the parties agreed that the defendant was competent to stand trial.

gold_sents: On October 17, 2013, the ACLU filed a lawsuit requesting an injunction forcing the DOJ to comply with a FOIA request regarding their policy on giving notice to criminal defendants against whom it intends to use evidence obtained from warrantless surveillance, including information obtained under surveillance orders authorized by the FISA Amendments Act § 702.[SENTMARKER]On March 3, 2105, the court granted part of each party's motion for summary judgment, and issued an order requiring the DOJ to conduct a further search for responsive documents, and disclose any that were not subject to FOIA exemptions.[SENTMARKER]On September 27, 2016, the court granted part of each party's motion for summary judgment, ruling that the DOJ's searches were adequate, and that all but one of the documents found by the DOJ were protected by FOIA's Exemption 5.[SENTMARKER]On May 2, 2017, the Court granted DOJ's renewed motion for summary judgment, finding that the remaining documents were properly withheld under FOIA Exemption 5.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 29, 2013, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request with the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) seeking records related to the government’s use of evidence derived from warrantless surveillance in criminal prosecutions.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU challenged the adequacy of the DOJ’s search and the applicability of Exemption 5 to the withheld documents, and the parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment on these two issues.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the government's summary judgment motion in part, finding that the DOJ had improperly limited its search under part 3 of its FOIA request by reading the word "added" into the request where it had not been written, and ordered DOJ to conduct a new search without the improperly-governing term and to release any responsive records not entitled to be searched under Exemption 5.[SENTMARKER]On March 3, 2015, the Court granted the DOJ's motion for summary judgement on the issue of whether Exemption 5 applied to the documents.[SENTMARKER]On October 17, 2013, the ACLU filed this lawsuit in the Southern District of New York, seeking an injunction requiring the DOJ to process its request, after DOJ failed to respond timely to the ACLU’s request.[SENTMARKER]After the ACLU's complaint, the National Security Division (NSD) identified five responsive documents, all of which were subsequently withheld by the DOJ.[SENTMARKER]The Court concluded that Exemption 5 applies only to documents that do not contain segregable information components and that the documents are protected with respect to NSD documents.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed cross motions for summary judgments on the issues of adequacy and applicability of exemption and the application of exemption.[SENTMARKER]On September 27, 2016, the court granted summary judgment for the DOJ on both of these issues, with the exception of the documents listed in the NSD’s Vaughn index.

Berman dismissed this case with prejudice due to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]NSA shall pay to the plaintiff $11,000, CIA shall pay $6,500, National Security Division shall pay $6,500, FBI shall pay $6,500, and ODNI shall pay $4,500.[SENTMARKER]The settlement amount totaled $35,000.[SENTMARKER]The court may retain jurisdiction over any issues that may arise relating to this order.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 17, 2016, the ACLU filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) action in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the National Security Agency (NSA), the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI), the Department of Justice (DOJ), and Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) seeking records related to Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) in order to inform the public about actual or alleged federal government activity.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, on or about September 14, 2016, Plaintiffs submitted a FOIA request to the NSA, ODNI, DOJ, and CIA seeking records relating to the FISA.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought expedited processing of the request on the grounds that there is a "compelling need" for these records because the information requested is urgently needed by an organization primarily engaged in disseminating information to the public.[SENTMARKER]The complaint further sought an injunction requiring the defendants to process the request immediately, an order enjoining them from assessing fees for processing the request, and an order to release the requested records to plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]On November 18, 2016, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed with prejudice.

gold_sents: On Apr.[SENTMARKER]12, 2017, the ACLUs of Virginia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, and Delaware sued DHS under FOIA, for information on the implementation of the travel ban Executive Orders at regional airports.[SENTMARKER]Defendants were unable to consolidate all nationwide ACLU cases in multidistrict litigation, and this case is proceeding here.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 27, 2017, the ACLU of Virginia and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) filed this Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) case in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU sought records related to the implementation of President Trump's executive orders barring refugees and other individuals from several predominantly Muslim countries from entering local ports of entry.[SENTMARKER]The case initially was brought as a class action, but the class was subsequently decertified by stipulation of both parties.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint status report on February 22, 2017, seeking expedited processing of FOIA requests to provide the public with information about how the Baltimore Customs Field Office read and implemented the executive orders.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for transfer to an as yet-to-be-created MDL, and the parties agreed to file a joint report no later than February 22, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion to transfer the case to a new MDL.[SENTMARKER]The MDL is expected to be completed by the end of the year.[SENTMARKER]On April 12, 2017, the parties filed this motion to enter a stay pending a ruling by the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation (JPML) on the parties’ motion to centralize the case.[SENTMARKER]The JPML granted the defendants’ motion and granted the plaintiffs’ request for expedited processing.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed an emergency motion to dismiss the case, which was denied by the court on April 12, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the MDL on April 13, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be transferred to an MDL and that the FOIA requests would be processed on a rolling basis.

gold_sents: In 2015, two foreign nationals and the estate of a third foreign national filed this suit in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants committed human rights abuses against them, including torture, non-consensual human experimentation, and war crimes, during their detention by the United States.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled via a confidential settlement agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 13, 2015, a group of alleged al-Qa'ida members brought suit against two psychologists who allegedly designed, implemented, and personally administered an experimental torture program for the United States Central Intelligence Agency.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants, James Elmer Mitchell and John Bruce Jessen, were psychologists who worked as independent contractors with the CIA.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs were subjected to solitary confinement; extreme darkness, cold, and noise; repeated beatings; starvation; excruciatingly painful stress positions; prolonged sleep deprivation; confinement in coffin-like boxes; and water torture.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the action based on the political question doctrine, which the court denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is currently on appeal to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The parties have filed cross-motions for 16 summary judgment motions, which have been denied.

gold_sents: After the DOJ indicates that it believes a North Carolina law limiting transgender individuals access to bathrooms violates federal law, president Pro Tempore of the North Carolina Senate and the Speaker of the North Carolina House of Representatives bring suit in federal court asking the Eastern District Court of North Carolina to declare that the law doesn't violate the laws cited by the DOJ and to declare that the DOJ action is illegal and unconstitutional.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 4, 2016, the U.S. Department of Justice sent letters to North Carolina public officials and agencies informing them that, by complying with Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Violence Against Women Act of 2013, they were engaging in a pattern or practice of discrimination in violation of three federal civil rights laws.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, the leaders of both chambers of the North Carolina General Assembly, and the American Civil Liberties Union of North Carolina, filed this declaratory judgment action against the defendants in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of the Carolinas.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to intervene, finding that the defendants had not violated the plaintiffs' due process and due process rights.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a motion to dismiss the case, claiming that the plaintiffs had not shown that Title VII and the VAWA had been violated.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 6, 2016, and the parties agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: In June 2014, a same-sex couple who had been lawfully married outside the State of Alabama filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama against the State of Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that Alabama's refusal to recognize the marriages of same-sex couples validly entered into outside of the State violated the Due Process Clause and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Subsequent to the Obergefell decision in June 2015 by the Supreme Court, Judge R. pegasus_output_sents: On January 1, 2004, several groups of Medi-Cal providers (physicians, dentists, pharmacists and beneficiaries) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the State of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought to enjoin a five percent cutback in reimbursement rates that was recently mandated by the California Legislature and is scheduled to take effect on January 1, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs contend that the rate reduction violates the Medicaid statute, particularly the quality of care 5 and equal access provisions, and they seek a preliminary 6 injunction preventing the State from implementing the 8 rate reduction.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, and the case was dismissed on the basis of 11th Amendment immunity.[SENTMARKER]The parties then appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 30, 2010, entities that represented Medicaid service providers filed this lawsuit in federal court against the California Department of Health Care Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs represented intermediate care facilities for the developmentally disabled and other facilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctions preventing California from implementing legislation that would freeze Medicaid reimbursement rates for these facilities.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs sought relief under the Supremacy Clause of the United States Constitution and 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted a preliminary injunction, which was vacated and remanded following the defendants’ appeal.[SENTMARKER]On June 9, 2014, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The next day, Judge Snyder dismissed the consolidated case and ordered each party to bear its own attorney’s fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 22, 2008, a group of developmentally disabled and mentally retarded persons (ICF/DD facilities) filed a lawsuit in the Central district of California alleging that the State of California's Medicaid program, Medi-Cal, was violating the terms of Section 14105.191(f) of the California Health and Safety Code by imposing a permanent freeze on the reimbursement rates paid to certain nursing facilities that are part of 20 hospitals (distinct part/nursing facilities or "DPINFs") and subacute pediatric 21 subacute care units (FSPs) for the developmentally disabled.[SENTMARKER]On August 18, 2008, the district court issued a preliminary injunction ordering the State to refrain from imposing the freeze.[SENTMARKER]On November 24, 2009, the California Hospital Association filed a similar suit in the same district court, challenging, among other things, the State's imposition of a permanent "freeze" on the payment of reimbursement rates to nursing facilities.[SENTMARKER]On April 30, 2011, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction and remanded the case to the State for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2013, the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed the District Court's decision in favor of the State.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: This lawsuit arose out of the funding provisions for elementary and secondary schools in the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) of 2020.[SENTMARKER]Filed by eight states (California, Michigan, Hawaii, Maine, Maryland, New Mexico, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin), Washington D.C., and four school districts (Chicago, Cleveland, New York City, and San Francisco), the lawsuit challenged a July 1, 2020 interim final rule from the Department of Education about how the funds may be distributed between private and public schools.[SENTMARKER]On August 26, 2020, the court granted a preliminary injunction prohibiting enforcement of the interim final rule.[SENTMARKER]On November 9, the court approved a permanent injunction that prevented the defendants from implementing the April 30 guidance and July 1 rule and from taking any action inconsistent with the proportional share formula in Section 1117 or other restrictions or penalties on the use of CARES Act funds.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction over the case for enforcement purposes.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 2020, a lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Education and Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos by the State of New Mexico, the Cleveland Municipal School District Board of Education, the City of Chicago, and the Oakland Unified School District.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Department's use of emergency funds for public school students affected by the COVID-19 pandemic was arbitrary and capricious in several respects.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged violations of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory relief, injunctive relief, and other relief pursuant to the Declaratory Judgment Act and the APA.[SENTMARKER]On August 26, 2020, the court granted a preliminary injunction barring the Department from implementing or enforcing against the plaintiffs, for violation of the spending principles; ultra- vires action; violation of separation of 10 principles; and the spending clause of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
