pegasus_output_sents: In August 2018, residents of Kentucky and Arkansas brought this lawsuit against the United States District Court for the District of Washington, alleging that the federal government's approval of the state's new Medicaid work requirements violated the Administrative Procedure Act, the Social Security Act, and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for intervention, which was granted on September 6, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a joint motion for summary judgment, which the court granted on April 4, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On April 10, 2019, the court entered final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties have now come back to the court for further consideration and have filed cross-motions for summary judgement.

gold_sents: In 2018, the Campaign Legal Center filed this lawsuit to compel the Department of Justice to comply with a Freedom of Information Act request by produce documents pertaining to the inclusion of a citizenship question on the 2020 United States census.[SENTMARKER]In 2020, summary judgment was granted for the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The government has since appealed.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 1, 2018, the Campaign Legal Center (CLC) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Justice (DOJ) seeking records related to the addition of a citizenship question to the 2020 Census Questionnaire.[SENTMARKER]On February 9, 2018, CLC submitted the FOIA request to the Office of the Attorney General (OAG) and the Justice Management Division (JMD), which are components of the DOJ.[SENTMARKER]The OAG responded to CLC's request on February 9, 2018 and provided the requested records to the Census Bureau.[SENTMARKER]On May 21, 2019, CLC filed a motion for summary judgment against the OAG and JMD, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]On June 1, 2020, the court granted summary judgment in favor of CLC, but denied the DOJ's motion to redact 20 pages and withhold 43 pages of the requested documents.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the plaintiffs' motion for injunctive relief.

gold_sents: In June 2020, the Trump Administration's Department of Health and Human Services issued a revised regulation under Section 1557 of the Affordable Care Act that limited protections for discrimination against LGBTQ individuals.[SENTMARKER]A group of LGBTQ-focused private healthcare providers, organizations providing community services, health professional associations, and individual providers filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the revised rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act, First Amendment, and the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On September 2, the court found that the plaintiffs had standing for most of their claims, and enjoined the Administration from implementing two provisions: (1) the 2020 Rule's elimination of "sex stereotyping" from the 2016 Rule's definition of "discrimination on the basis of sex" and (2) the 2020 Rule's use of Title IX's exemption of certain religious organizations from the statute’s nondiscrimination mandate.[SENTMARKER]It denied relief for the 2020 Rule's elimination of the 2016 Rule’s prohibition on categorical coverage exclusions for gender-affirming care, repeal of the 2020 Rule's notice requirements, and alleged violation of Section 1554, in addition to the plaintiffs' constitutional claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2019, a private health-care provider and two national associations of health professionals filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) seeking class-action status.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Affordable Care Act's (ACA) Section 1557 prohibition on discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity (gender identity) prohibited discrimination in health care because of an individual's individual religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2020, the Supreme Court held that this discrimination was based on sex, and the ACA's final rule, the 2016 Final Rule, was overturned by the Trump administration.[SENTMARKER]The final rule was implemented on July 1, 2019, and the parties filed this complaint on March 23, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought a preliminary injunction, in part, to enjoin HHS from enforcing its definition of sex discrimination insofar as it included gender identity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for summary judgment, granted their motion for preliminary injunction, and set aside the final rule.[SENTMARKER]The parties also filed a motion for class action status.[SENTMARKER]On July 1, 2020, the court granted their request for a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]In a parallel case, the Eastern District Court granted a temporary injunction against HHS on June 15, 2019.

gold_sents: The U.S. Department of Justice Civil Rights Division entered into this court-enforceable settlement agreement with Delaware in 2011 to remedy unconstitutional conditions in its state psychiatric hospital and to provide community-based services to prevent the unnecessary institutionalization of individuals with mental illness.[SENTMARKER]The State achieved full compliance with the agreement, and the case was closed in 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 16, 2013, the Department of Justice (DOJ) and the State of Delaware (D.C.) entered into a settlement agreement to resolve allegations of violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) with respect to the services provided to persons with mental illness at the Delaware Psychiatric Center (DPC) and other settings across the State.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement agreement, the DPC was required to provide community-based mental health services to low-income individuals with the disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the state on July 26, 2016, concluding that the state had fully complied with the settlement terms.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by a woman who was homeless and living in a hotel, who alleged that DPC did not provide adequate housing and services for her and other individuals with disabilities, and that she was unnecessarily institutionalized due to the lack of adequate community support and services.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into as an order of the court, and the parties agreed to a joint motion to dismiss the case, which was granted by the court on July 26.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into the agreement in July 2012 and the final judgment was entered in July 2016.

gold_sents: On January 15, 2008, a group of Medicaid-eligible adults with disabilities that were confined to a nursing-home facility filed a class action in U.S. District Court against Florida's Health Care Administration and Department of Elder Affairs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the state discriminated against them by failing to offer services that would enable them to live in a community setting.[SENTMARKER]After a bench trial, the court entered judgment for one of the named plaintiffs and decertified the class that he had previously approved.[SENTMARKER]In part because of recent legislation that greatly improved the state's efficiency at moving eligible persons from nursing homes to community living, the court determined that the conditions allowing for the class no longer existed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2010, a group of individuals with disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Florida against the Florida Agency for Health Care Administration and the Florida Department of Elder Affairs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the state was unnecessarily requiring Medicaid beneficiaries to enter or remain in nursing homes in order to receive care they could and should have received in the community.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss, and the plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction requiring the state to provide Medicaid coverage for a certified nursing assistant.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss and the case was dismissed on June 22, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Eleventh Circuit, which affirmed the district court's dismissal of the class certification order.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On September 6, 2011, a resident of Florida and applicant for Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) assistance filed this 42 U.S.C. § 1983 class action against the Florida Department of Children and Families in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida, Orlando Division.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff claimed that Florida's TANF application requirement that all applicants undergo suspicionless drug testing in order to be considered for assistance constituted an unreasonable search under the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court has issued a preliminary injunction and has certified the class action; an appeal of the injunction to the Eleventh Circuit is pending.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 6, 2011, a Florida resident, Luis W. Lebron, filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida, seeking to enjoin the enforcement of Florida’s mandatory suspicionless drug testing statute as a violation of his and all other applicants’ Fourth Amendment right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the State's motion for a preliminary injunction, and the State agreed to discontinue its drug testing regime as to all applicants until this litigation was fully resolved.[SENTMARKER]On October 24, 2011, the district court issued a final summary judgment in favor of the State, concluding that the state had established a substantial likelihood of success on the merits of this action.[SENTMARKER]The State then appealed the final judgment to the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court upheld the preliminary injunction and denied the state's request for a rehearing.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs were a lesbian couple who filed a complaint on July 20, 2004 challenging the Federal Defense of Marriage Act, as well as Florida's implementation of the statute, as violating the Full Faith and Credit Clause, the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Privileges and Immunities Clause, and the Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution, and sought declaratory relief.[SENTMARKER]On January 19, 2005, the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida held that DOMA falls within Congress' power under the Full Faith and Credit Clause, the right to same-sex marriage is not a fundamental right under the Constitution, and that DOMA passes the rational basis review test and does not violate the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]The Court dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 1, 2004, two same-sex couples filed this lawsuit in the Middle district of Florida against the U.S. Attorney General's Office and the State of Florida, alleging that the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and Florida statutes violated the Fourteenth Amendment and the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were married in Massachusetts and held a valid marriage license from that State.[SENTMARKER]They asked the court to declare DOMA unconstitutional and to enjoin enforcement of the laws.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case was dismissed on August 10, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled in favor of DOMA in a similar case in 2006, and the Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit held that the right to marry a person of the same sex is a fundamental right that is protected by the Constitution.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 24, 2012, Disability Rights Florida, Inc., a not-for-profit organization serving Florida's federally funded protection and advocacy system for individuals with disabilities, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida against the Agency for Health Care Administration (AHCA) and the Florida Department of Elder Affairs (EDA) alleging that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Medicaid Act (MDA) by failing to provide notice to persons with developmental disabilities of their right to a hearing upon their placement into the Aged and Disabled Adult Waiver program (A/DA Waiver) priority category.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, as of September 2010, there were at least 115 persons on the A/DA waiver waiting list residing in nursing facilities.[SENTMARKER]The individual named plaintiffs were all on the waiting list for the Florida Medicaid Developmental Disabilities Waiver program.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that defendants failed to provide written notice to each of the named plaintiffs of their rights under the ADA and MDA.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case on May 24, 2012 and the case was settled on July 3, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed from the active docket of the court on July 9, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to provide each named plaintiff with a community placement.[SENTMARKER]The case remains open.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs, individuals in Georgia with developmental disabilities and/or mental illness, challenged the state's change in coverage for a Medicaid-funded community-based program, alleging that this change put them at risk of unnecessary institutionalization in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The parties ultimately settled and the state agreed to provide the Plaintiffs with community-based services.
pegasus_output_sents: In September 2010, a group of individuals with mental disabilities filed this lawsuit against the State of Georgia and the Georgia Department of Community Health alleging that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 by terminating their Medicaid-funded services under the Service Options Using Resources in a Community Environment (SOURCE) program.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to preserve their receipt of care in the community.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction, and the parties entered a settlement agreement on December 18, 2012.[SENTMARKER]Under the settlement agreement, the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiffs with services for as long as they continue to satisfy the eligibility criteria for such services.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay the Atlanta Aid Society, Inc. a total of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) as attorney's fees and court costs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In September of 2011, one eighteen-year-old and four minor residents of Georgia with significant medical issues sued the agency responsible for administering Medicaid in Georgia.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the agency's decisions to deny or reduce hours of in-home, private nursing care violated the Medicaid act, the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]Two of the Plaintiffs settled and some of the Medicare, as well as the Fifth an Fourteenth Amendment Allegations were dismissed on summary Judgment, however, the District Court found for the Defendants on the remaining allegations.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed this decision and the Court of Appeals dismissed the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The district court also awarded attorneys' fees to the plaintiff, which was affirmed by the Court of Appeals.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 2010, four Medicaid-eligible children with significant medical needs filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Georgia's Medicaid program, the Georgia Pediatric Program (GAPP), violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, and the Georgia Public Health Act (GPH) by denying them private duty nursing services when they were medically necessary to correct or ameliorate their medical conditions.[SENTMARKER]On June 19, 2012, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and a declaratory judgment in violation of the ADA.[SENTMARKER]On August 2, 2012, the Court denied the plaintiffs’ motion to certify a class, finding that the plaintiffs had not established the numerosity requirement.[SENTMARKER]The court also found that the defendants had violated the GPH's GPH policy by denying or reducing services to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]On September 14, 2011, the defendants filed a motion for summary judgment, arguing that all of the claims should be dismissed with respect to the ADA and GPH policies.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendants' summary judgment motion and denied the class certification motion.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have entered into a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: On March 25, 2010, plaintiffs, minors with serious disabilities who were Medicaid recipients, filed this class-action lawsuit was filed in federal court against the Secretary of the Indiana Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA) and Director of the Office of Medicaid Policy and Planning of FSSA.[SENTMARKER]They all had been receiving medically necessary therapies paid for by the State's Medicaid program, administered by the FSAA, for several years.[SENTMARKER]These therapies were necessary to ensure the plaintiffs' conditions would not deteriorate and that they would not lose functional ability.[SENTMARKER]The FSSA had denied the named plaintiffs and others similarly situated continuing access to these therapies, citing two provisions of the Indiana Administrative Code.[SENTMARKER]On February 10, 2011, the Court granted summary judgment in favor of the Plaintiffs, issuing a permanent injunction preventing the Defendants and their successors from limiting or denying coverage for prescribed physical, occupational, or respiratory therapy, and/or speech pathology, for any person under 21 enrolled in the State's Medicaid program when such denial or limitation was based upon the two disputed provisions.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2010, a group of seriously disabled Medicaid recipients filed this class action lawsuit against the Indiana Family & Social Services Agency (FSSA) alleging violations of the federal Medicaid Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that FSSA's policy and practice of denying or limiting coverage for therapies prescribed by a Medicaid recipient's physician, refusing to cover maintenance therapy, and/or denying therapies for more than two years without a significant change in medical condition violated federal Medicaid law.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that between May 1, 2008 and May 1, 2010, FSSA denied 49 requests from Medicaid recipients who had further treatment pre-scribed by their providers.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and granted their request for a permanent injunctive injunction.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Seventh Circuit affirmed the district court's decision to grant summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 28, 2018, the NAACP and Prince George’s County, Maryland filed a claim against the U.S. Census Bureau and President Donald Trump for neglecting their constitutional duty to administer a fair and accurate census of the US population.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that underfunding and the flawed design of the 2020 Census might lead to undercounts of the US population in violation of the Enumeration Clause and to the detriment of minority populations, as the census count is tied to both public funding and governmental representation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs requested an injunction to require the US to develop a plan to ensure a fair and accurate count.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the claim for injunctive relief as unripe because census preparations were ongoing, but allowed the claim on underfunding to continue.[SENTMARKER]The court also allowed the plaintiffs to add two claims under the Administrative Procedure Act. On April 16, 2020, the court granted the government’s motion to dismiss; the case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 19, 2019, the Maryland NAACP filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland alleging that the Census Bureau was violating the Administrative Procedures Act (APA) by failing to adequately prepare for the 2020 Census.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that the Bureau's funding was inadequate.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the plaintiffs' claims for failure to state a claim and for lack of justiciability.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the plaintiffs appealed the district court's dismissal of the APA claims, which were dismissed on jurisdictional grounds.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the plaintiffs have agreed to dismiss their claims against President Trump.

gold_sents: On December 18, 2009 three young adult residents of Maine who were Medicaid recipients and who were diagnosed with cerebral palsy, filed a lawsuit against the Commissioner of the Maine Department of Health and Human Services in her official capacity.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed in the United States District Court for the District of Maine.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that DHHS had violated Title II of the ADA and other federal laws.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs alleged that the State had failed to accommodate Plaintiffs' disabilities and to provide medically necessary treatment in the most integrated setting possible, instead forcing them into nursing homes where they were functionally segregated from the outside world.[SENTMARKER]In August, 2010, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint reframing the case as a class action on behalf of all similarly situated Maine residents.[SENTMARKER]The parties began settlement discussions shortly thereafter.[SENTMARKER]On May 2, 2012, the Court (Judge Nancy Torresen) approved the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the State to establish a Medicaid Home and Community Based Waiver (HCBW) program, which would provide a limited number of qualifying class-members the opportunity to live in community-based settings.[SENTMARKER]The case is presumably closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 18, 2009, three individuals with developmental disabilities brought a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine against the Commissioner of the Department of Health and Human Services for the State of Maine for violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Medicaid Act, and the Nursing Home Reform Act (NHRA) by failing to provide them with adequate services that could enable them to live in the community.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the ADA, NHRA, and NHRA by denying them the specialized services they needed to be able to move out of nursing facilities and into a home that could meet their physical needs.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiffs with services in a community-based, integrated setting.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on July 15, 1999, requiring the defendants to comply with the terms of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay the plaintiffs and the class members a total of $325,000 in legal fees and costs.

gold_sents: On April 14, 2014, several same-sex couples married in Michigan on March 22, 2014 filed this § 1983 civil rights action against the State in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the American Civil Liberties Union and private counsel, asked the court to declare that the same-sex marriage ban was unconstitutional when applied to Michigan's same-sex couples, to enjoin the State of Michigan from refusing to recognize those marriages, and to award attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]On January 15, 2015, the District Court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 22, 2014, eight same-sex couples filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the State of Michigan, the Michigan Department of Human Services, and the Michigan Office of Retirement Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that Michigan's ban on marriage for same sex couples violated the due-process and equal-protection provisions of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on March 22, 2014.[SENTMARKER]On March 26, 2014, the Sixth Circuit issued a stay of the district court's decision.[SENTMARKER]On March 28, 2014, the Supreme Court ruled that the federal government should recognize the marriages performed in Michigan that day.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have filed a petition for a writ of certiorari.

gold_sents: Individuals with developmental disabilities who received home-based services under one of North Carolina's Medicaid waiver programs, challenged allegedly unreasonably and arbitrary reductions in their services under a new formula for calculating need.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction in March 2012.[SENTMARKER]The Fourth Circuit the denied the defendants' appeal of the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On April 6, 2015, the District Court approved the parties' proposed settlement agreement and the case was dismissed with prejudice on December 31, 2015.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 2011, a group of Medicaid recipients with severe developmental disabilities filed a class action lawsuit against the N.[SENTMARKER]Innovations program, a community-based federal Medicaid waiver approved by the federal secretary of health and human services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated the Social Security and Due Process clauses of the Medicaid Act and the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction in the form of a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The court further ruled that defendants had failed to comply with those requirements and ordered defendants to reinstate services to their prior levels without a hearing.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the district court's decision, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was brought by individuals in Nebraska who were eligible for and had applied for or attempted to apply for home and community-based developmental disability services.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs brought the case against the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services Finance and Support seeking declaratory and injunctive relief prohibiting Defendants from violating the ADA and various Medicaid laws and requiring them to adopt practices aimed at providing eligible persons with developmental disability services in home and community-based settings.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs also sought litigation expenses, costs, and attorney's fees.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2003, a group of developmentally disabled Nebraska residents filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nebraska alleging that the state violated the Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to properly allocate funding to individuals with developmental disabilities who are eligible for home and community-based Medicaid-funded services.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case with prejudice, holding that the plaintiffs were not prevailing parties and denied their application for attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed, claiming that the district court did not have jurisdiction to decide the issue of attorney's fees because the case was settled in March 2008 and the parties had not filed a joint motion to dismiss with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States (S.C.) granted the plaintiffs' motion for a declaratory judgment, finding that the defendants had not violated the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the plaintiffs have moved to dismiss the case on various grounds, including that they were not entitled to attorneys’ fees.

gold_sents: This case was brought on behalf of individuals in New York City jails with mental illness and chemical dependency seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to require the state to provide sufficient treatment programs instead of incarceration.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on March 11, 2008, because named Plaintiff's claims were moot.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 20, 2003, a group of individuals with mental disabilities filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District, New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504) by failing to reasonably accommodate plaintiffs and class members in residential treatment programs for mental illness and substance addiction.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case on the single ground that the plaintiffs had failed to exhaust administrative remedies as required by the PLRA.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion to intervene, which was granted by the district court on October 20, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into an agreement in which the parties agreed that the parties would work together to develop a plan to address the issues raised in the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On March 29, 2018, four transgender persons filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the Director of the Ohio Department of Health under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]Represented by the ACLU, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief as well as attorneys’ fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs summary judgment on December 16, 2020, following a failed attempt by the government to have the case dismissed for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]On February 1, 2021, the plaintiffs filed a motion for attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]On March 26, the court stayed this motion pending a joint status report detailing the discussions between the parties on the attorney fees motion and the government's compliance with the December 16 order.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered that a joint status report be submitted no later than July 26, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 29, 2018, four transgender individuals filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio against the State of Ohio, the Ohio Department of Health, and the Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles (Ohio BMV) alleging that the State's policy prohibiting transgender people from correcting the gender marker on their birth certificates to match their gender identity violates their constitutional rights to equal protection, due process, and freedom of speech.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Ohio BMV allows transgender people to change the sex on their driver's license and state ID card to reflect an individual's gender identity, but the State refuses to do so.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs allege that they have been harassed and menaced in their work as truck drivers because of the incorrect gender marker.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]On July 6, 2018, the court granted the defendants' emergency motion for stay of the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 14, 2014, a group of same-sex couples sued the State of Oregon, the County of Multnomah County, and the Oregon Family Fairness Act, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief for the violation of their rights under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by a not-for-profit organization that works to advance the rights of lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender Oregonians through education and advocacy.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, finding that Oregon's marriage statute was unconstitutional and that the County began to issue marriage licenses to same-Sex couples.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case on the grounds that the plaintiffs had failed to show that there was a substantial likelihood that they would prevail on the merits of the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then appealed the decision to the Oregon Court of Appeals, which remanded the case to the lower court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the defendants on May 14, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Polk Center and White Haven Center were Pennsylvania state facilities that cared for individuals with severe mental and disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The centers represented a type of care facility that function by providing intense care for their residents in isolation from the rest of society.[SENTMARKER]In August of 2019, Pennsylvania Governor Thomas Wolf announced a plan to move residents from these two centers to "community" residences, which are not isolated and whose treatment is not as intense.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit alleged that this switch was in violation of the residents' rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, the Medicaid Act, and that the switch violated residents' substantive due process rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 22, 2014, a group of same-sex couples filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Dakota, alleging that South Dakota's prohibition of gay marriage and refusal to recognize valid out-of-state marriages violated their equal protection and due process rights.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the prohibition deprived them of their constitutional rights to equal protection, due process, and travel.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment to the plaintiffs and issued a permanent injunction, but stayed it pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States (S.C.) held that Obergefell did not render the action moot.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on appeal, and the Supreme Court held that the appeal was dismissed for want of a substantial federal question.

gold_sents: Institutionalized adults with developmental disabilities filed this challenge to policies in Texas they alleged promoted the unnecessary institutionalization of people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The United States (DOJ) has intervened in the case, and the Court eventually granted class certification for a class of: All Medicaid-eligible persons over twenty-one years of age with intellectual or developmental disabilities or a related condition in Texas who currently or will in the future reside in nursing facilities, or who are being, will be, or should be screened for admission to nursing facilities pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 1396r(e)(7) and 42 C.F.R. § 483.112 et seq. A bench trial was held in late 2018, and as of August 12, 2020, the litigation is ongoing as the parties await the court's decision.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 20, 2010, a group of individuals with developmental disabilities brought this class action lawsuit against the State of Texas and the Texas Community Service Programs (PCSP) alleging that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Nursing Home Reform Amendments Act (NHRA), and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act ( FDIC) by failing to provide them access to the community-based services and supports they need to live safely in the community.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the plaintiffs alleged that they suffered from intellectual or developmental disabilities and related conditions and two organizations brought action against the defendants, in their official capacities, alleging that state and officials administered Medicaid program in violation of the ADA, the NHRA, and the FDIC.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in November 2015, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement in March 2016.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with access to community services and services they need, to implement a system of integrated services, and to pay the plaintiffs in full.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to a two-year consent decree that required the state to pay a total of $1 million to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 2016, states and religiously affiliated healthcare providers filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Affordable Care Act's regulation prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex (which included gender identity and termination of pregnancy) violated the Administrative Procedure Act, Religious Freedom Restoration Act and constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]In October 2016, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of this regulation, which was granted on December 31, 2016.[SENTMARKER]Defendants' motion to stay the preliminary injunction was denied in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]In May 2017, the defendants filed a motion for voluntary remand and stay, arguing that HHS should be given the opportunity to reconsider the regulation at issue in this case, which would conserve the resources of both parties and the court.[SENTMARKER]In July 2017, Judge O’Connor declined to remand the case, but imposed a stay of all proceedings while HHS reconsidered the regulation.[SENTMARKER]He clarified that the December 31, 2016 preliminary injunction order would be unaffected by the stay and would remain in full force and effect throughout the stay.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the stay was lifted, and the parties resumed litigating the case.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, Judge O'Connor vacated the rule's challenged provisions.[SENTMARKER]An appeal is pending before the Fifth Circuit.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 23, 2016, a group of employees of a Catholic health care provider filed suit in the District Court of the District of Columbia against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and HHS Secretary Sylvia Burwell, challenging a new HHS rule that expanded the definition of sex discrimination under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (CRCPA) and the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) to include gender-reassignment procedures.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the new rule violated the plaintiffs' religious and conscientious objections to performing medical transition procedures and violated the defendants' right to equal protection under the law.[SENTMARKER]On October 21, 2016, the plaintiffs moved for partial summary judgment, or in the alternative, a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On December 31, 2016, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motions for a temporary injunction, finding they were likely to succeed on their APA and RFRA claims.[SENTMARKER]On July 10, 2017, after a hearing, the Court granted the parties’ requests to lift the stay and set a briefing schedule for the parties to review the Rule.[SENTMARKER]The Court concluded that the Rule imposes a substantial burden on private plaintiffs’ religious exercise.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for summary judgment on August 23, 2017, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the Court of Appeals for the DC Circuit for further consideration.[SENTMARKER]On August 24, 2018, the Court remanded the case to the D.C. district court for further review of the Rule, and the parties filed another motion to intervene.[SENTMARKER]The court granted both of the parties' requests.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered on August 24, 2018.

gold_sents: Same sex-couples filed suit in August 2013 against the State of Virginia challenging Virginia laws denying same-sex couples the right to marry and refusing to recognize same-sex marriages entered into in other states as unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The case is pending but stayed, awaiting the Fourth Circuit's resolution of another case raising the same issue.

Symington in the District of Arizona (Judge Roslyn Silver), alleging that the Defendants were violating the constitutional rights of female inmates to be free from sexual misconduct and unlawful invasions of privacy.[SENTMARKER]Symington in the District of Arizona (Judge Roslyn Silver), alleging that the Defendants were violating the constitutional rights of female inmates to be free from sexual misconduct and unlawful invasions of privacy.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement, which was filed on March 11, 1999.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, defendants did not admit any constitutional violations, but agreed to adopt policy and procedures from the Federal Bureau of Prisons, improve screening and training of employees, promote inmate awareness and comfort in reporting abuse, and thoroughly investigate allegations of abuse.[SENTMARKER]On December 13, 1999, the parties jointly filed a stipulation to dismiss which Judge Silver granted in a December 17, 1999 order.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 8, 1996, the Department of Justice filed this civil rights class action lawsuit in the United States district court for the district of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment rights of female inmates incarcerated in Arizona women's prisons by failing to protect them from sexual misconduct and unlawful invasions of privacy.[SENTMARKER]The case was initially dismissed by the district court, but the case was re-opened and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement agreement, the defendants agreed to conduct an investigation of all allegations of sexual misconduct, conduct screening of potential employees, implement new policies, and provide training to employees.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is subject to final approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case is closed.

gold_sents: This case litigated by the ACLU in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California dealt with sanitation, classification, legal access and other conditions at the California Institute for Men (Chino).[SENTMARKER]In 1988, the prison and the plaintiffs entered a settlement agreement, which provided for various improvements and compliance monitoring that ended in 1993.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 1988, the ACLU Foundation of 10 Southern California filed this class action lawsuit against the California Departments of Corrections and Mental Health in the United States district court for the central district of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' intentional infliction of mental stress upon 23 prisoners in the Chino Reception Guidance Center violated the cruel and unusual punishment clause of the Eighth Amendment of the United 26 States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss, and the parties entered into a memorandum of understanding to resolve the remaining issues.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay $22,000 to each of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on September 29, 1988.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants on October 2, 1988.

gold_sents: In 2008, a California inmate filed a lawsuit against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, alleging that the CDCR acted unconstitutionally by segregating the prisoners by race and locking down an entire race of prisoners due to the actions of certain prisoners of that race.[SENTMARKER]The case survived the defendants' motion to dismiss and class certification was granted.[SENTMARKER]In October 2014, the parties entered into a stipulated settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the agreement, the CDCR agreed to a number of terms, including to cease implementation of race-based modified programs or lockdowns; to provide outdoor activity to prisoners in a modified program or lockdown for longer than fourteen days; to revise its policies concerning modified programs and lockdowns, and to train its staff on modified programs and lockdowns.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to pay attorneys fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction for 18 months to enforce compliance with the agreement, and on December 20, 2016, the parties filed notice that the court’s jurisdiction to enforce the settlement agreement had terminated and that the case was dismissed with prejudice in its entirety.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 2008, a class action was filed against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation (CDCR) alleging that the defendants violated the Eighth Amendment and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by imposing a race-based lockdown policy on all inmates in the California State Prison at High Desert.[SENTMARKER]The case went to trial and a jury found that defendants violated Norwood’s Eighth Amendment 7 right to outdoor exercise and the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion for summary judgment, which the court granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to implement a modified program to segregate inmates based on their race.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into on May 30, 2008, and the parties agreed to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for declaratory and injunctive relief as moot.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendants’ motion for class certification, which was granted on July 10, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on June 10, 2014 and the case was closed on June 11, 2014.

gold_sents: On May 16, 2020, five individuals filed a class action against Lompoc, a low-security prison facing one of the largest outbreaks of COVID-19 among U.S federal prisons, for immediate relief.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs proposed a class of all current and future people in post-conviction custody at Lompoc, and sought enlargement of custody to include home confinement, and if the conditions of confinement violated constitutional rights, for prisoners to be released.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO (temporary restraining order), and a preliminary injunction requiring Lompoc to undertake health and safety measures, and attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, the court denied the defendant's motion to dismiss the case and on October 8, the court granted plaintiff's motion to enforce compliance with the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]In January 2021, the plaintiffs filed another motion to enforce compliance with the preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In July 2019, a prisoner at a federal prison in California filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that the federal prison system's response to the COVID-19 pandemic was inadequate.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the prison's conditions of confinement were unsanitary and unsanitary, and that the BOP had failed to respond effectively to the pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the prisoner's motion to decertify the class, but denied his request for early release on the basis that his conviction or sentence was invalid.[SENTMARKER]In a second suit, the prisoner filed a habeas petition alleging that his parole had been rescinded by the parole commission.[SENTMARKER]The prisoner claimed that the parole was rescinded because he had violated the terms of his parole, and the court granted his motion for decertifying the class.[SENTMARKER]The judge denied his motion, but granted his request to release more prisoners to home confinement.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 22, 1980, inmates filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut against the Connecticut Corrections Department.[SENTMARKER]This case was consolidated and named lead case with five other cases filed against the defendant in 1981 and 1982.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were represented by the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union and Legal Assistance to Prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the plaintiff's rights under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments were violated because the facility was overcrowded, unsanitary, lacking in security, and unable to provide adequately the basics of general human living needs.[SENTMARKER]Judgments were reached that required screening of all admitted inmates, individualized health care summaries for HIV-positive inmates, routine health examinations, and the use of drug therapies for HIV-positive inmates; as well as requiring that the prison not increase its inmate population, continue operating as a medium security facility, and allow plaintiffs' lawyers access to the facility.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 15, 1988, a group of inmates at the Connecticut Correctional Institution at Somers filed a class action lawsuit in the United States district court for the district of Connecticut alleging overcrowding and unconstitutional conditions of confinement in the prison.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants failed to provide adequate medical and mental health care, access to medical care for HIV-infected inmates, and protection for the confidentiality of the identities of inmates with HIV-infection.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in May 1994 and the case was dismissed in July 1994.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a general agreement in which the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiffs with a minimum of one hour of training annually on HIV-related subjects, provide additional personnel for counseling and support services for counseling personnel, and provide additional showers for most of the inmate population.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was entered into by Judge Robert N. Chatigny and approved by Judge Holly B. Fitzsimmons of the district court.

gold_sents: In 1986, the prisoners at the Occoquan Facilites of the District of Columbia's Lorton Correctional Complex filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the District of Columbia government officials' overcrowding of the facility violated their Eighth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The court held that the defendants had violated the constitution, and required that the prison minimize its population.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in 2003.
pegasus_output_sents: In the wake of a prison riot, inmates at the District of Columbia's facilities in Occoquan, Virginia, brought suit in federal district court under 42 U.S.C.  1983 alleging that conditions at the prison violated the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted plaintiffs' motions for class certification and a preliminary injunction imposing a limit on the number of prisoners who could be housed at the facility.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the District had deliberately failed to obey its orders concerning overcrowding at the jail and held the District in civil contempt.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that the population cap was too broad a remedy and remanded the case to the District Court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

On August 6, 2006, Prison Legal News (PLN) submitted a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) seeking documents related to litigation expenses.[SENTMARKER]They asked the BOP to waive all search and duplication fees under the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]BOP refused to grant the fee waiver and PLN appealed the decision to the Department of Justice.

The DOJ upheld the denial of the request, so on September 13, 2005, PLN filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]After several years of litigation, the parties settled in 2017.[SENTMARKER]The BOP produced the requested documents and agreed to pay $420,000 in attorneys' fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 6, 2003, a non-profit legal journal, Prison Legal News, filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request under 5 U.S.C.  552 with the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP), an agency of the United States government, seeking documents showing all money paid by the Bureau for lawsuits and claims against it between January 1, 1996 and July 31, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also challenged the Bureau's search for responsive records and its utilization of the FOIA exemptions to withhold the redacted information and other documents that it claims have not been produced at all.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's request for declaratory and injunctive relief and ordered the Bureau to provide the plaintiff with all documents responsive to its FOIA request without any cost.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment, which was denied without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Four overdetained former Delaware prisoners, represented by private counsel, filed this § 1983 action against the Delaware Department of Corrections (DDOC) and Central Offender Records (COR).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that inadequate staff, training, discipline, and hours of operation, along with a host of other policies, caused dysfunction and frequent over-detention.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought suit individually and as a class on behalf of all those incarcerated in a DDOC facility as of October 1, 2008 or later who were not or will not be released within 12 hours of the expiration of their sentence or the forwarding of a court order for release.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment because the plaintiffs' failed to demonstrate that the defendants were deliberately indifferent to the overdetention problem.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Third Circuit affirmed the district court's decision to grant summary judgment to the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 1, 2012, four inmates, all of whom had spent time in custody, filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Delaware alleging that the defendants had violated the Fourth, Fifth, and Eighth Amendments of the United States Constitution by over-detaining them and denying them access to the courts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were injured when the defendants caused them to be overdetained and other members of the class.[SENTMARKER]The court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants, denied the plaintiffs' motion for class certification, and granted their motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to file a joint status report no later than October 6, 2014.

pegasus_output_sents: In December 2006, a prisoner at Valdosta State Prison filed a civil rights action in the United States District Court for the Middle District Of Georgia against the State of Georgia, the Georgia Department of Corrections, and the Georgia State Prison.[SENTMARKER]The prisoner alleged that he was beaten to death by CERT Team officers and that the beatings violated the Eighth Amendment of the Constitution and the civil rights laws.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants were deliberately indifferent to the pattern and practice of beatings of restrained inmates at the prison.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss for failure to exhaust administrative remedies, which was granted by the district court.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now pending before the Eleventh Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The court remanded the case, finding that the prisoner did exhaust the required administrative remedies.

pegasus_output_sents: In May 2014, a transgender inmate at Rodgers State Prison filed suit in federal court against three prison officials alleging that they violated her Eighth Amendment rights by failing to protect her from a fellow inmate who sexually assaulted her.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the prison officials, finding that no constitutional violation had occurred.[SENTMARKER]The court also dismissed the inmate's supervisory liability claims.[SENTMARKER]The inmate appealed the district court's decision, and the case was re-opened on January 6, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On January 6, 2019, the court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment on the supervisory liability claim.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 7, 2011, a group of Native Hawaiian inmates at a private prison in Arizona filed a civil rights lawsuit against CoreCivic, formerly known as Corrections Corporation of America.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their rights under the federal Constitution and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act of 2000 by preventing them from practicing the native Hawaiian religion during a Makahiki festival.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to transfer the case to the District of Arizona pursuant to  1406(a) as it could have been brought there.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case on the ground that the defendant was not at the time of service of the summons, and therefore, the venue requirements of 28 U.S.C.  1391(c) were not met.[SENTMARKER]The case was then transferred to the district court for the district of Hawaii.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in which the defendants agreed to allow the plaintiffs to meet with other Native Hawaiian practitioners on a daily basis for group worship and to publish in-cell retention list in the prison chapel and add list to [Saguaro] Policy 14-6.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay a total of $70,00 to the Native Hawaiian Legal Corporation for costs incurred.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and granted their motion for partial summary judgment.

gold_sents: In 2009, a group of Muslim prisoners filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the warden of the Federal Correctional Institute, alleging that the prison's allowance of only one hour of group prayer per week violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act.[SENTMARKER]The court ultimately issued a permanent injunction against the Federal Correctional Institute in 2013, holding that the prison's policy violated RFRA and, upon further clarification, ordered that the warden "is to allow group prayer during every Muslim prayer time for which the inmates are not confined to their cell."

gold_sents: In 2007, the Disability Law Center filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the ADA, and the Rehabilitation Act against the Massachusetts Department of Correction.[SENTMARKER]The DLC claimed that the DOC failed to take into account mental illness when subjecting prisoners to long periods of disciplinary and other forms of isolation and segregation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled in 2011, and the defendants agreed to make sure that mentally ill prisoners were not placed in isolation or segregation without a full evaluation and determination that such placement would not cause further injury; they also agreed to pay attorney fees.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed in 2015 as no one had requested to reopen the case since the settlement monitoring date ended.[SENTMARKER]In 2016 one of the prisoners tried to reopen the case since prison officials were violating the settlement agreement, but the judge refused to reopen the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 8, 2007, Disability Law Center, Inc., a not-for-profit corporation, filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Massachusetts Department of Correction (DOC) alleging that the DOC violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide adequate mental health care to prisoners held in segregation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that prisoners with mental illness in the custody of the DOC were denied access to mental health treatment, and that their confinement in segregation was in violation of the ADA and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in November, 2007, and the case was dismissed on April 12, 2012.[SENTMARKER]On May 20, 2015, the parties informed the court that they had agreed to a comprehensive settlement agreement (the "Agreement"), which was approved by the court on May 20, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the Court would be the sole forum for the enforcement of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The agreement requires the parties to provide the court with a copy of the remaining redacted records, and requires the court to hold a hearing to determine whether or not the agreement is valid.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for a stay of discovery, and the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case on May 30, 2015.[SENTMARKER]On May 30, 2015, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to comply with the terms of the agreement, including the release of the records, the payment of attorney's fees, and other costs.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: COVID-vulnerable inmates of the Maine Department of Corrections, seeking to represent a class of medically vulnerable and disabled inmates, brought this habeas action in an effort to force the Department to de-densify its prisons by releasing prisoners.[SENTMARKER]Filed May 15, 2020 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine, the complaint alleged that the Department had refused to grant medical furlough or home confinement to inmates; they alleged that this was in violation of the Eighth Amendment, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The action was assigned to Judge John A. Woodcock, Jr.[SENTMARKER]Although the Department reported its first case of COVID in May 2020, the court dismissed the plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunctive relief in June 2020.[SENTMARKER]Motions to dismiss the case and to convert the case to a different form of habeas were pending as of July 28, 2020.

pegasus_output_sents: On October 30, 2007, an inmate in the custody of the Michigan Department of Corrections (MDOC) filed a civil rights action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the MDOC and Correctional Medical Services, Inc. (CMS) alleging that his Eighth Amendment rights were violated when he was denied cataract surgery in his left eye.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants denied his request for cataract surgery on October 26, 2004 and that his requests for injunctive relief were denied by the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) on October 27, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case in January 2008, and the district court denied the motion.[SENTMARKER]In November 2007, the plaintiff filed a pro se motion for declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a Report and Recommendation on March 25, 2010, which recommended that the motion for summary judgment be denied.[SENTMARKER]The parties completed discovery in November 2009, and the parties entered a final judgment in March 2010.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the defendants have agreed to pay no costs or attorneys' fees.

gold_sents: This 2013 lawsuit was brought by several Muslim inmates of  the Lakeland Correctional Facility in the U.S. District for the Western District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that, in failing to provide adequate nutrition to prisoners observing Ramadan, the defendants, several agents of the Michigan Department of Corrections, had violated the First, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments as well as the RLUIPA.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Michigan, a group of Muslim prisoners sued the Michigan Department of Corrections (MDOC) for violating their First and Eighth Amendment rights under the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA) by failing to accommodate their requests for nutritionally-adequate meals during the Islamic month of Ramadan.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated their rights under RLUIPA by refusing to provide the plaintiffs with 2,900 calories of food per day during Ramadan, as required by MDOC policy, and instead reducing their calories to approximately 1,000 to 1,500 calories per day.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for summary judgment, claiming that the plaintiffs could only obtain adequate nutrition by violating their religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants qualified immunity, concluding that they were shielded by qualified immunity.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the district court and the defendants moved to dismiss the complaint with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the case was dismissed with prejudice, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, a transgender prisoner of the Missouri Department of Corrections filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that the “freeze-frame” policy of refraining from providing transgender prisoners necessary medical care for gender dysphoria unless they previously received such services violated the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, the court declared that the policy violated the Eighth Amendment’s Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause and issued a permanent injunction against the policy.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the defendants to provide the medical care necessary for the plaintiff’s gender dysphoria.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the court awarded the plaintiff attorney’s fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2016, a transgender woman in the custody of the Missouri Department Of Corrections (MDOC) sued the MDOC and Corizon Health, Inc. (Corizon) for their alleged deliberate indifference to her serious medical needs, which constitutes cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution, made applicable to the State through the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, Ms. Hicklin is a thirty-seven year old white transgender woman, diagnosed with gender dysphoria, who is housed at Potosi Correctional Center, a facility for male inmates, in Mineral Point, Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that the defendants violated Ms.Hicklin's Eighth Amendment rights by denying her medically necessary care, including hormone therapy to certain inmates, pursuant to MDOC's freeze-frame policy, which is not appropriate in a prison environment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, granted their motion for declaratory and injunctive relief, and entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 2005, the ACLU filed a class-action lawsuit on behalf of inmates confined in Unit 32 of the Mississippi State Penitentiary in Parchman, Mississippi, alleging dangerous and inhumane conditions of confinement.[SENTMARKER]The parties initially settled in 2006.[SENTMARKER]Then, the plaintiffs filed a motion for contempt in late 2006, seeking an order to compel defendants to immediately comply with the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]After two more settlements, the defendants agreed to close Unit 32 in 2010 and the case was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2005, the National Prison Project of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), the Mississippi ACLU, and Holland Knight, LLP, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi against the Mississippi Department of Corrections (MDOC) on behalf of prisoners confined in Unit 32 of Mississippi State Penitentiary (MSP), Parchman, Mississippi.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the MDOC violated the Eighth Amendment by subjecting the prisoners to inhumane living conditions and excessive force, deprives them of medical and mental health treatment, and denies them procedural due process in housing them in MSP.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a consent decree, which was signed by Judge Jerry A. Davis on February 20, 2006, and was entered as an order on April 28, 2006 (Dkt No. 24, attached here as an Exhibit A).[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the defendants to provide prisoners with a means for renouncing affiliation with a security threat group that does not require prisoners to provide identities of gang members as a condition for renunciation.[SENTMARKER]The court retained jurisdiction to enforce the terms of the consent decree after a fairness hearing in compliance with Rule 23 (e) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.[SENTMARKER]The defendants did not comply with this consent decree and the case was dismissed without prejudice on the terms set forth below.

gold_sents: In 2013, prisoners in the East Mississippi Correctional Facility (EMCF) filed a class-action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the Mississippi Department of Corrections, claiming that EMCF violated the Eighth Amendment's Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that the inhumane living conditions at EMCF, a prison for the mentally ill, harmed inmates.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the court granted class certification.[SENTMARKER]After engaging in discovery and a bench trial, the parties attempted to settle.[SENTMARKER]After the parties submitted their supplemental expert reports, the parties attempted to settle.[SENTMARKER]However, on January 24, 2019, the parties notified the court that the parties were unable to settle and that future settlement conferences would not be productive.[SENTMARKER]As of March 25, 2019, the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2007, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Mississippi on behalf of prisoners confined at the East Mississippi Correctional Facility in Meridian, Mississippi, which is designed to provide treatment and housing for mentally ill prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the conditions under which they were confined violated their Eighth Amendment right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The defendants, the Commissioner of the Mississippi Department of Corrections, the Chief Medical Officer, and the Deputy Commissioner for Institutions, were responsible for the promulgation of policies and practices related to the confinement of prisoners in conditions of solitary confinement.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree that prohibited the housing of seriously mentally ill inmates in long-term solitary confinement in Unit 32 for more than 14 days.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also prohibited the use of chemical agents and physical force on prisoners without warning and in the absence of an immediate threat of danger.[SENTMARKER]After the consent decree was entered, the defendants contracted with a new company, Centurion, to provide mental health care services at the prison.[SENTMARKER]As the case neared trial, the parties met on multiple occasions with the magistrate judge to try to settle the case without success.[SENTMARKER]The case was denied by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

gold_sents: This case is about the refusal of North Carolina's Department of Public Safety (DPS) to recognize Humanism as a faith group within the North Carolina state prison system.[SENTMARKER]On February 2, 2015, an inmate in a North Carolina prison and the American Humanist Association filed this lawsuit in the Eastern District of North Carolina against officers of the North Carolina Department of Public Safety that are involved in policy decisions related to recognition of faith groups in state prison under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]They alleged violations of the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross-motions for summary judgment, and on March 29, 2018, Judge Terrence W. Boyle granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and denied the defendants' motion.[SENTMARKER]He entered a permanent injunction ordering DPS to recognize Humanism as a faith group and to permit a Humanist study group to meet within North Carolina state prisons on the same terms as other faiths are allowed and entered declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]The court also awarded nominal damages and attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]Since the entering of the permanent injunction, there has been no activity in this case.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction remains in effect.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 25, 2015, the American Humanist Association (AHA) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina against the North Carolina Department of Public Safety (DPS) and the Director of Prisons for refusing to allow an inmate with sincerely held Humanist convictions to form a Humanist study group to meet on the same terms that Defendants authorize inmates of theistic religious traditions to meet.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Establishment and Equal Protection Clauses of the First Amendment by refusing to recognize Humanism as a faith group.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a declaratory judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, and the parties filed a motion for summary judgment on March 29, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment, but denied their motion for permanent injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case for nominal damages and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: This was a prison medical care case filed in 2002 in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey, seeking damages and an injunction against contract medical care providers and New Jersey corrections officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs that the New Jersey prison system was failing to treat them for Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]By the time the court adjudicated the class action issue, in May 2008, the New Jersey Department of Corrections had adopted major changes in how prisoners with HCV were treated; it updated its procedures to match those of the federal Bureau of Prisons, and "backscreened" all the prisoners willing to be screened for the virus.[SENTMARKER]Given that the injunctive relief requested by the plaintiffs was this same set of reforms, Judge Hillman denied the request for injunctive relief as moot.[SENTMARKER]As to two individual class members who had HCV, the court held there was sufficient evidence in the record to go to trial on their constitutional claims (though not on their Americans with Disabilities Act claims), and denied the state's motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2009, the case settled for money damages.[SENTMARKER](However, it seems from some papers filed by one of the plaintiffs that he may never actually have received  his money.[SENTMARKER]But when he sought the assistance of the court in enforcing the settlement against his lawyer, Judge Hillman ruled that the court lacked jurisdiction, and directed him to file a collection action in state court.  )
pegasus_output_sents: On July 25, 2003, a class of former and current inmates of the New Jersey Department of Corrections filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court in New Jersey.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act by failing to provide them with adequate medical treatment for their serious medical needs in violation of their Eighth Amendment right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiffs with a proper screening mechanism for new inmates and to pay the plaintiffs' attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on July 25, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion for class certification on May 15, 2006, and the case was transferred to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants on August 27, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On December 9, 2009, an inmate at the New Jersey state prison filed this civil action in the U.S. District Court for the District of N.J.[SENTMARKER]alleging that a ban on inmate preaching in the prison violated his First Amendment rights under the Religious Land use and institutionalized persons act of 2000 ("RLUIPA") and the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the inmate's motion for a preliminary injunction, but denied his request for injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Court of Appeals for the First Circuit reversed the district court's grant of summary judgment for the defendant department of corrections, holding that the prison failed to satisfy this burden under RLUIPA.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the District Court on December 10, 2009 and the parties agreed to settle the case.
