pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against a former New York City resident who allegedly defrauded investors out of millions of dollars.[SENTMARKER]According to the criminal complaint, filed in federal court in New York, the defendant, who has not been identified by name, defrauded more than 100 investors in the United States and Canada out of more than $10 million.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that the defendant used the investors' money to fund his lavish lifestyle, which included a lavish home, a luxury car, and a lavish lifestyle for himself and his family.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also allegedly used the investor money to pay off his personal debts.[SENTMARKER]The case is being handled by the Office of the Chief Judge of the New York District Court.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 6, 1980, inmates of the Special Housing Unit at Attica Correctional Facility in Attica, New York, filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the District of Western New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants, all state correction officials or prison authorities at the SHU, had violated the constitutional rights of the inmates by systematically violating their constitutional guarantees, including those against cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction on January 29, 1988, and the court of appeals affirmed the district court's order in an opinion dated June 13, 1988.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a Stipulation on June 13, 1988, requiring the defendants to provide mental health services to the inmates in SHU in accordance with specified procedures.[SENTMARKER]On March 6, 1998, the defendants appealed, claiming that the court lacked jurisdiction to hear the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted the defendants' appeal, and the case was dismissed on January 6, 1998.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 1997, prisoners at various facilities within the New York State Department of Corrections filed a class action lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against Department officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by Prisoners Legal Services of New York, brought the suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York, challenging the systemic deprivation of religious rights of Native American prisoners, in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]In 2000, the parties reached a settlement and the court dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 1997, a group of Native American inmates filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York against the New York state department of correctional services (DOCS) alleging that the DOCS was unlawfully preventing them from conducting religious cerehionies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their religious rights by failing to provide them with the opportunity to practice their traditional Native American religion.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an out-of-court settlement in September 1999, and the case was closed on March 24, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following conditions: (i) the hiring of a part-time minister for adherents of the Nation of Islam Faith once their numbers exceed 200; .[SENTMARKER](ii) the creation of a visitor hospitality center; .[SENTMARKER](iii) a limit on the number of guests each inmate may invite to each event; .[SENTMARKER](iv) the use of religious rugs in their religious communities; and (v) the right to participate in sweat lodge ceremonies outsjide of the facility.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 17, 2007, a class of disabled prisoners in the custody of the New York State Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) filed a class action lawsuit against the DOCS, alleging that the defendants failed to make their programs, services, and activities accessible to prisoners with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief, monetary damages, and reasonable attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, finding that the plaintiffs had not shown that they were deprived of their constitutional rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504).[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On January 21, 2003, an Oklahoma Department of Corrections prisoner filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. §1983 in the United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, alleging that his Constitutional rights under the Free Exercise Clause were being violated by the Oklahoma Department of Corrections' refusal to provide him with a Kosher diet.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated to include the complaints of two other prisoners.[SENTMARKER]The prisoners won both preliminary and permanent injunctive relief requiring the Oklahoma Department of Corrections to provide them a Kosher diet at no personal cost.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction, issued February 8, 2006, ordered the Director of the Oklahoma Department of Corrections 'to immediately provide to the plaintiffs Kosher diets at no cost, [while complying with nutritional requirements currently applicable to all other ODOC prisoners].'[SENTMARKER]On September 26, 2012 the Court found that the judgment entered in this case only applies to the claims pursued by the three named plaintiffs, and the permanent injunction relief does not apply to all Oklahoma Department of Corrections inmates.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1996, three inmates of the Oklahoma Department of Corrections filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado alleging a constitutional and statutory right to receive a kosher diet in accordance with Orthodox Jewish law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their rights guaranteed by the First Amendment's free exercise clause have been violated by the DOC's failure to provide them free of cost with kosher meals consistent with their Orthodox Jewish faith.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction requiring the DOC to provide these three plaintiffs a Kosher diet at no cost.[SENTMARKER]In 2002, the Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals issued a decision affirming the district court's decision.[SENTMARKER]The cases were then re-referred to United States Magistrate Judge Gary M. Purcell for further proceedings, including a determination whether permanent injunctive relief was warranted.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2005, the plaintiffs filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion, finding that the plaintiffs had not shown that the defendants' policy of not providing kosher diets violated their First Amendment right to freely exercise his Orthodox Judaism religion.[SENTMARKER]The case was re-opened and the parties agreed to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a final judgment on January 21, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with a kosher meal at no expense.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then appealed the final judgment to the United States Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the appeal and the case was closed.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2013, a trans woman housed in a mens prison in Oklahoma filed a pro se case against prison staff and administration in the District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma.[SENTMARKER]She claims that she has been denied appropriate transition related care and accommodations, amounting to a violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]Her request for a TRO and preliminary injunction were denied at the district court level, and the circuit court affirmed the denial of the preliminary injunction without comment on the TRO for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]On April 3, 2015, the district court granted defendants' motion to dismiss, dismissing the claims against all defendants in their individual capacities without prejudice, and all the claims against them in their official capacity with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]Though the plaintiff objected to the dismissal, the Court denied her motion and affirmed the dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 28, 2014, a state prisoner filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, alleging that her gender identity disorder (GID) violated her Eighth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that she was incarcerated at the Oklahoma State Reformatory (OSR) in 1986, after undergoing surgery to transform from male to female.[SENTMARKER]She also alleged that the OSR denied her request to be allowed to purchase female undergarments, such as bras and panties, and that she has failed to provide the proper level of hormone treatment.[SENTMARKER]The court denied her motion for a temporary restraining order, but granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]In October 2014, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed as moot.

gold_sents: On July 27, 2012, plaintiff, a male prisoner, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Middle District of Pennsylvania under Bivens against the Federal Bureau of Prisons.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiff claimed that the defendants violated plaintiff's right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution by forcing him to share a cell with a hostile prisoner, which caused a threat of violence, and by placing him in painful restraints that caused injury for prolonged periods on multiple occasions for refusing dangerous cell assignments with hostile prisoners; and that defendants violated his right to due process under the Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution by depriving him of any meaningful process prior to and during their use of punitive measures against him.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2013, the U.S. District Court (Judge William B. pegasus_output_sents: On December 7, 2011, a federal prisoner filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the Middle District Of Pennsylvania against the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) alleging that the BOP violated his Fifth and Eighth Amendment rights by placing him in painful restraints as punishment for refusing to accept dangerous cell assignments with hostile inmates.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the district court, but the parties appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted the appeal, and the case was remanded for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied class certification.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion to dismiss based on the insufficient allegations in the complaint, qualified immunity, and personal jurisdiction of the acting director of BOP.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then sought to dismiss the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed the case, concluding that the defendants had not alleged that the SMU program at USP Lewisburg has been shut down policy and subjecting inmates to harm.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on the issue of class certification, and remanded the case to the District Court.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 22, 2016, an African-American inmate with hepatitis C filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District Of Pennsylvania alleging that the Pennsylvania Department Of Corrections (DOC) was violating his constitutional rights by refusing to provide him with Hepatitis C treatment.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DOC had a policy of prohibiting all communication between hospital patients in the custody of the DOC and their lawyers, family, friends, and others not in the employ of theDOC or Geisinger Medical Center.[SENTMARKER]The DOC's counsel asserted that the prohibition on visitation and phone calls was the policy of Geisinger and not the DOC.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted Plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction, which the Court granted in part and denied in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the two matters should be consolidated and thereafter filed a Joint Motion for Consolidation Motion.[SENTMARKER]On August 31, 2016, the Court of Appeals for the 3rd Circuit granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that the defendants had not exhausted their administrative remedies as required by the PLRA.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed, claiming that the District Court had jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C.  1331 and that the district court had no jurisdiction over the case.[SENTMARKER]The appeals were denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the matter.

gold_sents: In June 2017, three mentally ill prisoners of the U.S. Penitentiary at Lewisburg (USP Lewisburg) filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued USP Lewisburg and the Federal Bureau of Prisons, alleging that the defendants’ failure to provide adequate treatment for prisoners with mental illness constituted cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs eventually dismissed their claims.

gold_sents: 47 inmates at the Beaumont Federal Correctional Institution in Midland, Texas filed a complaint against the United States under the Federal Tort Claims Act. Plaintiffs alleged that the conditions at Beaumont were unsanitary and inhumane, and that as a result of damage to the building caused by Hurricane Rita, they were subjected to confinement in a building unfit for inhabitants.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs also alleged they were entitled to damages for working conditions endured while working in a UNICOR factory manufacturing Kevlar helmets.[SENTMARKER]Defendant moved for dismissal or summary judgment in the alternate.[SENTMARKER]Several years later, but before the district court ruled, plaintiffs' counsel died, and the case was dismissed without prejudice for failure to prosecute.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 25, 2005, inmates at the Federal Correctional Complex at Beaumont, Texas, filed a lawsuit under the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) against the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) alleging that the BOP violated the FLSA by failing to provide suitable quarters, safekeeping, care and subsistence at the prison after Hurricane Rita.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were forced to work overtime in a building that contained hazardous vapors; failed to provide safety apparel; housing them in a condemned building; making them drink contaminated water and take cold showers; and allowing them less than an hour for their personal needs.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that the Eighth Amendment was violated because there was an absence of hygiene and that there was a lack of medical care.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment on the negligence claim, and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 21, 2012, a Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice (TDCJ) filed this pro se federal civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]He sued multiple TDCJ employees under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that TDJC policies that prevented his smoking a prayer pipe during Native American pipe ceremonies, limited his ability to wear a religiously significant medicine bag, and prevented him from growing long hair violated his rights under RLUIPA and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]He sought declaratory, injunctive, and monetary relief as well as attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]An additional Native American prisoner plaintiff joined the suit shortly after filing.[SENTMARKER]In February 2013, the plaintiffs amended their complaint, consented to proceedings before a Magistrate Judge, and voluntarily dismissed all of their claims except their three RLUIPA challenges against the TDCJ Director in his official capacity and their First Amendment claim seeking damages against the Program Analyst in his individual capacity.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On February 27, 2014, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment was granted and a final judgment entered in their favor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit and were successful in getting judgement on the RLUIPA grooming policy claim vacated and remanded.[SENTMARKER]On remand, the defendant’s motion for summary judgment on the RLUIPA grooming claim was denied.[SENTMARKER]As the RLUIPA grooming policy claim moved towards trial, the initial prisoner plaintiff in the case was released and his claims were dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the consolidation of cases Casey v. Davis (2:14-cv-13) and Cobb v. Morris (2:14-cv-22) with this case, as the two cases also were brought by Native American prisoner incarcerated at the McConnell Unit and involved RLUIPA grooming policy claims moving towards trial.[SENTMARKER]After a bench trial, Judge Ramos granted plaintiffs’ request for injunctive relief permitting them to grow their hair long, consistent with their Native American religious beliefs and entered a final judgment on February 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The defendant appealed, but moved to dismiss the appeal shortly after.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit granted the motion to dismiss the appeal on July 9, 2019.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 13, 1995, a Native American prisoner at the Texas Department of Criminal Justice (TDCJ) filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas, seeking injunctive relief in violation of the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA) and his First Amendment right to practice his Native American faith (D.E.).[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's motion for a temporary restraining order, and the parties reached a settlement.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2011, the plaintiff filed a motion for summary judgment, alleging that the defendants violated RLUIPA by denying him, inter alia, the right to participate in pipe ceremonies and smudging rituals.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants, concluding that the challenged regulations and practices were connected to valid government interest, and did not violate the First Amendment rights of the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed the district court's grant of summary judgment to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit reversed in part, holding that the defendant's grooming policy violated the religious rights of non-violent, low security offenders.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States granted the defendants' appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A Sunni Muslim incarcerated in Virginia Department of Corrections facility (VDOC) brought suit against the officers of the VDOC for failing to provide adequate food to him during his Ramadan fasts and interfering with his participation in post-Ramadan religious events.[SENTMARKER]The court issued a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the parties agreed to settle and the case was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 2006, a Muslim inmate at Keen Mountain Correctional Center filed a lawsuit against the Virginia Department of Corrections alleging that the defendants deprived him of adequate nutrition and calories during Ramadan.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendant, Keen Mountain, made special accommodations for providing inmates the opportunity to participate in the Ramadan fast.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, in violation of Islamic tenets, the defendants served what they described as the Eid ul Fitr meal on the evening of November 25, 2003, the final day of Ramadan, and after Couch and the other Muslims had fasted throughout the day.[SENTMARKER]The court held that such weightlessness was a violation of the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay $450,000 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2014, three Virginia prisoners placed in administrative segregation at Red Onion State Prison, filed this pro-se lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia.[SENTMARKER]They brought claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment, and the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]They sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as money damages.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the VDOC Operating Procedure 830.A, (a self-described Segregation Reduction Step-Down Program designed to help prisoners progress in stages toward a return to the general prison population), violated plaintiffs’ rights.[SENTMARKER]On September 28, 2016, Judge James P. Jones granted the defendants’ motion for summary judgement.[SENTMARKER]On October 6, 2016, the plaintiff appealed the district court’s September 28th ruling to the Fourth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On November 22, 2017, a panel of the Fourth Circuit, in an unpublished per curiam opinion, affirmed the judgment on the reasoning of the district court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 19, 2014, Eric J. DePaola filed this civil rights action in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Virginia against the Virginia Department of Corrections (VDOC) and 31 persons, including VDOC Director Harold Clarke, VDOC Chief of Operations A. David Robinson, Red Onion Warden Randall Mathena, and Red Onion IM-SL6 Closed Pod Manager J Artrip.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants' administrative segregation review procedures for IM prisoners violate his Fourteenth Amendment right to procedural due process rights; and that the conditions of prolonged solitary confinement constitute cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment to the defendants on each of De Paola's claims, including the claims at issue in this appeal.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Fourth Circuit reversed the district court's decision, finding that the court had erred in granting summary judgment on the procedural due-process claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 6, 2019, twelve prisoners who had been held in solitary confinement in two Virginia supermax prisons for at least two years filed this putative class action lawsuit in the District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that each prison had violated their Fourteenth and Eighth Amendment rights by continuing to implement a program that intentionally held prisoners in solitary confinement without the possibility of re-entering the general population.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that this program also violated an earlier settlement agreement, the Rehabilitation Act, and the Americans with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]The defendants, the Virginia Department of Corrections, its employees, and the wardens of each prison, filed two motions to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]District Judge Robert E. Payne has not yet issued a decision on either motion.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 1981, prisoners represented by the American Civil Liberties Union’s National Prison Project sued the Virginia Department of Corrections (VDOC) in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia for violating their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights by subjecting them to indefinite and long-term solitary confinement that results in serious deprivations of basic human needs, significant mental and physical harms, and substantial risk of harm.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that VDOC violated their constitutional rights to due process and freedom from cruel and unusual punishment by placing prisoners in solitary confinement based on factors unrelated to a prisoner’s behavior in prison.[SENTMARKER]In the wake of a 1984 Mecklenburg Study Committee Report, VDOC entered into a settlement agreement with the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties submitted the settlement agreement to the Court, which issued a consent decree on April 5, 1985.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required VDOC to: (1) abolish the Step-Down Program; and (2) end the Long-term Solitary Confinement Program at Red Onion and Wallens Ridge; and (3) accommodate the plaintiffs’ mental illness or mental health disabilities in periodic reviews of their solitary confinement.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the parties entered into an agreement in which VDOC agreed not to use any version of solitary confinement similar to that of the Phase Program or Special Management Unit.

gold_sents: In 2016, the plaintiff filed a pro se complaint in the District Court for the Western District of Virginia against the Virginia Department of Corrections alleging that their policies for beards, halal food, and television access for religious services for inmates in solitary confinement violated the Free Exercise Clause and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act. Judge John P. Jones denied the plaintiff's request for injunctive relief in 2017 and initially granted summary judgment in favor of VDOC in 2018, but the Fourth Circuit overturned him on appeal in late 2019, saying that VDOC's use of access to television for religious services as an incentive program unduly burdens the plaintiff's rights to practice a bona fide religious belief.[SENTMARKER]The panel stated that religious practice should be a right, not a privilege that can be taken away through an incentive program.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2017, an inmate at Virginia's Red Onion State Prison filed this civil rights action under 42 U.S.C.  1983 and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA) against the Virginia Department of Corrections (VDOC) for violating his right to free exercise of his Islamic religious beliefs under the First Amendment and RLUIPA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, Alfonza Hardy Greenhill, alleged that the defendants' policies and actions under those policies have substantially burdened his religious practices, and he seeks injunctive relief under both laws.[SENTMARKER]The court of appeals remanded the case for further proceedings on Greenhill's request for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for summary judgment, and the district court granted summary judgment for the defendants on the first two of the three claims.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 31, 2020, Judge Rebecca Beach Smith in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia approved a settlement between the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) Civil Rights Division and Hampton Roads Regional Jail Authority.[SENTMARKER]The agreement resolved the DOJ’s claims alleging unlawful conditions at the Hampton Roads Regional Jail (HRRJ) in violation of CRIPA and the ADA.[SENTMARKER]Under the agreement, HRRJ will develop and implement policies, procedures, and training regarding adequate medical and mental health care and appropriate housing for prisoners with serious mental illness.[SENTMARKER]These measures include specialized mental health housing units, increased training for medical, mental health, and security personnel, proper screening and assessment for medical and mental health concerns, adequate treatment planning and suicide prevention measures, and a quality assurance program.[SENTMARKER]Per the agreement, the parties jointly appointed a monitor to assess and assist with compliance with the agreement.[SENTMARKER]HRRJ must come into substantial compliance with the agreement within five years.[SENTMARKER]The agreement can be terminated by court order.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 12, 2016, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this civil rights suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia against the Hampton Roads regional jail authority (HRRJ) alleging violations of the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA) and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that HRRJ violated the rights of prisoners with mental illness by denying them access to services, programs, and activities because of their disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the jail violated the ADA by failing to provide adequate medical and mental health care to prisoners and its use of prolonged restrictive housing for prisoners who had mental illnesses.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into an agreement in which HRRJ agreed to pay a total of $1 million to resolve the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The agreement, which is subject to court approval, will be terminated in five years, or as outlined in 167, by order of the court, if the parties agree that the Jail has attained substantial compliance with all provisions of this agreement.

gold_sents: On June 25, 2009 the plaintiff, a former female prisoner, filed suit against the State of Washington, the Washington State Department of Corrections, the Washington Corrections Center for Women, and several correctional officers in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]She alleged violations of 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, and the Washington State Constitution based on the treatment of her while she was giving birth.[SENTMARKER]On May 3, 2010 the court denied the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment and granted in part and denied in part the defendants' motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case came to a close on May 7, 2010 after the parties reached a settlement on the remaining claims.[SENTMARKER]The details of the settlement are not known.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 25, 2009, a female inmate at the Washington Corrections Center for Women (WCCW) filed this suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]She alleged that the Defendants violated her Eighth Amendment rights under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution by shackling her during labor and delivery.[SENTMARKER]She also alleged that she suffered damages as a result of the Defendants' violation of her right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion for summary dismissal of the suit, finding that there was no evidence that the plaintiff was dangerous to herself or others and that the defendant's own policy prohibited the use of restraints during labor.[SENTMARKER]The district court also found that the defendants did not have to exhaust their administrative remedies under the Prison Litigation Reform Act (PLRA) and the doctrine of laches bars.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was denied by the district court.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case for undisclosed amounts.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have no further comment.

gold_sents: Washington state prisoners with serious medical problems sued the Washington Department of Corrections for failing to provide adequate medical care.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs believed that the DOC applied the term "medically necessary" too narrowly and denied immediate care and that decisions to provide outside treatment are decided arbitrarily, without medical justification.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought class action certification but Judge Richard A. Jones denied the certification on September 18, 2017 on the grounds that the proposed class lacked commonality.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals denied an appeal by the plaintiffs later that year.[SENTMARKER]Between June 2018 and March 2019, each remaining plaintiff filed to dismiss himself as a party.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the court closed the case on March 27, 2019 when no plaintiffs remained.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 27, 2018, a class-action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western district of Washington on behalf of inmates in the custody of the Washington Department Of Corrections (DOC).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' policies and practices violated the Eighth Amendment because they were deliberately indifferent to inmates’ health and safety and exposed 8 inmates to a substantial risk of serious harm.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and 16 injunctive relief for themselves and for the proposed class they seek to represent.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement in March 2018.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to provide medical care to inmates with serious and painful medical conditions.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to hold a hearing to determine whether there was a need for further litigation.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on March 27, 2018.

gold_sents: On October 20, 2017, four minor plaintiffs filed a class action lawsuit against King County and sought injunctive and declaratory relief for King County’s policy and practice of holding children in solitary confinement at King County's Maleng Regional Justice Center.[SENTMARKER]The Court approved the parties' settlement agreement and the plaintiffs will receive $240,000 from King County and $25,000 from the Kent School District.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is set to expire on January 31, 2022 if defendant complies with all terms.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2018, a class-action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington on behalf of children held at King County's Maleng Regional Justice Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that King County’s pervasive policy of holding children who have not been convicted of any crime in long term solitary confinement and denying them an adequate education violated their constitutional rights and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act of 1983 (IDEA).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, monetary relief, and the appointment of a guardian for each child held at the King County Jail.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in May 2018 and the case was dismissed by Judge John C. gold_sents: On April 3, 2008, Muslim prisoners sued the Wyoming Department of Corrections for violations of First Amendment Rights and the RLUIPA for failure to accommodate their religious practices.[SENTMARKER]The case was resolved by Consent Decree on November 19, 2008.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 3, 2008, two Muslim prisoners, Joseph Miller and Hurie Purdiman, Jr., filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Wyoming against the Wyoming Department of Corrections (WDOC) and the Warden of the Wyoming State Penitentiary (WSP) seeking relief under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution and injunctive relief and nominal damages.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that WDOC's policy requiring prisoners to eat their meals within twenty minutes after delivery, after which the meals are confiscated, substantially burdens their ability to practice their religion, as they must choose between eating their mea ls and praying.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment to prison officials on Mr. Shakur's RLUIPA claim, but the Ninth Circuit reversed.[SENTMARKER]The parties have reached a compromise that this Court may dismiss the case for attorney's fees.

gold_sents: Two non-profit organizations, the Colorado Criminal Defense Bar and the Colorado Criminal Justice Reform Coalition brought this lawsuit under 28 U.S.C. § 2201(a) against Colorado on December 2, 2010 in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by pro bono private counsel, sought a declaratory judgment that a Colorado statute was unconstitutional, violating the Sixth Amendment and Fourteenth Amendments by deferring the appointment of counsel to indigent defendants until after the prosecuting attorney has spoken with the defendant.[SENTMARKER]This case was voluntarily dismissed after the Colorado legislature passed a new statute that removed the requirement and subsequently allocated significant new funding to provide attorneys at initial appearances.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 1, 2008, Colorado criminal defendants filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against the Attorney General of the State of Colorado, the State Public Defender, and the District Attorneys of Colorado for violating the Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution by deferring the appointment of counsel for certain indigent criminal defendants until after such defendants engage in discussions with prosecuting attorneys regarding potential plea offers.[SENTMARKER]The defendants alleged that the defendants were denied their right to counsel under Colorado Rev Stat.[SENTMARKER]16-7-301(4), which requires the defendants to engage in uncounseled plea discussions with the prosecuting attorney.[SENTMARKER]On January 10, 2013, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the parties' motion, finding that the statute was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on July 10, 2013 and the parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed that the defendant would no longer conduct plea negotiations with the defendants.

gold_sents: Individuals who were eligible to be assigned a public defender in New Orleans, but were placed on a waiting list due to budgetary shortages, sued the city (OPD) and Louisiana state public defender's offices for violating their Constitutional rights to counsel, due process, and equal protection.[SENTMARKER]They seek attorney's fees and a declaratory judgment that their rights were violated.[SENTMARKER]On June 15, 2016 the parties filed a joint motion for judgment granting final declaratory and partial injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]On October 27, 2016 the court sua sponte raised the issue of subject matter jurisdiction, giving both parties a chance to submit briefs addressing the issue.[SENTMARKER]On January 31, 2017 the court (Judge James Brady) dismissed the case, citing grounds of federalism and comity.[SENTMARKER]On September 25, 2017 plaintiffs appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]On October 4, 2018 the Fifth Circuit dismissed the case as moot because it found that since the appeal was filed, Louisiana lawmakers had reallocated funding for appointed counsel sufficient to render the waitlists for non-capital defendants nonexistent.[SENTMARKER]This case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 14, 2016, three Orleans Parish arrestees filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana against the Orleans Public Defender’s Office and the Louisiana State Public Defender Board.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought to represent a class of Orleans Parish residents who had been or will be denied counsel indefinitely because of the State of Louisiana’s chronic underfunding of its public defender system.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a motion to dismiss, finding that it was required to increase funds for public defense services.[SENTMARKER]The Fifth Circuit affirmed the district court's dismissal of the case on August 23, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: A juvenile sex offender and his parents filed a lawsuit in 2013 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama objecting to the Sheriff's Office's program of unannounced, random, and suspicion-less compliance investigations of every individual in the county who is subject to requirements of the Alabama Sex Offender Registration and Community Notification Act, Ala.[SENTMARKER]Code  § 15-20A-4(12).[SENTMARKER]On February 13, 2014 the Court dismissed the case because they were informed that the parties reached a written agreement on the merits of the action and litigation costs
pegasus_output_sents: On April 13, 2013, a sex offender and his wife filed this civil rights suit in the United States District Court for the Northern district of Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subject to random, suspicionless searches of their homes without their consent and were threatened with arrest if they refused to cooperate with the searches.[SENTMARKER]They sought a declaration that their rights had been violated, a permanent injunction against future compliance inspections without suspicion, and damages from Defendants in their individual capacities to compensate them for their unlawful treatment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On June 26, 2003, two separate suits were filed against the City of Oakland and the Oakland Police Department (OPD), and related defendants, in federal court.[SENTMARKER]The suits were filed in response to the OPD's actions on April 7 at a peaceful antiwar demonstration at the Port of Oakland.[SENTMARKER]The Police, without giving sufficient notice to disperse and without provocation, barraged demonstrators with a variety of "less-lethal" munitions, while blocking the main exit routes.[SENTMARKER]Police pursued demonstrators and others present when they attempted to disperse, while continuing to fire at them and intentionally strike them with motorcycles.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2003, the Court ordered that the cases be officially related and heard before the same judge.[SENTMARKER]One of the two cases, Local 10 ILWU v. City of Oakland, was filed as a class-action on behalf of all persons who attended the April 7 demonstration.[SENTMARKER]City of Oakland, was filed as a class-action on behalf of all persons who attended the April 7 demonstration.[SENTMARKER]The suit also named as plaintiffs Local 10 of the International Longshore and Warehouse Union, plus nine of its members who were "standing by" in the vicinity of the demonstration but not active participants in it.[SENTMARKER]The other suit, Coles v. City of Oakland, sought relieve for several individual demonstrators who were allegedly injured by the OPD.[SENTMARKER]City of Oakland, sought relieve for several individual demonstrators who were allegedly injured by the OPD.[SENTMARKER]In both cases, Plaintiffs sought compensatory, exemplary, and punitive damages, as well as to recover legal costs.[SENTMARKER]They also sought declaratory judgments holding the Defendants' actions to be unlawful violations of the Plaintiffs' rights under the Constitutions of the U.S. and of California and of statutory law.[SENTMARKER]They sought injunctions that among other things would prohibit the Defendants from unlawfully interference with the constitutional and statutory rights of participants in public demonstrations and protests.[SENTMARKER]On December 24, 2004, the parties entered a court-approved partial settlement addressing the Plaintiffs' claims for injunctive relief to the extent that those claims related to the Defendants' crowd control policies.[SENTMARKER]Oakland adopted a new official Crowd Control Policy that forbade the police from dispersing crowds that had not behaved illegally or that did not pose a clear and present danger of imminent violence.[SENTMARKER]It also forbade the indiscriminate use of less-lethal weapons directly against crowds, even when specific individuals in the group were violent.[SENTMARKER]The remaining issues eventually settled, with awards of damages and attorneys' fees well in excess of $1,000,000.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 7, 2003, a group of anti-war protesters held an anti-Iraq war demonstration at the Port of Oakland in the City of Oakland, California.[SENTMARKER]On several occasions during the demonstration, after issuing dispersal orders to the crowd, officers from the Oakland Police 15 Department (OPD) employed crowd dispersal tactics which included the use of "less than lethal" ammunition, a motorcycle "BUMP" technique and police batons to move protesters away from areas where they were blocking traffic.[SENTMARKER]On October 1, 2003, the parties began negotiations gold_sents: The plaintiff filed the lawsuit on November 29, 2012 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, a demonstrator involved in the Occupy Oakland protest movement, alleged that when he was returning home from a protest, two Oakland police officers brutally beat him with clubs, sprayed painful chemicals in his face, and arrested him.[SENTMARKER]The suit was filed under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, and alleged that the polices' actions violated his First Amendment right to free speech, his Fourteenth Amendment rights to equal protection and due process, and the Fourth Amendment ban on unreasonable searches and seizures.[SENTMARKER]After two settlement conferences, the parties reached a settlement agreement which was ordered by the court on January 30, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The Defendants paid $645,000 to the plaintiff to compensate his claims including attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 2, 2011, a veteran of the war in Afghanistan participated in a political protest in the City of Oakland in support of economic justice and in response to brutality by the Oakland Police Department against the Occupy Oakland movement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging that Oakland Police Officer Frank Uu and other Oakland Police officers beat and arrested him in retaliation for his exercise of his First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the officers violated the plaintiff's rights to freedom of speech 14 and association, under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution, and California Civil Rights Act  52.1.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the suit in January 2014, and the case was dismissed on March 29, 2013.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to the San Francisco division of the court.

gold_sents: Protestors in downtown LA alleged they were unlawfully detained, searched, interrogated, and some arrested during demonstrations in November, 2014.[SENTMARKER]They brought a class action lawsuit against the City alleging violations of their 1st, 4th, and 14th amendment rights, as well as California state rights.[SENTMARKER]A settlement was reached on May 11, 2020, granting plaintiffs $750,000 of attorney's fees, court fees, and class damages.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 26, 2014, the National Lawyers Guild (NLG) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California against the City of Los Angeles and the Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) alleging that the LAPD violated the First Amendment rights of protesters by unlawfully arresting and detaining them without probable cause during two public demonstrations in downtown Los Angeles on November 26, 2014 and November 28, 2014 in violation of California  910 et seq.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that at the start of the march, LAPD officers instructed the protestors that they would be arrested if they marched in the street.[SENTMARKER]After an hour, plaintiffs began to march peacefully west on Beverly 24 Boulevard.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were ordered by the LAPD to continue the protest by marching in the streets.[SENTMARKER]The pretext for the LAPD’s actions was the purported interference with 28 traffic caused by the march.[SENTMARKER]The class consists of two damages subclasses and an injunctive relief class Id.[SENTMARKER]On January 10, 2019, the parties filed a notice of class certification, which was granted in part.[SENTMARKER]On February 13, 2020, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay the plaintiffs a total of $484,290 in damages, $476,801.93 in attorney's fees, and a portion of the costs of the case.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the court at a later date.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for final approval of the settlement on May 25, 2019.

gold_sents: In 2020, residents of Los Angeles filed a putative class action complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that false claims of gang association and gang identity led to unreasonable searches, seizures, and imprisonment that violated their First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of September 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 9, 2020, a class action lawsuit was filed against the City of Los Angeles, the Los Angeles Police Department, and the U.S. Department of Justice for violations of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution and the California Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the constitutional rights of a class of similarly situated individuals throughout Los Angeles who were victims of scofflaw LAPD officers who filed fraudulent reports, lied under oath, and abused 20 gang database systems.[SENTMARKER]The majority of those in the database were Black 4 and Latino men.[SENTMARKER]The class is represented by counsel with class action litigation experience, particularly against the L.A.[SENTMARKER]Police Department.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Judge Andre Birotte Jr. on August 5, 2020 and the parties entered a settlement agreement on August 10, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement, which is subject to court approval, provides that the plaintiffs will be compensated for all of their attorney's fees, costs, and any other costs associated with the case.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also provides for a permanent injunction against the defendants from violating the civil rights of innocent people.

gold_sents: This class action lawsuit was filed in response to police actions amidst the nationwide protests that ensued following the police killing of George Floyd.[SENTMARKER]The complaint, filed by seven private individuals, argues that the police use of weapons like pepper balls, pepper spray, and rubber bullets constituted violations of the protesters' First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The suit established two classes of plaintiffs, the Arrest Class and the Direct Force Class.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of January 2, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 29, 2020, a group of Denver residents filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Denver against Denver Police, the City of Denver, and other law enforcement agencies in the City and County of Denver.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Denver Police and officers from other agencies in Denver's mutual-aid network used violent crowd control tactics against peaceful protestors during the protests following the murder of George Floyd on May 25, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged that the defendants violated their and class members' First Amendment rights under the First Amendment by engaging in expressive activities in the city and county.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the case was dismissed on May 30, 2020.

gold_sents: Plaintiff brings this lawsuit under the Fourth Amendment, claiming that her rights were violated by a search of her home that was conducted without probable cause.[SENTMARKER]She claims that she was prevented from entering her home while the police conducted an illegal search based on misinformation and poorly conceived police procedures.[SENTMARKER]She claims that the officers during the arrest were abusive mentally and physically.[SENTMARKER]On September 30, 2016, the Court granted in part and denied in part the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]In May 2017, the parties reached a private settlement agreement and stipulated to a dismissal of the case, which is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 27, 2012, two residents of the District of Columbia filed this civil rights action against the Metropolitan Police department and the District.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the residents' Fourth Amendment rights when they entered their home and seized their property without a warrant.[SENTMARKER]The residents alleged that they were humiliated and embarrassed when the officers arrested and humiliated them after finding a gun in a jacket one of the residents represented belonged to him.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the complaint on January 12, 2009, and the case was dismissed with prejudice on January 9, 2016.[SENTMARKER]On April 24, 2016, the parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the District's Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a joint status report on or before January 9, 2017, regarding the status of the settlement negotiations.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeal granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on January 10, 2017, and the parties settled the case on April 24, 2017.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 1, 2020, Black Lives Matter D.C. filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Federal Bureau of Narcotics, the United States Attorney's Office, and the Metropolitan Police Department for violating the First Amendment rights of civil rights activists.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their rights when they used force to disperse peaceful protesters in and near Lafayette Square on June 1, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On May 31, 2020, President Donald Trump tweeted, "These people [civil rights protesters] are ANARCHISTS.[SENTMARKER]This is part of the system that seeks to change."[SENTMARKER]On June 2, 2020, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and granted the plaintiffs' request for injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]On August 7, 2020, President Trump issued a statement in which he described the protesters as "anarchists" and said that he would not enter St. John's Church.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion and granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants on August 7, 2020.

pegasus_output_sents: On November 24, 2009, a group of gay men sued the City of Atlanta, the Atlanta Police Department, and the Atlanta Red Dog Unit alleging that the defendants violated their civil rights under the United States Constitution and Georgia Constitution by conducting a warrantless raid of a gay bar on September 10, 2009 without search or arrest warrants.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the raid violated their constitutional rights to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures and to ask questions of and make comments to police officers regarding the discharge of their duties.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order in December 2010, which required the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with electronic mobile phones and Blackberries for inspection and to provide their online user-ids and passwords to third party internet providers to release online content.[SENTMARKER]On January 17, 2017, the parties filed an emergency petition for relief, which was dismissed by Judge Richard W. Story, who dismissed it as "procedurally improper."[SENTMARKER]The parties are now trying to determine whether the City is obligated to pay the plaintiffs' attorney's fees expended in defending against the emergency petition.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In November 1974, several individuals and groups filed a civil rights action against Chicago's mayor and police officials, claiming that they had engaged in unlawful intelligence gathering and electronic surveillance.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants had violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights, and they sought both damages and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]After the case was consolidated with a number of related cases, in August 1981, the parties entered into a consent decree settlement.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree barred the City from political spying, harassment, and investigation of certain activities protected by the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Despite the settlement, decades of litigation addressing enforcement of the decree followed.[SENTMARKER]In April 2011, the district court granted the City's motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The court's order permitted the plaintiffs to file a motion to reinstate the consent decree within 45 days if the City did not conduct an audit showing compliance with the terms of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]There was no further legal action taken by either party.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 11, 1981, a class action was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois on behalf of a group of political dissidents who alleged that the Chicago police department's Intelligence Division had violated their rights under the First Amendment and the Privacy Act of 1974 by conducting a domestic security investigation with the intent to harass and intimidate various groups and individuals for expressing their political views.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief and $17 million in damages.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree on August 11, 1981 and the parties signed a settlement agreement in the fall of 1981.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the FBI would not conduct domestic security investigations in the city of Chicago.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on October 2, 1991 and the case was re-opened on September 2, 2001.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed a motion with the court to enforce the consent consent decree, and the court granted the motion on rehearing en banc.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the defendants had violated the decree and ordered the FBI to comply with the decree.[SENTMARKER]In September 2001, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs and dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment of the district court was reversed and remanded the case with instructions to make the modifications to the decree that the City requested.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States later ruled that the case should be dismissed.

gold_sents: In a lawsuit filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, the plaintiffs challenged Chicago Police Department's alleged unconstitutional pattern and practice of detaining persons under its control for excessive periods of time and under conditions plaintiffs claimed reached the level of "soft torture."[SENTMARKER]This case settled on October 6, 2010 for $16.5 million.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 12, 2002, a class action was filed in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois on behalf of individuals who were detained in excess of 48 hours pending approval of felony charges by the State's Attorney in connection with a crime of which both were innocent.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants failed to provide proper bedding, nutrition, and access to sanitation for those in their custody.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the conditions in the interrogation rooms amount to physical and psychological "soft torture," which lead to increased suggestibility for the person being interrogated, and to false confessions.[SENTMARKER]The court granted class certification on October 12, 2004, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement in August of 2003.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was entered into to effect a full and final settlement with prejudice of all claims against the defendant.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to approval by the City Council of the City of Chicago.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed not to seek from the Court an award of attorney's fees, costs, or expenses in more than $5,000, and the settlement fund has been fully exhausted through payments to Class Members and any remaining members of one or more alleged classes.

gold_sents: On March 19, 2015 three Chicago residents filed suit against the City of Chicago and several members of the Chicago Police Department for unlawful arrest and detention and excessive use of force at the Homan Square detention facility.[SENTMARKER]In May 2015 defendants filed a motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]On March 31, 2016, the Court granted the defendants motion to dismiss; the dismissal order came 150 days later, though a written opinion and order came down on January 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed the Court's decision to grant the motion to dismiss to the Seventh Circuit after the written order was issued.[SENTMARKER]A Seventh Circuit panel agreed with the district court on September 30, 2019; they wrote that the appeal was not filed in a timely manner, and that the underlying case was filed after the statute of limitations had passed.[SENTMARKER]This decision was not appealed and the case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 2011, three Chicago residents were detained by Chicago police officers at Homan Square for eight to nine hours in violation of the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their Fourth Amendment right to be free from the use of excessive and unreasonable force.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the suit as untimely under the applicable two-year statute of limitations.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case by minute order on March 31, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed, and the district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the defendants are no longer required to pay the plaintiffs.

gold_sents: This case arose out of the protests that took place nationally after the police killings of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs were six individuals and one political group called the Kentucky Alliance Against Racial and Political Repression.[SENTMARKER]They filed a class-action suit against the Louisville and Jefferson County Metro Government and the Louisville police.[SENTMARKER]The complaint argued that police tactics used to quell the protests constituted violations of the U.S. Constitution as well as common law battery and assault.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of October 12, 2020
pegasus_output_sents: On May 28, 2020, a group of peaceful protesters in the city of Louisville, Kentucky, filed a civil rights lawsuit against the city's police department, alleging that the police department's use of tear gas against peaceful protesters violated their First and Fourth Amendment rights to protest and demand change from their government.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the district of Kentucky.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' use of crowd control weapons, including tear gas, flash bangs, impact rounds, batons, and other comparable crowd control weaponry, violated their constitutional rights to free speech and assembly and to record police misconduct.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: In July 1999, the U.S. Department of Justice [DOJ] initiated an investigation pursuant to 42 U.S.C. § 14141 of alleged misconduct by the Canine Section of the Prince George's County Police Department [PGPD].[SENTMARKER]The investigation followed some eighteen civil rights lawsuits filed between 1993 through 1998 by individuals that alleged dog attacks by the PGPD's canine unit.[SENTMARKER]Following the DOJ's investigation, DOJ, PGPD and local FOP officials met and negotiated agreements to address all of the DOJ's concerns which resulted in a Consent Decree being entered on January 22, 2004.[SENTMARKER]On February 12, 2007, the Court granted the motion stating that PGPD had a) complied fully with the consent decree, and b) eliminated the last vestiges of unlawful behavior and had thus satisfied the decree.
pegasus_output_sents: In July 1999, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a civil rights complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland alleging that the Prince George's County Police Department (PGPD) engaged in a pattern or practice of excessive force by officers of the PGPD's Canine Section (the "Canine Section") and by the failure of the County Defendants to adopt and implement proper management practices and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the use of choke holds and similar carotid holds by PGPD officers violated the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution's Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 11, 2004, the parties entered into a consent decree, which was terminated on March 11, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the parties to implement a personnel performance management system (PARS) for the Canine Section.[SENTMARKER]The PARS system is an automated personnel management system which was mandated in the Pittsburgh Police Department's Pittsburgh Consent Decree in 2003 and was implemented in the Villa Rica, Georgia Police Department, the Detroit, Michigan Police Department and the Mount Prospect, Illinois Police Department.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required the defendants to post each report on the County's public website.[SENTMARKER]On January 22, 2009, the parties signed a second consent decree in which the consent decree was terminated and the parties agreed to implement new policies and procedures to ensure compliance with the terms of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $100,000.

gold_sents: This is a case brought by the U.S. Department of Justice to remedy an alleged pattern or practice of unconstitutional misconduct by the Detroit Police Department, including the excessive use of force, false arrest, improper warrantless searches and failure to protect detainees.[SENTMARKER]It was filed in 2003, simultaneously with a consent decree in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The District Court adopted the decree, and monitoring has continued since.[SENTMARKER]The consent judgments were terminated on August 25, 2014 after a finding of substantial compliance.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and the City of Detroit, Michigan (City) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan on June 12, 2003 against the City for violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to display posters in the Detroit Police Department (DPD) that were compliant with the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the posters violated the ADA because they were not displayed in a manner that would be accessible to people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]On June 12, 2003, the parties filed two Consent Judgments with the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The consent judgments were entered on July 18, 2003, and the parties agreed to pay a total of $2,200 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The District Court entered two consent judgments on July 12, 2003.[SENTMARKER]On July 18, 2013, the parties amended the consent judgments to remove the posters.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the defendants would pay the plaintiffs for the cost of publicizing the consent judgment.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a final judgment against the defendants on July 22, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion for a declaratory judgment on July 23, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The district judge entered a judgment against Detroit on July 24, 2014, and the case was closed.

gold_sents: Several Missouri residents sued the City of Ferguson, Missouri, for acts allegedly perpetrated by Ferguson police officers in the wake of the civil unrest that followed the August 2014 shooting of Michael Brown.[SENTMARKER]The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri granted summary judgment to the defendants on qualified immunity grounds in 2016.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Eighth Circuit court of appeals, which affirmed the district court's ruling in part but reversed the grant of summary judgment on the excessive force claims of one plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]A jury found in favor of the defendants at trial, and the case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 13, 2016, a group of African-American citizens filed a federal civil rights suit against the City of Ferguson, the city's police department, and the county.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their civil rights by using racial slurs and excessive force against them while they were arrested at a Peace and Love rally in Ferguson.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants summary judgment on all of the plaintiffs' claims.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the individual defendants qualified immunity on plaintiffs'  1983 excessive force claims.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the plaintiffs appealed the district court's dismissal of their claims, claiming that the court had misapplied the law.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court remanded the case for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In January 2010, plaintiffs filed a class action suit against City of New York and the New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) claiming claim that the city and NYCHA employed a pattern and practice of illegal stops, seizures, questioning, searches, and false arrests of residents of, and authorized visitors to, NYCHA residences.[SENTMARKER]Nine plaintiffs settled, but nine remain.[SENTMARKER]In 2015, the parties settled, and they are currently implementing the terms of the settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: In 1999, the Center for Constitutional Rights filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on behalf of African-American and Latino residents of public housing properties in the Bronx and New York City.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the New York Police Department's policy, practice, and custom of operating roving pedestrian checkpoints, otherwise known as "vertical patrols" or "vertical sweeps," in NYCHA violated the Fair Housing Act and the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on May 21, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled the case in February 2015, with the parties agreeing to pay $270,000 to settle the individual damages claims of the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to revise the NYPD's rules regarding cooperation with NYPD inquiries, among other things, that the NYPD would not use personal information from the stop database to conduct criminal investigations.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed that the NYCHA would not enforce any of the terms of the settlement.

pegasus_output_sents: In July 2007, a Brooklyn resident, Sean Elijah Bell, filed a civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District Of New York against the New York Police Department, alleging that the defendants failed to adequately train, supervise, discipline, sanction or otherwise direct its police officers, including the officers at the scene in this case, regarding the protection of the constitutional rights of citizens and failed to tear down the "Blue Wall of Silence" so as to force the disclosure of these constitutional abuses and to take corrective measures.[SENTMARKER]The defendants, the City of NYC and the NYPD, have as a matter of policy and practice with deliberate indifference failed to properly train and supervise the police officers involved in this incident.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to hold a 50-H hearing in advance of commencing this lawsuit.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the court on October 2, 2007 and the parties entered into a settlement agreement on October 3, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement provided for the payment of $75,000 to the estate of the deceased, $50,000 to each of the officers involved, and $50,000 to the NYPD.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also provided for a permanent injunction against the use of excessive force.

gold_sents: New York Attorney General Letitia James filed this lawsuit against the NYPD on behalf of New York residents on January 14, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the NYPD regularly falsely arrested and used excessive force against peaceful protesters during the 2020 racial justice protests in violation of the First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]It also alleged violations of the New York State Constitution and state law, including instances of assault, battery, and false arrest and imprisonment by NYPD officers.[SENTMARKER]The suit sought declaratory and injunctive relief requiring the NYPD cease unconstitutional policing practices and change its existing policies and training practices.[SENTMARKER]As of March 7, 2021, the case is ongoing before the District Court.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 30, 2020, a group of civil rights activists filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the NYPD, alleging that the NYPD used unnecessary and excessive force against peaceful protesters at the 2020 Racial Justice Protests.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that NYPD officers used violence indiscriminately while making arrests of protesters who were unable to disperse from the protest zone.[SENTMARKER]As a result of the NYPD Officers’ actions, hundreds of peaceful protesters were wrongly detained for hours.[SENTMARKER]The NYPD continued its practice of unlawfully detaining and arresting people at the Protests, and the National Lawyers Guild and other legal observers routinely monitored the protests.[SENTMARKER]In a settlement agreement, the NYPD agreed to pay more than $1 million to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the NYPD to train, supervise, and discipline NYPD officers in the future.

gold_sents: Following an eight-year investigation, the United States DOJ filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 14141 against the City of Warren, Ohio and its police department.[SENTMARKER]The United States alleged that the Warren Police Department had engaged in a pattern of conduct involving the use of excessive force.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a quick, court-approved settlement that required the WPD to adopt new protocols and procedures.[SENTMARKER]The court terminated the decree in August 2019 after the U.S. determined that the WPD fully complied with the settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 2004, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this civil rights class action in the United District Court for the Northern district of Ohio.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Warren Police Department (WPD) engaged in a pattern or practice of violating the Fourth Amendment by subjecting individuals to excessive force in violation of the Constitution and the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994.[SENTMARKER]The complaint sought injunctive and declaratory relief for the defendants' violations of law.[SENTMARKER]On January 26, 2012, the parties reached a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into the settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on January 26, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement a new body-cavity and strip search policy, which will be posted on the website of the Special Litigation Section of the Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed that all non-anonymous complainants will be kept informed periodically regarding the status of the complaint investigation.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also requires that the city of Warren and the WPD maintain a record of all complaints filed against the city.[SENTMARKER]The case was handled by the Special litigation section of the DOJ's Office of Public Affairs.
