pegasus_output_sents: On May 30, 2020, a group of African-American protestors in Columbus, Ohio, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio against the City of Columbus and the Franklin County Prosecutor's Office alleging that a city-wide curfew was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the curfew violated the plaintiffs' Fourth Amendment rights by prohibiting them from participating in a peaceful protest, videotaping the events, serving as medics or reporters, and/or residing in the neighborhood.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, arguing that the plaintiffs had not alleged a seizure.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that plaintiffs had standing to sue.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This class-action lawsuit was filed on June 28, 2020 in response to Portland Police Bureau's allegedly illegal tactics in quelling the protests in that city after the police killing of George Floyd in May of 2020.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, who were members of media and legal observers of the protests, argued that their First Amendment and Fourth Amendment rights were violated by the PPB's use of pepper spray and rubber bullets, among other weapons.[SENTMARKER]They sought injunctive, declaratory, and monetary relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a TRO against the city, prohibiting the police from arresting or seizing the equipment of reporters or legal observers of the protests.[SENTMARKER]The court later granted a preliminary injunction against the city.[SENTMARKER]By July 16, President Trump had sent in federal officers from the DHS and USMS as reinforcement.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs added those two organizations as defendants and filed a motion for a TRO and preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The motion for temporary restraining order and the motion for preliminary injunction were both granted.[SENTMARKER]These decisions were appealed to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which has yet to rule on them.[SENTMARKER]However, on October 9, the Ninth Circut declined to stay the preliminary injunction pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The federal defendants filed a motion to dismiss, which remains pending.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing as of December 31, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 2019, a group of journalists covering the protests over the murder of George Floyd filed a class-action lawsuit in the District Court of Oregon against the City of Portland, the Portland Police Bureau, and the United States District Attorney's Office.[SENTMARKER]The journalists alleged that the Portland police had violated their First Amendment rights by using lethal or "less lethal" weapons against protesters and other neutrals who were documenting the police's violent response to the protests.[SENTMARKER]On June 30, the journalists filed a motion for a temporary restraining order ("TRO") and preliminary injunction against the federal defendants.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a TRO against the Federal Defendants on July 23, and the case was dismissed on August 10.[SENTMARKER]On August 10, the plaintiffs filed an appeal to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court dismissed the appeal, finding that the district court did not abuse its discretion in finding irreparable harm.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.

pegasus_output_sents: In July 2003, a class action was brought in the United States District Court for the District of Philadelphia on behalf of individuals who were arrested by Philadelphia Police officers on the basis of allegations that they owed fines and costs in connection with Motor Vehicle Code violations.[SENTMARKER]The named Plaintiff and the Plaintiff Class, who were indigent and unable to afford private counsel, were sentenced to periods of incarceration in the Philadelphia County Prison System until dates certain or until substantial amounts of money were paid to secure their release.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief as a result of the harms caused by Defendants' actions and the loss of fundamental constitutional rights under the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Plaintiff's motion for class certification on July 8, 2003 and the case was dismissed on July 10, 2003 without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The City of Philadelphia and the Traffic Court entered into a settlement agreement with the Plaintiff on July 11, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement provided for the Plaintiff to be released from custody with the financial means to pay a portion of the outstanding fine and costs, and for the Defendants to provide counsel to persons who are facing incarceration for violations of the Motor Vehicle code, including the named Plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the City would not enforce any of the terms of the settlement agreement.

pegasus_output_sents: In September 2006, a group of Hispanic high school soccer players filed a lawsuit against the Town of Coventry, Rhode Island, and several of its police officers under 42 U.S.C.  1983 ( 1983) and Rhode Island state law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their civil rights under the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution, as well as their rights to due process and equal protection pursuant to the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment to the defendants on all counts, but the case was appealed and the case went to the Rhode Island Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court upheld the district court's summary judgment, finding that there was no evidence that the plaintiffs were treated differently than others similarly situated based upon their race.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 14, 1978, the American Civil Liberties Union of Tennessee (ACLU-TN) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Tennessee against the City of Memphis, the Memphis Police Department, and several city officials.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the First Amendment rights of citizens exercising their right to freedom of speech and expression by using software that surveils social media for the purpose of political intelligence.[SENTMARKER]On August 10, 2018, the court granted the ACLU's motion for summary judgment in part and denied the City's Motion for Summary Judgment in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to comply with the terms of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree prohibited the use of social media to harass or intimidate persons exercising their First Amendment right.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the defendants to consult with the Federal Bureau of Investigation regarding national social media policies.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU-TN also alleged that it was an original party to the consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The Sixth Circuit affirmed the district court's decision to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action, relying on Laird Id.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 23, 2018, the Electronic Frontier Foundation and the Knight Institute filed a First Amendment lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against President Donald Trump, the White House, and White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the President's use of his personal Twitter account, @realDonaldTrump, as a primary vehicle for his official communications violated the First Amendment right to free speech.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, and an end to the practice of blocking individual users from the account.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants, and the case was remanded to the Second Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit affirmed the district court's decision on July 9, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Supreme Court, which remanded the case to the lower court.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 1964, a group of African American families filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant Jefferson Parish School Board had violated their rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by continuing to segregate the school system.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief, mandated desegregation of the school system, and required that the defendants use busing to speed up the integration process.[SENTMARKER]The injunction remained in place for several decades.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the School Board sought to implement a magnet school program in the hopes of boosting academics and increasing school diversity.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to supplement the desegregation plan to include the magnet school program, and the Court issued Consent Orders in 2008-2009 that enabled the School Board's plans.[SENTMARKER]However, issues arose in the following years with the School Board's implementation of the plan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants were using the Consent Orders as a pretext to conceal attempts to continue a system of racially segregated schools.[SENTMARKER]After the Consent Orders expired, the parties reached a settlement agreement and the Court declared Jefferson Parish Schools unitary in 2011.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 30, 1964, a group of African-American students in Jefferson Parish, Louisiana filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Louisiana alleging discrimination in the school system.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought class certification and an injunction to desegregate the public schools of Jefferson Parish and to eliminate the vestiges of the prior dual school system .[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion to intervene and entered a Final Judgment and Order dismissing the lawsuit with prejudice on June 30, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed an appeal in August 1971, which was denied by the district court and the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent agreement in August 1971.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to continue their affirmative efforts, in recruiting and outreach, to encourage applications for instructional and administrative positions from qualified Black applicants, and to make application to the Department of Education for the use of magnet programs as a voluntary desegregation methodology.[SENTMARKER]On August 10 1971, the District Court denied the appeal, and the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]In August 1971, the parties filed a joint motion to vacate and enter a final judgment and order dismissing the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the parties' motion for a stay of that order.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On Dec.[SENTMARKER]3, 1997, Barbara Grutter brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the University of Michigan Law School.[SENTMARKER]She claimed that, in denying her admission, the school discriminated against her on the basis of her race, and violated the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case made its way to the Supreme Court, which held that the law school's desire to obtain a "critical mass" of underrepresented minority students counted as a narrowly tailored use of race in its admissions process and was not unconstitutional.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 14, 2002, the University of Michigan's LS&A undergraduate law school rejected two applications for admission because of their race.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought to certify a class of all African American employees and applicants from 1979 to the present.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' request for declaratory and punitive damages, injunctive relief, and an injunction prohibiting the Law School from continuing to discriminate on the basis of race.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Court of Appeals reversed the district court's ruling, and the Supreme Court upheld the lower court ruling.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that the law school's admissions policy was narrowly tailored to serve its compelling interest in achieving a diverse student body.

gold_sents: On Oct. 14, 1997, two applicants who had been denied admission to the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor brought this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the university.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by public interest counsel, claimed that the university's admissions policy treated race as a predominant factor in granting admission, and that they, as white applicants, had been discriminated against in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case went to the Supreme Court, which held that the school's admission policy that automatically awarded 20 points out of a possible 150 to underrepresented minorities was not narrowly tailored to achieve the compelling interest of diversity in education and so violated the Equal Protection Clause.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 8, 2020, a group of African-American voters filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Georgia against the Secretary of State of Georgia and the DeKalb County Board of Registration.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Georgia's law requiring voters to pay postage on absentee ballot applications and absentee ballots constitutes an unconstitutional poll tax and an undue burden on the fundamental right to vote, especially in light of the current health crisis caused by COVID-19 and the resulting increase in absentee voting.[SENTMARKER]On April 30, 2020, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief, but denied their request for an injunction requiring the Secretary to provide prepaid postage for absentee ballots in time for the June 9, 2020 primary election.[SENTMARKER]On May 8, 2020, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a permanent injunction, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a conference with the Court and opposing counsel for the August runoff and the November general election.[SENTMARKER]The court granted relief to the plaintiffs in the form of a temporary restraining order requiring the defendants to provide pre-paid postage for their absentee ballots.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This suit was brought on May 19, 2020, by two non-profit organizations and three voter plaintiffs against the state of Louisiana to challenge Louisiana’s Excuse Requirement, Witness Requirement, and Cure Prohibition.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief enjoining the defendants from enforcing the Excuse and Witness Requirement, as well as provide absentee voters with notice and opportunity to cure defects in their absentee ballots for all elections in 2020 held in Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]On June 22, the court dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 11, 2020, the World Health Organization declared that it had become a pandemic.[SENTMARKER]On May 7, 2020, the League of Women Voters of Louisiana filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Louisiana seeking declaratory and injunctive relief under the Fourteenth Amendment and the Voting Rights Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Louisiana’s absentee ballot law violated the plaintiffs’ First and 14th Amendment rights as well as the voting rights of those who could not vote due to the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants’ motion to consolidate the two cases, and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 22, four individuals facing a heightened risk of contracting COVID-19 and the Family Unit, a non-profit organization, filed an action against the enforcement of South Carolina’s witness requirement applied to absentee voters, and the excuse requirement applied in order to vote by an absentee ballot.[SENTMARKER]On May 12, the South Carolina General Assembly passed legislation allowing all qualified South Carolina voters to vote by absentee ballot for the June primaries.[SENTMARKER]On May 25, the court granted the plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction motions in part, pertaining to the witness requirement.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, the Witness Requirement was enjoined for the November 2020 General Election in a separate case, and the district court stayed the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought reconsideration.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 1, 2020, the South Carolina Republican Party filed a motion in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina to intervene in a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of two provisions of the state's absentee voting laws.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the laws violated Section 201 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 by denying African-Americans the right to vote by absentee ballot and by requiring them to provide a witness signature on their absentee ballots.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a preliminary injunction, which the court granted on May 8, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On September 18, 2020, the court enjoined the witness signature requirement for all South Carolina voters in the upcoming November 2020 General Election.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed not to appeal.

gold_sents: In 2011 voters in Wisconsin filed this lawsuit in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that their fundamental right to vote had been violated by Act 23, Wisconsin's law implementing a voter ID requirement.[SENTMARKER]After much litigation, in 2016 a judge granted a preliminary injunction allowing voters without IDs to sign an affidavit in place of the ID requirement for the 2016 presidential election.[SENTMARKER]The state appealed the injunction to the Seventh Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit stayed the injunction pending the appeal.[SENTMARKER]As of December 2019, the appeal remained pending in the Seventh Circuit.
pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] 2011 Wisconsin Act 23 (the "photo ID law"), which requires voters in Wisconsin to present photo identification in order to cast their votes either in person at a polling place or by absentee ballot, was the subject of a lawsuit filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin in March 2012 by a group of voters who claimed that the law violated Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, but the case was appealed to the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit reversed the district court's decision, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: On June 21, 2016, individuals who had been forced to pay a $50 "extension fee" for inability to pay their monetary penalties in full, or go to gail for non-payment of court fines and costs, brought a putative class action lawsuit in the District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued the Bogalusa City Court and the sole judge who sits on the Bogalusa City Court, under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 alleging that the defendants (1) systematically jail and threaten to jail individuals who cannot pay fines and court costs that fund the city court; and (2) have created an illegal extension fee to generate additional revenue.[SENTMARKER]Shortly after U.S. District Court Judge Ivan L.R.[SENTMARKER]Lemelle denied the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, and held their request for a preliminary injunction in abeyance, the parties decided to explore settlement options.[SENTMARKER]They filed a stipulated agreement with the District Court, which was granted.

gold_sents: On June 20, 1989, foster care children of the District of Columbia filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by Children's Rights and the ACLU, asked the court to order improved policies related to protective services, family preservation and preventive services, child placement, case reviews, adoptions, and staffing, among other issues, claiming violations of 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 (AACWA), the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, the District of Columbia Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977, the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, and the District of Columbia Youth Residential Facilities Licensor Act of 1986.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that caseloads were too large, leaving many children in the foster care system for far too long with unresolved cases.[SENTMARKER]Additionally, the complaint alleged inappropriate placements for children and inadequate efforts to return children home.[SENTMARKER]In 1993, Judge Thomas F. Hogan approved a consent decree directing DHS to develop policies and procedures to rectify the system.[SENTMARKER]After many years of oversight, and periodic contempt orders, the system has gradually improved.[SENTMARKER]However, there is still a monitor in place reporting on the progress of the Child and Family Services Agency (CFSA) created as a result of this case.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 24, 2005, a group of abused and neglected children filed a class action suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Washington on behalf of children who were in the custody of the District's Department of Human Services (DHS) under the supervision of the DHS.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the DHS was violating the children's constitutional rights by failing to protect them from abuse and neglect and providing them with adequate services.[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a consent decree, which required the defendants to implement a number of corrective measures.[SENTMARKER]The parties worked out a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs in full and to provide the children with additional services.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the district court dismissed the case, but the parties appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the appeal, and the case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: On 2017, foster parents and three states filed a suit challenging the constitutionality of the Indian Child Welfare Act (the "ICWA").[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs allege the ICWA violates the Equal Protection Clause and anti-commandeering principles.[SENTMARKER]The district court held the ICWA is unconstitutional which was partially affirmed in a fractured en banc opinion by the Fifth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 7, 2018, a Native American couple filed this suit in the Fort Worth District Court, Texas, against the United States Department of Family Protective Services, the Bureau of Indian Affairs, and the Navajo Nation, alleging that the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) and the Final Rule violated the equal protection and nondelegation provisions of the Indian and Native American Civil Rights Act (APA) by denying them the ability to adopt A.L.M., a twenty-three-month-old girl.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the suit for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, but the district court denied the motion, concluding, as relevant to this appeal, that Plaintiffs had Article III standing.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted summary judgment in part, finding that ICWA violated equal protection, the Tenth Amendment, the anticommandeering doctrine, the Nondelegation doctrine and the Administrative Procedure Act, and that the challenged portions of Final Rule were invalid under the APA.[SENTMARKER]A panel of this court subsequently stayed the District Court's judgment pending further order of this appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now pending with the Supreme Court of Texas.[SENTMARKER]In a separate appeal, the defendants sought to have the case dismissed on the grounds of lack of standing, claiming that Plaintiffs lacked standing to bring this suit.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on all of their claims.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted Plaintiffs' motion to dismiss on the basis that the plaintiffs lacked standing, concluding that they had standing to challenge ICWA and the final rule as unlawful under the administrative procedure act.

gold_sents: California recipients of Adult Day Health Care services brought this class action to enjoin California from reducing or eliminating the ADHC program, which would put the plaintiffs at risk of institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California granted the plaintiff class a preliminary injunction in September 2009, forbidding California to modify it's adult Day Health Care program until an appropriate alternative could be provided to prevent institutionalization of individuals in the plaintiffs' class.[SENTMARKER]The District Court approved a settlement agreement that created a new program which will help to prevent the institutionalization of ADHC beneficiaries.

gold_sents: Two individuals who use wheelchairs for mobility sued the City of Steamboat Springs, for having inaccessible public transportation and facilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree requiring the city to make its services and facilities accessible, pay attorneys' fees and costs, and pay $12,250 to the plaintiffs.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2000, two individuals with disabilities filed this class action suit in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado against the City of Steamboat Springs.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the city had violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to make its public transportation system readily accessible to and usable by persons who use wheelchairs and by denying the benefits of its services, programs, and activities, as more fully set forth above.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree that was final and binding on all parties.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the city to make improvements to its transit system and to provide training for all bus and van operators, dispatchers, and mechanics.[SENTMARKER]The decree also required the City to ramp or otherwise provide access to the restrooms at the Alpine Slide/stables area on the east side of the city's rodeo grounds.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 12, 2000 without prejudice.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs were disabled individuals who sued the Colorado Rockies baseball club after it removed accessible seats in Coors Field and raised prices on others.[SENTMARKER]There was a trial held, after which the court dismissed all claims by stipulation.[SENTMARKER]It is unclear, however, whether the parties settled.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 1, 2004, a group of Colorado baseball fans filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado on behalf of individuals with physical disabilities and their friends, relatives, and allies who attend events at Coors Field.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disability Act by failing to provide wheelchair-accessible seating that is an integral part of the fixed seating at the stadium.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that defendants failed to provide a choice of admission prices and lines of sight comparable to those for members of the general public.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for partial summary judgment on a single issue, stating that the only seats in the lower level of Coors Field were in the back, with a wheelchair number in the outfield and none behind home plate and in the premium box section.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on April 2, 2004 without prejudice.

gold_sents: On April 29, four individuals with disabilities and Disability Rights New York filed a complaint against Andrew Cuomo, the Governor of New York State.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the absence of live televised American Sign Language (ASL) interpretation in Governor Cuomo’s daily televised briefings on COVID-19 discriminated against populations with disabilities residing in New York by failing to provide a live ASL interpreter.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, declaring the lack of ASL interpretation as a violation under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO and preliminary injunction requiring the defendant to immediately include live in-frame ASL interpretation for all briefings addressed to New York residents.[SENTMARKER]The preliminary injunction was granted on May 11, and the defendant was ordered to immediately implement live, in-frame ASL interpretation for his daily press briefings.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2020, a group of deaf individuals filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against New York County and Governor Andrew Cuomo, alleging that the county violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (RA) by failing to provide an in-frame American Sign Language (ASL) interpreter at every meeting held to discuss emergency decontamination in the plaintiffs’ community.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Governor Cuomo's failure to provide the interpreter deprived them of effective communication in violation of the ADA and RA because there was no ASL interpreter at some of the meetings, and at other meetings the ASL interpreter spent time interpreting individual discussions instead of interpreting the large-group discussion.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on May 11, 2020, and the case was closed on April 23, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case has since been reopened and the deadline for discovery is June 8, 2020.

gold_sents: On April 8, 2014, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island alleging that Rhode Island violated the ADA by segregating individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities in sheltered workshops and facility-based day programs that denied them the opportunity to associate with those who did not have a disability.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2014, the District Court approved a Consent Decree where Rhode Island agreed to, among other things, provide employment planning services to individuals with developmental and intellectual disabilities designed to encourage and assist them in working in integrated working environments, provide state support and services for those working in integrated settings and those making the transition to those settings, programs to educate relevant individuals about the programs and benefits that the Rhode Island offers to those working in integrated settings.[SENTMARKER]Rhode Island must also implement policies regarding the services required by the Consent Decree, train its personnel in the new procedures and working with individuals with disabilities, and Rhode Island must help sheltered workshops change their structure to become integrated working environments.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 11, 2013, the United States entered into an interim settlement agreement with the State of Rhode Island and the City of Providence to resolve a Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Olmstead v. L.C., 527 U.S. 581, which alleged that the State and Providence violated the ADA by unnecessarily segregating individuals in two particular facility-based employment and day settings and placing those individuals at risk of such segregation.[SENTMARKER]L.C., 527 U.S. 581, which alleged that the State and Providence violated the ADA by unnecessarily segregating individuals in two particular facility-based employment and day settings and placing those individuals at risk of such segregation.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into the consent decree in April 2014 to provide relief to approximately 200 Rhode Islanders with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD) who received services from one of two public programs in Rhode Island.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the State to change the nature and operation of day and employment services furnished to individuals with IDD who receive publicly financed supports, including a sheltered workshop run by a private non-profit agency; and a special education program which ran a segregated sheltered workshop inside a Providence public high school.[SENTMARKER]On September 24, 2014, the Rhode Island Department of Education (RIDE), the Office of Rehabilitative Services (ORS), and the Providence Public Schools Department (PPSD) entered into a contract agreement to meet the terms of the Consent Decree between January 1, 2015 and September 30, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that RIDE, ORS, andPPSD would provide or ensure the provision of a significant number of training opportunities for individuals with disabilities, including family employment awareness training (FEAT), self-determination training, and discovery/employment training (EDT).[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the state would not discriminate against individuals who worked more than one job, and that the city would pay the cost of its own fees and expenses incurred in connection with the consent agreement.[SENTMARKER]On July 26, 2016, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by the court, and the parties agreed to enter into a new consent decree, which is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In this case, a third-grader plaintiff who had autism and ADHD filed suit against the Kanawha County Schools system under the IDEA, the Rehabilitation Act, Title II of the ADA, the West Virginia Human Rights Act, and West Virginia Policy 2419.[SENTMARKER]The elementary school student had been subject to disciplinary removal from the classroom and his district had failed to provide the behavioral supports and programming required by law.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) requires public schools to provide all eligible children with disabilities a free appropriate public education.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), 42 U.S.C.  12132, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (Section 504) of the West Virginia Human Rights Act (W.Va.[SENTMARKER]HRA) by failing to adequately evaluate students with disabilities, or effectively implement behavior plans and other interventions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, G.T., K.M., and The Arc of West Virginia, brought this action on behalf of themselves and a class of similarly situated students.[SENTMARKER]They sought certification of a class consisting of all elementary school students who need behavior supports and have experienced disciplinary removals from any classroom.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, dismissed the case for lack of jurisdiction, and denied their requests for additional relief.

gold_sents: In October 2016, a group of Flint schoolchildren (via their parents) sued the state of Michigan and the school district in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, alleging that the state of Michigan and local educators are in violation of federal law by not screening to identify students who need special education services and violating the rights of students with disabilities in the imposition of school discipline.[SENTMARKER]In April 2018, the parties reached a partial settlement as to one of the plaintiffs' claims, but the rest are still in dispute.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), 20 U.S.C.  1400 et seq., and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) were violated by the Genesee Intermediate School District (GISD), the Michigan Department of Education (MDE), and Flint Community Schools (FCS), according to the complaint.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to provide necessary special education and related services to children who were at risk of developing disabilities as a result of elevated levels of lead in the drinking water in Flint, Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss, claiming that the Court was without subject matter jurisdiction to hear the case because the plaintiffs failed to exhaust their administrative remedies under IDEA.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion, and the case is now pending before the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The appeals court has jurisdiction over the case.

gold_sents: On November 17, 2014, Students for Fair Admissions, Inc. filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina under The Civil Rights Act of 1964, against the University of North Carolina.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief to prohibit the consideration of race in college admissions, claiming that UNC's current admissions policy discriminated against Asian American applicants.[SENTMARKER]The court denied summary judgement and, as of April 9th, 2020, the suit is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 17, 2014, a group of prospective applicants and applicants to higher education institutions filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Attorney's Office for the Middle District of North North Carolina alleging that the University's use of race in its undergraduate admissions process violated the Fourteenth Amendment and federal civil rights laws.[SENTMARKER]The case was stayed until August 1, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a joint motion to dismiss the case, which was granted by the Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit on November 17, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion to intervene in defense of the admissions policy on November 20, 2015.[SENTMARKER]On November 20, 2015, the Court granted the motion, and the parties agreed that the case should be dismissed as to all claims involving the admissions process pending the Supreme Court's decision in Fisher v. gold_sents: Former students and an employee of Rhinebeck Central High School filed suit against the School District and the former principal alleging that the District had violated Title IX of the Education Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by failing to rectify allegations that the principal had sexually harassed the female students.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a Consent Decree in which the District agreed to implement anti-discrimination procedures.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 9, 2003, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York entered a consent decree with the Rhinebeck Central School District and Thomas Mawhinney, then the Principal of the High School, in response to a Title IX complaint filed by three female students who alleged that they were sexually harassed and discriminated against in violation of Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree, which was entered on August 29, 2003, requires the District to revise its written policy prohibiting harassment and discrimination on the basis of sex, provide concrete examples of sexual harassment, and implement a training program for all employees.[SENTMARKER]The District also requires that the District maintain a written record of each incident of harassment or discrimination, including how and to whom to report it, how to tile a formal complaint, and what steps the District will take to investigate complaints and discipline those found to have engaged in prohibited conduct.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the District is required to inform students and their parents, through a minimum of annual meetings with all students, an annual distribution of notices to students and parents, and inclusion in student and parent handbooks, of the District's policies prohibiting harassment, discrimination, and retaliation against any student who reports an incident.[SENTMARKER]The district is also required to provide the students with a copy of the training program.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the consent decree without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint.

gold_sents: A 16-year old transgender male student sued Kenosha Unified School District No. 1 (Kenosha) in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin on July 19, 2016, arguing that the school violated the Equal Protection Clause and Title IX by denying Plaintiff access to the boys’ restrooms.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiff a preliminary injunction to use the boys' restroom throughout his senior year, which the Seventh Circuit upheld on May 30, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled on January 22, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The settlement required Defendant to pay Plaintiff $800,000, enjoined Defendant from prohibiting Plaintiff from using the boys’ restroom, and required the Defendant to notify all staff about the injunction.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 15, 2016, a transgender student at Tremper High School in the Kenosha Unified School District (KUSD) filed a lawsuit against the KUSD in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern district of Wisconsin.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the school violated Title IX by denying him full and equal access to student restrooms and overnight accommodations during school-sponsored trips offered to other male students because of his gender identity.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the parties filed a joint motion to vacate and enter a consent judgment on December 27, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The court found in favor of the plaintiff on each of the three counts and entered a final judgment on January 22, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the defendants to pay the plaintiff $800,000 in damages and reasonable attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a petition for writ of certiorari before the United States Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court declined to hear the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On August 11, 2005 a group of African-Americans filed a consolidated amended complaint Wal-Mart Stores Inc. in United States District Court of the Eastern District of Arkansas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Wal-Mart discriminated against African-Americans in hiring of over-the-road truck drivers.[SENTMARKER]On May 16, 2007, the court certified a class of African Americans who had not been hired or had been deterred from applying for these jobs.[SENTMARKER]Discovery continued in preparation for trial and on January 13, 2009 the court denied the defendant's motions for decertification and summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties thereafter reached a settlement that was approved by the court on March 5, 2009.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement Wal-Mart agreed to damages in the amount of $17,500,000 to be distributed to the named representatives, class members, and their attorneys.[SENTMARKER]It also agreed to provide EEO training, actively recruit minorities, impose benchmarks for hiring minority drivers, make specific job opportunities open to minorities, and engage in recordkeeping and reporting.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 16, 2005, a class action lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the Eastern District Of Arkansas on behalf of African American over-the-road truck drivers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants recruited new truck drivers by having its current drivers pass out cards with a 1-800 number to call for an application and that the practice of having current drivers distribute this number was discriminatory.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on September 24, 2004, which required the defendants to pay $17,500,000 to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement agreement were as follows: The parties agreed that the defendant would not discriminate against African Americans when hiring for OTR truck driver positions.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendant to provide training regarding equal employment opportunities and specific compliance with the provisions of Title VII and  1981.[SENTMARKER]After May 2007, the parties conducted discovery on the merits of the class claims and the parties reached an agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay the plaintiffs $17, $500,000 to be paid by the end of the term of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment on June 16, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
