pegasus_output_sents: On March 31, 2005, a former employee of Smith Barney filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California alleging that Smith Barney discriminated against female employees on the basis of gender.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff alleged that she was subjected to a hostile work environment after she complained about unfair, discriminatory treatment to the highest levels of 8 the company, including to the Director of Human Resources.[SENTMARKER]Instead, Smith Barney disclosed the fact that she had complained to her male coworkers and retaliated against her for making such complaints.[SENTMARKER]As part of the settlement, the Plaintiff and Smith Barney entered into a settlement agreement, which required Smith Barney to implement various revisions to its policies and practices, to provide its Human Resources staff with appropriate training regarding compliance with state, federal, and local EEO laws, to enhance its technology to allow its account distribution process to be computer automated, to maintain its commitment to its female broker networking meetings, to pay the cost of such binding mediation, and to post on its intranet site a statement in support of its anti-discrimination and harassment policies.

gold_sents: On September 25, 2006, the Denver Field Office and the Phoenix District Office of the EEOC filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sued Moreland Auto Group, LLP under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]Two former female employees sought injunctive relief to enjoin the defendant from discriminating against employees based on gender or from retaliating against employees who complain about discrimination.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2008 Judge Edward J. Nottingham approved a settlement agreement that included a $70,000 fund to be dispersed amongst the claimants, and an injunction enjoining the defendants from gender-based discrimination.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2008, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado against Moreland Auto Group, LLP d/b/a Kids Automotive, Inc., Kids Financial, Inc, and Brandon Financial Inc. alleging discrimination under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, more than 30 days prior to the institution of this lawsuit, two female employees of Kids Automotive filed charges of discrimination with the EEOC alleging violations of Title VII by Moreland.[SENTMARKER]The female employees alleged that they were subject to sexual harassment and a hostile work environment, by failing to take prompt remedial action intended to eliminate the sexual harassment, and by retaliating against the female employees for complaining about the work environment.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants engaged in a pattern or practice of tolerating sexual harassment in the workplace, by subjecting female employees to pornographic materials on work computers; directing obscene gestures at female employees, such as pointing to male genitals; and (f) allowing nude and pornographic pictures of women to be displayed in the work place.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also allegedly retaliated against the employees for their complaints.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay $70,000 to each of the plaintiffs, to provide annual training to its officers, managers and employees regarding discrimination, and to pay their own costs and attorneys fees.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was entered into on August 22, 2008 and is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: This case was brought by ten black current and former special agents of the United States Secret Service against the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Treasury and the Secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought equitable relief including back pay, front pay, compensatory damages, a declaratory judgment, and an injunction, alleging that the Secret Service discriminated against them on the basis of race in promotions as well as in transfers, assignments, testing, hiring, and disciplinary practices.[SENTMARKER]The court approved a settlement agreement that awarded $24 million in damages, $8 million in attorney's fees, and $860,000 in costs.[SENTMARKER]The agreement will remain in place until 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 2000, ten African-American Special Agents of the U.S. Secret Service filed this employment discrimination action against the Secret Service under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, 42 U. S.C.  2000e, and the Civil rights Act of 1991, as amended.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were discriminated against because they were not promoted on the first bid list on which they bid for promotion to the GS-14 level during the years 1995-2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties ultimately settled the case in 1996 and the parties are now disputing the implementation of the settlement.[SENTMARKER]In August 2006, the plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint, alleging individual and putative class claims of disparate treatment and disparate impact based on race.[SENTMARKER]On February 25, 2013, the district court granted a motion for class certification, certified the class, and granted the plaintiffs' motion for monetary relief and changes to the promotion system.[SENTMARKER]The court of appeals denied the parties' appeal on August 1, 2015, and the case is now ongoing.

gold_sents: This case was brought by eight Hispanic Special Agents against the U.S. Department of Treasury's United States Customs Service.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs sought equitable relief, compensatory damages, a declaratory judgment, and injunctive relief, alleging there was a pattern and practice of discrimination on the basis of national origin by the U.S. Customs Service.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted Defendant's Motion for Summary Judgment on March 20, 2007, thereby terminating the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 11, 1998, the EEOC filed this class action complaint in the District Court of Columbia against the United States Department of Homeland Security (DHS) alleging discrimination on the basis of national origin in violation of Title VII of the Civil rights Act of 1964.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the DHS discriminated against Hispanic special agents by administering an exam known as the Special Agent OS-14 (SA-14) test, which constituted further retaliation against the complainant for actively prosecuting the case in the EEOC's administrative process.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC certified the class and the case proceeded for several years until it was settled in 1996.[SENTMARKER]On September 21, 2004, the DHS filed a motion for summary judgment on the ground that plaintiffs failed to exhaust their administrative remedies.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion and granted the plaintiffs' motion for further discovery.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the EEOC for further processing.[SENTMARKER]On October 22, 1999, after a series of appeals through the EEOC, the case was certified as a class action.[SENTMARKER]On May 10, 2002, the EEOC found that Contreras had Exhausted the Class Claims.[SENTMARKER]The complaint was dismissed as moot on February 15, 1995, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was reached and approved by the Court on November 15, 2002.[SENTMARKER]The parties are now before the Court.

gold_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed suit against Yellow Transportation, Inc., and YRC, Inc., for discriminatory employment practices on behalf of 14 current or former black employees and the class of similarly situated black employees.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that Yellow Transportation (later merged into YRC) had violated §703(a) of Title VII, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e-2(a) by subjecting black employees to greater scrutiny, more frequent and greater discipline, lower paying and less favorable job assignments, more difficult and time-consuming work, and a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC sought injunctive and monetary relief, including economic and noneconomic harm to the employees, punitive damages, development of policies and programs to provide equal employment opportunity and eradicate the effects of its past discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC also sought to recover its costs.[SENTMARKER]The charging parties later intervened as plaintiffs on their own behalf, adding claims for retaliation.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement, which was entered as a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree resolved this case and the related case Brown v. Yellow Transportation, Inc. , linked below (Clearinghouse code: EE-IL-0329).[SENTMARKER]The decree awarded a total of $11 million ($1.1 million in attorney's fees) and no significant injunctive relief because of a consent decree in other litigation.[SENTMARKER]The case is technically open but effectively closed.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against Yellow Transportation, Inc. (YRC) and YRC Inc., d/b/a Roadway Express, in March 2009 under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (Title VII).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that African-American employees at YRC's Chicago Ridge facility were subjected to harassment and different terms and conditions of employment because of their race.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that the defendants created a racially hostile work environment by tolerating the repeated hanging of nooses in conspicuous places at the facility, failing to investigate, and failing to take disciplinary action against those individuals who hung the nooses.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated for purposes of entering a consent decree, which provides monetary relief to eligible employees.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is subject to final approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the consent decree are confidential.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs sued Sprint, alleging ADEA violations pursuant to 29 U.S.C. § 621, the ADA, and 42 U.S.C. §12203.[SENTMARKER]Class comprised just under 1,700 members.[SENTMARKER]Eventually, parties reached $57 million settlement agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 23, 2003, the EEOC filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Kansas on behalf of a former on-air investigative reporter for Sprint's television news program.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) by terminating the reporter on the basis of her age in connection with the company's reduction-in-force (RIF) policy.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed her claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendant agreed to pay a total of $57 million dollars in monetary relief to the 1,697 members of the class.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was subject to approval by the EEOC and the district court.[SENTMARKER]The court granted summary judgment to the defendant in part and denied the defendant's motion for summary judgment in part.[SENTMARKER]In part, the court dismissed the plaintiff's claims for failure to exhaust administrative remedies.

gold_sents: On April 26, 2004, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, on behalf of a black female applicant, filed a lawsuit in the District Court of Maryland, under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, against Advancemed Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the defendant refused to hire the complainant because of her race.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree where the defendant, among other things, agreed to pay the complainant $22, 000.
pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland on November 3, 2004 against Advancemed Corporation, a Maryland-based health care company, alleging that Advancemed violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by refusing to hire a black woman for a position of Chief Nurse because of her race.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that AdvanceMed continued to solicit and hire a similarly or less qualified applicant outside of Ms. Gaston's protected class despite her rejection.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent decree in which Advancemed agreed to pay a total of $22,000, less applicable taxes and other deductions, and to provide a minimum of two hours equal employment opportunity training to all personnel involved in the screening, selection, and hire of employees at its Bethesda, Maryland facility.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge Peter J. Messitte and approved by Judge Charles B.[SENTMARKER]Day of the District Court on November 10, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a final judgment in favor of the EEOC on November 12, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: This is a race discrimination class action brought by black police officers in Baltimore, alleging discriminatory discipline and hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]It was filed in December 2004, and settled in June 2009 for $2.5 million in damages to the 15 named plaintiffs and injunctive relief for the class.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 4, 2004, 15 African American police officers filed a class action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland against the Baltimore Police Department and the City of Baltimore alleging that the City engaged in racial discrimination in connection with the administration of the disciplinary system for Baltimore police officers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were subjected to disparate discipline, retaliation, non-promotion, and a hostile work environment because of their race and/or color, and that the conduct violated Title VII and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The class is too numerous to be joined in one action.[SENTMARKER]In May 2005, the parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to fund and hold no less than five (5) leadership training classes during the five years following the effective date of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 2005, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the City of Pontiac and the local firefighters' union.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ alleged that the collective bargaining agreements entered by the Pontiac Fire Department and the local firefighters' union discriminated on the basis of sex and race by explicitly creating and maintaining a dual system for hire and promotion requiring that one out of every thee hires or promotions be given to a minority.[SENTMARKER]In 2006, the DOJ and the City of Pontiac reached a settlement that required the City of Pontiac to not engage in any act or practice that discriminated on the basis of race or sex in violation of Title VII in relation to hiring or promotion in the Pontiac Fire Department and to provide remedial relief to those employees and applicants denied hire or promotion as a result of the dual system for hire and promotion.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in October 2008.
pegasus_output_sents: Pontiac City of Pontiac, Michigan and the International Association of Fire Fighters (the "Union"), a union of professional fire fighters and paramedics, entered into a consent decree in 2005 to settle a lawsuit brought by the United States alleging that the City violated Title VII by maintaining a dual hiring and promotional system based on race and sex.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was entered by Judge George Caram Steeh on August 16, 2006 and required the City to provide a total of 12,200 in monetary relief to two white males who were not hired by the Pontiac Fire Department.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the City agreed not to enforce the dual hiring or promotional system in the future and will not unlawfully discriminate on the basis of race or sex in connection with hiring or promotions.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that the Union would not be required to provide complete rtllief relief from the lawsuit.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by Judge Steeh and the parties agreed to settle the case.

gold_sents: On August 29, 2002, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed suit in the Albuquerque U.S. District Court for the District of New Mexico against Bell Gas, Inc. and related corporations on behalf of a female employee.[SENTMARKER]The EEOC alleged that the companies had violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e et.[SENTMARKER]seq.) by subjecting the employee to a sexually hostile work environment created by verbal and physical harassment from her immediate supervisor, including sexual assault.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Decree, which provided the employee received a total of $180,000; $60,000 up front and monthly payments of $2,000 for 60 months-and subjected Defendants to an array of injunctive provisions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 4, 2004, the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit against Bell Gas, Inc., a New Mexico-based gas company, alleging that the company violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by subjecting a female employee to verbal and physical sexual harassment because of her sex.[SENTMARKER]The complaint further alleged that the employee was retaliated against for complaining about the sexual harassment by her immediate supervisor, a 47-year-old manager, who sexually harassed and raped her.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled by a consent decree that required the defendants to pay $180,000 to the employee and to provide training on sex discrimination and harassment to each new employee hired for the duration of this decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is in effect for a five-year period and is secured by a mortgage lien on defendants real property.

gold_sents: In 2006, the EEOC sued Consolidated Reports in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nevada alleging violations of Title VII's prohibition on sex discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged and employee of the defendant sexually harassed the charging party and created a hostile work environment.[SENTMARKER]In 2008, the case settled when the parties agreed to a 1 year consent decree requiring the defendant to pay $55,000 to the charging party, to adopt anti-discrimination policies, provide training to employees, and comply with other requirements.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 7, 2006, the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the 13 District of Nevada against Consolidated Resorts, Inc., a Las Vegas-based resort company, alleging that it discriminated against a female employee in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ("Title VII").[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the female employee, Erin Dawson, was forced, on four occasions, to perform oral sex on one of her supervisors, Ramiro Rouco, under the threat of losing her job.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that Ms. Dawson was subjected to unwanted touching of her breasts and private body area, exposed his genitals to her, and made sexually offensive statements to her.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Decree, which required the parties to implement and monitor its compliance with Title VII and the provisions of this complaint, and to provide annual training to its managerial employees regarding employee rights and responsibilities under Title VII.[SENTMARKER]In its second suit, the EEOC alleged that 3 Consolidated Realty discriminated against another female employee by terminating her because of her sex.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required that the parties provide periodic reports to the EEOC regarding their compliance with the Title VII policies and procedures and to submit its 8 training materials on discrimination, harassment and retaliation in the future.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion for summary judgment, and the parties agreed to a final and binding consent decree, which was approved by the court on October 2, 2006.[SENTMARKER]The parties are continuing to implement the consent decree.

gold_sents: On July 12, 2005, three U.S. farm works from Yakima Valley who were illegally denied or terminated from agricultural employment brought this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Washington against Global Horizons, Green Acre Farms, and Valley Fruit Orchards under the Migrants and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act, 29 U.S.C. §§ 1801, the Farm Labor Contractors Act, 42 U.S.C § 1981 and the Washington Law Against Discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to go to trial, and after years of litigation the plaintiffs received a judgment in their favor under FLCA, as well as attorneys fees, for both trial and appellate legal work.[SENTMARKER]In January 2014, the Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for incentive payments.[SENTMARKER]There has been no further movement in the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 27, 2001, the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Maryland entered a judgment against Global Horizons, Inc., a farm labor contractor in violation of the Farm Labor Contractors Act, Section 1981, and 23 of the Washington Law Against Discrimination.[SENTMARKER]Global and its owner, Mordechai Orian, failed to disclose two production standards for pruning, thinning, harvesting and other activities in the written statement of the terms and conditions of employment.[SENTMARKER]Global also failed to provide adequate written 21 pay statements to members of the Green Acre subclass.[SENTMARKER]The court found that Global discriminated against workers on the basis of race and national origin and discharged them for other than lawful job-related reasons.[SENTMARKER]On July 12, 2005, the court awarded approximately $237,000 in statutory damages and denied the plaintiffs' request for injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on July 12, 2006.

gold_sents: On December 3, 2013, a non-profit organization filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado under the First Amendment, Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the Administrative Procedure Act against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by the Alliance Defending Freedom, asked the court to rule that the Affordable Care Act's (ACA) contraception insurance mandate, even with the accommodation for non-profit religious organizations, is unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 11, 2014, the plaintiff filed a motion for preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]Following the Supreme Court's decision in Hobby Lobby, the plaintiff stipulated to dismissal of the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 13, 2013, the U.S.[SENTMARKER]Conference of Catholic Bishops, at the conclusion of their fall General Assembly in Baltimore, Maryland, issued a "Special Message" regarding the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and its contraceptive coverage requirements.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, who were employees of a Colorado non-profit organization, alleged that the mandate violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA), the First and Fifth Amendments to the United States Constitution, and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) by requiring them to provide insurance coverage that includes education and counseling regarding contraceptives and abortifacients.[SENTMARKER]On April 29, 2014, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the defendants had not adequately considered the constitutional and statutory implications of the mandate on FOCUS and other religious non-profits.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, concluding that the plaintiffs had failed to show that they would be harmed by the mandate.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: On September 5, 2013, the voting stockholders of a Michigan for-profit corporation filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia asking the court to issue a preliminary and permanent injunction prohibiting enforcement of provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) extending universal contraception coverage to employer-sponsored private health insurance coverage.[SENTMARKER]In light of the ruling in Burwell v. Hobby Lobby the Court ruled in favor of the plaintiffs on October 24, 2014 permanently enjoining the defendants from enforcing compliance with the contraception coverage under the ACA.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2014, the United States District Court for the District of Columbia entered a final judgment in a lawsuit brought by a group of individuals who object to providing health insurance coverage for abortion-inducing drugs and related education and counseling for all women under the Affordable Care Act.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment found that the defendants violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the First and Fifth Amendments by failing to comply with the HHS Mandate.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also failed to show that their actions caused the plaintiffs and thousands of other individuals to violate their deepest held religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]In light of the final judgment, the defendants are permanently enjoined from enforcing against plaintiffs, their employee health plan, and/or third-party administrators with respect to such plan(s), the group health insurance insurance coverage provided in connection with such plan, the statute and regulations in effect in effect on June 30, 2014, that require plaintiffs to provide their employees with contraceptive methods, sterilization procedures, and patient education and Counseling.[SENTMARKER]The court also ordered the defendants to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees, costs, and legal fees in the amount of $2,200.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This is a case about President Trump's executive order that prohibits racial sensitivity training in federal agencies, contractors, and grant recipients.[SENTMARKER]On October 29, 2020, the National Urban League and National Fair Housing Alliance filed this lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Columbia against the President, the Secretary of Labor, and the Department of Labor, seeking an injunction, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that the executive order violated freedom of speech under the First Amendment by denying benefits to private entities that express ideas the Trump Administration doesn't like.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also argued that the executive order violated the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause because the order was too vague and created with an intent to discriminate on the basis of race, national origin, sex, and/or gender.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 22, 2020, the National Urban League, the National Fair Housing Alliance, and over 200 private, nonprofit fair housing organizations filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against President Donald J. Trump, the Department of Labor, and the White House for violating the First Amendment by prohibiting them from discussing and promoting race and sex discrimination in the workplace.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by prohibiting the use, or instruction on, certain defined "divisive concepts" by, inter alia, federal contractors and their subcontractors and vendors and federal grant recipients, including diversity or inclusion training programs in their workplaces.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as monetary and other relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to comply with the terms of the settlement and the parties agreed not to enforce the injunctions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 22, 2010, homecare providers who did not wish to support the designated labor union filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois seeking an injunction against enforcement of the agency-fee provision of the Illinois Public Labor Relations Act (PLRA) and a declaration that the law violated the personal assistants' fundamental rights.[SENTMARKER]On June 30, 2014, the Supreme Court held that the clearest case on point, Abood v. Detroit Bd.[SENTMARKER]431 U. S.[SENTMARKER]209 (1977), did not apply because the public employees at issue there were distinct from the care providers here.[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the Court stated the agency-fee provision must serve a compelling state interest that cannot be achieved through means significantly less restrictive of associational freedoms.[SENTMARKER]The Court found insufficient the interests contended by Defendants and held the Illinois PLRA unconstitutional.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 2014, a group of home care providers in the Rehabilitation Program of the Illinois Department of Human Services filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the Northern district of Illinois against SEIU Healthcare Illinois Indiana (SEIU HII) alleging that the State violated the First Amendment by requiring them to pay union dues and initiation fees to SEIU HII.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' claims for lack of subject matter jurisdiction because they lacked standing and their claims were not ripe.[SENTMARKER]The court remanded the case to the district court with instructions to dismiss the claims of the Disability Program plaintiffs without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The Seventh Circuit affirmed in part, concluding that the case was controlled by the Court of Appeals' decision in Abood v. Detroit Bd.[SENTMARKER]The First Amendment prohibits the collection of an agency fee from personal assistants who do not want to join or support the union.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and no further action is pending.

gold_sents: On May 8, 2018, several Texas organizations filed this lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that HUD suspended a provision of the Fair Housing Act that would require cities to report incidents of housing discrimination and that that this suspension violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA).[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss was granted, and the plaintiffs filed to reopen the case and amend their complaint.[SENTMARKER]This motion was denied on August 26, 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 8, 2018, three non-profit organizations representing low-income residents of Texas filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia against HUD.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that HUD violated the Fair Housing Act and the Administrative Procedure Act by suspending the use of an "Assessment Tool" to determine whether residents were eligible for housing assistance.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction because no plaintiff had standing.[SENTMARKER]The court granted HUD's motion to dismiss, and the case was dismissed on May 29, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then filed an amended complaint on May 8, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the defendants' motion for preliminary injunctive relief and ordered HUD to rescind the January 2, 2018 notice and take all necessary steps to implement and enforce the AFFH Rule.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: A group of recovering alcoholics and drug addicts filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing Act, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the City of Boca Raton.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that an ordinance enacted by the city unlawfully prohibited drug and alcohol recovery facilites from operating within residentially zoned areas.[SENTMARKER]The court entered judgment in favor of the plaintiffs as to their Fair Housing Act claims.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded nominal damages and the city was enjoined from enforcing section 2 of Ordinance 4649 and Section 28-2 as applied to recovering individuals.[SENTMARKER]This case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In March 2003, a group of disabled residents of Boca Raton, Florida, brought this suit against the City of Palm Beach, Florida under the Fair Housing Amendments Act ( FHA) and the Americans with Disability Act (ADA) alleging that a city ordinance violated the FHA and ADA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the city violated the ADA by failing to grant them a reasonable accommodation from the City's purported limitation on four or more unrelated persons living together in a single dwelling unit.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that the plaintiffs lacked standing to bring certain of their claims where they are not disabled or handicapped and that the defendants did not grant a requested reasonable accommodation to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed.

gold_sents: Owners and prospective purchasers of condominiums in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing Act against Sunrise Lakes Condominium Apartments, claiming that the condo association had prevented Hispanics from purchasing units in the condo building.[SENTMARKER]Following a stipulation of dismissal on October 16, 2007, the court (Marcia G. Cooke) dismissed the case on October 19, 2007.[SENTMARKER]We have no further information concerning this case.
pegasus_output_sents: Sunrise Lakes Condominium Apts., Phase 3, Inc., a Florida corporation, and its board members are alleged to have discriminated against condominium unit owners of Hispanic origin by refusing to approve their purchase of a home on the basis of national origin.[SENTMARKER]On April 16, 2006, plaintiffs Hernando and Bertha Gonzalez entered into a contract for the sale of their condominium for $68,000 with Hector and Benigna Ochoa, who are of Hispanic descent.[SENTMARKER]They were also responsible for the monthly maintenance cost was $262.90.[SENTMARKER]On information and belief, none of the board members of the defendant Association were of Hispanic national origin, and the condominium association did not use the same management company.[SENTMARKER]On October 19, 2007, the plaintiffs filed this suit against the defendant in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and permanent injunctive relief, monetary damages, and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case on October 19, 2007 and the case was closed on October 20, 2007.

gold_sents: On June 24, 2010, the United States filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Minnesota, under the Fair Housing Act, against owners and operators of an apartment complex located in Red Wing Minnesota alleging discrimination on the basis of race and sex against an African-American male.[SENTMARKER]On July 29, 2011, Judge Frank approved a two year Consent Decree agreed to by the parties enjoining defendants from continuing to engage in discriminatory practices and ordering defendants to pay $15,000 in damages to the complainant.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 24, 2010, the U.S. District Court for the District of Minnesota entered a consent decree in a discrimination case brought by the Department of Housing and Urban Development against Loki Properties LLC and its owner, Robert Ryan, in violation of the Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1968 (the "Act").[SENTMARKER]The consent decree, which was entered on July 28, 2011, requires Loki Properties and Ryan to comply with the Act's anti-discrimination provisions, including a policy of not renting to anyone with a conviction of a felony or a violent crime.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the consent decree requires that Loki Properties provide a program of educational training on the race and sex-related provisions of federal, state, and local fair housing laws, regulations, and ordinances to its employees and agents.[SENTMARKER]The parties have agreed to pay a total of $325,000 in disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and attorney's fees to the Plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The terms of this consent decree are subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In March 2011, the National Fair Housing Alliance and Paralyzed Veterans of America filed this federal suit the Western District of Virginia under the Fair Housing Act, alleging that real estate development company HHHunt Corporation and affiliated entities discriminated against people with disabilities by designing and building apartment complexes without the required accessible and adaptable features.[SENTMARKER]In October 2012, the District Court (Judge James C. Turk) entered a stipulated order, under which the defendants agreed to make numerous improvements to the subject properties.[SENTMARKER]Following the settlement agreement, claims concerning the liability of an architecture firm lingered, but were ultimately resolved by a stipulated dismissal on January 14, 2014.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement agreement, the District Court retained jurisdiction to resolve disputes between the parties until October 2015.[SENTMARKER]Since there has been no docket activity after 2014, the case is presumed closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 17, 2011, the National Fair Housing Alliance (NANTS) and Paralyzed Veterans of America (Paralyzed VA) filed a civil rights action in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Virginia against HHHunt Corporation, a private, nonprofit, fair housing organization, for violations of the Fair Housing Act of 1968 (Fair Housing Act) and the Fair Design Act of 1988 (Fair Design Manual) in violation of Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that, as more fully set forth in the complaint, the defendants failed to comply with the required elements of fair housing by failing to design and construct multifamily apartment complexes without full adherence to the requirements of the fair housing act and the fair design manual.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs in the form of a judgment, which was entered on March 26, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The judgment required the defendants to provide all of their executives with supervisory responsibility for the design and/or construction of covered multifamily dwellings and on-site management employees with supervision responsibility for all such alterations within a period of thirty-six months from the date of the execution of the judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to provide the plaintiffs with a copy of each of the published design and construction plans for all covered multifamily properties that are owned in whole or in part by the defendants and to prominently display in the sales or rental offices of those properties a conspicuous sign indicating that all dwellings are available for rental on a nondiscriminatory basis.

gold_sents: In 2011, the plaintiff, an individual with intellectual disabilities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued then Director for the Agency for Persons with Disabilities pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §§ 1938 & 1988.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff was involuntarily committed to residential services pursuant to Florida statute but never received any periodic review of his continued need for involuntary confinement to residential services.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Defendant's motion for summary judgment on the basis that the Agency's scheme of review satisfied the Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]On October 20, 2015, the US Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit reversed this decision and remanded the case to the lower court.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 28, 2013, a group of developmentally disabled residents of a state-operated developmental center sued the Illinois Department of Human Services (DHS), alleging that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (R&A) by failing to provide adequate levels of medically necessary care and services to the residents.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that defendants' conduct, particularly implementation of the allegedly rigged assessment and transfer process, violated the ADA and R&A.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2013, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was closed on October 8, 2013.[SENTMARKER]On October 8, 2013, the district court issued a preliminary injunction against the defendants preventing the transfer of the residents of the Warren G. gold_sents: In October of 2006, a class action lawsuit was brought in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of California on behalf of agricultural workers alleging that defendant employers had engaged in a massive scheme to hire undocumented immigrants in an effort to depress employee wages.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed without prejudice in May of 2008 after the plaintiff failed to timely amend his complaint to substitute in a suitable class representative.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 2006, a resident of Marin County, California filed a class action lawsuit against Fruit Patch, Inc. of Reedley, California and its owners, Leo Balakian, Anthony Balakian and Vince Balakian.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Balakians had conspired to employ more than 10 undocumented, illegal aliens in each of the last four years, knowing each was smuggled into the country and/or harbored once they arrived here.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss was granted on the ground that the complaint failed to adequately allege violation of the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), Section 1324(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), and that the plaintiffs had a duty to report immigration violations to their employers or to an appropriate government agency.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion for class certification, and the case was transferred to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]In October 2006, the plaintiffs filed a motion to class action on behalf of all legal hourly-paid workers who had been employed by Fruit Patch.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought to be the sole class representative for 10 several thousand legal workers at Fruit Patch and were granted class certification in part with leave to amend their complaint.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles brought this suit against the U.S. Attorney General and  Secretary of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs challenged the federal immigration rule restricting eligibility for asylum for noncitizens who transited through another country prior to reaching the southern U.S. border.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs successfully sought a preliminary nationwide injunction.[SENTMARKER]However, defendants appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit and the nationwide scope of the injunction was stayed.[SENTMARKER]Then the District Court restored the nationwide scope of the injunction on September 9, 2019, but the government again appealed and the U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay pending disposition of the appeal in the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued a separate preliminary injunction against another rule issued by the Department of Homeland Security in the closing days of the Trump Administration which was substantially similar to the one already enjoined.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the original injunction in April, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing but is likely to terminate soon given the change in presidential administrations.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 16, 2019, a group of non-profit organizations representing asylum seekers filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California against the Departments of Justice and Customs and Border Protection.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the government violated the Administrative Procedures Act (APA) by failing to provide notice and an opportunity to comment in a timely manner.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought a preliminary injunction, a temporary restraining order, and a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]On December 19, 2018, the district court granted the preliminary injunction preventing the government from taking any action to continue to implement the 2018 Rule.[SENTMARKER]On June 30, 2020, the court granted summary judgment for the plaintiffs and vacated the interim rule, finding that it was invalid under the APA for failing to adhere to notice and comment procedures.[SENTMARKER]On July 17, 2019, the parties filed a motion for a restraining order to prevent the Rule from taking effect.[SENTMARKER]On September 9, 2019, the court issued an order restoring the nationwide scope of the injunction, which was stayed in full pending disposition of the government's appeal.

gold_sents: On August 16, 2019, several health care providers and nonprofit organizations serving immigrant communities filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Department of Homeland Security's Final Public Charge Rule (the Rule), which added non-cash benefits to the factors considered in determining whether a person applying for legal permanent residence is likely to become a public charge.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Government violated the Administrative Procedure Act by exceeding its statutory authority, claimed that the Rule was "arbitrary and capricious," and asserted that the Rule violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2019, a district court judge denied the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction enjoining the government from implementing the Rule, but issued an order for preliminary injunction in a related case that would enjoin the implementation of the rule in California, Oregon, the District of Columbia, Maine, and Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]This preliminary injunction was stayed by the Ninth Circuit in December 2019.[SENTMARKER]It was affirmed a year later in December 2020, but the order was stayed pending petitions to the Supreme Court in the Second, Seventh, and Ninth Circuits.[SENTMARKER]The Rule was abandoned by DHS on March 9, 2021.[SENTMARKER]As of April 15, 2021, the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 14, 2019, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) published the final rule entitled 22 "Inadmissibility on Public Charge Grounds," published by DHS in the Federal Register.[SENTMARKER]The final rule is intended to prevent the disenrolling of eligible U.S. citizen children from Medicaid due to fears that their children's health care coverage will affect their ability to seek immigration relief.[SENTMARKER]On August 15, 2019, the district court for the Northern District of California granted the defendants' motion for preliminary injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The district court also granted the plaintiffs' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On November 20, 2014, a local sheriff in Arizona filed a lawsuit in the District Court for the District of Washington against the President, the Attorney General, the Secretary of Homeland Security, and the Director of the Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) alleging that President Obama's Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) and Executive Order Amnesty (EOA) programs were unconstitutional abuses of the President's role in our nation's constitutional architecture and exceeded his constitutional authority.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction, ECF No. 7, and dismissed the complaint for lack of subject matter jurisdiction because the plaintiff had failed to allege a cognizable injury in fact for purposes of Article III standing.[SENTMARKER]The court affirmed the district court's dismissal of the case.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff appealed to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court denied the defendant's appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In May of 2019, asylum seekers detained under the jurisdiction of the New Orleans ICE Field Office filed a class action lawsuit against DHS, ICE, and the New Orleans ICE Field Office, alleging that they were giving blanket parole denials without individualized reviews.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, the court granted preliminary injunction, enjoining defendants from continuing to detain asylum seekers without individualized consideration.[SENTMARKER]In March 30, 2020, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, plaintiffs filed an emergency motion for preliminary injunction, seeking immediate reviews of class members still detained.[SENTMARKER]The court denied the motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then filed a motion for order to show cause why the defendants should not be held in contempt for violating the 2019 preliminary injunction order, expedited discovery, and the appointment of a special master.[SENTMARKER]The court granted limited discovery.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 30, 2019, a group of asylum seekers, represented by the Southern Poverty Law Center, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the Southern District of New Orleans against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking injunctive and declaratory relief setting aside NOLA ICE's blanket parole denial policy.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' policy of categorically denying parole to asylum-seekers in violation of the Parole Directive of 2009 violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (APA) and the Constitution's guarantees of due process and equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' motion to dismiss was granted in part and denied in part, and the parties filed a joint status report on October 2, 2019.[SENTMARKER]In part, the parties asked the court for a preliminary injunction, which the court granted.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion for summary judgment, which was denied by the court on October 3, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case on October 10, 2019.

gold_sents: In May 2018, the Council on American-Islamic Relations - Chicago (CAIR-Chicago) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Citizenship & Immigration Services for failing to process its FOIA request for immigration records since the 2008 institution of the Controlled Application Review & Resolution Program, alleging that this conduct was a wrongful delay of release of records in violation of FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs dismissed their claims without explanation on June 28, 2019.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 2018, the Council on American-Islamic Relations-Chicago (CAIR-Chicago) filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against United States Citizenship Immigration Services (USCIS) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking the release of records concerning a policy called the Controlled Application Review Resolution Program (CARRP).[SENTMARKER]CARRP imposes extra-statutory rules and criteria to delay and deny immigration benefits to which applicants are entitled.[SENTMARKER]Under the CARRP program, Muslim applicants for numerous immigration benefits, including those seeking to naturalize as American citizens, have had their applications delayed and ultimately denied without legal authority, and without even being informed of the existence of the program.[SENTMARKER]On August 1, 2017, CAIR-Chicago submitted an electronic FOIA request to the USCIS National Records Center FOIA/PA Office seeking information on all individuals who have applied for naturalization, change of status, and asylum through forms N-400, I-589, and I-485 since April 11, 2008, and the processing time for each application, the number of times each applicant was interviewed by USCIS agents, and the number, if any, of subsidiary applicants and the status of their citizenship applications.[SENTMARKER]The FOIA request also sought expedited processing and a waiver of fees.[SENTMARKER]On May 1, 2018, the court granted CAIR- Chicago's request for injunctive and declaratory relief with respect to the release and disclosure of the requested records.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants' motion for partial summary judgment in favor of the FOIA request.

gold_sents: In September 2019, the Irish International Immigrant Center sued U.S. Citizenship & Immigration Services and President Trump.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff alleged defendants illegally terminated an immigration relief program that granted "deferred action" to seriously ill individuals and their families.[SENTMARKER]Represented by the ACLU, the plaintiff sought injunctive and declaratory relief for violations of Equal Protection and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a joint motion to stay the case on October 31, 2019, so parties could seek a nonjudicial resolution.[SENTMARKER]This followed a USCUS announcement that the deferred action program would return but requests would only be granted “based on compelling facts and circumstances.”[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff voluntarily dismissed the case without prejudice on June 15, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 17, 2019, the Irish International Immigrant Center (IIIC) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the acting director of the USCIS for the abrupt termination of a longstanding government program that protects seriously ill people from deportation and death.[SENTMARKER]The IIIC represented individuals and families applying for deferred action from USCIS as a result of a serious medical need.[SENTMARKER]The defendants’ termination of deferred action was impermissibly motivated by racial animus and animus based on national origin, in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment, and contrary to law.[SENTMARKER]On June 22, 2020, the court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case for mootness and granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2018, the City of Baltimore filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that certain changes to the Public Charge rule by the U.S. President, Secretary of State, and Department of State were made without following proper administrative procedure and in violation of equal protection.[SENTMARKER]The rule increased the number of immigrants barred from applying for visas for having previously received public assistance.[SENTMARKER]The rule was preliminarily enjoined in a different lawsuit on July 29, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit is ongoing, but proceedings are stayed until May 24, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: In January 2019, the City of Baltimore and the City Council of Baltimore filed this lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District court for the District of the Maryland against the President of the United States, the Department of State, and the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (OIRA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Administrative Procedure Act and the Constitution by restricting the ability of non-citizens to use public benefits to apply for a visa.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss the complaint pursuant to Federal Rule 12(b)(1) for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, and for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, finding that Baltimore had sufficiently alleged multiple plausible legal challenges as well as its standing to bring those challenges.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a preliminary injunction barring enforcement of the restrictions.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted a temporary restraining order against the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On May 4, 2020, two individuals in ICE (US Immigration and Customs Enforcement) custody sued ICE and the Department of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that restrictions to telephone access by impsing costs and denying access to incoming calls during the COVID-19 pandemic when in-person visitations have been rendered impossible is unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, they alleged that their Fifth and First Amendment rights had been violated by preventing communication with counsel, denying their right to legal representation, and other resources critical to support their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: January 20, 2020 DATE ||| ICE ORG ||| Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)<n>ICE and its parent agency, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), have engaged in a common course of conduct that severely restricts the constitutional, statutory, and regulatory rights of individuals held in government custody pending immigration proceedings.[SENTMARKER]ICE has acknowledged that it refuses to accommodate confidential legal calls.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by the ACLU of Northern California on behalf of individuals who are or will be detained in the 8 custody of ICE at El Paso Service Processing Center and the Otero County Processing Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, class certification, appointment of class counsel, and attorneys’ fees.[SENTMARKER]The district court certified the class and held a bench trial, finding shortcomings with the prison system, including the training of staff, the updating of legal materials, the availability of photocopying services, and the lack of access to the courts.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which ICE and DHS agreed to implement certain procedures and practices to ensure that class members were able to access free, confidential telephone access in order to speak to their attorneys and to be able to effectuate their constitutional and statutory rights in their immigration proceedings, including access to judicial review and access to court documents.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the class certification motion for summary judgment, and denied class certification for a single proceeding, finding that the defendants lacked subject-matter jurisdiction over the case.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then appealed to the United States Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court declined to hear the appeal.

gold_sents: A group of immigration legal service providers filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon on December 18, 2019, alleging the federal government had manipulated the immigration adjudication system in a way making it virtually impossible for asylum seekers to succeed.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged violations of the Take Care Clause of the U.S. Constitution, as well as provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act and the Administrative Procedure Act. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]After the defendants filed a motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs moved for a Temporary Restraining Order due to the COVID-19 pandemic, alleging that the immigration courts had failed to take adequate public health measures to protect judges, respondents, attorneys, and staff.[SENTMARKER]On April 1, 2020, the District Court denied the plaintiffs' motion.[SENTMARKER]On July 31, the court granted in part and denied in part the defendant's motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The defendants sought reconsideration, which was denied on September 10.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2020, a group of non-profit legal advocacy organizations filed a lawsuit in the District Court of Oregon against the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) alleging that the government's use of video teleconferencing in the immigration court system violated the Take Care Clause of the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the First and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought an emergency order with respect to immigration courts nationwide for the duration of the national COVID-19 emergency or the next 28 days, whichever is shorter.[SENTMARKER]They also sought declaratory relief as well as injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, and the case was dismissed for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 15, 2009, two longtime permanent residents of the United States who had been detained in Pennsylvania prisons for periods exceeding six months while they pursued challenges to decisions to deport them filed a class action lawsuit against the Department of Homeland Security, the Department of Justice, and the prisons that held them, claiming that their prolonged detention without a hearing to determine whether such detention was justified violated the due process clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On August 10, 2009, the Court (Judge John E. pegasus_output_sents: On June 27, 2008, a group of lawful permanent residents of the United States challenged the Department of Homeland Security's detention of them under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The Petitioners sought declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of themselves and a class of similarly-situated persons.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the Petitioners' motion for a preliminary injunction for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, dismissed the petitioners' petition seeking class certification, and denied their motion for class certification.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This is a class action lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of a South Carolina immigration law which requires state and local law enforcement officers to investigate the immigration status of any individual they stop, detain, or arrest whenever they have a "reasonable suspicion" that the individual lacks immigration status, allows law enforcement officers to arrest individuals solely for failing to carry registration documents, makes it a crime to harbor or transport an undocumented immigrant or to be harbored or transported by others if one is an undocumented immigrant, and imposes civil liability on the police for failing to enforce its provisions to the maximum extent possible.[SENTMARKER]The law was patterned after Arizona's SB 1070.[SENTMARKER]The District Court has issued a preliminary injunction barring enforcement of the law, and this injunction has been appealed to the Fourth Circuit; in the meantime, the case, along with several others like it from different states, are stayed at the District Court or U.S.[SENTMARKER]Appellate level pending the decision of the Supreme Court in United States v. Arizona.[SENTMARKER]After Arizona v. United States was decided the issue was remanded to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The district court left in place most of its original preliminary injunction, enjoining the state from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6 (B)(2).[SENTMARKER]The 4th Circuit per Judge Davis agreed and affirmed the order on July 13, 2013.[SENTMARKER]In March of 2014 Judge Gergel permanently enjoined South Carolina from enforcing Sections 4, 5, and 6(B)(2).[SENTMARKER]Furthermore the state agreed to more favorable interpretations of Section 7, and the remainder of Section, encouraging the Plaintiffs to dismiss their claims on those sections without prejudice.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 25, 2012, a group of individuals and advocacy groups (hereina fter collectively "private plaintiffs") filed suit in the United States District Court, Charleston, South Carolina, challenging South Carolina's comprehensive immigration law, Senate Bill 20 (S.C. Code  16-9-460, 17-13-170(B)(2), 16-13-480) (the "Act").[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Act violated the Supremacy Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and the Constitution's due process and equal protection provisions.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive and declaratory relief, finding that certain sections of the Act were preempted by federal immigration law and regulations.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals, which remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case was ultimately dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled in June 2012 that Arizona v. pegasus_output_sents: On February 12, 2004, a class action lawsuit was filed in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of Illinois on behalf of a group of male inmates in the custody of the Cook County department of corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' policy of strip searching all male inmates returning to the jail after receiving court orders making them eligible for release violated their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights under the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to a settlement in March 2011, which required the defendants to stop strip searches upon their return from court.[SENTMARKER]The parties disagree about how many inmates can be held in the jail's various bullpens.[SENTMARKER]In March 2011, the parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed not to strip search any female inmates returning from court, both male and female, for out-processing after being ordered released.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the county to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]On March 21, 2011, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered on March 21, 2011.

pegasus_output_sents: On November 19, 2009, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Louisiana filed this civil rights class action against the Terrebonne Parish Juvenile Detention Center (TPJDC), a juvenile detention facility in Terrebonne, Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the facility violated the constitutional rights of youth by failing to adequately protect them from harm by detention staff, failing to provide an appropriate housing classification system, and failing to hold staff accountable for misconduct related to confinement checks, suicide precautions, and youth supervision.[SENTMARKER]On January 18, 2011, the United States issued an investigative findings letter which concluded that certain conditions at the Facility violated the rights of juveniles detained or committed to the facility pursuant to the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 ("Section 14141").[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on April 17, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement corrective measures to ensure that the conditions of confinement at the facility do not violate youth's constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to a monitor to oversee compliance with the terms of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a final judgment in favor of the parties in April 2014 and the parties entered a revised settlement agreement in May 2014 that was approved in June 2014 and is subject to court approval.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 25, 2016, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee on behalf of a juvenile who was held in solitary confinement at the Rutherford County Juvenile Detention Center in Columbia, Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by placing him in solitary for disciplinary or punitive reasons, beginning at isolation for periods of twelve hours and continuing up to indefinite solitary confinement.[SENTMARKER]The court certified a class of all juveniles who were or were placed into solitary confinement or isolation for punitive reasons from April 25, 2015 to the present.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed not to use solitary confinement as a form of punishment for minor rules violations.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was subject to approval by the court.[SENTMARKER]On April 26, 2016, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The motion was denied, and the parties entered a final judgment in which they agreed to dismiss all of the claims as part of the settlement.

pegasus_output_sents: On April 1, 2014, Twitter, Inc. filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California against the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the National Security Agency (NSA) seeking declaratory and injunctive relief from the government's restrictions on Twitter's First Amendment rights under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) and National Security Letters (NSLs) of the USA Freedom Act (USA Freedom Act).[SENTMARKER]On October 7, 2014, Twitter filed the amended complaint, which alleged that the FISA secrecy provisions are unconstitutional under the First Amendment as applied to Twitter and that the Government's content-based restrictions are not narrowly tailored to serve a governmental interest.[SENTMARKER]On October 8, 2014, the court granted the Defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was closed on October 10, 2015.[SENTMARKER]On October 17, 2015, the court issued a final judgment in favor of the Defendants, concluding that the government had not violated the Freedom Act.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case for lack of standing.

pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2014, The New York Times Company and its reporter, Charlie Savage, filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York against the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) and its constituent part, the National Security Division (NSD) seeking documents related to surveillance activities and FISC decisions.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the government's failure to provide responsive documents to the plaintiffs violated the FOIA.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment and ordered the DOJ to produce documents responsive to categories 3 through 6 of the FOIA request.[SENTMARKER]On October 9, 2014, the parties filed a joint motion to dismiss the complaint, which was granted by the court on October 10, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the parties agreed that the court would dismiss the case with prejudice and that the parties would pay the court's costs and attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on October 28, 2015.

pegasus_output_sents: In June 2003, a disabled Medicaid recipient filed this suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas, alleging that the defendants had violated the rights of her and thousands of other disabled individuals by refusing to give her an application for services under the Developmental Disabilities Alternative Community Services waiver program.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief, finding that the waiver program was an optional program that Arkansas had chosen to include in its State Medicaid Plan, and that the plaintiffs would suffer irreparable harm without an injunction.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion for summary judgment, which was denied by the district court.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case, and the case was closed on June 2003.

gold_sents: On January 20, 2010, an employee of the federal judiciary married to her same-sex partner under California law filed a lawsuit against the federal Office of Personnel Management (OPM) in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, San Francisco Division, alleging that the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) violates the Fifth Amendment by refusing to recognize lawful same-sex marriages for purposes of the laws governing spousal health benefits for federal employees, thereby denying her of a benefit that would be available to her if her spouse were of the opposite sex.[SENTMARKER]On February 22, 2012, the District Court granted summary judgment to the plaintiff, holding that the application of DOMA to deny spousal health benefits in this case did not have a rational basis and thus constituted a Fifth Amendment violation.[SENTMARKER]It entered a permanent injunction prohibiting the defendants from interfering with the enrollment of the plaintiff's wife in her family health benefits plan.[SENTMARKER]On July 3, 2012, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a petition in the Supreme Court for certiorari prior to judgment.[SENTMARKER]That petition was held without decision while the Court considered the California Prop.[SENTMARKER]8 case (PB-CA-0029 in this Clearinghouse) and Windsor, the DOMA case from the Second Circuit (PB-NY-0017 in this Clearinghouse), in which the Court granted review on December 7.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed following the decision in Windsor holding § 3 of DOMA unconstitutional.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 2012, a lesbian woman married under California law, who is unable to secure federal health benefits for her same-sex spouse, filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court in California.[SENTMARKER]The case arose after Ms. Golinski, a staff attorney with the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals for more than 20 years, was denied health coverage for her spouse Amy Cunninghis, to whom she is lawfully married.[SENTMARKER]The Department of Justice argued, and the district court agreed, that DOMA violates equal protection.[SENTMARKER]In light of the Supreme Court’s decision in Windsor, the parties have jointly stipulated that the case should be disposed of in abeyance pending the court’s disposition of the Department’s petition for certiorari before judgment in this case.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the motion to dismiss on the basis that it lacked jurisdiction to issue mandamus relief and dismissed the matter with leave to amend.[SENTMARKER]On December 12, 2012, the court entered a permanent injunction requiring the defendant to enroll her wife in her family health benefits plan.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a joint motion for summary judgment, which was granted by the court and the court of appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court issued a final judgment in Windsor on December 11, 2012 in favor of DOMA and the parties agreed that the parties should settle the case together.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the parties' motion for a summary judgment on December 12, 2012 and the case was dismissed on March 16, 2011.

pegasus_output_sents: On December 4, 2012, California resident Pablo Carranza filed this civil rights action in the United States District Court for the Eastern District Of California against the State of California and the California Departments of Health and Care Services.[SENTMARKER]Carranza alleged that the defendants violated Title II of the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by denying him funding for home and community-based services that would otherwise be available for institutional services.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed not to seek recoupment of any monies paid to Western Home 2 Health Agency pursuant to the settlement agreement, and to pay Carranza's attorney's fees and costs in a total amount of $69,500.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the settlement, the parties agreed to provide notice to Carranza of the 13 proposed reduction of shift nursing hours to Medi-Cal recipients such as him when they turn age 14 and to provide him with written notice that explains their right to a hearing, and if a hearing is requested, refuse to continue benefits pending the hearing.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also required the defendants to offer reasonable modifications to their programs and policies to enable Carranza to receive medically necessary in-home nursing as ordered by his physicians.[SENTMARKER]In a parallel action, Carranza also filed a separate suit against the defendants, alleging that they violated the Americans with Disabilities Act, Section 504, and the due process clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 4, 2013 by Senior Judge William Shubb.
