pegasus_output_sents: In October 2007, a same-sex couple who jointly parent their child as legal parents filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana against the State of Louisiana, seeking a declaration that the state's refusal to issue a birth certificate based on an out-of-state adoption decree violated the Full Faith and Credit Clause (the "Clause") and the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on their full faith and credit claim.[SENTMARKER]The district court held that the amended statute was unconstitutional because it violated the FF&C Clause, and the court ordered Oklahoma to issue an amended birth certificate to one of the couples.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Louisiana Supreme Court upheld the district court's summary judgment ruling.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 9th, 2014, several same-sex couples residing in North Carolina filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the state of North Carolina.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs asked the court to declare that North Carolina's ban on same-sex is unconstitutional, declare North Carolina laws prohibiting joint adoption by same-sex couples are also unconstitutional,  enjoin the state from enforcing any of its laws banning same-sex marriage, direct the state to recognize same-sex marriages entered into in other states, and award the plaintiffs costs of suit and reasonable attorney's fees.[SENTMARKER]The court ruled in the plaintiffs' favor on October 14, 2014, declaring the North Carolina laws in question unconstitutional to the extent they prevent marriage and recognition of same-sex couples.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 14, 2014, three same-sex couples filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of North Carolina challenging the constitutionality of the state's laws that exclude same-Sex couples from marrying and that effectively void the marriages of those couples lawfully entered into in other jurisdictions.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the laws violate the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case was stayed pending the outcome of the Fourth Circuit's decision in Bostic v. Schaefer, Case No. 14-1167.[SENTMARKER]The parties have previously filed briefs in response to the court's July 30, 2014 order requesting as to the effect of the court’s July 30 opinion, which found the laws to be unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2014, the court granted defendants' motions to dismiss and to stay further proceedings in the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On December 2, 2014, seven same-sex couples seeking marriage or recognition of an out-of-state marriage in Nebraska filed claim against the state of Nebraska under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the United States District Court for the District of Nebraska.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and it was affirmed by the Eighth Circuit on interlocutory appeal following the Supreme Court's decision in Obergefell v. Hodges.[SENTMARKER]On February 4, 2016, Judge Bataillon issued a permanent injunction striking down Nebraska’s ban on gay marriage.
pegasus_output_sents: Plaintiffs are loving, committed same-sex couples who seek to marry in Nebraska or already are married, having wed in another state, but are treated as legal strangers in Nebraska.[SENTMARKER]They bring this action pursuant to 42 USC 1983 seeking declaratory and injunctive relief for the violation of their rights under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution caused by Nebraska’s exclusion of the couples from marriage and its prohibition against recognizing their marriages validly entered into in other jurisdictions.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, but the case was remanded to the Eighth Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit remanded the case to the district court for further determination.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the case is remanded for entry of a permanent injunction.

gold_sents: In 2016, a same-sex married couple filed this Civil Rights Act of 1871 complaint in the District Court of South Carolina (Columbia Division).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming violations of their fundamental right to marry and other protected liberties related to the differential treatment of birth records for children with same-sex married parents.[SENTMARKER]Summary Judgment was granted in favor of the Plaintiffs and a consent decree entered ordering South Carolina to make changes to the policies of their birth-record keeping, as well as the issuance of corrected birth certificates to the Plaintiffs and all who qualified under the new policies and requested such a correction.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an undisclosed settlement for attorney’s fees and the case closed in June 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 15, 2017, a married couple who were denied accurate birth certificates for their newborn twins filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of South Carolina.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, Casy and Jacqueline Carson, are married and the same-sex parents of their twins, S.B.C.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff Jacqueline became pregnant with their children by means of artificial insemination.[SENTMARKER]They filed this suit against DHEC, alleging that DHEC's policy of refusing to issue birth certificates listing both spouses as parents on the same terms to the children of the same sex violates the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]In its February 15, 2017 consent decree, the Court granted the plaintiffs' request for declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required DHEC to issue two-parent birth certificates to married, different-Sex parents, and to use the same protocols, including the use of the birth certificates, as it does for married, separate-sEX parents.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the Plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, and granted their motion for a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On October 22, 2013, parolees in custody or under supervision of the Illinois Department of Corrections filed a class action lawsuit alleging violations of their due process rights due to procedurally unfair parole review proceedings, which functioned as essentially an automatic approval of parole board recommendations.[SENTMARKER]In January of 2017, the parties reached a settlement agreement which directs Illinois to revise its parole review proceedings and inform parolees of their rights.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 22, 2013, the Illinois Department of Corrections (DOC) and the Illinois Prisoner Review Board (PRB) were sued in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois by three parolees who alleged that the defendants violated their due process rights by failing to consider whether parolees qualified for the appointment of counsel, and failing to appoint counsel to those who did qualify.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that defendants' policies and procedures allowed parolees to be violated and reimprisoned based solely on the fact that the parolee was subject to arrest, regardless of the merits of the case against him.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, approximately 40% of the population incarcerated in Illinois prisons in 2012 was imprisoned for violating the conditions of their parole.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a draft settlement agreement on October 24, 2016, which was approved by the Court on October 27, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the parties would share the cost of any such mediation, and that the Court would enter a final judgment dismissing the action without prejudice if the parties comply with the terms of the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: A transgender woman incarcerated at a men's prison in Illinois brought this action against the Illinois Department of Corrections and its officers in federal court, for abuse, harassment, and equal protection violations.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought an injunction ordering the Department to transfer her to a women's facility.[SENTMARKER]On November 7, 2018, Judge Nancy Rosenstengel of the Southern District of Illinois granted a preliminary injunction requiring the defendants to provide basic mental health services to the plaintiff and consider all evidence as to whether she should be transferred to a women's prison.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 22, 2019, a transgender inmate in the custody of the Illinois Department of Corrections (IDOC) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois against the IDOC and two of its officials alleging violations of the Eighth Amendment and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the ADA by failing to provide Plaintiff with reasonable accommodations for her Gender Dysphoria disability.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that they violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, and the Illinois Hate Crimes Act, by refusing to provide her with appropriate mental health services and denying her access to facilities.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the complaint, which was denied by the Court.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment and the case was dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2018, a former prison inmate from Illinois sued the Illinois Department of Corrections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff had spent 20 years in solitary confinement, where his mental health declined substantially.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the Department had violated his Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights, as well as the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Rehabilitation act, by placing him in solitary confinement, providing no opportunity to appeal his placement, and providing him with insufficient psychiatric care.[SENTMARKER]As of July 8, 2020, the litigation is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 16, 2018, a prisoner, Anthony Gay, filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Central District of Illinois against the State of Illinois for violating the Americans with Disability Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (RA) by denying him medical and mental health care that caused him physical and psychological harm.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the ADA by failing to provide a reasonable accommodation for Anthony's disability.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also violated the RA by refusing to segregate disabled and non-disabled persons in solitary confinement.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the District Court and the parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to provide Anthony with a variety of programs, services, and specialized mental health services as necessary to treat his mental illness.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to pay the Plaintiff's attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered in October 2019.

gold_sents: On January 21, 2009, the ACLU filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. Section 1983 against the Federal Bureau of Prisons in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana.[SENTMARKER]The complaint challenged the creation of Communication Management Units (CMUs) in the federal prisons.[SENTMARKER]On July 28, 2010, plaintiff filed a motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]This case was dismissed on July 29, 2010 without prejudice in the Southern District of Indiana.
pegasus_output_sents: In April 2006, a prisoner at the federal prison in Terre Haute, Indiana, filed a class action suit against the federal government under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) alleging violations of the Constitution's guarantees of due process and equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Constitution by imposing severe restrictions on the prisoner's communications and other liberties.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on July 29, 2010 without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2019, a group of current and former prisoners filed a complaint against the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services for violating their rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, and Maryland State Law.[SENTMARKER]A similar case was consolidated with this one in January 2020, and a motion to dismiss the complaint is pending in federal court.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 30, 2019, two inmates of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services (DPSCS) filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were denied the opportunity to participate in pre-release programming, including home detention, work release, and "outside detail" because of their disabilities.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that the defendants failed to engage competent medical service providers to oversee and administer the healthcare needs of prisoners committed to the custody of DPSCS.[SENTMARKER]On December 18, 2018, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment in part and denied the motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in part on August 30, 2020, and the case was dismissed on December 18, 2020, without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A group of prisoners at a North Carolina private prison sued the prison company and the Federal Bureau of Prisons for deliberate indifference to their medical and mental health needs.[SENTMARKER]After lengthy procedural maneuvering involving a change of venue from D.C. to North Carolina and failed attempts at class certification, the last remaining named plaintiff was transferred and the court dismissed the case.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 26, 2007, two inmates at the Rivers Correctional Institute filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Carolina alleging that the defendants had violated their Eighth Amendment rights by failing to provide medical, dental, and mental health care to them.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that defendants GEO Group, Inc. ("GEO"), a private, for-profit corporation owned and operated by GEO, and the BOP had violated and were violating federal and state law in connection with their medical care, programs, services, and activities at Rivers because of the plaintiff's disability.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to transfer the case out of the district court for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction and for failure to state a claim, or in the alternative, to transfer it to the District Court.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the defendants' motion for transfer and dismissed the case on July 26, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The case was then transferred to the federal district court in North Carolina, where the plaintiffs filed a third amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the defendants have moved to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: On October 23, 2009, an individual plaintiff filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the District of New Jersey under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the Hackensack Police Department, Hackensack Municipal Court, Bergen County Jail in the City of Hackensack, Bergen County Municipal Court, and Bergen County Prosecutor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, bringing suit pro se, sought compensatory and punitive damages plus special damages for future legal fees.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff specifically claimed that the defendants violated his Second and Fourteenth Amendment rights by attempting to break in and enter his home, threatening to imprison him, fabricating stories to have him incarcerated, and asserting false criminal charges, which led to plaintiff spending three months and five days in county jail.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendant’s and plaintiff’s motions for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]In Dec.[SENTMARKER]2014, the Third Circuit affirmed the district court’s decision to deny summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]Settlement discussions have since been unsuccessful and the case is ongoing in the district court, pending trial once public health conditions allow.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 23, 2009, a resident of Hackensack, New Jersey filed a civil rights suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey, alleging that Hackensack police officers violated his civil rights by false arrest, false imprisonment, malicious prosecution, and conspiracy.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants were the servants, agents, and employees of their co-defendant, the Bergen County Jail and several of its employees.[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss the complaint, which was granted on April 23, 2010.[SENTMARKER]On October 8, 2010, the Court granted in part and denied in part the defendants' motions to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, which the District Court denied.[SENTMARKER]On October 16, 2013, the parties filed this interlocutory appeal.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the parties' motion for summary judgement and denied the cross motion.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: A deaf prison inmate who primarily communicates in American Sign Language filed a lawsuit under the Americans with Disabilities Act against the Oregon Department of Corrections, claiming they failed to communicate with him for over 14 years.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit claimed that, instead of providing interpreters, the prison made him train other inmates as his interpreters and they were not qualified to help him and were also privy to confidential information.[SENTMARKER]In May 2016, the Court granted partial summary judgment for the defendant.[SENTMARKER]Following a jury trial on the remaining claims, the Court dismissed the plaintiff's ADA claim for failure to exhaust administrative remedies under the PLRA.[SENTMARKER]The jury awarded the plaintiff $400,000 in noneconomic damages.[SENTMARKER]The Court awarded the plaintiff $683,873.13 in attorneys' fees, $18,155.19 in costs, and $3,924.79 in litigation expenses.[SENTMARKER]Although both parties appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, they agreed to voluntarily dismiss their appeals in September 2017.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 5, 2014, an inmate at Columbia River Correctional Institution (CRCI) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon against the Oregon Department of Corrections (ODOC) alleging discrimination under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, Title II of the ADA, and common law tort claims.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant failed to provide the inmate with an interpreter of any kind for the 12 education, training, classes, and other programs offered at OSCI and did not engage in effective 13 communication with Mr. VanValkenburg as part of offering these programs or services.[SENTMARKER]On May 6, 2014, the defendant moved the court for an order dismissing the complaint in part for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendant's motion for summary judgment and denied the plaintiff's request for injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On November 10, 2011, the plaintiff--an Oregon Department of Corrections inmate-- filed this lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, in U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the Oregon Department of Corrections violated his First Amendment free speech rights, his Fourteenth Amendment Due Process rights, and his Eighth Amendment right to be free of cruel and unusual punishment, when they rejected a return a letter written to another ODOC inmate because the envelope had a drawing on it.[SENTMARKER]On May 14, 2015, the District Court enjoined the challenged prison policy.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 10, 2011, an inmate of the Oregon Department of Corrections filed this civil rights action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon, alleging that the defendants violated his First Amendment, Eighth Amendment, and Fourteenth Amendment rights under the United States Constitution by denying him the right to send an inmate mail containing artwork on the front of the envelope.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that defendants rejected his mail in retaliation for having filed a lawsuit against the New Mexico Corrections Department.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2013, the parties filed a motion for summary judgment and a stay of discovery.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a declaratory judgment that the defendant's policy violated the First Amendment rights of other inmates and their correspondents.[SENTMARKER]On February 11, 2014, the court entered a final judgment in favor of the defendant, granting summary judgment on all of the plaintiff's claims.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff was transferred to the Florida Department of corrections, where he is currently in custody.

gold_sents: The Disability Rights Network (DRN), a Pennsylvania non-profit, filed this Eighth Amendment suit against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (PDOC) for the PDOC's use of solitary confinement with severely mentally ill prisoners.[SENTMARKER]On January 5, 2015, the parties executed a settlement agreement for dismissal of the matter, in which the PDOC agreed to implement certain improvements and to pay $750,000 to DRN.[SENTMARKER]In particular, the PDOC will evaluate all incoming prisoners for serious mental illness, and will place prisoners with serious mental illness in solitary confinement only in "exceptional" circumstances; even then, a prisoner with serious mental illness can be kept in solitary confinement for no longer than 30 days and must be allowed out of their cells for 20 hours per week.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also provided for a monitor to report on compliance, and will remain in effect for 3 years (less if the defendant demonstrates substantial compliance for a period of 18 months).[SENTMARKER]There has been no activity on the docket since May 2015 and the case is presumably closed since the three year time period set in the agreement has lapsed.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 11, 2013, the Disability Rights Network of Pennsylvania (DRN) filed a federal law suit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections (DOC) alleging that the DOC violated the Eighth Amendment rights of prisoners with serious mental illness by placing them in solitary confinement for extended periods of time.[SENTMARKER]According to the suit, the DOC's policies, practices, and procedures, including the practice of segregating them for long periods, can cause grave harm to their mental and physical health.[SENTMARKER]The DRN also alleged that the treatment of these prisoners, who make up about 33% of the total RHU population, was not adequately taken into account before disciplining them.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on January 5, 2015, which required the DOC to provide the plaintiffs with constitutionally adequate mental health care, provide them with unconstitutional adequate solitary confinement, and protect them against dangerous and unconstitutional conditions of confinement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement was signed by Judge Martin C. Carlson and Judge Susan E. Schwab on May 24, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a motion for partial summary judgment on May 26, 2015, and the case was dismissed by Judge Carlson on May 27, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to Judge Schwab for further proceedings.

gold_sents: Incarcerated prisoners, Prison Radio, Human Rights Coalition, a network of educators, and Prison Legal News, filed these two consolidated lawsuits in the Middle District of Pennsylvania under 42 U.S.C.§ 1983 and Pennsylvania state law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the Penn.[SENTMARKER]Revictimization Relief Act--which banned certain public speeches by those convicted of crimes--violated their free speech rights.[SENTMARKER]The District Court agreed, striking down the law on April 2015.[SENTMARKER]Defendants elected not to appeal the judgment.[SENTMARKER]Since July 2015, there has been no activity on the docket and the case is presumably closed.
pegasus_output_sents: In November 2018, a group of individuals and organizations filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections, the Pennsylvania Attorney General, and the Philadelphia County District Attorney for violating the First and Fifth Amendments of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On October 21, 2014, then-Pennsylvania Governor Tom Corbett signed into law a statute that violated the due process and First Amendment rights of a broad array of individuals, organizations, and individuals.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the law is an unconstitutional restriction of speech in violation of the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' requests for declaratory and injunctive relief, and permanently enjoined the defendants from enforcing the law.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.[SENTMARKER]The defendants have filed a motion to dismiss the case, which is pending in the Pennsylvania Supreme Court.

gold_sents: In 2013, a prisoner in Pennsylvania state prison filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that his 22 years of solitary confinement violated the Eighth Amendment as well as his Fourteenth Amendment right to due process.[SENTMARKER]In 2016, the parties concluded successful mediation as a result of systemic changes to Pennsylvania's policies concerning solitary confinement and the case was dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 23, 2013, a prisoner with serious mental illness and intellectual disabilities filed a lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania against the Pennsylvania Departments of Corrections and Secretary John E. Wetzel.[SENTMARKER]The prisoner alleged that his prolonged years in solitary confinement deprived him of physical health and exercise.[SENTMARKER]He also alleged that the conditions of his solitary confinement were cruel and unusual punishment under the Eighth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the long-term use of solitary confinement on mentally ill prisoners violated the Constitution's prohibition against cruel punishment and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).[SENTMARKER]The court granted the prisoner's motion for class-action status, and the case was transferred to the federal court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is still ongoing.

gold_sents: On February 3, 2010, a group of 11 individuals held in Virginia prisons filed a class action lawsuit against the Virginia Parole Board for denying parole requests because of the nature and circumstances of the crimes they had been convicted of committing.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case with prejudice, and the Fourth Circuit affirmed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 1, 1995, a class of inmates in Virginia's prisons filed this suit against members of the Virginia Parole Board in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia alleging violation of their constitutional rights with respect to discretionary parole release.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Board's policies and procedures violated their rights under the Due Process Clause and the Ex Post Facto Clause.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case, but the case was appealed and the case is now pending in the Virginia Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.

gold_sents: In 2015, the plaintiff filed this in the U.S. District Court of Vermont alleging disability-based discrimination while incarcerated.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sought declaratory, injunctive, compensatory, and punitive relief and the judge dismissed the matter after the parties reached a full settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2016, Disability Rights Vermont (DVR) filed this class action lawsuit against the Vermont Department of Corrections (DOC), the Vermont Agency of Human Services (DAIL), and the Vermont Fair Housing and Public Accommodations Act (VFHPAA) on behalf of a man with schizo-affective disorder and depression who was incarcerated at the Southern State Correctional Facility in Springfield, Vermont.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants willfully and knowingly caused Plaintiff to be held in unnecessarily segregated circumstances when he would be eligible for community placement if the appropriate, State-funded available community supports and services were implemented.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiff was denied the equal benefit of those programs as compared to his non-disabled peers because of the defendants' failure to have a reasonably functional system in place to identify and implement appropriate disability-related supports in the community to prevent continued, unnecessary and harmful institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The court granted Plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction, granted his motion for injunctive relief, and granted his request for a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on June 6, 2016.

gold_sents: In 2016, current and former public housing residents filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged rampant discrimination on the basis of race and family status, rent overcharges, and a failure to maintain rental units.[SENTMARKER]After participating in settlement conferences, the plaintiffs agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice and without costs in July 2017.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 13, 2017, a group of current and former residents of the Alexander County housing authority filed a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Illinois against the housing authority.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that ACHA and its agents have discriminated against residents of its McBride and Elmwood family housing developments based on their race and familial status, in violation of the Fair Housing Act and the Illinois Civil rights Act of 2003.[SENTMARKER]In 1974, the Department of Justice filed a lawsuit against ACHA for intentionally segregating its two main public housing complexes by race.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit was eventually settled, and ACHA agreed to stop segregation of its housing based on race.[SENTMARKER]However, for at least ten years, ACHA, through its Executive Directors, have implemented a rule prohibiting families with children from living in Connell Smith, Shoemaker, and several of the scattered site developments and improperly reserved them for seniors and people with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants' actions as described above perpetrate segregation on the basis of race and family status discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The defendants were warned that failure to comply with the court's order could result in dismissal of their claims for want of prosecution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: The NAACP and individual people sued the city of San Jose and political officials for policing tactics that allegedly deprived them of their First, Fourth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, protesting systemic racism in policing, alleged that the police used excessive force in a racially motivated manner to end the protests.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 29, 2020, the San Jose NAACP and San Jose Peace and Justice Center filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the City of San Jose and its police department.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the city's police department violated the plaintiffs' First Amendment rights to free speech and assembly when it imposed a city-wide curfew on demonstrators protesting the police killing of George Floyd on May 29, 2020 in San José, California.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the plaintiffs were met with brutal and racially targeted repression by the defendants, who used batons, pepper spray, and other physical force to disperse the demonstrators.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also failed to provide reasonable accommodations for people with disabilities to equally participate in constitutionally protected free speech during demonstrations.[SENTMARKER]The complaint sought injunctive and declaratory relief, injunctive relief, and compensation for the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on June 7, 2020, when the court entered a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs, finding that the defendants had violated the plaintiff's rights.

gold_sents: This is a lawsuit brought by several black activist groups, legal organizations, and news media outlets, against the heads of various federal agencies, including the DHS, ICE, Federal Protective Services, and the DOJ.[SENTMARKER]They argued that the deployment to Chicago of these federal agencies by President Trump during the protests that ensued after the police killing of George Floyd were unlawful and unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]They argued that the defendants violated the First, Fourth, and Tenth Amendments by using these agents, and that they were in conspiracy to deprive Chicago residents of their rights.[SENTMARKER]When Joe Biden replaced Donald Trump as President, the change in administration mooted the case.[SENTMARKER]It was voluntarily dismissed by the plaintiffs in January 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 17, 2017, the NationalLawyers Guild Chicago (NLG Chicago) filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois against the Departments of Justice (DOJ) and Homeland Security (DHS) alleging that federal law enforcement in Portland, Oregon violated the First, Fourth, and Tenth Amendments during protests in Chicago.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their First Amendment rights by sending infiltrators to surveil protest groups and using technology to spy on the communications of protesters and organizers.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion for a temporary restraining order on standing grounds, and the defendants subsequently dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Individuals issued summonses by the NYPD without probable cause brought a class action suit against the City of New York.[SENTMARKER]They alleged that the NYPD's 'quota' policy is linked to officer promotion and demotion, and as a result, leads to commanding officers ordering police officers to arrest and issue summonses to individuals without probable cause, in contravention of the federal and state constitutions.[SENTMARKER]Judge Sweet, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, granted the case class action status in April 2012.[SENTMARKER]On January 24, 2017, Judge Sweet preliminary approved the parties' settlement agreement, in which the parties agreed to settlement benefits of up to seventy-five million dollars.[SENTMARKER]On April 18, 2017, the court granted final approval.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing for compliance purposes.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 25, 2010, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on behalf of hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers who were issued summonses by the New York City Police Department (NYPD) in violation of the First Amendment right to peaceably assemble.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the NYPD violated the plaintiffs' constitutional rights by issuing summonses that were later dismissed upon a judicial finding of facial insuff iency and who were ticketed without probable cause.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement on January 23, 2017, in which the parties agreed to pay $18,500 in attorney's fees and costs, subject to Court approval, to settle the class action.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement is non-collusive and does not require the plaintiffs to pay any additional fees or costs associated with the litigation.

gold_sents: On August 28, 1997, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the City of Steubenville pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §14141 in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio to remedy an alleged pattern or practice of unconstitutional misconduct by officers of the Steubenville Police Department.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into consent decree contemporaneously with filing the complaint.[SENTMARKER]Monitoring and reporting continued into 2005, when the parties filed and the court granted a joint motion for termination.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. Department of Justice and the City of Steubenville entered into a consent decree on September 3, 1997 in the Southern District of Ohio for the hiring of a new police chief.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the City to develop and implement an extensive training policy for all of its police officers as well as an internal affairs policy.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the City had violated the terms of the consent decree by failing to hire a police chief from outside the department.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved for summary judgment on all of the plaintiffs' claims, claiming that the relief sought by the plaintiffs was in direct contradiction to the consent consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion, holding that there were genuine issues of material fact on the warrantless-entry and false-arrest claims.[SENTMARKER]On May 8, 2006, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the defendants' motion, finding that the plaintiffs had failed to show that they had met the requirements of the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on May 8, 2006.

gold_sents: In July 2008, the plaintiffs sued the City of Tenaha under the Fourth Amendment (unreasonable search and seizure) and the Fourteenth Amendment (equal protection).[SENTMARKER]They claimed that law enforcement officials in and around the City of Tenaha have developed an illegal practice of targeting, stopping, detaining, searching, and often seizing property from people who appeared to be non-white or who were traveling with non-white passengers.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that they had been victims of such stops and seizures of amounts up to $50,000, as well as false prosecution or detention.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a preliminary settlement in August 2012.[SENTMARKER]Their proposed consent decree included: video and audio recordings of all stops; written documentation with details of the stop; no more dog searches in routine traffic stops; written and oral consent for a search; all asset forfeiture revenue must be donated to nonprofits or used for audio/video equipment or training; and use of an impartial monitor.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree, which it later extended to early 2021 after the plaintiffs alleged noncompliance by the City.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2012, a class action lawsuit was brought against the Shelby County Police Department by African-Americans who alleged that the department's practice of targeting, stopping, detaining, searching, and often seizing property from individuals who are, or appear to be, members of a racial or ethnic minority and their passengers violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought an injunction requiring the defendants to provide them with "mutually affordable health care" and to pay their attorneys' fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties negotiated and agreed to a consent decree, which was approved by the court in August 2012.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree provided remedies for the plaintiffs' complaints, including that the defendants would not use canines during traffic stops and that they would make audio and video recordings of all stops and all searches, seizures, detentions, and arrests that result from traffic stops.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also agreed to institute internal review procedures every quarter to ensure compliance with the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The court granted class certification in August 2012 and the parties entered into an interlocal agreement with Shelby County Precinct Constables Zack Warr (Pct.)[SENTMARKER]to implement an impartial policing policy.[SENTMARKER]The district attorney's office, the ACLU, and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) filed a joint motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the district attorney’s office and the case was dismissed.

gold_sents: In 2021, the ACLU and private counsel brought this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California in response to President Trump’s June 11, 2020 Executive Order authorizing economic sanctions against individuals who assist the International Criminal Court in investigating or prosecuting war crimes.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and §706 of the Administrative Procedure Act. They sought declaratory relief and an injunction that would prevent the Trump Administration from implementing or enforcing the Executive Order.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: June 15, 2020 DATE | U.S. District Court ORG | Northern District of California DATE ||| International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) DATE | OFAC DATE | ||||||| Executive Order Date ||| June 30, 2020 DATE .<n>On June 15, 2020, a group of individuals representing victims of atrocity crimes filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of Northern California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU's Human Rights Program, alleged that the Executive Order and its implementing steps violated their First Amendment rights by prohibiting their constitutionally protected speech with the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) and the International Criminal Prosecution Service (ICC).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as permanent injunctions.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Judge Charles R. Breyer, who granted the plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment in favor of OFAC and the ICC.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the case on June 30, 2020.

gold_sents: The Alliance Party and two third-party presidential sued the District of Columbia Board of Elections.[SENTMARKER]The D.C. city government had lowered the signatures required for ballot qualification from 5,007 to 250 on August 6, 2020, the day after petitions to appear on the ballot were due.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs contended that they had ceased collecting signatures because it was "impossible" to collect 5,007 signatures while adhering to social distancing guidelines, but would have continued their efforts if they knew they only had to get 250.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied a motion for temporary restraining order, the 2020 election was held and this case was dismissed soon after.
pegasus_output_sents: December 7, 2020 DATE | Alliance Party ORG | U.S. District Court DATE ||| August 5, 2020 DATE DATE | ||| September 1, 2020 DATE On December 7, 2020, the Alliance Party filed this civil action in the United States District Court for the District of Colombia against the District's Board of Election Commissioners.[SENTMARKER]The Alliance Party alleges that the Board violated the First Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendments by enforcing a law that lowered the number of signatures required to be filed by third party presidential candidates to secure access to the District’s 2020 general election presidential ballot.[SENTMARKER]The District also reduced the signature requirement for candidates for elective office in the District from the lesser of 3,000 signatures or 1.5% of all registered voters to a flat 250 signature requirement.[SENTMARKER]As part of its emergency response to the ongoing health crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, the District dramatically lowered the signature requirements for every candidate for the Office of President and Vice President, except independent and third-party presidential candidates.[SENTMARKER]On August 6, 2020, the day after the deadline to file the petition had already passed, the signatures required for third party candidates were lowered in time to take advantage of the reduced signature total and secure ballot access.[SENTMARKER]On September 1, 2020, the District extended the deadline until September 1, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief and issued an emergency restraining order and a temporary restraining order enjoining the Board from enforcing the law.[SENTMARKER]The Court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case without prejudice.

gold_sents: In 2015, residents of Jefferson County, Florida filed this action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county's 2013 redistricting plan was guilty of "prison-based gerrymandering," and was thus guilty of violating the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought and received a declaration that the 2013 plan was unconstitutional as well as an injunction requiring the defendants to produce an acceptable redistricting plan.[SENTMARKER]The defendants' plan was approved and parties then settled on the attorneys' fees.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 22, 1983, a group of African-American residents of Jefferson County, Florida, filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Florida against the Jefferson County Board of Commissioners and Jefferson County School Board.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the county's 2013 redistricting plan violated the Fourteenth Amendment right to equal representation under the "one person, one vote" principle of the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that the district that houses the Jefferson Correctional Institution ("JCI") unlawfully inflates the political strength of actual residents in the district and dilutes the voting strength of those living in all of the other districts in the county.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory and injunctive relief, an injunction preventing Defendants from conducting elections for the Boards under the current scheme, and attorney's fees and litigation expenses reimbursement.[SENTMARKER]On March 19, 2016, the Court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Several citizens and residents of Arizona subject to the death penalty brought suit under 42 U.S.C. §1983 against the Arizona Department of Corrections (ADC) and several associated governmental employees.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the ADC's lethal injection procedure violated their First Amendment right to access governmental proceedings, the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Eighth Amendment, and the Federal Supremacy Clause.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a stipulated agreement prohibiting the defendant from using certain chemicals for execution, among other limitation.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing after the Ninth Circuit remanded counts for retrial.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 26, 2014, a group of death-row inmates filed this suit in the District of Arizona, seeking equitable, injunctive, and declaratory relief under the First Amendment right of access to the courts.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Arizona's lethal injection procedures violated the Constitution's due process rights by requiring a "humane," "dignified" death that results in 9 "the least amount of discomfort" possible.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the plaintiffs' claims under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to stay the litigation until the Department published a set of revised execution procedures.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court vacated the district court's denial of the inmates' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2012, plaintiffs filed suit in the Eastern District of Michigan, alleging that the Sex Offender Registration Act (SORA), when applied retroactively, violated their rights to due process, was unconstitutionally vague, violated prohibitions on ex post facto laws, and violated their fundamental rights.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, upon remand from the Sixth Circuit, the district court held that SORA violated the Ex Post Facto clause and could not be applied retroactively.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2012, Plaintiff John Does I-IV and Mary Doe filed this lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Attorney's Office for the Eastern district of Michigan against the director of the Michigan State Police.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Michigan's sex offender registration law violated their First and Fourteenth Amendment rights by requiring them to register as sex offenders, even though they had not been convicted of a sex offense.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case was dismissed and sealed.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals, which remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now before the court on remand.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the parties agreed that the law would not require sex offenders to register for life, rather than for twenty-five years, and that the sex offenders would be required to submit to the Internet reporting requirements for life.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement, the defendants agreed to provide the court with a list of all registered sex offenders in the state of Michigan who would be subject to the online reporting requirements.[SENTMARKER]The district court agreed to dismiss the case and seal the records of all sex offenders who were not registered for the lifetime registration requirement.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States ruled in favor of the defendants in a similar case in 2014.

gold_sents: Six Insane Clown Posse fans, or "Juggalos," sued the DOJ and FBI in the the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan under the Administrative Procedures Act and the Declaratory Judgment Act, alleging that the FBI had designated the Juggalos as a "loosely organized hybrid gang" in 2011, which had caused various harms to the plaintiffs, including extra police attention.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case upon finding that the designation was not a final agency action, and the Sixth Circuit affirmed the dismissal.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 29, 2016, a group of self-identified Juggalos filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan against the Department of Justice (DOJ) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) under the Administrative Procedure Act and the Declaratory Judgment Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants violated their First and Fifth Amendment rights by using the term "hybrid gang" in reference to the Juggalo in National Gang Intelligence Center threat assessment.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case for lack of standing.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed and the Sixth Circuit reversed and remanded, finding standing adequately shown.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States affirmed the district court's dismissal of the case in a divided opinion.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On June 28, 2018, Black Love Resists in the Rust and four individual plaintiffs filed this class action lawsuit against the City of Buffalo in the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that the Buffalo Police Department disproportionately used vehicle checkpoints in Black and Latino communities to generate revenue, resulting in disparate impact on Black and Latino people.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought an injunction to end and remediate these traffic enforcement practices, as well as monetary damages for the financial harm, humiliation, and loss of liberty and property.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on May 21, 2020; the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 29, 2018, a class action was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York against the City of Buffalo, the Buffalo Police Department, and the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants targeted Black and Latino neighborhoods and residents for aggressive and punitive traffic enforcement in order to generate revenue for the City budget via tickets, impounds, and towing fees.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants’ policies, practices, and/or customs have directly caused the state to suspend thousands of driver’s licenses belonging to low-income people of color in Buffalo.[SENTMARKER]Most of the drivers pulled over for secondary inspections were Black.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that each defendant acted with deliberate indifference to the Fourteenth Amendment rights of Named Plaintiffs and class members.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification on June 29, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 30, 2020, Disability Rights California brought a suit against Alameda County in the Northern District Court of California.[SENTMARKER]Disability Rights California alleged that Alameda County had discriminated against residents with serious mental health disabilities by institutionalizing and segregating them instead of providing adequate treatment and services.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2021, the Court granted Alameda County’s motion to dismiss with leave to amend and denied their motion to strike.[SENTMARKER]Disability Rights California has filed an amended complaint as of February 23, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 21, 2020, Disability rights California (DRC) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the County of Alameda, the County's Behavioral Health care services, and California's Medi-Cal program.[SENTMARKER]DRC's complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Rehabilitation Act, and the California Government Code sections 9135 and 11139 by failing to provide sufficient community-based treatment programs that would reduce institutionalization in the County.[SENTMARKER]DRC also alleged that it was subject to unnecessary institutionalization and an unnecessary risk of 18 institutionalization.[SENTMARKER]The defendants moved to dismiss DRC’s claims for lack of standing and for failure to state a claim for which relief may be granted.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants’ motions to dismiss with leave to amend.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2015, a deaf individual filed a lawsuit against Parkview Health Systems Inc.[SENTMARKER]He claimed that he was not provided an interpreter in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act, which severely influenced his communications with hospital staff regarding his critically injured daughter.[SENTMARKER]The case settled for changes in policy and practice.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 6, 2015, the Civil Rights Education and Enforcement Center (CREC) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado on behalf of George Baca, a resident of Colorado who is deaf and who is enrolled in the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Colorado Anti-Discrimination Act (COLO REV STAT).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the ADA by failing to provide effective communication services to Mr. Baca and by denying him equal enjoyment of the goods, services, facilities, privileges, advantages, or accommodations of the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the defendants agreed to pay a total of $65,00 to the plaintiff.[SENTMARKER]The terms of the settlement were not disclosed, but the parties agreed that the defendant would not make the settlement public in any way.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: On January 1, 2014, deaf and hard of hearing inmates in the Kentucky prison system filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky against the Commonwealth of Kentucky and the Kentucky Department of Corrections, alleging violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act, and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that they were denied access to telecommunications and denied interpretative services for religious services, job training, disciplinary hearings, public announcements, educational and vocational training effectively excluding them from many governmental services.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached settlement which was entered by the court in a consent decree in June, 2015.[SENTMARKER]A monitor was appointed, who will submit a  semi-annual report during the five-year term of the settlement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement includes provision of services and accommodations through a qualified interpreter and communication technologies, staffing, and training.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 24, 2015, two deaf inmates filed a class-action lawsuit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Attorney's Office for the Eastern district of Kentucky against the Kentucky Department of Corrections (KDOC) alleging violations of their rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act of 2000 (RLUIPA).[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the KDOC failed to provide deaf inmates with equal access to telecommunications services in order for them to communicate with family, friends, and other individuals outside of prison.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that deaf inmates were denied effective telecommunication services due to the failure of KDOC to provide videophone services to them.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement, which was approved by the district court on April 24, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement provided for the use of videophones for deaf and hard-of-hearing inmates, hearing aid earphones for deaf inmates, and hearing aid headphones for the deaf inmates.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also provided for a hearing aid headset for each deaf inmate.[SENTMARKER]The deadline for the parties to file into the record their agreed order dismissing the case was set for April 27.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on April 24 2015.

gold_sents: In January 2015, the plaintiff, a prisoner, filed this putative class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania, alleging that the Pennsylvania Department of Corrections systematically denied medical care to individuals with severe eye conditions, including severe cataracts, in violation of the ADA, § 504, and his Eighth Amendment right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, and the Department of Corrections changed their cataract policy, no longer denying surgery to individuals who had "One Good Eye."
pegasus_output_sents: In January 1983, a prisoner with severe eye conditions filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District Of Pennsylvania on behalf of hundreds of inmates who were denied necessary medical care for their eye conditions.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Pennsylvania Department Of Corrections's (DOC) policy and practice of denying necessary medical treatment to inmates with eye conditions including severe cataracts, thereby condemning them to partial or total blindness, violated Title II of the Americans with Disability Act of 1990 and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and the Eighth Amendment of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to eliminate Defendants’ actions, policies, and practices which infringe their rights.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a settlement agreement in which the parties agreed that the DOC would provide post-operative treatment for each inmate undergoing cataract surgery in accordance with the outside ophthalmologist's recommendation, including follow-up examinations, refraction for new glasses, and laser and surgical procedures to address any postoperative complications.[SENTMARKER]The settlement also required the DOC to inform its staff, and outside medical providers, of its new cataract surgery policy and to inform potential Affected Inmates to inform them of the new cataract policy.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the DOC was required to inform the plaintiffs of any complications resulting from the cataract surgery.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment in favor of the settlement agreement.

gold_sents: Students in Mobile County schools sued the county for violations of the Fourteenth Amendment Right to Due Process by denying the students a hearing before issuing long-term suspensions and expulsions.[SENTMARKER]The case entered mediation and was settled on the terms of the agreement that amended the school district's disciplinary procedures and practices.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2011, a group of students filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Alabama against the Board of School Commissioners of Mobile County (the "Board"), alleging that the Board violated the Fourteenth Amendment right to due process by imposing long-term suspensions on students without providing even the reduced due process required by the District's challenged policy.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the students' parents were not adequately informed of the right to a due process hearing when their children were suspended without assignment to alternative school.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that school administrators at Blount High School and Scarborough Middle School had been engaging in a practice of imposing long term suspensions without even the limited due process requirements of the challenged policy, and that the District did not provide educational services to most general education students who are on the waiting list for alternative schools.[SENTMARKER]In June 2011, the Board entered into a settlement agreement with the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into the settlement agreement, which was approved by the Board in June 2010, and the parties agreed that the School System would provide reasonable career preparation assistance and assistance with the graduation exam for all students who were suspended for more than ten days without proper notice or a hearing for minor infractions.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement also provided that the plaintiffs would be required to pay their legal fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The Court dismissed the case with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2017, four low-income African American mothers filed suit against the numerous officials of the State of Mississippi claiming the state failed to live up to the educational requirements set by the Mississippi Readmission Act of 1870.[SENTMARKER]They sought declaratory relief that the requirements are still intact.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed in 2018 due to the state sovereign immunity under the Eleventh Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs appealed to the Fifth Circuit which affirmed in part and reversed in part.[SENTMARKER]The defendants requested rehearing en banc, but the Fifth Circuit denied the request.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a petition for review with the Supreme Court and a request to stay the Fifth Circuit's mandate in January 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: In May 2017, a group of low-income African-American women with school-aged children filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District, alleging that Mississippi had violated the federal education clause of the Mississippi Constitution by amending the education clause after its ratification following the Civil War.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the amendment had resulted in a grave disparity in the education being provided to students who attend either predominantly White or predominantly Black schools around the state.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the case on several grounds, including the political question doctrine, the Mississippi Readmission Act, and the Eleventh Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The Third and Fourth Circuits both held that these claims were barred by sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the case was re-opened and the district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a declaratory judgment against 14 state officials.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the case is closed.

gold_sents: This federal lawsuit was filed in 2000 in the Eastern District of California; in it, a former high school student and the Gay-Straight Alliance Network sued his school district for failure to take effective measures to remedy continuing harassment that he faced based on his sexual orientation.[SENTMARKER]The case settled for a consent decree entered August 15, 2002, which required the defendants to implement a mandatory staff training program, revise its policies, select compliance coordinators, develop systems for reporting harassment and discrimination, allow students to form a gay-straight alliance, and create a community advisory group.[SENTMARKER]The decree implementation period was 6 months.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 8, 2009, a high school student and his younger sister, through their parents and next friends, brought a Title IX and Equal Access Act lawsuit against the Indian River School District in the United States District Court for the Northern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the school district and its Board of Education violated Title IX of the Education Amendments Act of 1972 and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by denying them permission to form a Gay-Straight Alliance (GSA) organization.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the plaintiffs' requests for permission to use the school's public address system, denied their requests for a yearbook, and refused to allow A.E.P.[SENTMARKER]as alleged herein as alleged.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, granted their motion to dismiss, and dismissed the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the plaintiffs have no further legal recourse.

pegasus_output_sents: On February 28, 2007, a lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Alabama against Cook's Pest Control, Inc., a pest control company based in Birmingham, Alabama.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendant violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by discouraging job applications by African-Americans by telling callers with a dialect or diction that may indicate they are African, or African-American, who apply in person, that there are no jobs available.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement in October 2011, and the parties filed a joint motion for preliminary approval with this court on November 3, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement fund of $2,500,000, which includes all costs and expenses of the Claims Administrator.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved by the court on January 27, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the parties' motion to stay the action pending further mediation.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on November 2, 2011.

pegasus_output_sents: On May 9, 2009, a class action lawsuit was brought in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Samsonite Company Stores, Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiary, Samsonite Corporation.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that they were paid less than minimum wage and overtime for their work as store managers in the retail stores of Samsonite.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants violated the Fair Labor Standard Act (FLSA) by failing to pay them at least minimum wages and overtime.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay $850,000 to all 89 of the class members to resolve all outstanding wage and hour claims under the FLSA, 17 California, and New York law.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was approved by the court on May 10, 2009.[SENTMARKER]The parties then filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was denied on May 11, 2010.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties are awaiting final court approval.

pegasus_output_sents: In April 2000, a black mechanic/welder filed a complaint in the Denver District Court, alleging that he was discriminated against on the basis of his race while employed by defendant TimPte.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant's managers and supervisors used racial slurs and racist symbols in the workplace, including swastikas, "KKK," "die nigger," "nigger," and a doll with a noose around its neck.[SENTMARKER]The court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendant, finding that it had no policy against racial harassment and that it did not hire anyone to conduct training on harassment of any kind.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed in October 2000 and the defendant has since sold its Commerce City facility.

pegasus_output_sents: On March 16, 2001, a former African-American employee of DC WASA filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the District of Washington, alleging that the Defendant discriminated against him and other African-Americans with respect to pay and promotions.[SENTMARKER]The District Court granted the Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment in part and denied the Defendant's appeal in part.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an out-of-court settlement in August 2012 and the District Court entered a final judgment in favor of the Plaintiff in March 2013.[SENTMARKER]The Court held that WASA had violated Title VII by failing to post a copy of its compensation policies on its website, failing to provide compensation policies to all new hires upon hire, and failing to comply with the terms of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The Court also held that the Plaintiff had failed to show that he had been discriminated against by the Defendant in violation of Title VII.[SENTMARKER]The Defendant appealed the final judgment, which was granted in part, and the case was settled in March 2014.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals granted the Defendant’s motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case without further litigation.

pegasus_output_sents: In the early 1980s, a class of asylum seekers sued the Department of Homeland Security for unlawful administrative voluntary departure practices in Southern California.[SENTMARKER]In June 2013, the parties reached a settlement agreement in the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties sought declaratory and injunctive relief to correct the unlawful practices of immigration enforcement agencies.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement, which was entered into by the parties on June 4, 2013, provided that certain individuals would be allowed to return to the United States in a manner that restores them to their legal position that they had occupied prior to their respective voluntary departures.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed that the parties would provide each other with a copy of the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to dismiss the case with prejudice.
