pegasus_output_sents: On December 18, 2017, the ACLU of Northern California filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) seeking records about the treatment of immigration detainees in ICE's San Francisco Area of Responsibility (ACLU-NC).[SENTMARKER]The ACLU-NC and East Bay Express (EBE), a local independent newspaper, filed a FOIA 9 request to ICE seeking information about policies, procedures, and guidelines for detaining and transporting immigration detainees.[SENTMARKER]ICE has not produced a single document in response to either the First FOIA 15 Request or the Second FOIA Request.[SENTMARKER]The ACLU has suffered irreparable injury from ICE’s unlawful withholding of government documents pertaining to the subject of 13 FOIA requests.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the ACLU’s motion for partial summary judgment and ordered ICE to produce the requested records.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This case was filed in response to the July 6, 2020 directive by ICE that would effectively force international students studying under F-1 and M-1 visas to attend in-person classes or risk deportation.[SENTMARKER]The state of California filed this suit against ICE and DHS on July 9, arguing that the directive was in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) in two ways.[SENTMARKER]First, the directive was arbitrary and capricious in that it failed to take into account students' and universities' reliance interests and the defendants gave no reasoned basis for the new order.[SENTMARKER]Second, the defendants were in violation of procedural elements of the APA, because they failed to use proper notice-and-comment rule-making when issuing the new order.[SENTMARKER]On July 15, in a different lawsuit filed against the administration over the same July directive, plaintiffs met with counsel for the government and worked to get the regulations rescinded.[SENTMARKER]In order to effectuate the rescission, ICE removed the guidance from its website and replaced it with the previous guidance and as a result, plaintiffs withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]California continued to monitor the alterations ICE made to its website between July and September and filed a notice of voluntary dismissal on October 19, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 13, 2020, the State of California filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for rescinding the in-person learning exemption for F-1 and M-1 nonimmigrant students.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the rescission of the exemption violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) because it was arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the State's motion for declaratory, injunctive, and other relief, and granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On July 20, 2010, the American Immigration Lawyers Association (AILA) filed suit against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for failing to adequately respond to FOIA requests regarding USCIS procedures for inspecting potential H-1B visa fraud.[SENTMARKER]On March 30, 2012, the District Court ordered DHS to provide adequate description of the exempted information in response to the FOIA request so that AILA could make a proper segregability determination.[SENTMARKER]This was the last action in this case.
pegasus_output_sents: The American Immigration Lawyers Association (AILA) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and its component, the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) in March 2011 seeking the release of records concerning agency policies and procedures relating to nonimmigrant temporary workers and particularly the adjudication of petitions for their lawful employment in the US.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated FOIA by failing to comply with AILA's FOIA requests for records concerning the current procedures for reviewing and adjudicating H-1B cases.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also alleged that AILA had violated FOIA exemptions, including the failure to segregate non-exempt information from allegedly exempt information, and the alleged applicability of FOIA exemptions to the records sought.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment, finding that they had complied with their FOIA obligations.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the matter.

gold_sents: Central American mothers and children detainees brought suit against the Department of Homeland Security and its various agencies for the government's unlawful expedited removal policies at the Artesia Family Residential Center.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case in January 2015 after DHS remedied the violations of Plaintiffs' rights in their immigration proceedings and closed the Artesia facility.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 22, 2014, a mother and her two daughters from El Salvador and Honduras filed this lawsuit in the District Court in Washington, D.C. against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) seeking class-action status under the Equal Access to Justice Act (E.A.J.[SENTMARKER]Act) and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) for their detention at the Artesia Family Residential Center in New Mexico.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the government's new expedited removal policies and procedures make it much more difficult for detained women and children to present and substantiate their claims to asylum or other forms of immigration relief, and to seek the assistance of counsel in doing so.[SENTMARKER]In particular, this case concerns the government’s creation of a new, revised expedited removal system for use in cases involving recently arrived Central American families.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the plaintiffs and other detainees have gone into their credible fear interviews without knowing what to expect or understanding what rights they had, and have been forced to present their claims in front of their young children.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for class action status, granted their motion for summary judgment, and dismissed their claims without prejudice.

gold_sents: On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents separated from their children filed a civil action against various federal agencies and officials in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for immediate reunification with their children.The plaintiffs were detained after crossing the United States-Mexico border without inspection with young accompanying children, seeking asylum.[SENTMARKER]After plaintiffs were apprehended at the border, the children were separated under the “zero-tolerance” immigration policy announced April 6, 2018, which criminally prosecuted adult entrants crossing the border illegally and placed accompanying minors in custody of the government.[SENTMARKER]All three plaintiffs crossed the border prior to the Executive Order issued on June 20, 2018, which allowed immigrant parents and children apprehended at the border to remain together during the pendency of their proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged interference of family integrity in violation of Due Process, and sought preliminary and permanent injunctions to immediately reunite plaintiffs with their children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs obtained preliminary relief and were (along with another parent who joined the case later to prevent separation from her daughter) ultimately re-united with their children.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 6, 2018, the Attorney General of the United States announced a "zero-tolerance" immigration policy, under which all immigrant parents unlawfully crossing the U. S.-Mexico border with their young children would be subject to criminal prosecution and separated from their children.[SENTMARKER]On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents filed this lawsuit against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and certain federal agencies and officials responsible for enforcing immigration laws and regulations.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a preliminary injunction requiring the government to immediately reunify children under the age of five with their parents by July 10, 2018, and those age five and over by July 26, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On July 9, 2018, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order, and the parties agreed to meet and confer and provide a joint status report to the Court.[SENTMARKER]On July 5, 2018, the Court granted plaintiffs' TRO with respect to certain outstanding requests, but held the TRO in abeyance and suggested that the parties meet on July 6, 2018 to resolve the remaining issues.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that they would meet, confer, and provide the court with a joint report by July 6, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The court held a hearing on July 13, 2018 and issued a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment held that the government could not remove the plaintiffs from the country until July 26, 2018 and that the court had jurisdiction to issue a writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: This action, filed Jan.[SENTMARKER]31, 2017, challenges President Trump’s Jan.[SENTMARKER]27, 2017 Executive Order ban on admission to the U.S. of nationals of Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleges that in preventing a Syrian national with a valid U.S. visa from returning to the U.S. pursuant to the EO, the defendants violated the First Amendment Establishment Clause, Fifth Amendment due process and equal protection rights, the Immigration and Nationality Act, the Administrative Procedure Act, and international law.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff seeks declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by private counsel and Bernard Harcourt of Columbia Law School, is a resident in the University of Illinois Chicago/Advocate Christ Hospital.[SENTMARKER]He returned to the United Arab Emirates to get married on Jan.[SENTMARKER]23, and upon returning to the U.S. to continue his residency, he was detained at Abu Dhabi International Airport on Jan 29.[SENTMARKER]Despite his valid visa, he was detained pursuant to the EO.[SENTMARKER]If the plaintiff cannot return to the U.S., he faces the risk of being deported to Syria, where he is a citizen but has never been a resident.[SENTMARKER]That same day, the plaintiff also filed a motion for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Judge Elaine Bucklo.[SENTMARKER]At a status hearing on February 1, the parties told the judge they had reached a "settlement in principle."[SENTMARKER]On February 2, the plaintiff successfully entered the United States at Chicago O'Hare International Airport.[SENTMARKER]On February 8, the plaintiff filed a motion for voluntary dismissal and leave to reinstate on or before August 1, 2017.[SENTMARKER]Judge Bucklo granted this motion and terminated the case.[SENTMARKER]This case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On January 31, 2017, a medical resident of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern district of Illinois against the Department of Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and President Donald Trump.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the President's January 27, 2017 Executive Order (EO) barring entry into the U.s. of certain foreign nationals from seven countries violated the First and Fifth Amendments of the Constitution, the Administrative Procedure Act, and the Constitution's Due Process Clause.[SENTMARKER]According to the EO, the entry of non-citizens from Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen is suspended from 90 days from the date of the EO.[SENTMARKER]The EO also deprived Plaintiff of his right to due process of law and his statutory and regulatory rights.[SENTMARKER]The court granted Plaintiff's motion for a temporary restraining order, granted his motion for summary judgment, and granted his request for a permanent injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on February 10, 2018.

gold_sents: On Aug.[SENTMARKER]14, 2013, 13 Indian guestworkers filed suit in S.D.[SENTMARKER]Miss.[SENTMARKER]for harm suffered as a result of an allegedly fraudulent and coercive employment recruitment scheme.[SENTMARKER]In Oct. 2013, the court transferred this case to E.D.La where it was consolidated with the Achari lead case.[SENTMARKER]The Achari case was dismissed due to settlement agreement but the court retained jurisdiction.
pegasus_output_sents: In October 2013, a group of Indian workers brought a human trafficking case against Signal International, Inc. (Signal), a private limited liability company organized under the laws of India, and Global Resources, LLC (a/k/a Medtech Consultants) alleging that they were forced to live and work in conditions that violated their rights under the Civil Rights Act of 1866.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Signal threatened anyone who complained about these conditions with reduced pay, suspension, dismissal, or deportation.[SENTMARKER]Some of the workers have been imprisoned for being in the United States without proper visas.[SENTMARKER]The case was consolidated with another case in October 2013 and the parties agreed to settle the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed with prejudice, and that Signal would pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees and costs.

gold_sents: In 2015, six refugees living in Utica, NY filed this class action in the Northern District of New York against the Utica School District Board of Education and the Utica City School District.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that that the defendants consistently denied Utica residents between the ages of 17 and 20 who were limited English proficient (LEP) and immigrants access to educational opportunity.[SENTMARKER]In 2016, the parties reached a settlement requiring the defendants to end their discriminatory practices and enact a detailed remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]Enforcement of the consent decree is ongoing as of November 2018.
pegasus_output_sents: On June 6, 2016, a class action was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District Of New York on behalf of a group of limited English proficient (LEP) students aged 17-20 who were excluded from Proctor High School in Utica, New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had a policy and practice of excluding LEP students from high school and diverting them to either the Newcomer Program or the APPLE Program.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, the defendants did not test LEP immigrant students to determine their level of English proficiency before placing them in the Newcomer program.[SENTMARKER]The defendants also excluded LEP immigrants from the District’s GED program and have no regular contact with English-speaking students.[SENTMARKER]As required by the Equal Educational Opportunities Act (EEOA), the District and the defendants entered into a consent decree on June 6, 2016.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree is effective immediately upon the signature of the court.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement corrective measures to address language barriers that impede equal participation by ELLs aged 16-20 in the district's instructional programs.[SENTMARKER]In addition, the parties agreed that the district would provide the plaintiffs with the opportunity to earn a high school diploma.

gold_sents: In 2020, two immigration detainees in the Batavia Federal Detention Facility in Batavia, NY, filed this class action in the United States District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that they and others similarly situated had been improperly denied bond, that non-bond alternatives to detention had not been properly considered by their immigration judges, that such considerations were required by the Immigration and Nationality Act, and that the policy of placing the burden of proof on the Plaintiffs to show they posed no flight risk violated their Fifth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]The court granted relief for pre-hearing detainees, agreeing that they pled sufficient facts to state a Due Process Claim that the government is required to bear the burden of proof at bond hearings for individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. §1226(a).[SENTMARKER]It denied Plaintiffs' request to certify the putative post-hearing class.[SENTMARKER]Both parties appealed; the case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On March 11, 2020, a group of immigration detainees filed a class action lawsuit in the United States district court for the district of Buffalo, New York against the Department of Justice (DOJ), the Executive Office for Immigration Review (EOIR), and the Buffalo Federal Detention Facility (BFDC) seeking class certification, a declaratory judgment, and a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The petition alleged that the defendants violated the Immigration and Nationality Act and its implementing regulations, the Administrative Procedure Act, and the Fifth Amendment by failing to justify detention by proving by clear and convincing evidence that the detained individual is a danger to others or a flight risk.[SENTMARKER]The court granted in part and denied in part the defendants' motion for a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]The case was transferred to the district court on July 22, 2020, and the defendants filed a motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion, finding that there was no basis for the motion and that the case had no merit.[SENTMARKER]In part, the court granted the defendants’ motion for class certification and certified a Pre-Hearing Class, defined as individuals detained at the BFDC who will have a custody hearing before the Batavia or Buffalo immigration courts.[SENTMARKER]The D&O also denied the class members’ motion to be released unless provided with such a detention hearing.[SENTMARKER]On July 22, 2019, the court dismissed the case without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The parties filed a joint motion for summary judgment, which was granted by the court and the court of appeal.

gold_sents: In May 2015, parents of children born in Texas sued the Texas Department of State Health Services.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs, all Mexican or Central American citizens, asked for the release of their U.S.-citizen children's birth certificates, which defendant would not issue after refusing to accept the parents' consular identity documents.[SENTMARKER]The parties privately settled in July 2016.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 23, 2015, a group of parents of children born in the United States to undocumented immigrant parents filed this class action lawsuit in the Western District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' denial of birth certificates to their children on the basis of their parents' immigration status violated the Equal Protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for a Declaratory Judgment and ordered the defendants to provide the plaintiffs with certified copies of the birth certificates for their children.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on December 23, 2015.

gold_sents: This suit seeks to support Texas's law Senate Bill 4 (SB4), which requires local Texas law enforcement to cooperate with federal immigration officials and punishes them if they do not.[SENTMARKER]Unlike the suits that seek to challenge President Trump's "Sanctuary City" Executive Order, this suit aims to support the work of federal immigration officials.[SENTMARKER]There are, so far, four cases addressing SB4.[SENTMARKER]On May 7, 2017, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed this suit seeking a declaratory judgment approving SB4.[SENTMARKER]Defendants are Travis County, City of Austin, and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund (MALDEF).[SENTMARKER]The defendants filed a motion to dismiss for lack of jurisdiction on May 24, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The court dismissed the case without prejudice to refiling on August 9, 2017, finding that Texas lacked actual or imminent injury, which was required for Article III standing to seek declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Texas appealed to the Fifth Circuit, who affirmed the district court's dismissal of the claim on December 12, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 7, 2017, the State of Texas filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas against the City of El Paso, the League of United Latin American Citizens, Travis County, Maverick County, and the Texas Organizing Project Education Fund ( TOPEF) alleging violations or state and federal law in violation of Senate Bill 4 (SB 4).[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that El Paso had violated SB 4 by refusing to cooperate with federal immigration law enforcement.[SENTMARKER]The district court dismissed the suit for lack of jurisdiction, ruling that the City sought an impermissible advisory opinion.[SENTMARKER]The case is now controlled by the Supreme Court's decision in Franchise Tax Bd (SB 4) and the district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The defendants in Texas's declaratory case moved to dismiss, arguing that the court lacked jurisdiction and, in any event, should dismiss in its discretion.[SENTMARKER]The District Court dismissed this case on August 9, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court ruled that the case should be dismissed on the grounds of a lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.

gold_sents: On May 3, 1993, the U.S. Department of Justice investigated the Harrison County, MI jail.[SENTMARKER]The DOJ found violations of inadequate staffing and medical care.[SENTMARKER]Apparently after negotiation, the Attorney General filed an action under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. 1997 et seq., against the jail in 1995.[SENTMARKER]Six days later, Judge Walter J. Gex III approved a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree mandated doubling the number of officers, increased training, and hiring of medical professionals for the physical and mental health of the patients.[SENTMARKER]The decree was enforced sporadically throughout the next ten years.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2015, the parties filed a joint motion for dismissal, with the county agreeing to continue to use its best efforts to improve its mental health and medical care.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on August 12, 1995.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 3, 1993, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi against Harrison County, Mississippi, alleging that the county violated the constitutional rights of inmates confined at the Harrison County Adult Detention Center (HCDC) by failing to provide them with adequate access to the courts and law books and legal research materials.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants failed to provide inmates with adequate mental health care, adequate medical staffing, adequate training, adequate legal access, and adequate use of the facility's strip cell for disciplinary purposes.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered a consent decree in which the defendants agreed to comply with the terms of the decree.[SENTMARKER]The decree was entered on August 12, 2003, and the parties entered into a final judgment on December 12, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment was entered by Judge Louis Guirola, Jr. on August 26, 2003.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the conditions of confinement and treatment of the inmates at the HCDC would be supervised and controlled by the VJarden, the county's chief of staff, and the county would pay the court's attorney fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The judgment was terminated with prejudice, each party to bear its own attorney fees, and was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.

gold_sents: In 2003, prisoners filed this class-action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Erie County Sheriff's Department had an unconstitutional policy and practice of strip-searching prisoners when they entered the county facilities.[SENTMARKER]In 2012, the Supreme Court ruled that a similar strip search policy was constitutional in Florence v. Board of Chosen Freeholders.[SENTMARKER]Board of Chosen Freeholders.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs in this case argued that their case was distinguishable from Florence.[SENTMARKER]However, no further action occurred in the case after 2012.
pegasus_output_sents: In the course of a lawsuit by a class of arrested persons against Erie County (and certain of its officials) alleging that they were subjected to unconstitutional strip searches of non-felony detainees, the plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that since at least 2001, the Sheriff’s Department had implemented a policy to subject every detainee who entered the Erie County Holding Center or Erie County Correctional Facility to an invasive strip search without regard to individualized suspicion or the severity of the offense alleged, in violation of the Fourth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a writ of mandamus, and the district court's April 17, 2006 order was vacated.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a motion to appeal the order, which was denied by the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit denied the defendants' request for a stay pending an appeal.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Two detainees in Shelby County Jail in Tennessee filed this petition for a writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that failure to take sufficient COVID-19 precautions violated the Fourteenth Amendment, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and they sought release.[SENTMARKER]The court appointed an "Independent Inspector" to assess conditions at the jail and, based on his report, denied preliminary relief.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied defendants' motion to dismiss, and a trial is scheduled for May 2021.[SENTMARKER]An Independent Inspector was tasked with inspecting the jail to evaluate the conditions.[SENTMARKER]While praising defendants' professionalism, he wrote that several adjustments needed to be made in order for the jail to be a safe place for detainees.[SENTMARKER]After attending mediation and filing a joint motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement, the court preliminarily granted the consent decree requiring monthly reports on the status of COVID-19 in the Jail and unannounced, periodic inspections by the Inspector.[SENTMARKER]A final approval hearing is scheduled for March 5, 2021.
pegasus_output_sents: On August 7, 2020, three pretrial detainees filed a class-action suit against the Shelby County Sheriff's Office in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District for the District of Tennesee, alleging that their constitutional and statutory rights were being violated by the conditions in their jail due to the COVID-19 pandemic.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive relief to protect medically vulnerable people and people with disabilities detained at Shelby County Jail.[SENTMARKER]On June 10, 2020, the Court denied Defendants' motion and certified a class and subclass of medically vulnerable and disabled individuals detained at the Jail.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a proposed consent decree, which was approved by the Court on July 10, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the jail would provide at least one mask to each of the plaintiffs and that all inmates were to receive free soap and that soap was not to be confiscated if the inmates had more than one bar.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree also required the jail to follow certain procedures to protect people from COVID, including the Jail's Quarantine / Isolation procedures, the Jail’s efforts to limit movement in the Jail, the jail’s policies concerning medically screening staff and/or visitors to the jail, and its efforts to reduce the population of the Jail due to COVID.[SENTMARKER]The court approved the consent decree in the form of a final judgment, which is summarized below.[SENTMARKER]On July 11, 2020, the parties filed a motion to dismiss the case.

gold_sents: In August 2014, detainees at the Franklin County Jail filed a lawsuit alleging that jail officials used excessive force against them and that the jail provided inhumane living conditions, in violation of the First, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]In March 28, 2016, the parties settled.[SENTMARKER]The defendant paid $400,557.66 in attorneys’ fees and was required to hire additional staff, renovate the prison, and adopt new mental health services policies.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 2014, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Washington on behalf of inmates at the Franklin County Corrections Center.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the jail's widespread unconstitutional 13 practices, including the use of four point restraints against inmates, violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought injunctive and declaratory relief in the form of attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on February 5, 2016 and the case was closed on July 31, 2019.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the plaintiffs were entitled to an award of their 19 reasonable attorneys' fees and expenses pursuant to the settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The defendants denied the allegations in the complaint and continue to deny liability for the allegations.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.
pegasus_output_sents: The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California granted the government's motion to stay this case pending the resolution of its appeal in John Doe, Inc v. Mukasey, 549 F.3d 861 (2d Cir.)[SENTMARKER]in which the plaintiffs alleged that the National Security Letters (NSLs) issued by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to telecommunications and Internet service providers violated their First Amendment rights.[SENTMARKER]The district court held that the NSLs violated the First Amendment and that the nondisclosure provision was unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the Second Circuit for further proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit agreed with the district court's decision, and the case was dismissed.[SENTMARKER]The NSL statute is now pending before the Ninth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a stay of the case pending resolution of the appeal.

gold_sents: In 2014, an investigative reporter filed suit under the Freedom of Information Act against the National Security Agency and U.S. Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that the defendants were improperly withholding records concerning the NSA's surveillance of federal and state judges.[SENTMARKER]The Court ordered the defendant conduct an email search for draft memoranda or opinions concerning such surveillance program.[SENTMARKER]The search wielded no results.[SENTMARKER]A settlement agreement was reached paying plaintiff's attorney's fees on February 27, 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 11, 2016, Plaintiff Jason Leopold filed this FOIA request in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia under 5 USC  552(a)(4)(B) seeking records related to the NSA's bulk collection and storage of telephone metadata.[SENTMARKER]In March 2014, Mr. Leopold submitted two FOIA requests, one to NSA and one to the DOJ's Office of Legal Counsel (OLC).[SENTMARKER]In July 2015, the district court granted the defendants' first motion for summary judgment, finding that the defendants had failed to conduct an adequate search and had not adequately provided basis for their search in certain limited respects.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a second motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the motion, and the parties agreed to settle the case for a fee waiver.[SENTMARKER]On August 11, 2016, the parties filed a motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case should be dismissed on the basis that the parties had not provided sufficient basis for the search and that the search would impose an unreasonable burden on the defendants.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On September 16, 2016, The Associated Press, Gannett Satellite Information Network LLC, and Vice Media, LLC, filed a lawsuit seeking information about the recently purchased tool allowing government access to the phone of one of the perpetrators of the mass killings in San Bernardino, California on December 2, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the defendant's summary judgment motion on September 30, 2017, finding information at issue was protected under FOIA exemptions 1, 3, and 7.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 30, 2017, two news organizations filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request with the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) seeking documents related to the purchase of a tool used to circumvent the need for a court order to access the locked iPhone of Syed Rizwan Farook, one of the perpetrators of the mass killings in San Bernardino, California last year.[SENTMARKER]The FBI initially denied each request on the basis of FOIA Exemption 7(A), which permits agencies to withhold records for law enforcement purposes to the extent that the production of such records could reasonably be expected to interfere with law enforcement proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The News Organizations appealed the denial, arguing that the FBI had applied exemption in violation of the law.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the News Organizations' motion for summary judgment and ordered the FBI to produce the records sought by USA TODAY and the Vice News.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: On September 11, 2014, two same-sex couples filed this lawsuit in the Northern District Court of Indiana against the State of Indiana, the Lake County Clerk's Office, and the Indiana Attorney General.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and permanent injunctive relief for their violation of the Fourteenth Amendment's guarantees of liberty and equal protection under the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order and/or a preliminary injunction, but the parties agreed that the case should be stayed until the Supreme Court issues its decision regarding the appeal in an adversarial legal system.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed that they would not enforce Indiana Code  31-11-1-1(a), 3-11-1-1(b), and any other sources of Indiana law that exclude same-Sex couples from marriage or from recognition of marriages entered into in other jurisdictions.[SENTMARKER]The case is now pending an appeal.

gold_sents: This class action was about whether the City of New York improperly denied federally sponsored cash assistance to qualified New York City residents under a program implemented by the city in the late 1990s.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs each claimed to be qualified welfare beneficiaries who had been improperly denied assistance by one of New York City’s new job centers in violation of the fourteenth amendment guarantee of due process, the city’s obligations under 7 U.S.C. §2020 (the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program—then referred to as Food Stamps) and 42 U.S.C. §1396 (Medicaid), in addition to violating state law; the plaintiffs sought class certification for all similarly situated New York City residents, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on December 16, 1998, with Judge William H. Pauley presiding.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a temporary restraining order on the same day directing the city to provide emergency food stamps and cash assistance to the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in-part to the plaintiffs on January 21, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the city to (1) allow applicants for public assistance to apply for benefits the first day they visit a job center, (2) cease conversion of income support centers to job centers without a formal hearing, (3) make eligibility requirements for food stamps and Medicaid separately from the eligibility determination from cash assistance, (4) send applicants timely notice of the city’s decision on whether they qualify for benefits, and (5) form a corrective plan for achieving its policy goals while also meeting the needs of public assistance applicants.[SENTMARKER]The city moved to vacate the preliminary injunction on December 10, 1999, after procuring more evidence surrounding the efficacy of the job centers in achieving their welfare obligations.[SENTMARKER]Meanwhile, the State of New York moved to dismiss the complaint against them for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]Judge Pauley denied both motions and granted the plaintiff’s motion for class certification on July 21, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on December 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction directed both the city and state to: (i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applications within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](iii) send notices to applicants confirming voluntary withdrawals for Medicaid in accord with 42 C.F.R. 435.913 and document such withdrawals pursuant to 7 C.F.R. 273.2(c)(6); and (iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing certain documentation.[SENTMARKER]The injunction also required the state to supervise the city and make sure it met the obligations of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the part of the December order in which the court concluded that 8 N.Y.C.R.R.[SENTMARKER]§ 387.8(a)(2)(i)(a) did not confer a privately enforceable right of action and that plaintiffs’ claim under New York Social Services Law § 133 was barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion on February 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Final judgement was entered on December 14, 2005; the court also granted the plaintiffs declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Both the state and the city appealed the permanent injunction to the Second Circuit on January 12, 2006, but the city dropped its appeal.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, the Second Circuit reversed the district court, ruling that the state did not have a non-delegable duty to administer the decentralized Medicaid and Food Stamp programs, the state’s efforts in supervising the city since the permanent injunction was issued were adequate, and the district court exceeded its authority by issuing a permanent injunction in light of New York State’s affirmative supervisory steps it had taken to assure compliance.[SENTMARKER]In a series of stipulations and orders from January 31, 2007 to July 22, 2011, the City of New York agreed to pay a total of $2,920,675.94 to plaintiffs for attorney fees and costs sought; the state agreed to pay a further $639,918.98.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

pegasus_output_sents: In September 2013, an African-American inmate at the Arizona state prison complex in Tucson, Arizona, filed a pro se civil rights suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona, alleging racial segregation of African-Americans in the prison complex.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the prison's policy of racial segregation violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On June 9, 2014, the defendants filed a motion to dismiss the suit, which was denied by the court.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to settle the suit on December 22, 2015, with the defendants agreeing to implement a racial segregation program, develop policies, procedures, and practices necessary to implement an integrated housing program, and pay the plaintiff monetary damages.

gold_sents: In 2005, a group of California prisoners with mental illness filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation alleging that the prison system's policies regarding prisoners with mental disabilities violated the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled in 2015 and the court retained jurisdiction to enforce the terms of the settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: This is an action for relief from Defendants’ violation of the rights of persons with psychiatric disabilities under the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, the Americans with disabilities Act of 1990, and California Government code section 11 135.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought under the Eighth Amendment on behalf of 28 inmates with severe mental disorders housed in California state prisons.[SENTMARKER]The defendants’ motion to dismiss was heard on February 8, 2007, and the parties determined that they could not reach an agreement, and that those claims would be dismissed without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]On December 1, 2005, the parties filed amended complaints, alleging violations of the 18 ADA and Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement, which was approved by the court on December 1, 2005.[SENTMARKER]The parties then appealed to the United States Supreme Court, which affirmed the court's decision on May 3, 2011.[SENTMARKER]The case continues today.

gold_sents: In 2014, Disability Rights Florida filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that certain inmates with mental illness at Dade Correctional Institution had been subject to torture, beatings, verbal harassment and food deprivation in violation of their Eighth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that these inmates had received insufficient care in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Federal Rehabilitation Act. Disability Rights Florida requested declaratory and injunctive relief to deem these practices unlawful and unconstitutional, and assurance that such practices would not continue.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement which required improved conditions for prisoners and ran through November 2017.[SENTMARKER]Subsequent litigation in this case resulted from its consolidation with a related civil rights case seeking monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]That portion of the litigation settled for $4.5 million in 2018.[SENTMARKER]As of July 2020, the court retains jurisdiction to enforce the settlement agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: [ENTITYCHAIN] Disability Rights Florida (DRF) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida in November 2014 against Wexford Health Sources, Inc. (Wexford) and Dade Correctional Institution (Dade CI) alleging that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (Title II of the A.D.A.)[SENTMARKER]and the Federal Rehabilitation Act (Federal Rehabilitation Act) by terminating the employment of a mental health counselor at Dade CI.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a private settlement agreement (Private Settlement Agreement) in May 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case would be dismissed with prejudice on May 31, 2017 if no material breach of the agreement had occurred and the parties could not reach an agreement regarding reasonable attorneys' fees and costs within 60 days of the dismissal.[SENTMARKER]The Parties agreed to extend the date by which Plaintiff is required to dismiss or re-open the case with the Court by six months with all other terms of the Agreement remaining unchanged.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the parties' motion for administrative closure of the case, which allowed the parties to resolve the issue of reasonable attorney's fees and expenses in the event that the parties failed to reach agreement through negotiation or mediation.

gold_sents: Deaf inmate at the Georgia Department of Corrections filed lawsuit for injunctive relief in the form of communication aids and damages for pain and suffering.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed following a show cause order from the judge suggesting that case should be consolidated with a nearly identical case.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 6, 2017, a blind inmate at Central State Prison filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle district of Georgia against the Georgia Department of Corrections (GDOC) alleging that GDOC violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the Rehabilitation Act, and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA) by failing to provide him with auxiliary aids and services at important meetings and events while under GDOC's control and supervision.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that he was discriminated against on the basis of his disability when he worked in the kitchen at ASMP Doc.[SENTMARKER]He also alleged that his native language was American Sign Language (ASL) and he was held in solitary confinement for a week.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' Motion to Stay Discovery pending consideration of their Motion to Dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The same day, the court granted a motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2016, two Missouri Medicaid recipients filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri after being denied medication to treat their Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Missouri Department of Social Services and MO HealthNet denied medically necessary treatment to Medicaid beneficiaries with Hepatitis C, discriminated against similarly situated Medicaid beneficiaries, failed to provide "reasonably prompt" treatment, violated due process, and violated the American with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]In November 2017, MO HealthNet modified its policies and the case was dismissed as moot without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in November 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 22, 2013, the U.S.[SENTMARKER]Food and Drug Administration approved a new direct acting antiviral (DAA) treatment for Hepatitis C virus (HCV), a serious and communicable disease that can cause severe liver scarring, liver damage, cancer, and death.[SENTMARKER]The defendants’ coverage policies result in long delays for medically necessary services, and they exclude some Medicaid enrollees with HCV from medically necessary DAA treatment while providing the same treatment to other Medicaid beneficiaries with HCV.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri against the Missouri Department of Social Services, the Missouri HealthNet, and the state of Missouri under Title XIX of the Social Security Act.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants’ arbitrary and improper policies that restrict treatment only to the sickest beneficiaries resulted in the denial of medically necessary treatment for the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs’ request for a preliminary injunction prohibiting the defendants from requiring three months of negative drug and alcohol screens prior to submitting requests for DAA approval.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled on February 14, 2016.

gold_sents: Four incarcerated women alleged that their First, Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights were violated by being housed in the same facilities as transgender women.[SENTMARKER]After years of litigation, the claims were eventually dismissed.
pegasus_output_sents: On April 12, 2018, three female inmates of the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) filed this lawsuit against the Bureau and the United States Department of Justice (D.J.)[SENTMARKER]alleging that the BOP violated the Equal Access to Justice Act (E.A.CPA) and the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) by allowing male inmates to be housed in the same facilities that house female inmates.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the male inmates were subject to cruel and unusual punishment, including being placed in solitary confinement, and threatened with rape.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, and the case was dismissed on May 31, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs are seeking injunctive relief, attorney's fees, and costs.

gold_sents: This case was filed by a trans woman incarcerated in a men's prison in Washington State on September 5, 2017 in the District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]She alleges that the blanket policy in the Washington Department of Correction denying prisoners access to gender affirming surgery amounts to a violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]She is represented by the ACLU, and is seeking injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a preliminary settlement agreement on March 20, 2020, and proceedings were stayed for 180 days in an attempt to implement the agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: On October 27, 2017, a transgender female inmate, CORR CRONIN LLP, filed a civil rights lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the Washington State Dept.[SENTMARKER]of Corrections (DOC) alleging that the DOC's policy banning gender surgery for all inmates violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants' policy was a blanket ban on gender confirmation surgery, precluding surgery without any consideration for medical necessity.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to provide the plaintiff with medically necessary treatment for her gender dysphoria and allow her to begin hormone therapy.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was entered into on April 15, 2019, and the parties agreed that the Court may retain jurisdiction over this matter solely for the entry of an order dismissing this action with prejudice once the terms of the settlement have been 5 satisfied.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed with prejudice on April 10, 2019.

gold_sents: Three indigent persons charged with crimes filed a class action lawsuit in Skagit County Superior Court against the City of Mount Vernon and the City of Burlington alleging defendants failed to provide adequate assistance of counsel.[SENTMARKER]The Cities jointly contracted with two attorneys to handle all public defense assistance cases, and each attorney handled over 1,000 cases per year.[SENTMARKER]The Court found the plaintiffs established their rights were systematically deprived and the Cities were responsible for the deprivation.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief requiring the City of Mount Vernon and City of Burlington re-evaluate their contract for the provision of public defense services and hire one part-time public defense supervisor.
pegasus_output_sents: On December 15, 2010, the ACLU of Washington filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington on behalf of four indigent defendants who were charged with crimes in the municipal courts of the cities of Burlington and Mount Vernon.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants were violating the constitutional rights of the defendants by systematically failing to provide assistance of counsel to the defendants, leaving them without representation at critical points during the prosecution of criminal cases.[SENTMARKER]The defendants agreed to extend the duration of the contract by two years to 2 December 31, 2012.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a memorandum of agreement in 2009 to reform the public defense system provided by the King County Correctional Facility.[SENTMARKER]In 2009, the United States entered a Memorandum of Agreement with King County, 6 Washington to reform that system.[SENTMARKER]In 2011, the defendants removed the case to federal court in order to challenge the constitutional adequacy of the system.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached an agreement in 2012 that extended the contract for two more years, and the parties agreed to pay the plaintiffs' attorneys' fees.[SENTMARKER]The case is still pending.

gold_sents: On November 13, 2018, CNN and CNN’s chief White House correspondent Jim Acosta sued President Trump and several senior members of his administration for violating his First and Fifth Amendment rights by revoking his White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]under The plaintiffs sued under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Declaratory Judgments Act, arguing that defendants violated the Constitution and APA when they revoked Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 13, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, requesting that the court require the defendants to restore Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 16, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case on November 19, 2018 after the Trump administration returned Acosta's White House press credentials to him.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 19, 2018, the White House revoked the press credentials of CNN's chief White House correspondent, Jim Acosta.[SENTMARKER]The White House had not told CNN and Acosta that their credentials were revoked in advance of the revocation.[SENTMARKER]On November 7, 2018, President Trump held a press conference to discuss the 2018 midterm elections.[SENTMARKER]Acosta used his hard pass to enter and cover the press conference for CNN.[SENTMARKER]The Press Secretary accused Acosta of "placing his hands" on a White House staffer who attempted to take the microphone from him during that press conference.[SENTMARKER]In response, CNN filed this suit in the District Court in Washington, D.C., on November 19, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The case is being handled by John F. Kelly, the Chief of Staff to the President of the United States, and Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the President's Press Secretary.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed by Judge Timothy J. Kelly on December 19, 2018.[SENTMARKER]On December 19, 2018, Judge Kelly granted a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction against the defendants.

gold_sents: When mass protests against police violence were exempted from New York’s COVID-19 gathering restrictions, but congregational worship continued to be prohibited, two Catholic priests and three Orthodox Jews brought this lawsuit, alleging that New York officials were discriminating against people of faith.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction on June 26, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: In June 2020, a group of religious groups filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of New York against New York's governor, attorney general, and mayor.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that New York’s 10-person outdoor gathering limit and the Phase 2 limitation on indoor religious services at 25 percent capacity violate their First Amendment rights to participate in congregate religious activities.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the First Amendment right of freedom of speech and assembly.[SENTMARKER]On June 11, 2020, the plaintiffs filed an application for a temporary restraining order (TRO) Dkt No. 7.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion for preliminary injunctive relief on June 26, 2020, and the parties agreed to a final injunctive order on October 9, 2020.[SENTMARKER]On October 9, 2020, the court issued a final TRO.[SENTMARKER]On October 10, 2020, the defendants filed an appeal to the Second Circuit Court of Appeals.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit denied the appeal, and the case was closed.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: The NAACP and Detroit students and parents sued the Detroit school board and other state defendants in federal court, alleging unconstitutional segregation in Detroit's schools.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that Detroit's schools were illegally segregated, in part because of decisions made by the school board to create and maintain and segregated system.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that a Detroit-only remedy would be insufficient, and ordered a busing plan that would have affected students in city schools and 53 largely white suburban school districts, but the Supreme Court rejected this plan and a Detroit-only remedy was implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: In August 1970, a group of African-American students in the Detroit public schools filed a lawsuit against the Detroit Board of Education, the Detroit Federation of Teachers, and the State of Michigan alleging intentional racial segregation.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the Detroit School District was segregated on the basis of race and ordered the parties to submit plans to desegregate the Detroit Public Schools.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the District Court for an expedited trial on the merits.[SENTMARKER]On appeal, the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed the district court's denial of a preliminary injunction, but held that portions of Act 48 were unconstitutional and ordered that the Governor and Attorney General remain as parties to the litigation.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted certiorari and the case was dismissed.
